BIER--Bernard H. My Dearest Father, Missing you everyday. With all my love, Jody 1/3

SPENCER--Olga Brom, PhD.,died October 29th after a long illness. She was an esteemed professional as the Director for The Center for Family Development and New York and World Trade Family Center, N. She was active in retirement as an author, lecturer and in charities. She made a mark on all who knew her and will be deeply missed. A Memorial Service will be held at 2pm on Saturday, November 15, 2014 at Wilton Congregational Church, 70 Ridgefield Rd., Wilton, CT 06897. For travel directions or to sign her online register, please visit www.LeskoPolkeFuneral Home.com 1/3

SMITH--Stanley W.,Sr., a WWII veteran who saw active service on the USS Intrepid in the Pacific Theater while serving in the Navy died on October 25, 2014 from complications due to cancer. He was 91. After the war, he joined the IRS in Chicago, IL and later transferred to the Small Business Administration where he worked his until retirement from the federal government. He was a longtime resident of Riverdale, NY and Teaneck, NJ. He later relocated to Totowa, NJ. He will be missed by his loving family and friends. He was the devoted husband of Barbara Wesley Smith and father to his two children Monique Smith and Stanley W. Smith, Jr. He is also survived by grandson Kai Jace Smith; nephew Kermit Smith; grandniece Zoe Smith and cousin Edward Pierson, III. His funeral will be held on Saturday, November 8 at Rosedale Chapel, 408 Orange Rd., Montclair, NJ with visitation from 10am-Noon and a service beginning at noon. Visit Stanley's tribute page at www.volkleber.com. 1/3

RASKE--Eleanore. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale family mourns the passing of Eleanore Raske, beloved mother of our dear friend and colleague Kenneth E. Raske. Eleanore was a delightful woman who enjoyed the devotion of a wonderful family. We extend condolences to Ken and Janet and the entire Raske family. Daniel Reingold, President & CEO 1/3

MARKMAN--Glenn. Glenn Markman was a true mensch. He was taken from us much too early, but lived life to the fullest. I always knew Glenn to be kind, gentle, passionate and caring of others. We read parts of "Kohelet" together just last week. We will miss you. Michael Kleinberg and friends at MKDA. 1/3

MARKMAN--Glenn. The Board of the Brain Tumor Foundation (BTF), is deeply saddened by the passing of our friend and colleague, Glenn Markman. A long- standing, active board member, Glenn was a staunch supporter of BTF's Early Detection campaign. And with his help, Team BTF was privileged to be part of NYC's TCS Marathon for the past several years. We express our sincere condolences to Glenn's family. He was a revered businessman and for the Brain Tumor Foundation, a strong advocate. He will be greatly missed. May the family find comfort in their shared memories during this sorrowful time. Zeesy Schnur, Director Michael Schreiber, Chairman The Brain Tumor Foundation 1/3

KESSLER--Dr. Samuel, 92, beloved and devoted husband to Lona, loving father of Denise and Kevin, father-in- law to David and Shari, and cherished grandfather. Dr. Kessler practiced internal medicine in New Rochelle, NY for 55 years. Funeral services at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale on November 7 at 9:45am. Memorial contributions may be made to American Heart or Alzheimer's Association. 1/3

HARRIS--Jo Ann. The Robert B. Fiske, Jr. Association and the John S. Martin, Jr. Association mourn the passing of their beloved colleague, Jo Ann Harris. Ms. Harris epitomized the ideals of a generation of Assistant United States Attorneys, with her impeccable judgment, wise counsel, and generosity of soul. Her impish wit, unknown to many, could be deployed unexpectedly, always to perfect effect. Ms. Harris was a master of her craft. A fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers, she played a central role in many of the most important federal criminal cases of the last 40 years. Always a leader, she became the first woman Executive Assistant in the US Attorneys Office, and served two stints in the Department of Justice, first as Chief of the Frauds Section and again in 1993 when President Clinton nominated Ms. Harris to be the first woman to head the Department of Justice's Criminal Division. For her exemplary service, Ms. Harris was awarded the Department of Justice Henry Peterson award, named for a legendary career attorney who presided over the Criminal Division during the turbulent Watergate years, protecting its integrity against political forces. As a testament to her reputation for incorruptibility and fairness, she was tapped by two separate Independent Counsels to conduct investigations in the early 1990s, Ms. Harris served as Associate Independent Counsel to Hon. Arlin Adams in his investigation of corruption at the Department of Housing and Urban Development and, in 2002, by Independent Counsel Robert Ray to investigate allegations of professional misconduct stemming from prosecutors' confrontation and interview of Monica Lewinsky. In addition to her extraordinary public service accomplishments, Ms. Harris was a master teacher and mentor. A member of the faculty at Pace University School of Law and the National Institute of Trial Advocacy, she was awarded NITA's prestigious Faculty Award. In the last two decades, she played a pivotal role in creating a tribal advocacy program for Native American tribal courts and chaired the Board for the Center for the Study of First Americans. In recent years, Ms. Harris devoted time to rock art in Siberia and digs at prehistoric flint mines in Montana and Wyoming. She was devoted to Shumla, a non-profit archeological research and educational center for Lower Pecos rock art in Comstock, Texas and served as a dedicated Vice President of its Board. We offer our condolences to her brother, Richard Murray, her stepdaughter, Liz Harris, her stepson, David Harris and her four grandchildren, who were the joy of her life. 1/3
HARRIS--Jo Ann. Thank you for being an outstanding trial advocacy professor. Michael J. Lane 1/3

GELLERT--Abby Leslie Plitt, passed away suddenly on Wednesday, November 5, 2014. She was 67. Abby was a graceful dancer who loved everything dance, a joyful world traveler and supporter of the arts. A life-long New Yorker, she grew up spend- ing her summers in Raananah Park and Camp Kindervelt upstate. A graduate of Syra- cuse University, she worked at Halstead since 1985, most recently as Executive Director of Sales for the Westside office. She served as Co- Chair of REBNYs Residential Education Committee. She is survived by her husband Paul Gellert; her children, Melissa Gellert Neulander, Leon Gellert, his wife Jenny Rieg Gellert; and her sister Tamar Plitt Halpern. She is also survived by her grandsons Nathan Toby Neulander and Henry Lawrence Gellert, who were the lights of her life. 1/3

BOSBOOM--Barbara E.,on November 5, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Herman. Dear mother of Lisa Gordon, Jeffrey and David (Lilian) Bosboom. Dear sister of Edward Roth. Adored grandmother of Evan, Jared, Ilona, Anjelica, and Joshua. She was loved and adored by all. Services Sunday, 11am at Guttermans, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, LI. Donations may be made to Alzheimer's Assoc. 1/3

ZELNICK--NEIL Born April 22, 1943 passed away Monday November 3, 2014. Beloved father of Scott and Julie Zelnick, Brad and Amy Zelnick. Grandfather of Eliza, Mack, Sam, and Harry. He will always be remembered.

SELIGMAN--Suzanne E.,nee Stierstadt. Beloved wife of the late Henry W. Seligman. Passed away November 2, 2014 at age 97. Loved by her family; Gilbert, Arlene and Madeline and grandchildren Daniel, Neil and Gail. Suzanne was steadfast in her interests, her warmth, humor and creativity. A blessing, she will be missed by all. Memorial service Friday, November 7, 2014 at 2pm, Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Leo Baeck Institute, 15 West 16 St., New York, NY 10011-6301.

RIDDER--Esther M. The Board of Directors, staff and volunteers of the Carter Burden Center for the Aging note with profound sadness the loss of Esther Ridder, our distinguished Board Member. Her commitment to helping others and her dedication to the mission of the agency profoundly affected our programs and our growth. Ms. Ridder helped us see possibilities and develop initiatives that addressed the needs of an ever growing constituency of older adults. We mourn the passing of our colleague, and our dear friend who so compassionately taught us by example that we can make a difference. Jeffrey A. Weber Chairman William J. Dionne Executive Director

MANNING--John J.,Jr (Jack), passed away peacefully on September 4, 2014 at Coastal Carolina Hospital. Jack was born in Philadelphia, PA on December 8, 1932, and grew up in Elkins Park. He graduated St. Joseph's Prep class of 1950 and in 1954 from The Wharton School of Business, University of Pennsylvania. After serving two years in the US Army, he started his marketing career in Cincinnati at Proctor and Gamble. Several years later he made his way to Madison Avenue working for BBD&O, spending 12 years there rising to Executive Vice President and a Member of the Board. He managed accounts such as Gillette, American Tobacco, Pepsi Cola and many others. Working on the Gillette business in the 1960's, it was his idea to have Gillette sponsor Major League Baseball's All Star Game. It would be one of the major sponsorships undertaken in any professional sport. He then went to McCann-Erickson as a senior executive on the Miller Brewing Company account where he helped create a new category in the beer business. The successful marketing of "Lite" beer by the McCann-Erickson team changed the landscape of the beer business forever. After a few years he moved to the client side, eventually helping to form Sports Marketing Enterprises (SME), a division of RJ Reynolds Tobacco and the Nabisco Companies. He would be its first president. SME was responsible for the sponsorships of many RJR/Nabisco brands: the Vantage PGA Senior Golf Tour, the Winston Cup NASCAR Series, the Nabisco Tennis Championships as well as the Nabisco Dinah Shore LPGA Golf Championship. He retired in the early 1990's and moved to Hilton Head Island, SC. At the time of his death he was a popular member of Belfair Plantation, Bluffton, SC. He was an accomplished and well travelled golfer who enjoyed not only the sport but the camaraderie it provided with his many friends. He had been a member of many golf clubs including Winged Foot GC, Ridgewood CC. Long Cove Club and The Vintage Club. He is survived by his wife of 15 years Sally Ann Manning of Bluffton, SC, and by his sons, John of Tarrytown, NY, Christopher and his wife Linda, of Middlebury, CT, six grandchildren and one great grandchild, and his first wife, Rita Manning of Indian Wells, CA.

D'ATTILIO--Mary Theresa, "Terry", died on October 25, after a brief illness. With a Master's degree from Hunter College, Terry was a beloved teacher at PS 161 in Harlem. Terry redefined selflessness over her lifetime. Her love of life, walking in the woods, and thin crust pizza was rivaled only by her love of animals and children. She committed her whole life, both work and play, to helping animals and children in every way that she could. A celebration of her life will be held on November 8 at 11 am at Mallozzi's, Schenectady, NY. In lieu of flowers, please consider a donation in her name to Caring About the Strays, 3415 Leroy St, Schenectady, NY 12304 or Animal Protective Foundation, 53 Maple Ave, Scotia, NY 12302

HARRIS--Jo Ann. The Robert B. Fiske, Jr. Association and the John S. Martin, Jr. Association mourn the passing of their beloved colleague, Jo Ann Harris. Ms. Harris epitomized the ideals of a generation of Assistant United States Attorneys, with her impeccable judgment, wise counsel, and generosity of soul. Her impish wit, unknown to many, could be deployed unexpectedly, always to perfect effect. Ms. Harris was a master of her craft. A fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers, she played a central role in many of the most important federal criminal cases of the last 40 years. Always a leader, she became the first woman Executive Assistant in the US Attorneys Office, and served two stints in the Department of Justice, first as Chief of the Frauds Section and again in 1993 when President Clinton nominated Ms. Harris to be the first woman to head the Department of Justice's Criminal Division. For her exemplary service, Ms. Harris was awarded the Department of Justice Henry Peterson award, named for a legendary career attorney who presided over the Criminal Division during the turbulent Watergate years, protecting its integrity against political forces. As a testament to her reputation for incorruptibility and fairness, she was tapped by two separate Independent Counsels to conduct investigations in the early 1990s, Ms. Harris served as Associate Independent Counsel to Hon. Arlin Adams in his investigation of corruption at the Department of Housing and Urban Development and, in 2002, by Independent Counsel Robert Ray to investigate allegations of professional misconduct stemming from prosecutors' confrontation and interview of Monica Lewinsky. In addition to her extraordinary public service accomplishments, Ms. Harris was a master teacher and mentor. A member of the faculty at Pace University School of Law and the National Institute of Trial Advocacy, she was awarded NITA's prestigious Faculty Award. In the last two decades, she played a pivotal role in creating a tribal advocacy program for Native American tribal courts and chaired the Board for the Center for the Study of First Americans. In recent years, Ms. Harris devoted time to rock art in Siberia and digs at prehistoric flint mines in Montana and Wyoming. She was devoted to Shumla, a non-profit archeological research and educational center for Lower Pecos rock art in Comstock, Texas and served as a dedicated Vice President of its Board. We offer our condolences to her brother, Richard Murray, her stepdaughter, Liz Harris, her stepson, David Harris and her four grandchildren, who were the joy of her life. 1/3

GLASSER--Alvin M.,CPA, JD, age 83 of Rockville Centre, NY, passed away peacefully on November 7, 2014 with his family by his side. Beloved husband of Rhoda for 55 years. Devoted father to Jay, Mindy, Karen. Proud grandfather of five. Graveside services on November 9 at Beth Moses Cemetery in Farmingdale, NY. 1/3

CLARK--David Crawford, of Oyster Bay, NY on October 24th. Born August 5th, 1925, Glen Head, NY. Husband of the late Elizabeth Ives Clark for 57 years. Son of Frances Stokes and Louis Crawford Clark; brother of Louis Crawford Clark Jr. and Frances Ellen Clark Paul. Graduate of the Buckley School (New York City), St. Mark's School (Massachusetts), and Harvard University. Served in the United States Navy aboard the submarine USS Kingfish (SS-234) during WWII. His career spanned many years at Clark, Dodge & Co. and Kidder, Peabody & Co. He dearly loved his family, friends, sailing, trains, church, reading, history, and wry humor. Past trustee of the American Museum of Natural History, St. Luke's Hospital, St. Mark's School, Village of Oyster Bay Cove, director of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Association, and vestryman and senior warden of the Church of the Epiphany (New York City) and St. John's Church (Cold Spring Harbor, NY). Past member of the Porcellian Club, Harvard Varsity Club, Knickerbocker Club, Down Town Association, Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, Cruising Club of America, Royal Ocean Racing Club, and The North American Station of the Royal Scandinavian Yacht Clubs. Father of David Jr., Henry and Peter; grandfather of Antonia, Elizabeth, Caroline, Hillary, Avery and Charlie; father-in-law of Peri, Harriet and Elizabeth; and friend to many. Memorial service, St. John's Church, 1670 Route 25A, Cold Spring Harbor, NY on Saturday, November 15 at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, the family welcomes donations to St. John's Church, PO Box 266, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 11724. 1/3

KRUPMAN--William A.,passionate lover of life, passed away peacefully and courageously at 78, surrounded by his family. He built his life on the triad of family, work and service. Bill spent 32 years at Jackson Lewis, was Board Chair at The Children's Village, and a senior advisor to his daughter Pam's literacy organization, LitWorld. He cherished and championed his children and grandchildren, his wife Anne, and extended family. Donations can be made to LitWorld, litworld.org/donate and The Children's Village, http://childrensvillage.org/ get-involved/donate/

KRUPMAN--William A. It is with great sadness that we mourn the passing of our extraordinary partner, leader, colleague and friend. During Bill's 48-year tenure, as associate, partner, and Managing Partner from 1975-2006, our Firm prospered and multiplied in size, talent, quality, and innovation. For all of that, and so much more, we at Jackson Lewis thank him from the bottom of our hearts. Our thoughts and prayers are with Bill's wife and our former colleague, Anne, and with his children Pamela Allyn, Sally, and Ted and grandchildren Katherine, Charlotte and Angelo. The Shareholders and Staff Of Jackson Lewis P.C.

HARRIS--Michael A.,of Ogunquit, Maine, 85, of Frazier Pasture Road, died on Wednesday, November 5, 2014 at home, surrounded by caregivers and family. He was born September 12, 1929 in Lynn, MA, a son of the late William and Mildred (Leavitt) Harris. He grew up and attended schools in Swampscott, MA. He attended Lenox Academy after high school and then became a graduate of Dartmouth College, Class of '51. He remained an active caring alumnus of the college. He is recognized as a member of the Bartlett Tower Society in addition to sponsoring the Michael A. Harris Scholarship for selected students from Southern Maine. He served four years in the United States Air Force. His professional life included working in Boston and NYC as a Certified Financial Analyst, retiring in 2002. He was an avid sailor for many years as well as a skier. He remained a great sports fan, to the Red Sox. He is survived by his loving partner, Constance Jones Griffin, a sister Susan Brown, four nephews, and grand-nephews and nieces. A sister Jo-Anne Simon predeceased. A graveside service will be held at 2pm on Sunday November 9th in the Congregation Shirat Hayam Cemetery, 506 Lowell St., Peabody, MA. A Celebration of Michael's life will be held at his home, which he truly loved, 105 Frazier Pasture Rd., Ogunquit, ME on November 22 from 12-4pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Jimmy Fund, http://www.jimmyfund.org/. Lucas & Eaton Funeral Home, 91 Long Sands Rd., York, ME, is directing services. Visit www.lucaseaton funeralhome.com

BREYDING--Betty, passed away November 4, one day after her birthday. Betty was born in St. Louis, MO. She was predeceased by her parents Walter and Matilda Breyding and sister Mary Flynn. Betty graduated from McMurry College with a Bachelor's degree. Betty had an illustrious career as head of Human Resources of Rockefeller Family and Associates. Betty is survived by her nieces Elizabeth Wiegand, Carolyn Marcus, her nephew Jack Flynn and many grandnieces and nephews. As well as Ruth Haupert and Pat Bush, her long-time friends. Contributions in her memory may be sent to Bidawee Animal Shelter. She will be reposing at Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, NY. Viewing on Sunday, 2-5pm and 7-9pm.

SURATT--Samuel T.,former Archivist of CBS News died October 27 in New York City. He was 81. From 1969 to 1991, Sam oversaw and managed the transformation of all CBS News information resources to the computer age. In 1977 he co-founded the International Federation of Television Archivists. Prior to joining CBS News he was Archivist of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. Sam also volunteered in the Map Division of The New York Public Library. A member of the class of 1955 at Princeton University, he helped develop Princeton Project 55 (now Princeton AlumniCorps), which has provided 1500 Princeton students and graduates with opportunities to serve in the public interest. Sam is survived by his wife of 35 years, Judith Hole, two sons from his previous marriage to Sue Shearer Suratt, Benjamin (Christine) and Daniel (Cameron Blanchard), four grandchildren, and a brother William, (Carole). Donations in the name of Samuel T. Suratt may be made online to the Princeton Alumni Corps (http://home.alumni corps.org) or by mail to Princeton Alumni Corps, 12 Stockton Street, Princeton, NJ 08540. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East 29th St., New York City at 11:00am, on Saturday, December 13, 2014. 1/3

SPENCER--Olga Brom, PhD.,died October 29th after a long illness. She was an esteemed professional as the Director for The Center for Family Development and New York and World Trade Family Center, N. She was active in retirement as an author, lecturer and in charities. She made a mark on all who knew her and will be deeply missed. A Memorial Service will be held at 2pm on Saturday, November 15, 2014 at Wilton Congregational Church, 70 Ridgefield Rd., Wilton, CT 06897. For travel directions or to sign her online register, please visit www.LeskoPolkeFuneral Home.com 1/3

RUSSELL--Dr. Helen Ross, 99, died November 7 in the presence of Dr. Robert, husband, and her extended family. An early female PhD grad of Cornell's Nature Study Department; she taught at Fitchburg State College becoming it's first woman dean. A self described environmental biologist, her books "Foraging for Dinner" and "City Critters" were outsold by her bestselling "Ten Minute Field Trips". With consultancies at New York Academy of Science and both city botanical gardens she found time to teach at Manhattan Country School and was a true force of nature. Services Wednesday 10am Christ Church, Jersey City. Visiting Tuesday 3-7pm Evergreen Funeral Home, Jersey City 201-333-7171. 1/3

RIDDER--Esther M. The Brearley School deeply mourns the passing of Esther M. Ridder, Class of 1943 and an Honorary Trustee of the Brearley School. A beloved member of our community, this remarkable woman, who was so devoted to the School, provided wise and strong leadership for Brearley. Known for her kindness and wonderful sense of humor, she served as a member of the Board (1992-2004), as its Chair (1998-2004) and as the Co-Chair of the Campaign for Brearley (1995-2000). We send our sincere condolences to her family. 1/3

RIDDER--Esther Margaret. Born January 17, 1925, peacefully died November 4th at her New York City home. Beloved sister of Mary, Gretchen, Walter, Robert, and Joan, she is survived by Gretchen Ridder Nicolas of New York City, Joan Ridder Challinor of Washington, DC, and her longtime friend Alma Jenkins of New York City. She will be sorely missed by her many devoted nieces and nephews and all whose lives she touched. A lifelong advocate for children, she worked on their behalf with the New York Children's Courts and Louise Wise Services adoption agency. She also taught psychiatric social work at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. She served on the Council of Voluntary Child Care Agencies, the Community Council of Greater New York, and on the board of The Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, NY. She was a Trustee and President of the Board at The Brearley School in Manhattan. She earned her B.S. from Adelphi University, Magna Cum Laude, and her M.S. in Social Work from Columbia University. 1/3

QUITTNER--Arnold M.,born 1927, a life-long Los Angeles resident and one of the founders of the modern field of international bankruptcy law, died peacefully on Tuesday, November 4th in Miami surrounded by his wife, daughters, and several grandchildren. He was a partner at Gendel, Raskoff, Shapiro and Quittner. He practiced law into his 80s. An avid sailor and aviator, he traveled the world as both a cultural explorer and as the attorney for the first of many cross-border insolvencies (Japan and America). He was a speaker for the Practicing Law Institute and gave lectures on contract law in emerging democracies for the International Monetary Fund. He leaves behind his wife of 64 years Marjorie, three daughters, Katherine, Alexandra and Claudia and four grandchildren, Rachelle, Jordanna, Aaron and Ezekiel. He will be missed for his amazing energy and quick wit, but above all, his intellectual command of the law. He was a life-long liberal and proudly supported causes for those in need. He enjoyed a long, adventurous, and vibrant life. A memorial service is planned for 2015. 1/3

PRICE--Dr. Clement A. The Rutgers University Newark community mourns the loss, but celebrates the remarkable life and legacy, of Dr. Clement A. Price--historian, teacher, mentor, husband, friend, citizen, neighbor, collaborator, patron of the arts and humanities, public servant, public intellectual, advisor to leaders at all levels of government, and clear- eyed sage of Newark, New Jersey. He not only touched, but shaped so many of us. As we grieve deeply, we extend our arms and hearts to embrace Clem's beloved wife, Mary Sue, and his siblings, Jarmila and James. The family asks that in lieu of flowers or other expressions of remembrance, contributions may be made to support Dr. Price's life's work at the Rutgers University-Newark Institute on Ethnicity, Culture and the Modern Experience. Contributions should be made to the Rutgers Foundation, and sent to Irene O'Brien, Vice Chancellor of Development, Rutgers University-Newark, 123 Washington Street, Newark, NJ 07102. To learn more about supporting the Institute for Ethnicity, Culture and the Modern Experience, please call 973-353-3320, or email iobrien@rutgers.edu. 1/3

HUNT--James Allen, passed away at 84 on November 5th. He is survived by his three loving children Sarah, Jennifer and Matthew and his widow Karen. HENRY--William Barklie. Grandfather, father, husband, lover, musician, writer, seafarer, culinary artist, armchair shrink, practitioner of integrative medicine, and skillful driver of anything on wheels. Barklie Henry, who was all these things and much more to his family and friends, died at his home in the hills of Big Sur, California, on October 29, three weeks shy of his 87th birthday. Barklie's full and varied life transitioned as he wanted: in his living room overlooking the Pacific Ocean in the presence of people he loved and surrounded by family. William Barklie Henry was born on November 18, 1927, in New York City and raised on Long Island. He attended Phillips Exeter Academy, where he played bass in a jazz band and began his lifelong passion for music. At Princeton University he majored in philosophy and minored in late- night visits to the top jazz clubs in New York City where he played with numerous jazz luminaries. Barklie's multi- dimensional interests, ventures and pastimes over the past eight decades include: professional race car driver in the late 1950s; CIA intelligence analyst during the early years of the Cold War; influential member of the board of the Whitney Museum of American Art; filmmaker; and business entrepreneur. In the early 1970s, Barklie fell in love with Big Sur's rugged, unspoiled beauty. He studied at Esalen Institute before buying a hilltop property near Pfeiffer State Beach that became the center of his life for the next four decades. Barklie found the land and community in Big Sur a perfect fit for his Bohemian soul and his twin passions of healing arts and music. He launched and played percussion in two World Beat bands based in Big Sur -- "Barefoot", which featured renowned violinist Steve Kindler, and "Dark Chocolate," an improvisational jazz-fusion ensemble. Their jam sessions and concerts drew loyal fans and ecstatic dancers and produced six CDs and popular success on the World Beat music charts. Barklie was predeceased by his parents, William M. "Buzz" Henry and Barbara Headley, and his sister, Gertrude Conner. The center of the last part of Barklie's life was his large family, who brought him great joy, as he did them. He is survived by his daughter, Linda Barnwell; his five sons, Eric, Bill, Jason, Laurence and Jules Henry ranging in age from 60 to 30; and seven grandchildren ranging in age from two to 29. 1/3

HARRIS--Jo Ann. The Robert B. Fiske, Jr. Association and the John S. Martin, Jr. Association mourn the passing of their beloved colleague, Jo Ann Harris. Ms. Harris epitomized the ideals of a generation of Assistant United States Attorneys, with her impeccable judgment, wise counsel, and generosity of soul. Her impish wit, unknown to many, could be deployed unexpectedly, always to perfect effect. Ms. Harris was a master of her craft. A fellow of the American College of Trial Lawyers, she played a central role in many of the most important federal criminal cases of the last 40 years. Always a leader, she became the first woman Executive Assistant in the US Attorneys Office, and served two stints in the Department of Justice, first as Chief of the Frauds Section and again in 1993 when President Clinton nominated Ms. Harris to be the first woman to head the Department of Justice's Criminal Division. For her exemplary service, Ms. Harris was awarded the Department of Justice Henry Peterson award, named for a legendary career attorney who presided over the Criminal Division during the turbulent Watergate years, protecting its integrity against political forces. As a testament to her reputation for incorruptibility and fairness, she was tapped by two separate Independent Counsels to conduct investigations in the early 1990s, Ms. Harris served as Associate Independent Counsel to Hon. Arlin Adams in his investigation of corruption at the Department of Housing and Urban Development and, in 2002, by Independent Counsel Robert Ray to investigate allegations of professional misconduct stemming from prosecutors' confrontation and interview of Monica Lewinsky. In addition to her extraordinary public service accomplishments, Ms. Harris was a master teacher and mentor. A member of the faculty at Pace University School of Law and the National Institute of Trial Advocacy, she was awarded NITA's prestigious Faculty Award. In the last two decades, she played a pivotal role in creating a tribal advocacy program for Native American tribal courts and chaired the Board for the Center for the Study of First Americans. In recent years, Ms. Harris devoted time to rock art in Siberia and digs at prehistoric flint mines in Montana and Wyoming. She was devoted to Shumla, a non-profit archeological research and educational center for Lower Pecos rock art in Comstock, Texas and served as a dedicated Vice President of its Board. We offer our condolences to her brother, Richard Murray, her stepdaughter, Liz Harris, her stepson, David Harris and her four grandchildren, who were the joy of her life. 1/3

GREEN--Lea. The entire staff of Christies America is saddened by the death of our friend and colleague Lea Green. Her knowledge, charm and wit will be much missed both within our firm and in the wider New York art community. We extend our deepest sympathy to her entire family. Marc Porter, Chairman Douglas Woodham, President 1/3

GREENE--Harvey Martin, 79, of Rockaway Beach and Manhattan, passed away on Saturday, November 8, 2014. Harvey was surrounded by the love of his life and wife of 54 years, Myrna Greene, and his three children: Darrin Greene (Los Angeles), Dawn Roth and her husband Jack (New York), and Mark Greene and his wife Jane (New York). Harvey is also survived by five grandchildren, whom he cherished. Harvey was born to the late Mr. and Mrs. Ira and Betty Greene on August 25, 1935 in Brooklyn, NY. He graduated valedictorian of Stuyvesant High School in New York City, and went on to receive a Bachelor of Arts degree in economics from Brooklyn College and a Juris Doctor from New York Law School where he graduated first in his class. Soon after passing the New York State Bar, Harvey began practicing law in New York City. Always an entrepreneur, Harvey ultimately opened his own practice in Manhattan and was viewed as a trusted and valued advisor protecting the rights of small business owners, like him, for over forty years. Harvey's strong connection to his Alma Mater led him to return to Brooklyn College to serve as a Professor of Economics. Harvey is remembered as an active and beloved member of the Rockaway Beach Community. For many years, he served as the President of the Congregation of Temple Beth-El. Lauded as a community craftsman and handy-man, Harvey was always offering assistance to those in need. He was also was an avid automobile aficionado with a passion for building and restoring vintage and rare vehicles. Harvey's family and friends would like to thank the doctors, nurses and staff of Mount Sinai Hospital for their generosity of care, as well as their physical and emotional support during Harvey's stay. The family asks, in lieu of flowers, that you honor Harvey's memory with a donation to the National Parkinson's Foundation. More information can be found at www.parkinson.org. 1/3

GETSCHEL--Charlotte, 83, of Great Neck, died Wednesday, November 5. GELLERT--Abby Plitt. Halstead Property and Terra Holdings are deeply saddened by the sudden passing of our dear friend and colleague, Abby Gellert. Abby was truly beloved by all of our Agents, Staff and Executives. She was a world-wide traveler who was always excited to find new adventures in new places. Her love of real estate was clear to anyone that came in touch with her and we will forever remember her knowledge, passion, drive and commitment. Following a successful career in finance, Abby joined Halstead as a broker in 1985 where she proved to be a natural at real estate. During her time as a broker, she was honored with prestigious recognitions for her success in the industry. She became a Director of Sales for the West Side office in 2003 and was promoted two years later to Executive Director. CLARK--David Crawford, of Oyster Bay, NY on October 24th. Born August 5th, 1925, Glen Head, NY. Husband of the late Elizabeth Ives Clark for 57 years. Graduate of the Buckley School (New York City), St. Mark's School (Massachusetts), and Harvard University. Served in the United States Navy aboard the submarine USS Kingfish (SS-234) during WWII. His career spanned many years at Clark, Dodge & Co. and Kidder, Peabody & Co. He dearly loved his family, friends, sailing, trains, church, reading, history, and wry humor. Past trustee of the American Museum of Natural History, St. Luke's Hospital, St. Mark's School, Village of Oyster Bay Cove, director of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Association, and vestryman and senior warden of the Church of the Epiphany (New York City) and St. John's Church (Cold Spring Harbor, NY). Past member of the Porcellian Club, Harvard Varsity Club, Knickerbocker Club, Down Town Association, Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club, Cruising Club of America, Royal Ocean Racing Club, and The North American Station of the Royal Scandinavian Yacht Clubs. Father of David Jr., Henry and Peter; grandfather of Antonia, Elizabeth, Caroline, Hillary, Avery and Charlie; father-in-law of Peri, Harriet and Elizabeth; and friend to many. Memorial service, St. John's Church, 1670 Route 25A, Cold Spring Harbor, NY on Saturday, November 15 at 1pm. MANNING--John J.,Jr (Jack), passed away peacefully on September 4, 2014 at Coastal Carolina Hospital. Jack was born in Philadelphia, PA on December 8, 1932, and grew up in Elkins Park. He graduated St. Joseph's Prep class of 1950 and in 1954 from The Wharton School of Business, University of Pennsylvania. After serving two years in the US Army, he started his marketing career in Cincinnati at Proctor and Gamble. Several years later he made his way to Madison Avenue working for BBD&O, spending 12 years there rising to Executive Vice President and a Member of the Board. He managed accounts such as Gillette, American Tobacco, Pepsi Cola and many others. Working on the Gillette business in the 1960's, it was his idea to have Gillette sponsor Major League Baseball's All Star Game. It would be one of the major sponsorships undertaken in any professional sport. He then went to McCann-Erickson as a senior executive on the Miller Brewing Company account where he helped create a new category in the beer business. The successful marketing of "Lite" beer by the McCann-Erickson team changed the landscape of the beer business forever. After a few years he moved to the client side, eventually helping to form Sports Marketing Enterprises (SME), a division of RJ Reynolds Tobacco and the Nabisco Companies. He would be its first president. SME was responsible for the sponsorships of many RJR/Nabisco brands: the Vantage PGA Senior Golf Tour, the Winston Cup NASCAR Series, the Nabisco Tennis Championships as well as the Nabisco Dinah Shore LPGA Golf Championship. He retired in the early 1990's and moved to Hilton Head Island, SC. At the time of his death he was a popular member of Belfair Plantation, Bluffton, SC. He was an accomplished and well travelled golfer who enjoyed not only the sport but the camaraderie it provided with his many friends. He had been a member of many golf clubs including Winged Foot GC, Ridgewood CC. Long Cove Club and The Vintage Club. He is survived by his wife of 15 years Sally Ann Manning of Bluffton, SC, and by his sons, John of Tarrytown, NY, Christopher and his wife Linda, of Middlebury, CT, six grandchildren and one great grandchild, and his first wife, Rita Manning of Indian Wells, CA.

LEWIN--Harold F. May 9, 1929-November 7, 2014. Harold F. Lewin, a multi-faceted musician and intellectual, who founded the acclaimed summer music series Music & More, New Marlborough, MA, died Friday in New York City. Lewin founded Music & More in 1991, passionately dedicating his uncompromising standards and deep knowledge of music to elevate the series and attract world class performers. Born in Boston, Lewin studied piano at Manhattan School of Music and earned his Ph.D in theory and piano performance at Indiana University, studying with Menahem Pressler. Lewin was a founding member of the Arioso Trio, debuting at Carnegie Hall in 1979. He performed at some of the world's most prestigious venues including Lincoln Center, The Library of Congress, and Sibelius Academy in Helsinki. As president of the Sibelius Society for over 25 years, he was decorated with the Lion of Finland Medal for his contributions to Finnish Music. He was on music faculties of Indiana University, University of Cincinnati and Manhattan School of Music where he founded the Doctor of Musical Arts Program. He is survived by wife Susan Grant Lewin, daughter Gabrielle Lewin and her husband Jim Nachlin, daughter Jeanne Lewin and her husband Craig Fox, son Adam Lewin and his wife Nicole, and Granddaughters Lily Nachlin and Natasia DaSilva. Memorial is planned. Contributions can be made to the Harold Lewin Endowment Fund For Music and More, (NMVA, 154 Hartsville-New Marlborough Rd., New Marlborough, MA 01230), or to the Muscular Dystrophy Assn.

HAMBURGER--Robert N. Born January 26, 1923 in Queens, New York City to Samuel Hamburger and Harriet Newfield. Deceased October 6, 2014 from congestive heart failure. He was predeceased by his daughters Hilary, Debra and Lisa. He is survived by his wife of 72 years Sonia, sister Evelyn, granddaughter Toya and great-granddaughters Saylor, Jasper and Mercy as well as many beloved friends, family members and colleagues from his long and lustrous life as physician, professor, scientist, pilot, parent and good friend. He was a decorated P-47/P-38 pilot in the Army Air Corps during World War II serving in the Pacific Theater. Bob was awarded the Air Medal with Oak Leaf Cluster and the Purple Heart. He fervently opposed war throughout his life. A graduate of the University of North Carolina and the Yale School of Medicine. Bob was one of the founders of the UCSD School of Medicine serving as Assistant Dean; Head of the Immunology and Allergy Division; Director of the UCSD Allergy Immunology Laboratory. A Distinguished Fellow American College of Allergists; Life Fellow American Academy of Pediatrics; Fellow American Academy of Allergy, Asthma, and Clinical Immunology; Fellow of the National Board of Medical Examiners. AMA and NMA Life Member. Invited Member of the British Society of Immunology and the American Association of Immunologists. A Rockefeller Foundation Scholar; Fullbright Fellowship; Keese Prize Yale university; UCSD Chancellors Outstanding Research award. The Federico Gomez; Memorial Lecturer. Mexico. A-Femandez Cruz Memorial Lecturer, Spain. Bela Schick, Sherman Memorial Lecturer. An Honorary Member of the Swiss Allergy Immunology Society. Bob taught and lectured throughout the world and held 17 U.S. and international patents, wrote and published over 230 scientific articles and wrote and edited several chapters of the book, "Food Intolerance in Infancy ..." One of his last areas of research was on the consequences to children of high mold levels in the home (Sick Building Syndrome, UCSD TV, April 2001). Bob brought calm and understanding to many people during the most difficult experiences of their lives and had a gift for explaining the complex and lessening fear. Bob was a connoisseur of bad to great jokes and used them deftly. He was a true physician and healer. His marriage to Sonia was and is an exemplar of love and passion and steadfastness. Bob's life a testament to honor and achievement. We will always need him. Private Memorial Services will be held at the UCSD Faculty Club in La Jolla on November 16, 2014. In lieu of flowers contributions to the family in care of Toya Holiday are suggested.

BETTY GOES BANANAS Written and illustrated by Steve Antony. 24 pp. Schwartz & Wade. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5) 
 
Frustration! When you’re a hungry baby gorilla and you see a banana, you want to eat it. But how does the darn thing open? Betty tries hands, teeth and feet, then brings out the big guns: wails, kicks and screams. It takes words of wisdom from a gentlemanly toucan, and a few false starts, before Betty gets her snack. This simple, close-up tale, brightly illustrated by Antony with crayonlike strokes of black with soft pink and yellow, speaks to the foot-stamping, banana-gobbling toddler in all of us.

MATISSE’S GARDEN By Samantha Friedman. Illustrated by Cristina Amodeo. 44 pp. Museum of Modern Art. $19.95. (Picture book; ages 4 to 8) 
 
The story of how Matisse came up with the ideas behind his cutouts (currently at MoMA in a rapturously reviewed show) makes for an ingenious picture book. As Amodeo’s collaged paper figure of the artist cuts out birds and then adds other objects, we see how shape creates feelings and memories. When he adds color, an entire personal world comes into being. Friedman’s spare text hits its marks perfectly, and foldout pages of Matisse cutouts provide an extra hit of happiness.

CLAMMY CLAM Written and illustrated by Chris ­Raschka. 24 pp. Abrams Appleseed. $6.95. (Picture book; ages 2 to 4) 
 
The latest in Raschka’s ingenious “Thingy Things” books — mini-homages to toddler logic — introduces Clammy Clam: a black outline and a few strategic peach and yellow brush strokes. “Say hello, Clammy Clam,” the narrator says. No dice; this mollusk stays clamped shut, even after a few entreaties and a sharp “Clammy Clam!” Like many a flummoxed parent, the narrator cries uncle, and the book ends where it started, with a resigned and suddenly funny “This is Clammy Clam.”

On these pages, one image from each of the 10 New York Times Best Illustrated Children’s Books of 2014 is displayed. 
 
Every year since 1952, the Book Review has convened an independent panel of judges to select picture books on the basis of artistic merit. It’s the only annual award of its kind. This year’s judges were Jennifer M. Brown, Brian Floca and Jerry Pinkney.

STEINBERG--Harold. November 10, 2011. My beloved husband. Always in my heart. Eternal Love, Monette 1/3

SURUT--Lee E.,Major General United States Army (ret.), 89 years young, died July 20. His beloved wife of 65 years, Trudy Surut, and their children, grandchildren, great-grandchild and extended family celebrate his loving warmth, wisdom and wit every day. Burial with full military honors at Arlington National Cemetery on November 12. 1/3

SURATT--Samuel T.,former Archivist of CBS News died October 27 in New York City. He was 81. From 1969 to 1991, Sam oversaw and managed the transformation of all CBS News information resources to the computer age. In 1977 he co-founded the International Federation of Television Archivists. Prior to joining CBS News he was Archivist of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. Sam also volunteered in the Map Division of The New York Public Library. A member of the class of 1955 at Princeton University, he helped develop Princeton Project 55 (now Princeton AlumniCorps), which has provided 1500 Princeton students and graduates with opportunities to serve in the public interest. Sam is survived by his wife of 35 years, Judith Hole, two sons from his previous marriage to Sue Shearer Suratt, Benjamin (Christine) and Daniel (Cameron Blanchard), four grandchildren, and a brother William, (Carole). Donations in the name of Samuel T. Suratt may be made online to the Princeton Alumni Corps (http://home.alumni corps.org) or by mail to Princeton Alumni Corps, 12 Stockton Street, Princeton, NJ 08540. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Transfiguration, 1 East 29th St., New York City at 11:00am, on Saturday, December 13, 2014. 1/3

RUSSELL--Dr. Helen Ross, 99, died November 7 in the presence of Dr. Robert, husband, and her extended family. An early female PhD grad of Cornell's Nature Study Department; she taught at Fitchburg State College becoming its first woman dean. A self described environmental biologist, her books "Foraging for Dinner" and "City Critters" were outsold by her bestselling "Ten Minute Field Trips". With consultancies at New York Academy of Science and both city botanical gardens she found time to teach at Manhattan Country School and was a true force of nature. Services Wednesday 10am Christ Church, Jersey City. Visiting Tuesday 3-7pm Evergreen Funeral Home, Jersey City 201-333-7171. 1/3

RAPPAPORT--Joseph, on November 8, 2014. Husband of the late Naomi Chaitman. Father of Joyce and Ruth. Father-in-law of Rabbi Lionel Moses and Peter Wetherbee. Grandfather of Zev, Jeremy, Ezra, and Benjamin. Brother of Yvette and Albert Marrin. Son of Yiddish writers Malka Lee and Aaron Rappaport. Historian, Assistant to Senator Herbert Lehman. Former president, Dropsie University. At Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 90th St. and Amsterdam Ave., for service at noon, Monday, November 10. 1/3

NIRENBERG--Edna, on November 8, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Jesse. Devoted mother of Elizabeth Brondolo, Sheila Nirenberg and Nina Youngstrom. Cherished grandmother of Emma, Elena, Cassie and Gracie. Loving sister of Martha Bernstein and Harold James Fontek. Services Today 11:30am at "The Riverside", 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

HUNT--James Allen, passed away at 84 on November 5th. He is survived by his three loving children Sarah, Jennifer and Matthew and his widow Karen. He is also remembered by his grandchildren Edward and Rosemary, and son-in-law Edward Horgan. He was a partner at Kalb Voorhis and a director of McDermott International. 1/3
HAUPT--Melville I. The members and directors of the Seventh District Foundation record with sorrow the passing of its lifelong member. Our condolences to his wife Gloria and his family. 1/3

HAUPT--Melville, passed away on November 8, 2014 at the age of 96. Beloved husband of Gloria. Dear father of Leslie Mayesh (Jay), Samuel (Rosalina Leung) and Debra Haupt-Saltzman (Steven). Devoted grandfather of Stacey (Stan), Beth, Mathew, and Hilary. Loving great- grandfather of Davis and Liv. Philanthropy, Masonry, WWII Veteran, extraordinary businessman all describe his persona, but family was the very soul of his life. 1/3

GREEN--Lea. The entire staff of Christies America is saddened by the death of our friend and colleague Lea Green. Her knowledge, charm and wit will be much missed both within our firm and in the wider New York art community. We extend our deepest sympathy to her entire family. Marc Porter, Chairman Douglas Woodham, President 1/3

BRUSTEIN--Ira. January 29, 1946 --November 7, 2014. "The Mayor of Park Slope". Wall Street analyst, young people's coach, mentor and father figure, for many years owner of The Rosey Tomato on 7th Avenue in Brooklyn, he knew everybody and everybody knew him. And those who knew him loved him. He will be missed. Condolences may be sent to Betty Mandlin, 70 Prospect Park Southwest, #

BLAIKIE--Donald Blair, husband of Sandra Shapiro passed away early Saturday morning, November 8, 2014. He was born in New York City on June 18, 1936 to the late Robert and Matilda Blaikie. Don attended and graduated from All Hallows High School in The Bronx, New York and then attended Notre Dame University. He completed his Bachelor of Arts degree at Columbia University in New York City. He enlisted in the Marine Corps and upon his discharge returned to New York where he entered the insurance industry, first working with his father then opening his own firm Donald B. Blaikie, Inc. which ultimately became The Blaikie Group. He remained in that business for 40 years, retiring in 2001. For the past 13 years he spent his time with his wife and extended family at his homes in San Diego and Borrego Springs, California where he enjoyed off roading, tennis, golf and entertaining. Don was an avid athlete who was proud to say that he ran and completed two NYC marathons, his last at age 65. He is survived by his loving wife Sandra, his four children, Jennifer, Nick, Peter and Dana; son-in-law Larry, daughter-in-law Emily; his most beloved grandchildren, Magda, Sophie, Henry, Joe and Bailey; his brother Robert P. Blaikie as well as his step children Rob, Christine and Scott; his loving extended family Jeff, Amy and Jordan, their spouses and children and many wonderful nieces and nephews. The funeral service will be held at El Camino Memorial located at 4710 Cass Street, San Diego, CA 22109 on Thursday morning, November 13 at 11:00am. The family requests donations to Doctors Without Borders in lieu of flowers. 1/3

BAKER--Thomas J.,of the Bronx, son of the late Thomas J. and Nellie Crane Baker, passed away on November 7, 2014. He attended Mount St. Michael High School in the Bronx, and obtained his undergraduate and graduate degrees from Manhattan College. Tom also served for a year in the U.S. Army. He began his career as an engineer before changing to what he loved to do most teach. Tom taught Math at Xavier High School in Manhattan for 44 years. Simply put, he was devoted to Jesuit education and loved Xavier. His magnificent photographs of Xavier school activities, especially the Cross Country and Track teams, are legendary. Predeceased by his brother William. He always stayed attuned to the lives of his many nieces and nephews. Wake will be held at McNulty Funeral Home in the Bronx, 4-8pm Tuesday, November 11th and 10am-Noon, Wednesday. Funeral Mass is 12:45pm Wednesday, November 12th at Church of Our Lady of the Assumption, Roberts Ave., Bronx. 1/3

ROTH--John J. Loving husband of the late Mary (Henry), father of the late Elizabeth Danbeck (Robert), and surviving children Jane, John (Andrea), James (Frances), Mary Karl (Billy Bob), Kathryn Lilly (Kevin), Patricia, Margaret Depp (Oren Richard); PopPop to 16 cherished grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren and Uncle "Kiffee" to his special niece and companion Regina Henry as well as numerous nieces and nephews. He passed away at home, in peace and grace. Born on the West Side in 1918, John graduated from Manhattan College in 1940, served as Lt. in the U.S. Navy in WWII, including the D-Day landings, and went on to serve as a Special Agent of the FBI from 1947 1978. He was a loyal supporter St. Veronica's Church in Greenwich Village and of Immaculate Conception Church where he served as a trustee, President of the Parish Council and lector until his late 80's. Devoted to his God, his family and his country, he will be missed by his family and all who knew him. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Ave. at 21st St. on Monday and Tuesday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Immaculate Conception Church 414 E. 14th St. on Wednesday 11am. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to Manhattan College, Immaculate Conception School Helping Hands Fund or the Inner City Scholarship Fund: innercityscholarshipfund.org or a charity of your choosing.

MEVORAH--Joyce, nee Hornik of Brooklyn, New York, born on July 19, l926 passed away on November 5, 20l4. LIPIN--Dr. Bernard. It is with great sadness that the family of Dr. Bernard Lipin mourns the passing of their dearest and beloved Bernie. Born and bred New Yorker, Dr. Lipin, 85, of Branford, CT, devoted husband of Joan Lipin, died at Yale-New Haven Hospital on Friday, November. 7, 2014 after complications from abdominal surgery. Born July 2, 1929, he was a son of the late Charles and Anna Lipin. Beloved Father of Hilary Dworkin of Potomac, MD, Steven (Amy) Lipin of NYC, Nancy (Michael O'Brien) Lipin of NYC, Jennifer Fennell of Fairfield, Abbie Fennell of Boston, MA, Lori (Mark) Ruthfield of Southborough, MA, and Stacy (Robert) Giglietti of Fairfield. Dear Brother of Martin Lipin of Los Angeles, CA. Bernie cherished his grandchildren Emily, Madeleine, Anna, Margot, Samuel, Hannah, Noah, Adam, Joshua and Zachary. Born to immigrants who sailed from Hamburg to Ellis Island in the early 1920s, Bernie grew up in the Morningside Heights section of Harlem, where his parents owned a tuxedo rental shop frequented by Columbia undergrads. A child of the Great Depression, a proud Korean War veteran who played the trumpet in a marching band stationed at Fort McPherson, Georgia, he was a beneficiary of the GI Bill, which helped him graduate from Long Island University with a Bachelors in speech pathology. He moved from the Bronx in 1963 to make a life for his family as a Beltone hearing-aid sales representative in New Haven, CT, and became a member of the health-care and small business community in his adopted home. But he always considered himself a New Yorker, which meant frequent visits and never paying for parking. Bernie was a vivacious lover of life, avid chronicler of life's moments photographically, and a devoted daily reader of The New York Times and Wall Street Journal. He stressed education to all his children and was always about self-betterment. He obtained his Masters degree in audiology from Teacher's College at Columbia, a school whose shadows he grew up under, and eventually completed his PhD in audiology at the age of 78 from the AT Still University of Health Sciences. He somehow had time to take German along the way, benefiting from growing up hearing and speaking Yiddish at home. His charitable efforts were also about education: He was a nearly 50-year member of Rotary Club, and was very proud of the organization's commitment to providing college scholarships. He was a gourmet and foodie before the word existed, loving his Zabar's from its origins as a tiny storefront and introducing it to his kids and grandkids; his New Haven pizza; his visits to Chinatown and zeal for the next hot restaurant. He enjoyed traveling with his wife Joan around the world, whether it was Argentina, Alaska or a trip down the Danube. He cherished his summer birthdays and wedding anniversaries in Montauk with Joan, his children, grandchildren and close friends, and began to enjoy winters in Boca Raton. He was a dapper man and indeed one of the earliest known shopaholics who had a keen sense of fashion and style, and was always decked out to a T. He never took anything for granted, loved life, and life loved him back. Funeral Services at Congregation Mishkan Israel, 785 Ridge Rd., Hamden, CT, Monday, November 10 afternoon at 1:30pm with Interment Services to follow at the Mishkan Israel Cemetery, Jewell St., New Haven. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to Rotary Scholarship Fund (New Haven) and Mishkan Israel.

LANDIS--Elayne S.,passed away peacefully at home surrounded by family. Devoted wife of the late Leonard Landis, beloved mother of Carolyn, Dean (Mara), and Andrew (Hilary), adored grandmother of Teddy, Luke, Jamie, Emma, Harry and Owen. A lifelong New Yorker, Elayne enjoyed the arts, the Hamptons, her friends and family. Later in life, she received a masters from NYU becoming director of Admissions at the Allen Steven School and went on to pioneer the field of admissions counselling for primary and secondary education. Her wit, intellect and friendship will be greatly missed.

For all of that, and so much more, we at Jackson Lewis thank him from the bottom of our hearts. WEINFLASH--Bernard, 94, died on November 9, at home with his children at his side. Born on June 3, 1920, to David and Lena Weinflash on the Lower East Side; served honorably in WWII, graduated from CCNY and New York Law School. While an accountant and lawyer by education, and stockbroker for Oppenheimer & Co. by vocation, Bernie at heart was a lover of mankind both by nature as well as by intellect. On the board of directors of Temple-Emanu-el of Closter, Kaplen JCC on the Palisades and the Jewish Book Council, and past president of the American Jewish Committee of NNJ, his heart and soul went into the founding, along with his wife Ruth, z"l, of the Shirah Chorus conducted by Mati Lazar. Cherished husband of Ruth (nee Stupell) of 55 years who predeceased him. Survived by his adoring children: Jody (Steve) Konstadt, Jeff (Elahna) Weinflash and Carol (Michael) Kopelman; and treasured Granbee of Michelle, Debbie, Sarah, Eden, Noah, Emily and Naomi. He was a man of supreme intellect, unquenchable curiosity and above all love for his fellow man. Services will take place at 10:30am on Tuesday at Temple Emanu-el in Closter, NJ. 1/3

FOSTER--Israel Howard. We mourn the death of our husband and father, Israel Howard Foster, on November 2, shortly after his 91st birthday. Hal was the center of our universe as we were the constellation of his. Hal's sense of adventure and duty led him to many ports of call as a Pharmacist's Mate First Class in the Navy during WWII. He afterward owned and operated Foster's Pharmacy in Bedford Stuyvesant, where he was a fixture and beloved member of that community for over thirty years. Hal was a handsome man with beautiful, empathetic eyes and an uncomplicated joy in his life that endeared him to all who fell within the orbit of his gaze. He could do anything and do it well and we depended upon his quiet competence for the safety of our world. Hal's life was defined by his love for his family: Essie, his wife of almost 64 years, his five children Michael, Stacy, Tamar, Rafe, and Jody, and his eight grandchildren. This happiness was immutably altered in 2003 with the untimely death of his youngest son, Rafe, and again in 2012 with the death of his eldest son, Michael. This assault on his spirit took its toll on his already declining health and Hal spent the last four and a half years lovingly tended in the home of his daughter Tamar. Our dearest Hal, we love you so much, your spirit will be with us always. 1/3

ALVY--Susan Weissman, 67, on November 10, 2014, after a courageous battle with cancer. Daughter of the late Evelyn and Louis Weissman. Mother of Rachel and Richard Relkin and Deborah and Scott Semaya. Grandmother of Sydney, Adam, and Sophie. Sister of David Weissman and sister-in-law to Andrea. Best friend and twin sister of Judy Weiss and sister-in-law to Barry. Nieces and nephews Steven and Stephanie, Jessica, Rebecca, Daniel and Becky, Elliot, and Julia. Susan was an accomplished tennis player and enjoyed twenty years as the manager of Rockville Racquet Club. Recipient, 2013 Lifetime Achievement Award USTA Eastern Long Island Region. Attended Camp Robindel, Lawrence High School and Ithaca College. Services on Wednesday, November 12, at 11am at "Gutterman's" 175 N. Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre. 1/3
GORE--Gerie. Born 11/11/1919 Still giving us her wisdom, wit, and love. Eternally incomparable. Happy Birthday, with endless love from Eloise & Allen.

Marzouk--Dr. David, 83, passed away on November 4 in Boca Raton. Born in Cairo, David came to US in 1958. After a Teaching and Research Fellowship at Harvard, David established his own OB/GYN practice In Smithtown. He was an attending physician at St. Catherine Hospital, and a Stony Brook Assoc. Prof. David delivered thousands of babies. He loved to travel abroad, debate political, business and religious issues. David leaves behind his wife, Suzette, of 57 years-his children Sam, Ben, and Gina and his six grandchildren Danielle, Shelby, Zachary, Jordan, Noah and Sophie, his true pride and joy.

LIPIN--Dr. Bernard. It is with great sadness that the family of Dr. Bernard Lipin mourns the passing of their dearest and beloved Bernie. Born and bred New Yorker, Dr. Lipin, 85, of Branford, CT, devoted husband of Joan Lipin, died at Yale-New Haven Hospital on Friday, November. 7, 2014 after complications from abdominal surgery. Born July 2, 1929, he was a son of the late Charles and Anna Lipin. Beloved Father of Hilary Dworkin of Potomac, MD, Steven (Amy) Lipin of NYC, Nancy (Michael O'Brien) Lipin of NYC, Jennifer Fennell of Fairfield, Abbie Fennell of Boston, MA, Lori (Mark) Ruthfield of Southborough, MA, and Stacy (Robert) Giglietti of Fairfield. Dear Brother of Martin Lipin of Los Angeles, CA. Bernie cherished his grandchildren Emily, Madeleine, Anna, Margot, Samuel, Hannah, Noah, Adam, Joshua and Zachary. Born to immigrants who sailed from Hamburg to Ellis Island in the early 1920s, Bernie grew up in the Morningside Heights section of Harlem, where his parents owned a tuxedo rental shop frequented by Columbia undergrads. A child of the Great Depression, a proud Korean War veteran who played the trumpet in a marching band stationed at Fort McPherson, Georgia, he was a beneficiary of the GI Bill, which helped him graduate from Long Island University with a Bachelors in speech pathology. He moved from the Bronx in 1963 to make a life for his family as a Beltone hearing-aid sales representative in New Haven, CT, and became a member of the health-care and small business community in his adopted home. But he always considered himself a New Yorker, which meant frequent visits and never paying for parking. Bernie was a vivacious lover of life, avid chronicler of life's moments photographically, and a devoted daily reader of The New York Times and Wall Street Journal. He stressed education to all his children and was always about self-betterment. He obtained his Masters degree in audiology from Teacher's College at Columbia, a school whose shadows he grew up under, and eventually completed his PhD in audiology at the age of 78 from the AT Still University of Health Sciences. He somehow had time to take German along the way, benefiting from growing up hearing and speaking Yiddish at home. His charitable efforts were also about education: He was a nearly 50-year member of Rotary Club, and was very proud of the organization's commitment to providing college scholarships. He was a gourmet and foodie before the word existed, loving his Zabar's from its origins as a tiny storefront and introducing it to his kids and grandkids; his New Haven pizza; his visits to Chinatown and zeal for the next hot restaurant. He enjoyed traveling with his wife Joan around the world, whether it was Argentina, Alaska or a trip down the Danube. He cherished his summer birthdays and wedding anniversaries in Montauk with Joan, his children, grandchildren and close friends, and began to enjoy winters in Boca Raton. He was a dapper man and indeed one of the earliest known shopaholics who had a keen sense of fashion and style, and was always decked out to a T. He never took anything for granted, loved life, and life loved him back. Funeral Services at Congregation Mishkan Israel, 785 Ridge Rd., Hamden, CT, Monday, November 10 afternoon at 1:30pm with Interment Services to follow at the Mishkan Israel Cemetery, Jewell St., New Haven. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to Rotary Scholarship Fund (New Haven) and Mishkan Israel.

CHILDERS--Rory. Renowned cardiologist, husband of Michele Javsicas, father of Peter and Daniel, on August 27 in East Hampton, NY, age 83. Grandson of Robert Erskine Childers and Mary Alden "Molly" Osgood. Son of Erskine Hamilton Childers 4th President of Ireland and Ruth Ellen Dow. Trinity College Dublin BA (Mod) 1953, MB BCh BAO 1954, MD 1958. 50 years on faculty of UofChicago Medical School; Professor of Medicine; Director Heart Station. President ISCE 2011-14. Lifetime Achievement Award SFSU 2011. Scholar of Irish and Russian literature, Irish history and culture. November 13 1pm Rockefeller Chapel, UofChicago campus. Gifts to doctorswithoutborders.org

YOUNG--Annita Imogene Applegarth, of Mamaroneck, passed away November 9, 2014 at age 87. Annita was born May 21, 1927 in Cambridge, MD to Harold Gregory and Edith Imogene Applegarth. A devoted homemaker and caretaker, she is survived by her beloved children, Christopher Young (Catherine), Frederick Young (Karen) and Stephanie Young, eight grandchildren, her brother Charles Applegarth (Marie), and their children. She is predeceased by her brother, Harold Pierre Applegarth. Family and friends will gather Saturday morning 8:30-10:30am at Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home, 767 E. Boston Post Rd., Mamaroneck. 914-698-5968. Funeral Mass will be held Saturday 11am at St. Pius x RC Church in Scarsdale. Annita went to Mount Saint Agnes in Baltimore, and then to the University of Notre Dame of Maryland. She lived in Baltimore, MD, in Virginia, and in Illinois, as well as the on the Eastern Shore of Maryland and New York. Annita was continuously inquisitive about the world and its beauty, instilling that wonder and curiosity in her children and grandchildren. Annita enjoyed gardening, sailing, being with people, loved the Eastern Shore of Maryland, and truly appreciated being a part of her grandchildren's lives. Deeply loved, Annita will be very much missed by family and friends. Annita will be committed at St Mary's Star of the Sea RC Church in Golden Hill, MD. For those wishing to make a donation as a remembrance, Annita was a life member of the Star of the Sea Golden Hill Foundation, Inc., Post Office Box 187, Fishing Creek, MD 21634, a small church serving a rural community on the Eastern Shore of Maryland. For more information or to place a condolence, www.coxeandgraziano.com. 1/3

Board member of The Long Island Breast Cancer Action Coalition, Coalition Against Child Abuse & Neglect, The Maurer Foundation, and The American Society of Italian Legion of Merit. Visitation at Oyster Bay Funeral Home, 261 South St., Oyster Bay NY 11771, from 3:00-5:00 and 7:00- 9:00pm on Wednesday, November 12. Lewis--Beatrice J.,passed away on November 10, 2014 in Manhattan at the age of 92. Daughter of the late Joseph Adisman and Frances G. Adisman (Gertz). Beloved wife of the late Sydney B. Lewis, MD. Devoted sister of the late Kenneth I. Adisman, D.D.S. Loving mother of Stephen I. Lewis and Joan L. Lewis (Howard F. Jaeckel). Cherished grandmother of Shoshana K. Goldberg and Franny M. Goldberg. Dear aunt of Kathryn R. Adisman and Leslie J. Adisman. Beatrice was born in Manhattan and graduated from The High School of Music and Art in 1939. She and Sydney moved to Trenton, New Jersey in the late 1940s so that he could establish his radiology practice. She received college and graduate degrees from Trenton State College and Rider University. After living in the Trenton area for many decades, Beatrice and Sydney moved back to Manhattan in 2001. Beatrice loved opera, writing, and playing bridge. She was greatly loved by her family and friends and will be terribly missed. 1/3

LEVEEN--Pauline "Polly" The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family in mourning the loss of Pauline "Polly'' Leveen, professor emerita of History and Government at Corning Community College, where she taught for many decades. Ms. Leveen was the mother of Dr. Adriane Leveen, wife of JTS Chancellor Arnold M. Eisen; David Leveen; and Amy Yaggy. She is also survived by her nine grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Ms Leveen, who was deeply devoted to Judaism, was a former president of the board of Congregation Shomray Hadath, an award-winning activist and volunteer, and a respected educator who enjoyed empowering other women. May her family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair 1

KRUGER--Manuela Ditz, 75, died unexpectedly in early October of a heart attack in her lower East Side apartment. She was the loving mother of three sons, Daniel, David and Samuel, and grandmother of Nathaniel and William. She was a 1962 graduate of the University of Chicago and was a brilliant editor of many well-known nonfiction books throughout a five-decade career that never stopped. She began her career at Praeger Publishers in New York and moved on to the Oxford University Press, and spent the last decades as a much-in-demand free lance editor. As a former cellist with the Youth Symphony Orchestra of Chicago, her hometown, she remained a musicologist at heart, but her deep interest in and knowledge of current events, nationally, internationally and locally, informed and deepened her work. New York City, with its diversity and its opera was another passion. She will be sorely missed by colleagues and family as well as dear lifelong friends, who counted on her boundless love, her keen insight and her phenomenal gift for remembering and treasuring all the vital moments of their lives. 1/3

HAUPT--Melville. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with deepest sorrow the death of our longtime, cherished member and Honorary Trustee. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife Gloria and their family. May God comfort his loved ones and may his memory be for blessing. Rabbi Deborah A. Hirsch Michael Starr, President 1/3

HARRINGTON--Robert Dudley Jr.,a lifelong New Englander, died on November 5, 2014, of complications from Lewy Body Disease. Mr. Harrington was an entrepreneur, venture capitalist and financier, working for Morgan Guarantee in New York, NY. He held an MBA from Columbia Business School and a bachelors from Brown University, and served in the National Guard. Mr. Harrington was a president of the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution Associates. He was a Commodore of Edgartown Yacht Club and a member of New York Yacht Club, Connecticut Travelers, Round Hill Club, Ad Sports, Greenwich Riding Club, Fairfield Group, New England Society, Pilgrim Society, and three Masonic lodges. He is survived by his wife, Clare Gesualdo Harrington, and sister, Sarah Harrington Williams. He is predeceased by his parents, Robert Dudley Harrington and Ann Harrington. Memorial service: Saturday, November 15, 2014, 11:00am at Round Hill Community Church, 395 Round Hill Rd., Greenwich, CT 06831; reception to follow at Round Hill Club, 33 Round Hill Club Road. Private burial will be held in advance. An additional memorial service will be held in Edgartown, MA, in summer 2015. In lieu of flowers, donations are requested to Lewy Body Dementia Association Inc., www.lbda.org, or to Treasure Hunt Farm Foundation, c/o Sarah Harrington Williams, P.O. Box 696, Rutland, MA 01543. 1/3

GROSS--Donald. The Board of Governors and the members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our esteemed member Donald and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Linda and the entire family. Board of Governors Michael Mann, President 1/3
GROSS--Donald. Our condolences to Linda and family on Donald's passing, a dear friend for fifty years. We will miss him. May he rest in peace. Joyce and Mel Paradise and Family 1/3

GROSS--Donald Joel, born May 3, 1935, passed away on November 11, 2014 after long courageous battles against Sepsis. He leaves behind a grieving family. Children Kenneth and Debbie, Ira and Moeh Moeh, Valerie and John; grandchildren Jaime, Dani, Allie, Jessica and Dylan; devoted wife Linda of 54 years. My darling Donald you ask how long I'll love you, I'll tell you true until the Twelfth of Never, I'll still be loving you. The family thanks Evan for years of excellent care and devotion. Funeral at Riverside in Great Neck on Friday, November 14, at 9:30am. Shiva at the home of Ira Gross, Saturday after sundown through Wednesday; afternoons from 1pm-4pm evenings from 7pm-9pm. 1/3

EVANS--Leo, 89, passed away on November 10th after a long illness. Beloved father of Joel and Eve, father-in-law of Robin and Roger, grandfather of Jarad, Spencer, Dylan and Evan. Devoted husband of Shirley, son of Esther and Joseph, and brother of Martha and Eli. Adored uncle of eight. He was a proud WWII veteran and recipient of many medals. A witty and charming polymath, who loved books, knowledge, humor, and family. 1/3

EHRLICH--Dr. Robert, 76, of New York, New York died on November 8, 2014. He is survived by his partner Susan Levit, his children, Paul and Christie Ehrlich, Todd and Irina Ehrlich, his brother Dr. Roy Ehrlich and sister Marcia Ehrlich-Halley. Dr. Ehrlich was a intensivist pediatric cardiologist who graduated from Downstate Medical Center and later became Chief Pediatric resident at Kings County Hospital. While serving as captain in the Air Force he discovered his passion for pediatric cardiology and upon his return to Kings County made that his lifes pursuit. In 1977 he became Director of the Department of Pediatric Cardiology/associate professor at the Medical College of Ohio where he also served on the Board of Directors at the Ronald McDonald House. In 1988 he assumed the position of medical director of the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit at Brackenridge Hospital as well as clinical professor at the University of Texas. He served there until retiring to New York where he was a senior lecturer in Pediatrics at both Columbia Presbyterian and Cornell Weill medical school. In addition, Dr. Ehrlich was an accomplished artist, educator and humanist. He is loved and will be missed by all. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Ronald McDonald House. 1/3

DOAR--John, 92, on November 11, 2014. Beloved father of Gael, Michael, Robert and Burke. Visitation Thursday 7 to 9pm and Friday 2 to5pm at Frank E Campbell (The Funeral Chapel) Madison Avenue at 81st Street. 1/3
QUITTELL--Dr. Glenn S. To my extraordinary father, whose warmth, wisdom, and wit is missed every day, especially today. All my love, Robin

Marzouk--Dr. David, 83, passed away on November 4 in Boca Raton. Born in Cairo, David came to US in 1958. After a Teaching and Research Fellowship at Harvard, David established his own OB/GYN practice In Smithtown. He was an attending physician at St. Catherine Hospital, and a Stony Brook Assoc. Prof. David delivered thousands of babies. He loved to travel abroad, debate political, business and religious issues. David leaves behind his wife, Suzette, of 57 years-his children Sam, Ben, and Gina and his six grandchildren Danielle, Shelby, Zachary, Jordan, Noah and Sophie, his true pride and joy.

Ginsburg--Ina. Loving mother of Jonathan, Susan, and Mark, and grandmother of Zachary and Garth, died peacefully in her home surrounded by family November 9, at age 98. Viennese-born Ina was a pioneering spirit behind and stalwart supporter of the National Symphony Orchestra, the Washington National Opera, the American Film Institute and the Kennedy Center. Ina was also the spirit behind the Fine Arts Advisory Panel of the Federal Reserve Bank. Ina will be missed by her loving family and friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Washington National Opera, PO Box 101510, Arlington, VA 22210, and to the Fine Arts Program at the Federal Reserve Board, which will be used to establish an art acquisitions fund in memory of Ina Ginsburg. Checks should be made out to the "Fine Arts Trust Fund" and mailed to: Federal Reserve Board, Attn: Accounting MS 152, 2001 Constitution Ave NW, Washington, DC 20551. A memorial celebration will take place at The Kennedy Center early 2015.

DRAZIN--Avrum. The Yeshiva University family and the Canadian Friends of Yeshiva University are grieved by the passing of Avrum Drazin. Mr. Drazin was a widely respected leader in the Montreal Jewish community, a devoted alumnus who served on the Yeshiva College Board of Overseers and, together with his beloved wife, Ruth, was a YU Guardian. Heartfelt condolences to his wife and to his children: Faiga (and Michael) Joseph, Shlomo (and Sari) Drazin, Ami (and Aviva) Drazin, Shifra (and Dani) Bendheim, to his brother and brother-in-law, Joe (and Frances) Drazin, Louis (and Malca) Drazin, and to his cherished grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus Jeremy Magence, CFYU National President
