Lewis--Beatrice J.,passed away on November 10, 2014 in Manhattan at the age of 92. Daughter of the late Joseph Adisman and Frances G. Adisman (Gertz). Beloved wife of the late Sydney B. Lewis, MD. Devoted sister of the late Kenneth I. Adisman, D.D.S. Loving mother of Stephen I. Lewis and Joan L. Lewis (Howard F. Jaeckel). Cherished grandmother of Shoshana K. Goldberg and Franny M. Goldberg. Dear aunt of Kathryn R. Adisman and Leslie J. Adisman. Beatrice was born in Manhattan and graduated from The High School of Music and Art in 1939. She and Sydney moved to Trenton, New Jersey in the late 1940s so that he could establish his radiology practice. She received college and graduate degrees from Trenton State College and Rider University. After living in the Trenton area for many decades, Beatrice and Sydney moved back to Manhattan in 2001. Beatrice loved opera, writing, and playing bridge. She was greatly loved by her family and friends and will be terribly missed. 1/3

HOGUET--Peter, J. The Officers, Trustees and Friends of myFace (formerly the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, "NFFR") mourn the loss of our esteemed former President, Mr. J. Peter Hoguet. An enthusiastic supporter of patients with facial difference, he worked tirelessly on their behalf to ensure that they could reach their potential. His commitment to the NFFR laid the foundation for its continued success in serving its patients. This is his enduring legacy. Peter fully epitomized "the greatest generation" and we will be forever thankful to him. 1/3

HOGUET--Joseph Peter. It is with great sadness that the family of Joseph Peter Hoguet, 92, announce his death. Peter died on November 10, 2014 at Englewood Community Hospital and lived in Boca Grande, Florida. Born in New York City, July 15th 1922, he attended St. Bernard's and the Groton School. Peter served in the Office of Strategic Services from 1942-45 and was part of the first allied unit to liberate prisoners from the Dachau concentration camp. A former governor of the River Club in New York, Peter worked for the Marcona Mining Company until his retirement in 1987. He was Chairman of the Board of the National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction from 1994 until 2008 and served as a trustee for the Hospital for Special Surgery from 1986-1992. He is survived by his sister Nancy Hoguet McBean and his son Eric. 1/3

EHRLICH--Dr. Robert, 76, of New York, New York died on November 8, 2014. He is survived by his partner Susan Levit, his children, Paul and Christie Ehrlich, Todd and Irina Ehrlich, his brother Dr. Roy Ehrlich and sister Marcia Ehrlich-Halley. Dr. Ehrlich was a intensivist pediatric cardiologist who graduated from Downstate Medical Center and later became Chief Pediatric resident at Kings County Hospital. While serving as captain in the Air Force he discovered his passion for pediatric cardiology and upon his return to Kings County made that his lifes pursuit. In 1977 he became Director of the Department of Pediatric Cardiology/associate professor at the Medical College of Ohio where he also served on the Board of Directors at the Ronald McDonald House. In 1988 he assumed the position of medical director of the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit at Brackenridge Hospital as well as clinical professor at the University of Texas. He served there until retiring to New York where he was a senior lecturer in Pediatrics at both Columbia Presbyterian and Cornell Weill medical school. In addition, Dr. Ehrlich was an accomplished artist, educator and humanist. He is loved and will be missed by all. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Ronald McDonald House. 1/3

BADER--Deirdre Russell, (nee Murphy), beloved wife of Lawrence S. Bader, adoring mother of Ethan Russell Bader, cherished daughter of Daniel Murphy and Sally Kandle, passed away peacefully on November 11, 2014 at the Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. Deirdre was the Executive Director of Star Track, a cycling charity for New York City children between the ages of 7 and 14. Using the City's outdoor velodrome in Kessina Park in Queens, Deirdre founded the charity in connection with New York's bid for the 2012 Olympic games and led Star Track's growth over the past 12 years to the point where, in this year, 300 children were enrolled in Star Track, with a long waiting list. Star Track is a free program that teaches children how to ride specialized bicycles designed for competition on banked tracks called velodromes. It was Deirdre's hope that by learning to ride on a velodrome, the children could develop fitness, self-esteem and teamwork. Deirdre's involvement in competitive cycling began when she was 32 years old, and she retired at the age of 41, having just competed for Ireland in the women's road race in the Sydney Australia Olympics. Deirdre was born and raised in New York City, and while in high school, obtained Irish citizenship at the urging of her father. Years later, representing Ireland, Deirdre raced against international competition in Montevideo, Uruguay in a qualifying race to determine which countries could send their road cycling competitors to the 2000 Olympics. By finishing fourth in that race, Deirdre qualified Ireland to send its first woman road cyclist ever to the Olympics. Deirdre was also the Women's World Masters champion in 1997 for all women over 30 years old, earning her the coveted "Rainbow Jersey" worn by the reigning world's champion in one of cycling's disciplines --in her case, the road race. In her career, she won 81 races. Deirdre married her husband, Lawrence in 2002 and gave birth to their son, Ethan, in 2007. Deirdre was an extraordinarily beautiful woman who embodied generosity of spirit, warmth, loyalty, competitiveness and intelligence. She will be missed terribly by all who knew her. It was her request that in lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory be made to Star Track at "Bike New York/Star Track", 12 East 87th Street, New York, N.Y. 10128. A funeral service will be held at The Brick Presbyterian Church at 1140 Park Avenue on Saturday, November 15 at 11am, followed by a reception. 1/3

Ginsburg--Ina. Loving mother of Jonathan, Susan, and Mark, and grandmother of Zachary and Garth, died peacefully in her home surrounded by family November 9, at age 98. Viennese-born Ina was a pioneering spirit behind and stalwart supporter of the National Symphony Orchestra, the Washington National Opera, the American Film Institute and the Kennedy Center. Ina was also the spirit behind the Fine Arts Advisory Panel of the Federal Reserve Bank. Ina will be missed by her loving family and friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Washington National Opera, PO Box 101510, Arlington, VA 22210, and to the Fine Arts Program at the Federal Reserve Board, which will be used to establish an art acquisitions fund in memory of Ina Ginsburg. Checks should be made out to the "Fine Arts Trust Fund" and mailed to: Federal Reserve Board, Attn: Accounting MS 152, 2001 Constitution Ave NW, Washington, DC 20551. A memorial celebration will take place at The Kennedy Center early 2015.

She leaves an extraordinary legacy in her husband, Larry and their precious son, Ethan. Deirdre will be forever in our hearts. Our deepest sympathy to her family and all who share this loss. WEINFLASH--Bernard, 94, died on November 9, at home with his children at his side. Born on June 3, 1920, to David and Lena Weinflash on the Lower East Side of New York, Bernie served honorably in WWII -US Army Air Corps. He graduated from CCNY and New York Law School. While an accountant and lawyer by education, and stockbroker for Oppenheimer & Co., by vocation, Bernie, at heart was a lover of mankind both by nature as well as by intellect. On the board of directors of Temple- Emanu-el of Closter, Kaplen JCC on the Palisades and the Jewish Book Council, and past president of the American Jewish Committee of NNJ, his heart and soul went into the founding, along with his wife Ruth, z"l, of the Shirah Chorus conducted by Mati Lazar. Cherished husband of Ruth (nee Stupell) of 55 years who predeceased him. Survived by his adoring children: Jody (Steve) Konstadt, Jeff (Elahna) Weinflash and Carol (Michael) Kopelman; and treasured Granbee of Michelle, Debbie, Sarah, Eden, Noah, Emily and Naomi. Two of Bernie's wonderful brothers survive him, Nathan of Florida and Irving of Hicksville, NY. His beloved brother George, who was a Cantor, passed away in 2004. Bernie was a man of supreme intellect, unquenchable curiosity and above all, love for his fellow man. Services were held on November 11, 2014 at Temple Emanu-el in Closter, NJ. Donations may be made to Temple Emanu-el or to Shirah Chorus at Kaplen JCC on the Palisades. 1/3

PRICE--Dr. Clement. The Save Ellis Island Foundation mourns the loss of our longtime board member and former Chair, Dr. Clement Alexander Price. It was our good fortune to have such a distinguished educator, historian and scholar to guide our organization. Clem was our advisor and mentor, a source of support and inspiration, a dear friend. Words cannot express the depth of our sorrow. In memory and honor of Clem, a man who cared deeply about telling Americas story, Save Ellis Island will continue to advance his vision and important preservation work on Ellis Island to restore the historic Ellis Island Hospital and to share the stories of the 12 million immigrants who passed through its doors. 1/3

PINCUS--Leonard "Lee", 83, passed away on November 12 after a long illness. Born in Chicago to the late George and Florence and brother to the late Irwin Pincus, Lee graduated from Cornell University and worked in the family international music business for over 60 years. He authored "The Songwriters Success Manual" in 1978 and helped hundreds of musicians in their careers. While living and working in London, Lee saw the then barely known Beatles perform in 1963, and, on behalf of Gil Music, he acquired the rights to six early Beatles songs. Lee is survived by his devoted sister, Gloria Tannenbaum (Maurice), loving nieces and nephews, and friends all over the world. He lived his life with a quiet grace and was generous and loyal to those who knew him well. He will be missed. Shiva will be held at the Tannenbaum home, 200 Riverside Boulevard in Manhattan from 1:00-4:00pm on Sunday, November 16. In lieu of flowers, donations. An be made to Parkinson's Research Foundation. 1/3

MAN--Albon Platt IV, died Wednesday, October 22, 2014, at his home in Palisades, NY. He was 95. He was a community volunteer and activist for peace both early and late in his life. Preceded in death by his wife of 44 years, Yolanda Abruzzi Man. Survived by son Anthony Man (partner Clayton Brown) of Wilton Manors, FL; daughter Angela Pungello (husband Steven Pungello) of Washingtonville, NY, and grandson Steven Pungello of Washingtonville. 1/3

BADER--Deirdre Russell, (nee Murphy), beloved wife of Lawrence S. Bader, adoring mother of Ethan Russell Bader, cherished daughter of Daniel Murphy and Sally Kandle, passed away peacefully on November 11, 2014 at the Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. Deirdre was the Executive Director of Star Track, a cycling charity for New York City children between the ages of 7 and 14. Using the City's outdoor velodrome in Kessina Park in Queens, Deirdre founded the charity in connection with New York's bid for the 2012 Olympic games and led Star Track's growth over the past 12 years to the point where, in this year, 300 children were enrolled in Star Track, with a long waiting list. Star Track is a free program that teaches children how to ride specialized bicycles designed for competition on banked tracks called velodromes. It was Deirdre's hope that by learning to ride on a velodrome, the children could develop fitness, self-esteem and teamwork. Deirdre's involvement in competitive cycling began when she was 32 years old, and she retired at the age of 41, having just competed for Ireland in the women's road race in the Sydney Australia Olympics. Deirdre was born and raised in New York City, and while in high school, obtained Irish citizenship at the urging of her father. Years later, representing Ireland, Deirdre raced against international competition in Montevideo, Uruguay in a qualifying race to determine which countries could send their road cycling competitors to the 2000 Olympics. By finishing fourth in that race, Deirdre qualified Ireland to send its first woman road cyclist ever to the Olympics. Deirdre was also the Women's World Masters champion in 1997 for all women over 30 years old, earning her the coveted "Rainbow Jersey" worn by the reigning world's champion in one of cycling's disciplines --in her case, the road race. In her career, she won 81 races. Deirdre married her husband, Lawrence in 2002 and gave birth to their son, Ethan, in 2007. Deirdre was an extraordinarily beautiful woman who embodied generosity of spirit, warmth, loyalty, competitiveness and intelligence. She will be missed terribly by all who knew her. It was her request that in lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory be made to Star Track at "Bike New York/Star Track", 12 East 87th Street, New York, N.Y. 10128. A funeral service will be held at The Brick Presbyterian Church at 1140 Park Avenue on Saturday, November 15 at 11am, followed by a reception. 1/3

ROWAN--Rita Honor. November 16, 2012. Hunter College B.A. Beloved sister, dear friend and colleague, devoted parishioner. Deeply missed. 1/3
RISKIN--Milton. 1905-2004 Ten years today. Thanks for everything dad. You were the best. Michael and Eliot 1/3
DEAN--Andy Chen, M.D.,Ph.D. 3/26/60 -11/15/06. We remember you with love and respect. Your Family 1/3

ZIMAND--Harvey Folks. Harvey Folks Zimand, passed away on November 10, 2014 peacefully at his home in New York City. He was 86. He was born in NYC and attended Friends Seminary, graduated from Colgate University, received a master's degree in political science at the University of Chicago, and his law degree from Yale University. After law school, he joined Kelley Drye & Warren where he became a partner and specialized as a trusts and estates attorney for over 50 years. He was selected as one of The Best Lawyers in America in the Trusts & Estates and Litigation for over twenty years. He was a lifelong resident of New York City and spent many summers with his family in Randolph, New Hampshire, where he loved to hike and was a member of the Randolph Hiking Club. Mr. Zimand is survived by his two daughters, Patty Carpenter and Stephanie Plexico, his four grandchildren and his stepsons Chris Manfre and Mark Manfre and their two sons. Funeral services will be held on Saturday November 22, 2014 at 1:30pm at Frank E Campbell, The Funeral Chapel. 1/3

OESTREICH--Herbert. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Herbert Oestreich, and extend sincere condolences to his family. James Dreyfus, President 1/3

OESTREICH--Dr. Herbert M.,unexpectedly on November 12, 2014, age 82. Beloved husband, father, "Grandpa Sir" and brother. Superb clinician, devoted to his profession and patients. Former chief of Neurosurgery, White Plains Hospital, trustee American Association of Neurological Surgeons and president New York State Neurosurgical Society. Associate Professor Neurosurgery New York Medical College and Westchester Medical Center. Avid golfer, tennis player and skier; music, opera and gadget lover; student of Torah; wry humorist. Services Sunday, 1pm, Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY. 1/3

MARTIN--Dorothy The Board of Governors and the members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of Dorothy, wife our esteemed member Buddy Martin and extend our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Board of Governors Michael Mann, President 1

MARTIN--Dorothy. We mourn the loss of Dorothy, our dear friend for more than 50 years. She was a talented and accomplished lady, loved by all. Our condolences to Buddy and the entire family. We will always remember her. Joan and Martin Rosen 1/3

MARTIN--Dorothy "Dotsy", beloved wife, mother and grandmother, died on November 13, 2014, after a courageous seven-year battle with Alzheimer's. Dorothy was the only child of Mary and William Martin. She met Buddy, her soul mate and husband of 62 years, at Evander Childs High School. Dorothy and Buddy were inseparable and an inspiration to all as a kind, loving, and deeply devoted couple. Everyone who met Dorothy loved her. Dorothy enjoyed golf, cards, knitting, travel, and the piano. She was a lifelong active volunteer for many charities. Most of all, Dorothy loved spending time with her family. Her family and countless friends admired her sense of humor, wit, intelligence, generosity, and extraordinary beauty inside and out. Dorothy is survived by her adoring husband, Buddy, and their four children Lynn (Mitchell), Steven (Edie), Jamie (Steven) and David, and grandchildren Raquel, Alexis, Alanna, Hank, Morgan and Mia. Dorothy will be greatly missed. Memorial contributions may be made to Alz.org/JudyFund or to the charity of your choice. 1/3
LEWIS--Myron "Mike" James, wife of the late Barbara Lowenberg, died Thursday, November 13 2014. For information go to www.guttermanmusicant wien.com 1/3

LEVINE--Jacques. With a sad heart we mourn our uncle Jacques. His kindness, love of family and positive outlook was an example to all of us. Susan and Bob Klein, Ricki and Bob Conway, Susan Waterfall 1/3

LEVINE--Jacques. Role model for us all: loving, honorable, reliable. He never forgot a birthday. Condolences and love to Jacques' whole family. Rudi and Janet de Winter, Maggie Hoffman, Elizabeth Wiener and Emily Bukow 1/3

LEVINE--Jacques. Passed away after a brief illness at the age of 92. Beloved husband of departed Florence (Tananbaum), father of late Harold (Carol), Alan (Alison Newman), Minna (Ron Calvanio), and David (Sherrie Zacharius), grandfather of eight, and great- grandfather of five. The name Jacques Levine is synonymous with style and elegance for women's footwear. For his stewardship of Middletown Footwear during much of its 78-year history, he was inducted into the Footwear News Hall of Fame in 1998. He was dedicated to the Boy Scouts of America, Gomez Foundation for Mill House, Orange County Land Trust, Jewish Federation of Orange County, and Temple Sinai. His contributions over a lifetime to his Middletown and Orange County communities, the Jewish community, and the footwear industry are a model for generations. An inspirational, charitable, and loving man, he was deeply rooted in history and tradition (and a loyal Quaker, University of Pennsylvania class of '43). We loved him dearly. Contributions shall be made to the Jacques and Florence Levine Endowment of UJA- Federation of Orange County and Orange County Land Trust. The Levine Family 1/3

LEVINE--Jacques. Adored father, grandfather and great grandfather, loved by his extended family and friends, Jacques will be remembered for his strength (the rock), integrity, and loyalty. He was always there for every family event and never forgot anyone's birthday with a hand written card which made us feel so important. His smile always brightened our day and we will miss him terribly. Deedy and David, Karen and Jim, Julie and Rob, Patty 1/3

LEBENTHAL--James A. James A. Lebenthal was more than a longstanding trustee of the Museum of the City of New York. He was a beloved trustee. He infused every meeting he attended with optimism, kindness, a sense that yes, we can and should do it! He was the clarion call, able to galvanize support and create enthusiasm. Always engaging, always irrepressible, always funny, smart, and entertaining, Jim was a mainstay at the City Museum. At an event on this past Monday, Jim was honored for his enormous contributions to the institution and for the endowment of the James A. Lebenthal Timescapes Gallery. We will always remember how beautifully he spoke and how he urged us to pursue our mission. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife Betty, to his three children, James, Alexandra, and Claudia, and to all his grandchildren. James G. Dinan, Chairman, Susan Henshaw Jones, Ronay Menschel Director, all Jim's fellow trustees, both past and present, and the City Museum staff 1/3

JACOBS--Harold, was born to immigrant parents in Williamsburg, Brooklyn in August of 1919. He passed away on November 13th. He was the founder and president of Crown Surgical Corporation, a manufacturer of surgical instruments. During World War II, he earned an E Award for meeting schedules for orders to the U.S. Military. His love of theater and opera led him to organize entertainment for troops at hospitals and USO venues here and abroad. He was active in raising funds for Israel, and a proud member of the Kane Street Synagogue in Park Slope. Hal was quite a sportsman, active in skiing, tennis and fencing. He was a collector of Egyptian, Greek and Roman antiquities. Many of his pieces have been donated to his favorite museums. Hal was devoted to his beloved wife Mildred, sister Sylvia and numerous nephews, and nieces who will remember him fondly as Uncle Heshie, a down to earth guy who cried freely, laughed heartily, and had a good life. 1/3

GORDON--Philip H. The Bard College community mourns the passing of Philip H. Gordon '43, longtime friend and Alumni/ae Trustee of the College. Throughout his life he was committed to helping provide exceptional educational opportunities to all; that commitment continues, thanks to his support of Bard. We send our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Sandy, and his children, grandchildren, nieces, and nephews. Charles P. Stevenson Jr., Chair David E. Schwab, Chair Emeritus Leon Botstein, President 1/3

GELBER--Sidney, 89, died in his sleep on the morning of November 13. Devoted father of Alexis, Stephen, and Valerie Gelber, father-in-law of Mark Whitaker, Susan Luciano, and Abraham Yacob, and adoring grandfather of Nadine and Regina Sobel, Rachel and Matthew Whitaker, and Rose Luciano, Sidney was predeceased in 2012 by his beloved wife of 64 years, Anita Gelber. Sidney was a brilliant and compassionate thinker, professor, and university administrator who dedicated his life to higher education. Born in New York, he attended DeWitt Clinton High School and Columbia College, and served in U.S Army counterintelligence during World War II. He received his B.A and Ph.D from Columbia University and joined the Philosophy Department faculty. Sidney was on the editorial committee that rewrote the source book for Columbia's famous Contemporary Civilization course, and he taught classes with Lionel Trilling and Fred Dupee. Sidney went on to help create and build the State University of New York at Stony Brook, and rose to become Academic Vice-President and Provost. In 2001 he published a book, "Politics and Public Higher Education in New York State: Stony Brook--A Case History," a definitive history of the university. He also shared his expertise with Ben-Gurion University of the Negev in Israel, where he was on the Board of Governors and received an Honorary Doctorate and a Lifetime Achievement Award. Sidney possessed a rare combination of wisdom, humor, political insight, and managerial savvy. He was an accomplished pianist who performed in Carnegie Recital Hall with Anita and valued the two years that he was President of the Mannes College of Music while such great musicians as Murray Perahia, Richard Goode, and Frederica von Stade were students. His mind was sharp and his sense of humor intact until the end, and he was beloved by his children, grandchildren, former students, and colleagues. He is an irreplaceable force in his family's life. Funeral service will be held on Sunday, November 16 at 10am at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. 1/3

diBELARDINO--Philip, a world-renowned wine expert, lecturer and spokesman and Specialist for Banfi Cru Artisan Wines, died peacefully, after a short illness, on Thursday, November 13 in New York City. Son of Constance Tempesta and Aldo DiBelardino, founder of Mediterranean Importing, Philip oversaw the reorganization of the family business into the fine wine division of Heublein, Inc. where he served for 15 years as Vice President. He was then brought to Banfi Inc. to oversee the education and marketing of their fine wines. He developed close relationships with many renowned Italian producers and led seminars, tastings and enoteca tours throughout the USA and Europe. He also held the Banfi Chair at Cornell University, in Ithaca, New York where he taught courses on Italian wines for their restaurateur degree program. Philip was an inductee into the Wines of Italy Hall of Fame. A graduate of Xavier High School in New York City, he held a B.A. from Boston College and a Masters in Theatre from Catholic University in Washington, D.C. Prior to his success in the wine business, Philip was a theatrical director, producer and entrepreneur, and his "Collector's Item" revue played nightclubs, resorts and cruises for several years. He was also a lifelong devotee of opera, theatre and the performing arts. He is survived by his brother and sister-in-law, Mario and Susan Belardino, two nephews David (Janine) and Adam (Michelle), and numerous cousins and extended family. In lieu of flowers, the family has suggested that contributions be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461. Attention Vincent Spinelli, Executive Vice President, Calvary Fund. Viewing will be on Sunday from 4-7pm and Monday from 2-4pm and 7- 9pm at the Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel) Madison Ave. at 81st. Street, New York City. There will be a private funeral on Tuesday. 1/3

CLASTER--Jill. Friends Seminary mourns the passing of Professor Jill Claster, prominent scholar and teacher, mother of the late Elizabeth Claster '79 and abiding friend. Robert (Bo) Lauder, Principal, Matthew Annenberg and Elizabeth Enloe, Clerks, School Committee 1/3

CLASTER--Jill. The NYU community mourns the loss of Jill Claster --distinguished scholar, teacher, mentor, and the first woman and alumna to serve as dean of NYU's College of Arts and Science. Beloved by her students, admired and respected by her colleagues, cherished by her friends, she was a prominent member of the generation of NYU faculty and administrators that --against all odds --transformed NYU. A model University citizen for decades, and a model of courage and dignity in her final days, she will be sorely missed. Her family and friends will be in the hearts of the NYU community, which loved Jill and shares their sense of loss. Martin Lipton, Chair, NYU Board of Trustees John Sexton, President, NYU Gabrielle Starr, Dean, NYU College of Arts and Science 1/3

BADER--Deirdre. Morvillo Abramowitz Grand Iason & Anello mourns the death of Deirdre Bader, beloved wife of our partner Larry Bader. Deirdre was a devoted and loving mother to their son Ethan, a talented and accomplished athlete, a generous champion of Star Track, a charity that brings the sport of competitive cycling to children of New York City, and a cherished friend to all at our firm. 1/3

Moser--Marvin Dr. Marvin Moser, 90, died Thursday, November 13 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. He was a world leading expert in hypertension and a clinical professor at Yale Medical School. He leaves behind a loving family: his wife Joy, daughter, Jill (David), sons Stephen (Catherine) and John (Pamela) and his four granddaughters. Services will be held on Monday, November 17 at 9:45AM at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY.

CLASTER--Jill Nadell (Midonick) died Nov. 14 at home after a short illness. She was predeceased by her husband Judge Millard Midonick and daughter Elizabeth. Scholar, teacher, author, friend, mentor, theatre and opera-lover, aspiring actress, wife, mother, aunt, party-thrower, shoe-collector, world traveler, good neighbor, she will be missed by thousands. Jill was Professor Emerita of Medieval History at New York University and still teaching her course on Renewal and Expansion in Europe in the Twelfth Century until two weeks ago. Brooklyn born and raised, she received her BA and MA from NYU and a PhD from the University of Pennsylvania and taught at the University of Kentucky before coming to NYU in 1964. At NYU she served as dean of the College of Arts and Sciences from 1978 to 1986 and director of the Hagop Kevorkian Center of Near Eastern Studies from 1991 to 1997. Jill served on multiple boards and was a champion of the Elizabeth Claster Lower School Library at Friends Seminary. Funeral services will be at 10:00 AM Monday, November 17 at Riverside Memorial Chapel. A Memorial Service at NYU will be announced later. In lieu of flowers please consider donations to the Elizabeth Claster Library at Friends Seminary, 222 E.16th St., NY, NY 10003 or the Elizabeth Claster Memorial Scholarship Fund c/o Cynthia Young, NYU, 25 W. 4th St., NY, NY 10012.

ROWAN--Rita Honor. November 16, 2012. Hunter College B.A. Beloved sister, dear friend and colleague, devoted parishioner. Deeply missed. 1/3

MALFETTI--James L.,Sr. Professor Emeritus James L. Malfetti, a teacher for 43 years at Columbia College and Teachers College, Columbia University, died a year ago at his home in Carefree, AZ., at 92. The pioneer in sex education and traffic safety research was a born leader and teacher, whose students flourished because he made them feel valued. Remembered as a man who genuinely liked people of all kinds, Professor Malfetti was beloved for his generosity, fairness, optimism and sense of humor. "Reproduction, Sex and Preparation for Marriage," which he co-authored in 1964, was a groundbreaking sex-education text published in at least five countries. In his 1957 "Electronic Controls and Traffic Safety," he envisioned self-driving cars. Adaptations of his 1970 "DWI Phoenix" program are still in use globally. Professor Malfetti was born in 1920 in College Point, NY, to Vincent and Annie Burns Malfetti. He grew up in New York City, where in his youth he was a Bronx Home News paperboy, baseball park ice cream hawker, bouncer, maitre'd, lifeguard and Fuller Brush man, among numerous other jobs. In WWII, he was Navy officer in the European and Asian theaters. He went to college on the GI Bill, earned his doctorate, taught human sexuality and transportation safety and served on committees of the Transportation Research Board, National Research Council and National Academy of Sciences. The AAA Foundation, government and numerous corporations funded his research and publications at Columbia, where he was Assistant to the Dean of Columbia College, Associate Director of the Bicentennial of Columbia University and Associate Director of the American Assembly, a body of prominent thinkers founded by President Eisenhower to address national problems. Professor Malfetti was a widely admired educator, speaker, administrator and lover of art and literature, who in his 90s, recited Shakespeare sonnets and Housman poems by heart -a storyteller's storyteller who enlightened and entertained generations of students, his family and all those fortunate enough to have known him. He is deeply missed. 1/3

ZIMAND--Harvey Folks. Harvey Folks Zimand, passed away on November 10, 2014 peacefully at his home in New York City. He was 86. He was born in NYC and attended Friends Seminary, graduated from Colgate University, received a master's degree in political science at the University of Chicago, and his law degree from Yale University. After law school, he joined Kelley Drye & Warren where he became a partner and specialized as a trusts and estates attorney for over 50 years. He was selected as one of The Best Lawyers in America in the Trusts & Estates and Litigation for over twenty years. He was a lifelong resident of New York City and spent many summers with his family in Randolph, New Hampshire, where he loved to hike and was a member of the Randolph Hiking Club. Mr. Zimand is survived by his two daughters, Patty Carpenter and Stephanie Plexico, his four grandchildren and his stepsons Chris Manfre and Mark Manfre and their two sons. Funeral services will be held on Saturday November 22, 2014 at 1:30pm at Frank E Campbell, The Funeral Chapel. 1/3
WILNER--Ruth, passed away on November 8, 2014 at the age of 98 following a short illness. She was the former principal of PS105 Queens. She is survived by her daughter Merrill. 1/3

WEISS--Julia, died peacefully in her home on November 13, 2014 after a long fight with cancer. Julia, more widely known to her friends as Judy, was the quintessential, old- fashioned Upper West Sider: an outspokenly opinionated, ultra-liberal, Zabars bag-toting, no prisoners-taking, New Yorker. She also had a terrific warmth and a quick smile, and was fiercely loyal to her family and friends. Judy loved the New York Philharmonic and was a duplicate bridge master. As Chief Administrator of the Impartial Hearing Office of the New York City Board of Education for many years, she was a tireless advocate for children. She will be profoundly missed by her loving children, Hallie and Bob, and grandchildren, Andrew, Lizzy and Daniel. 1/3

STOTT--Robert Leslie, Jr.,84, of Vero Beach, FL, died peacefully, surrounded by family, at home on November 10. Bob is survived by wife of 30 years, Heidi Bingham Stott; brother Donald B. Stott of Summit, NJ and North Palm Beach, FL; sons David and Lawrence; daughters-in-law Micki and Megan; five grandchildren; stepchildren Kathleen Fell Connor, John Fell, Michael Fell and Jeffrey Fell; and four step-grandchildren. Services will be held at The Community Church of Vero Beach, FL on November 21. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Vero Beach Museum of Art, 3001 Riverside Park Drive, Vero Beach, FL 32963 or The Community Church of Vero Beach, 1901 23rd Street, Vero Beach, FL 32960. 1/3

STORCH--Anne, 96, a pioneer instrumental in putting Mexico on the map as a major tourist destination starting in the 1950s under the name Asti Tours. Mexico bestowed innumerable awards on her including Woman of the Year; a first for a non-Mexican. Beloved Mother to Bronnie Kupris and Dr. Marc Storch; adored "Grannie Annie" to six, "GG" to nine, her elegance, her indomitable spirit and her life lessons will be remembered and treasured by us all. 1/3

SCHLANG--Maurice, 105, Beloved husband of Barbara. Devoted daughters Adrienne Garnett, Audrey Diamond, step-daughter Meryl Wolper, grandfather of five, great- grandfather of six. He had a long, productive life and we will miss him. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Shirley (nee Sussman), age 85, of New York City, loving mother, aunt and loyal friend died very peacefully on Sunday, November 9, 2014. Her loving son Jerrold together with her exceptional home aids and close friends were at her bedside. Rabbi Leser officiated a beautiful service at Riverside Memorial Chapel. My mother was feisty and brave and her memory will live in my heart forever. You are safe in Hashem's hands. Rest in peace my dear mother. 1/3

SANDO--Ernest. Ernest "Ernie" Sando, 64, of Rehoboth Beach, DE, and a retired business executive, died October 31, 2014. Born in Hazelton, PA, May 25, 1950, Mr. Sando graduated from Hazleton High School in 1968 and earned a degree in political science from Mansfield College. Mr. Sando worked for the 1972 George McGovern campaign and later accepted a job with Sen. Alan Cranston. During his career, he was a stockbroker with Johnston, Lemon, and Co.; vice president, investor relations at Georgeson and Co., New York, from 1979 to 1982; and director, investor relations and corporate communications, at Flexi-Van Corp. and for DF King and Co. before returning to Georgeson in 1987 as senior managing director and member of the board of directors. In 2000, he accepted a position with Hill and Knowlton Inc., as U.S. director, financial communications, and senior managing director. He was a member of the National Investor Relations Institute Board of Directors and the New York Financial Communications Society. In 2003, he and Carl Grimm, his partner of 23 years, retired to Rehoboth Beach, DE., formed C&E Partners together and purchased Bayberry, a flower shop and event business. In addition to Mr. Grimm, Mr. Sando is survived by his mother Irene Tamanini Sando Joyner; brothers, James Sando, Michael Sando and Larry Joyner; sister Cynthia Farley; nieces and nephews, Sarah Sando Cocchimiglio, Alex Sando, Kiernan Farley, Victoria Farley Buckwalter, Shealyn Farley, and Harrison Sando; and a great- nephew, Anthony Cocchimiglio IV. He was predeceased by his father Ernest Sando and his stepfather Cliff Joyner. Mr. Sando was a loyal, generous friend, considered by all who knew him as a true gentleman. He shared his life with his family and an incredible group of friends. Funeral services were private. A celebration of life will be held at a later date. Memorial contributions in Mr. Sando's name may be directed to the Beebe Healthcare Margaret H. Rollins School of Nursing Annual Fund, the Rehoboth Beach Fire Department or the Children's Beach House --Lewes. 1/3

QUIGLEY--Catherine T.,died peacefully at home October 28, 2014. Age 88. She was lovingly taken care of by her daughter AnneMarie. She was the beloved wife of Richard M. Quigley who preceded her as did two sons Richard (Linda) and Kenneth (Kathleen). Born in New York City, January 2, 1926 to William and Ana Magner, she attended Cathedral High School, Hunter College and Notre Dame of Staten Island. She taught fifth grade at St. Mary's and horticulture at McAuley School. An avid gardener, she also became a professional artist at 80 in 2006. She was devoted in religious beliefs and became an associate of the Sisters of Mercy in 1986. She is survived by Patricia (Daniel) Lescop, AnneMarie, Michael (Kathleen), Mary (Michael) Borrosh and nine grandchildren. 1/3

PORTER--Dr. Robert, died October 14, age 95. Child and adolescent psychiatrist affiliated with New York's Mt. Sinai Hospital for more than 60 years. Wife Mary Kay died in 2006. He is survived by his sister, Betty Hussman and nephew, Mark Hussman, of Minden, NV. Highly respected and admired for his intellect, clinical skills, humanity and philanthropic activity, "Bob" is mourned by family, friends, former supervisees and colleagues. 1/3

PINCUS--Leonard "Lee", 83, passed away on November 12 after a long illness. Born in Chicago to the late George and Florence and brother to the late Irwin Pincus, Lee graduated from Cornell University and worked in the family international music business for over 60 years. He authored "The Songwriters Success Manual" in 1978 and helped hundreds of musicians in their careers. While living and working in London, Lee saw the then barely known Beatles perform in 1963, and, on behalf of Gil Music, he acquired the rights to six early Beatles songs. Lee is survived by his devoted sister, Gloria Tannenbaum (Maurice), loving nieces and nephews, and friends all over the world. He lived his life with a quiet grace and was generous and loyal to those who knew him well. He will be missed. Shiva will be held at the Tannenbaum home, 200 Riverside Boulevard in Manhattan from 1:00-4:00pm on Sunday, November 16. In lieu of flowers, donations. An be made to Parkinson's Research Foundation. 1/3

PETERS--Muriel, Born Muriel Burns in New York City, died on November 1, 2014. Daughter of Rose and Joe Burns; sister of Nellie Goldstein. Loved by all, but married to, and loved and adored by Allan Peters. After being widowed, Muriel started work with her long time friend, Leona Helmsley, in real estate. Later she worked for Glenwood Management for several decades. She was one-of-a-kind. A glamorous card shark who was considered one of the best female gin players on the east coast. Muriel was also a best friend to many great New York City Italian restaurants. We raise a glass to this fabulous woman who will be missed by all! 1/3

PEERCE--Lois S. Congregation Emanu-El of the city of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Lois S. Peerce. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Joshua M. Davidson Senior Rabbi John H. Streicker, President 1/3

OESTREICH--Dr. Herbert M.,unexpectedly on November 12, 2014, age 82. Beloved husband, father, "Grandpa Sir" and brother. Superb clinician, devoted to his profession and patients. Former chief of Neurosurgery, White Plains Hospital, trustee American Association of Neurological Surgeons and president New York State Neurosurgical Society. Associate Professor Neurosurgery New York Medical College and Westchester Medical Center. Avid golfer, tennis player and skier; music, opera and gadget lover; student of Torah; wry humorist. Services Sunday, 1pm, Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY. 1/3

NOTARAS--Demetra K. 82, passed away Sunday, September 21 in Los Angeles, CA surrounded by her beloved family. She is survived by her sister, Christine Pavlounis; her children, Maria, Paul, Jim and George; her daughter-in- law Martha; and four grandchildren Andrew, Charlotte, Tyler and Paige. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations in Demetras name to one of her great passions: The Great Books Foundation (www.greatbooks.org). 1/3

MITZMAN--Neil. To our darling Neil whose kind spirit and sense of humor will always be remembered. You will be missed and in our hearts forever. Brenda and Carlin Axelrod and Family, Marjorie and Robert Emden and Family, Sharon Stone 1/3

MARTIN--Dorothy. We mourn the loss of Dorothy, our dear friend for more than 50 years. She was a talented and accomplished lady, loved by all. Our condolences to Buddy and the entire family. We will always remember her. Joan and Martin Rosen 1/3

MARTIN--Dorothy "Dotsy", beloved wife, mother and grandmother, died on November 13, 2014, after a courageous seven-year battle with Alzheimer's. Dorothy was the only child of Mary and William Martin. She met Buddy, her soul mate and husband of 62 years, at Evander Childs High School. Dorothy and Buddy were inseparable and an inspiration to all as a kind, loving, and deeply devoted couple. Everyone who met Dorothy loved her. Dorothy enjoyed golf, cards, knitting, travel, and the piano. She was a lifelong active volunteer for many charities. Most of all, Dorothy loved spending time with her family. Her family and countless friends admired her sense of humor, wit, intelligence, generosity, and extraordinary beauty inside and out. Dorothy is survived by her adoring husband, Buddy, and their four children Lynn (Mitchell), Steven (Edie), Jamie (Steven) and David, and grandchildren Raquel, Alexis, Alanna, Hank, Morgan and Mia. Dorothy will be greatly missed. Memorial contributions may be made to Alz.org/JudyFund or to the charity of your choice. 1/3

MAN--Albon Platt IV, died Wednesday, October 22, 2014, at his home in Palisades, NY. He was 95. Mr. Man received bachelor's, master's and law degrees from Columbia University and worked at the publishing company Prentice-Hall, where he became editor-in-chief of his division, and at the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. He was a community volunteer and activist for peace both early and late in his life. Preceded in death by his wife of 44 years, Yolanda Abruzzi Man. Survived by son Anthony Man (partner Clayton Brown) of Wilton Manors, FL; daughter Angela Pungello (husband Steven Pungello) of Washingtonville, NY, and grandson Steven Pungello of Washingtonville. 1/3

LEVINE--Jacques. With a sad heart we mourn our uncle Jacques. His kindness, love of family and positive outlook was an example to all of us. Susan and Bob Klein, Ricki and Bob Conway, Susan Waterfall 1/3

LEVINE--Jacques. The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family in mourning the loss of Jacques Levine, father of JTS Trustee Alan Levine and a longtime friend to JTS. Known to the world as an impressive and innovative businessman, to his family, friends, and community Jacques was a vibrant, compassionate, and thoughtful person who loved Judaism and lived it each and every day of his life. He set the highest example for his children and grandchildren, who follow in his steady and generous footsteps. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold M. Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair 1/3

LEVINE--Jacques. Role model for us all: loving, honorable, reliable. He never forgot a birthday. Condolences and love to Jacques' whole family. Rudi and Janet de Winter, Maggie Hoffman, Elizabeth Wiener and Emily Bukow 1/3

LEVINE--Jacques. Passed away after a brief illness at the age of 92. Beloved husband of departed Florence (Tananbaum), father of late Harold (Carol), Alan (Alison Newman), Minna (Ron Calvanio), and David (Sherrie Zacharius), grandfather of eight, and great- grandfather of five. The name Jacques Levine is synonymous with style and elegance for women's footwear. For his stewardship of Middletown Footwear during much of its 78-year history, he was inducted into the Footwear News Hall of Fame in 1998. He was dedicated to the Boy Scouts of America, Gomez Foundation for Mill House, Orange County Land Trust, Jewish Federation of Orange County, and Temple Sinai. His contributions over a lifetime to his Middletown and Orange County communities, the Jewish community, and the footwear industry are a model for generations. An inspirational, charitable, and loving man, he was deeply rooted in history and tradition (and a loyal Quaker, University of Pennsylvania class of '43). We loved him dearly. Contributions shall be made to the Jacques and Florence Levine Endowment of UJA- Federation of Orange County and Orange County Land Trust. The Levine Family 1/3

LEVINE--Jacques. Adored father, grandfather and great grandfather, loved by his extended family and friends, Jacques will be remembered for his strength (the rock), integrity, and loyalty. He was always there for every family event and never forgot anyone's birthday with a hand written card which made us feel so important. His smile always brightened our day and we will miss him terribly. Deedy and David, Karen and Jim, Julie and Rob, Patty 1/3

LEBENTHAL--James A. James A. Lebenthal was more than a longstanding trustee of the Museum of the City of New York. He was a beloved trustee. He infused every meeting he attended with optimism, kindness, a sense that yes, we can and should do it! He was the clarion call, able to galvanize support and create enthusiasm. Always engaging, always irrepressible, always funny, smart, and entertaining, Jim was a mainstay at the City Museum. At an event on this past Monday, Jim was honored for his enormous contributions to the institution and for the endowment of the James A. Lebenthal Timescapes Gallery. We will always remember how beautifully he spoke and how he urged us to pursue our mission. We send our deepest sympathies to his wife Betty, to his three children, James, Alexandra, and Claudia, and to all his grandchildren. James G. Dinan, Chairman, Susan Henshaw Jones, Ronay Menschel Director, all Jim's fellow trustees, both past and present, and the City Museum staff 1/3

KINSELLA--Cynthia. Cynthia Rodstrom Kinsella, 92, died November 6, 2014, at Indian River Estates in Vero Beach, Florida. Born June 17, 1922 to Captain Charles Rodstrom and Cora Adelaide Waterhouse. Married to John Lawrence Kinsella, who predeceased her. She graduated from Hunter College in New York City, and the Bellevue School of Nursing, which she later directed. She earned her Master's and Doctoral degrees at Columbia University, and held a variety of professional appointments, including a Presidential appointment to the National Advisory Committee on Nurse Training, a Governor's appointment to the New York State Health Resources Commission, and a Mayoral appointment to the Comprehensive Health Planning Board. She was appointed Dean of the Mount Sinai School of Nursing of the City College, holding a joint appointment as Director of Nursing at the Mount Sinai Hospital. She served as a Trustee of the Mount Desert Island Hospital in Bar Harbor, Maine, as Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport, New York, and as a member of the Governor's Council on Excellence in Long Term Care in Florida. The family will memorialize Cynthia's life at a private graveside service at the Calvary Cemetery. Contributions in her memory may be made to the ACTS Samaritan Fund, 375 Morris Road, P.O. Box 90, West Point, PA 19486-0090. 1/3

JACOBS--Harold, was born to immigrant parents in Williamsburg, Brooklyn in August of 1919. He passed away on November 13th. He was the founder and president of Crown Surgical Corporation, a manufacturer of surgical instruments. During World War II, he earned an E Award for meeting schedules for orders to the U.S. Military. His love of theater and opera led him to organize entertainment for troops at hospitals and USO venues here and abroad. He was active in raising funds for Israel, and a proud member of the Kane Street Synagogue in Park Slope. Hal was quite a sportsman, active in skiing, tennis and fencing. He was a collector of Egyptian, Greek and Roman antiquities. Many of his pieces have been donated to his favorite museums. Hal was devoted to his beloved wife Mildred, sister Sylvia and numerous nephews, and nieces who will remember him fondly as Uncle Heshie, a down to earth guy who cried freely, laughed heartily, and had a good life. 1/3

GROSS--Donald. Condolences to our dear friend Linda and her wonderful children and grandchildren for the loss of their husband, father and grandfather. We have been friends for over 70 years since the days we went to Camp Onibar. Donald was a wonderful man and Linda you kept him alive for as along as you could. We will miss him forever. Sandy and Joel 1/3

GROSS--Donald Joel, born May 3, 1935, passed away on November 11, 2014 after long courageous battles against Sepsis. He leaves behind a grieving family. Children Kenneth and Debbie, Ira and Moeh Moeh, Valerie and John; grandchildren Jaime, Dani, Allie, Jessica and Dylan; devoted wife Linda of 54 years. My darling Donald you ask how long I'll love you, I'll tell you true until the Twelfth of Never, I'll still be loving you. The family thanks Evan for years of excellent care and devotion. Funeral at Riverside in Great Neck on Friday, November 14, at 9:30am. Shiva at the home of Ira Gross, Saturday after sundown through Wednesday; afternoons from 1pm-4pm evenings from 7pm-9pm. 1/3

GRIMMELMANN--Ihler, born April 2, 1922, died November 10, 2014. Survived by his wife of 65 years, Frances, by his children, Erik (Louise Gikow) and Ellen (Moshe Adler), and by his half-brother Frank. Predeceased by daughter Lisa Bidwell and by his sib- lings Dorothy, Ann, and Karl. Much loved grandfather of James (Aislinn Black), Rachel, and Lily. Great-grandfather of Beatrice. Graduate of Middlebury College (1943) and Columbia University's Teachers College (1948). Worked as a child psychologist in White Plains, NY as well as with Head Start and in early childhood education. Among his happiest times were his sailing years on "Tranquillity" with Frances. Thank you to Emy, Alice, Lulu, and Ouli. Anyone who wishes to make a memorial contribution should consider Amnesty International, the Vera Institute of Justice, or The New Press. The family may be reached at: IGNYC49@gmail.com 1/3

GOROWITZ--June, (Altman, (nee) Barshop) passed away on October 19th. June, a retired NYC teacher and Guidance Counselor resided in Boynton Beach, FL and is survived by her beloved husband, Mort, her sister, four daughters, five grandchildren and two great -grandchildren. 1/3

GELBER--Sidney, 89, died in his sleep on the morning of November 13. Devoted father of Alexis, Stephen, and Valerie Gelber, father-in-law of Mark Whitaker, Susan Luciano, and Abraham Yacob, and adoring grandfather of Nadine and Regina Sobel, Rachel and Matthew Whitaker, and Rose Luciano, Sidney was predeceased in 2012 by his beloved wife of 64 years, Anita Gelber. Sidney was a brilliant and compassionate thinker, professor, and university administrator who dedicated his life to higher education. Born in New York, he attended DeWitt Clinton High School and Columbia College, and served in U.S Army counterintelligence during World War II. He received his B.A and Ph.D from Columbia University and joined the Philosophy Department faculty. Sidney was on the editorial committee that rewrote the source book for Columbia's famous Contemporary Civilization course, and he taught classes with Lionel Trilling and Fred Dupee. Sidney went on to help create and build the State University of New York at Stony Brook, and rose to become Academic Vice-President and Provost. In 2001 he published a book, "Politics and Public Higher Education in New York State: Stony Brook--A Case History," a definitive history of the university. He also shared his expertise with Ben-Gurion University of the Negev in Israel, where he was on the Board of Governors and received an Honorary Doctorate and a Lifetime Achievement Award. Sidney possessed a rare combination of wisdom, humor, political insight, and managerial savvy. He was an accomplished pianist who performed in Carnegie Recital Hall with Anita and valued the two years that he was President of the Mannes College of Music while such great musicians as Murray Perahia, Richard Goode, and Frederica von Stade were students. His mind was sharp and his sense of humor intact until the end, and he was beloved by his children, grandchildren, former students, and colleagues. He is an irreplaceable force in his family's life. Funeral service will be held on Sunday, November 16 at 10am at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY. 1/3

FISHMAN--Abby, 83. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife Rita, of 64 years; his daughters, Iris and Heidi; his sons-in-law, Jay and Harold; his grandchildren, Jamie, Amber and Scott; his sister Sylvia; his sister-in-law, Minerva, and his niece and nephews, Ronda, Larry and Eddie. He deeply loved his family and will be sorely missed. 1/3
EISENBERG--Miriam, 88. "Mitzi" passed away on October 27 after a long illness. Beloved mother of Arlene, loving aunt to Barbara. Predeceased and adored by son, Lawrence, and husband, Sam. 1/3

DOAR--John. Princeton '44 mourns the loss on November 11th of our esteemed classmate John Doar whose life of extraordinary service above self was an inspiration to all. His civil rights involvement under Presidents Eisenhower and Kennedy was of great national import. Honored by President Obama with the Medal of Freedom, we were blessed by his friendship and devotion to us and to Princeton. We mourn with his family. 1/3

DIDDEL--Kathryn C.,93, died November 3, 2014. She is survived by her children, Glenn, Scott and Heather Diddel. Her husband Andrew Diddel and her daughter Katha Diddel Sussman predeceased her. Funeral Mass on November 21 at 10am, memorial tribute and reception at 12 noon, St. Mary's Church, Greenwich, CT. Donations may be made to the Katha Diddel and Warren Family Fund for Genome Research at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, at http:// mskcc.convio.net/goto/ KathaDiddel or by mail: Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Attn: India Laughlin, 633 3rd Ave, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017 1/3

diBELARDINO--Philip, a world-renowned wine expert, lecturer and spokesman and Specialist for Banfi Cru Artisan Wines, died peacefully, after a short illness, on Thursday, November 13 in New York City. Son of Constance Tempesta and Aldo DiBelardino, founder of Mediterranean Importing, Philip oversaw the reorganization of the family business into the fine wine division of Heublein, Inc. where he served for 15 years as Vice President. He was then brought to Banfi Inc. to oversee the education and marketing of their fine wines. He developed close relationships with many renowned Italian producers and led seminars, tastings and enoteca tours throughout the USA and Europe. He also held the Banfi Chair at Cornell University, in Ithaca, New York where he taught courses on Italian wines for their restaurateur degree program. Philip was an inductee into the Wines of Italy Hall of Fame. A graduate of Xavier High School in New York City, he held a B.A. from Boston College and a Masters in Theatre from Catholic University in Washington, D.C. Prior to his success in the wine business, Philip was a theatrical director, producer and entrepreneur, and his "Collector's Item" revue played nightclubs, resorts and cruises for several years. He was also a lifelong devotee of opera, theatre and the performing arts. He is survived by his brother and sister-in-law, Mario and Susan Belardino, two nephews David (Janine) and Adam (Michelle), and numerous cousins and extended family. In lieu of flowers, the family has suggested that contributions be made to Calvary Hospital, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, New York 10461. Attention Vincent Spinelli, Executive Vice President, Calvary Fund. Viewing will be on Sunday from 4-7pm and Monday from 2-4pm and 7- 9pm at the Frank E. Campbell (The Funeral Chapel) Madison Ave. at 81st. Street, New York City. There will be a private funeral on Tuesday. 1/3

DESHELL--Maier. Beloved uncle, brother, and friend, Maier Deshell passed peacefully at home on October 16th. Born in Winnipeg, Canada, March 1st, 1928 he attended the Jewish Theological Seminary and was a practicing Rabbi before a successful career as a magazine and book editor. Maier was the esteemed Editor of Jewish Publication Society (1974-1983), Associate Editor of Commentary Magazine (early 70s) and Editor of Congress Monthly (American Jewish Congress) from which he retired in 1998. Maier's masterful and sensitive translations from the Yiddish of Yehoshue Perle's "Everyday Jews" (2008) and Jacob Glatstein's "The Glatstein Chronicles (Homeward Bound)" (2010) earned him special acclaim. Maier was awarded The Leviant Memorial Prize (2011) for an "Outstanding Translation" of "Everyday Jews." He is survived by brother Sam Deshell (Winnipeg) and sister Alice Cooper (Chicago). "The Prince of Editors," our Precious Uncle and Friend will be missed. 1/3

COHEN--Beth Gold, 60, of Roslyn, NY, died Wednesday, November 12, 2014. Beth was born December 19, 1953, in Brooklyn, NY, and attended the State University of New York at New Paltz. She married Mark Cohen on November 11, 1984. Beth was a fashion entrepreneur and devoted mother of two. She developed a keen sense of style as a professional buyer with Macy's in the 1970s and 1980s, after which she began raising her daughters full time on Long Island. After her first bout with breast cancer in 2006, she designed and constructed a pair of shapewear leggings for herself while seeking fashionable yet comfortable clothes for recovery. With these leggings, she founded Lysse, a shapewear clothing company which grew to international success in the last years of her life. Beth was an active fundraiser for numerous charities, including The Children's Medical Fund of New York and the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. She was honored by the Sass Foundation for Medical Research with the Courage Award in 2011. Beth is survived by her husband, Mark Cohen, of Roslyn, NY; her daughters Jessica Benvenisty, of Brooklyn, NY, and Chelsey Cohen, of Roslyn, NY; her parents, Herman and Lois Gold, of Boynton Beach, FL; her sister, Amy Winters, of New York, NY. She was a beloved aunt to Rachel Winters and Ben Winters, and a beloved mother-in-law to Brian Benvenisty. Donations can be made in Beth's honor to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. 1/3

COHEN--Beth. It is with profound sadness that we mourn the passing of our dear friend and business associate. Our hearts and prayers go out to the entire Cohen family. Beth was a fighter, and a loyal, honest, and compassionate friend. We will all miss her. John Miller, Aries Worldwide Partners and all at the Asian Global Trading Corporation 1/3

COHEN--Beth Gold. Lysse fondly remembers its inspirational founder, Beth Gold Cohen, who created a remarkable womens fashion company by women and for women. Her unique vision created a new way of dressing where fit, fabric and fashion come together with innovation, so real women look great. She fought for a higher standard with custom fabrics, producing her designs first in New York where she founded her company. We are proud to carry on her legacy. 1/3

CLASTER--Jill. The NYU community mourns the loss of Jill Claster --distinguished scholar, teacher, mentor, and the first woman and alumna to serve as dean of NYU's College of Arts and Science. Beloved by her students, admired and respected by her colleagues, cherished by her friends, she was a prominent member of the generation of NYU faculty and administrators that --against all odds --transformed NYU. A model University citizen for decades, and a model of courage and dignity in her final days, she will be sorely missed. Her family and friends will be in the hearts of the NYU community, which loved Jill and shares their sense of loss. Martin Lipton, Chair, NYU Board of Trustees John Sexton, President, NYU Gabrielle Starr, Dean, NYU College of Arts and Science 1/3

BRESSLER--Josephine, on November 4, 2014 at the age of 90. Beloved wife of John for 28 years. Cherished Mother of John H. and Patricia, loving sister of Frances of New York and Joan of North Hollywood, California. Josephine was much involved in Fashion, she was the Fashion Editor for Sports Illustrated and was instrumental with the initial Swim Suite Issues. Josephine then went on to Look Magazine as a Fashion Editor until the end. She was also involved with Civitas on New York City as a secretary and Board Member. A memorial service will be held on Monday November 17th at 11am at the Brick Church of NYC. 1/3

BRESSLER--Jo Ahern. Board of CIVITAS mourns the loss of Jo Ahern Bressler, longtime Board member and Board Secretary from 1981-2012. A professional editor, Jo worked with August Heckscher and other founding members to shape the direction of CIVITAS and publish the Newsletters. We will miss her, her love of community, and her contributions to the success of CIVITAS. Funeral Service at Brick Church, 1140 Park Avenue, at 91st Street, on Monday, November 17 at 11am. 1/3

ATTARDI--Luigi (1952-2014). Luigi Attardi (pen name Nail Chiodo), of Rome, Italy, died on October 31, 2014, in Zurich. He was 62. A tireless defender of poetry, he will live on in his work and in the heart of those who loved him. A memorial service will be held on November 22 at 6.30 p.m. at the Church of Santa Maria in Portico in Campitelli in Rome, Italy. nailchiodo.com/about 1/3

ABRAMS--Jerome, MD, died peacefully after a distinguished career in Obstetrics and Gynecology in the Plainfields and Fanwood, NJ. Born in Plainfield to Leah Cantor Abrams and Hyman Abrams, he served as an Ensign in the Pacific during WWII. After graduating from Swarthmore, he obtained an MA in History from Columbia University and completed his MD and residency at Jefferson. He published numerous articles in the field of Ob-Gyn, was an associate editor of the New Jersey Medical Journal, and a Clinical Professor at Rutgers Medical School. Later in his career he obtained a Masters of Public Health from Rutgers University. Passionate about opera and history, in the early 1960's he was published in the Metropolitan Opera News. After retirement he was a frequent lecturer at Rutgers Institute for Lifelong Learning in the fields of History, Political Science and Medicine. A gentleman, scholar, and renaissance man, he was kind and loving to his wife Rosalyn Yaskin, his sons Alan (Cheryl) of Villanova, PA, Joseph (Marie) of Rye, NY, his grandchildren Harrison, Emilie, Thomas, and Jonathan, and his brother Hon. Herbert Abrams (Joan) of Brookline MA. Donations in his name to the Center for Hope Hospice of Scotch Plains, NJ or the Parkinson's Disease Foundation would be appreciated. 1/3

WHITE--Reverend Herbert DeRevere. Born March 6th, 1933 in Peekskill, NY of Irma Cecelia DeRevere and James Herbert Faber White. Died on October 19th, 2014. Survived by spouse - Jessica Cruzin Fernandez, two children - David Eric White and Susan White Moore, one grandchild - Zachary James Marine, his sister - Marie Bodin, and brother-in-law- Carl Bodin. Graduated Cum Laude from Maryville College in 1955, and from Union Theological Seminary in 1958. Served as Assistant Pastor at the Brown Memorial Presbyterian Church in Baltimore, MD, and as Pastor for the Covenant-Lebanon Presbyterian Church in Buffalo, NY. As Director of the Board for Urban Ministry in Rochester, NY, worked with Saul Alinsky in creating the Freedom, Integration, God, Honor Today (F.I.G.H.T.) organization. As Associate Director of the Institute on Urbanization (Yonsei University, Seoul, Korea) in 1968-70, he trained Koreans in community organization and contributed to the Democratization movement in that Nation. As Training Director of the Philippine Ecumenical Council for Community Organization (PECCO) in 1970-72, he organized the Zone One Tondo Organization. ZOTO effectively represented a squatter community of 250,000 in Manila. He served as Secretary for Citizen Organizing and Public Policy Development of the Board of Homeland Ministries, UCC; NY, NY in 1972-79, and 1982-88. As Co-Director of the Bombay Organizing Program of the Christian Institute for the Study of Religion and Society (CISRS), Bangalore, India in 1979-81, he co-organized the People's Responsible Organization of United Dharavi. He served as Associate Director (1995-99) Consultant (2000-05) of the Faith Action for Community Equity (FACE) in Honolulu, Hawaii.
VAUGHN--Wilson, C. 83, international banker with Citibank and Barclays, died Oct 23, 2014 in Black Mountain NC. Survived by daughter Anne W. Siddens, son David C. Wilson and three grandchildren.

SCHNEIDER--Robert C. November 6, 2014. 69 years young. Native New Yorker, acclaimed Bay Area chef, dog expert, talented artist, Aretha devotee, Binnie's dad, extraordinary friend. Rock steady, Robbie. You will be with us forever.

SCHNEIDER--Robert C. 69, November 6 in California. Survived by Nancy and David Schachnovsky, Amy, Peter, Mikey and Meadow Valerio and John, Carmen and Cole Schachnovsky. An acclaimed author, chef, artist. Contributions in his memory to The Redwood Coast Humane Society, PO Box 1072 Gualala, CA 95445-1072.

PEERCE--Lois Pearlman, devoted and cherished mother of Pamela Landis, treasured stepmother of Steven Peerce (and Wendy), Margie Peerce Fuerst (and Mark) and the late Carol Peerce, beloved Grandmother to Justin and Kelsey Landis, as well as Ben and Sarah Fuerst and Sam Peerce, lifelong best friend of Judy King and Jean Minskoff Grant, and beloved life partner of Chris Wiseman, died on November 14 after a valiant fight against lung disease. The beloved daughter of the late Sylvia and Nat Pearlman, Lois was an indefatigable presence dressed to the nines, and she blazed with all the charm, character, class and chutzpah of her beloved city of Manhattan. Born on October 18, 1943 Lois devoted the past twenty-plus years to helping other New Yorkers find their homes in the great city as an accomplished and award winning real estate broker with The Corcoran Group. Fiercely loyal to people and canines alike, Lois treated friends like family, treated canines like royalty, and treated family like gold. Friends may call Sunday, November 16th (3pm-7pm) at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Services will be held Monday morning, November 17th at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street. Contact Temple Emanu-El for further details. Donations may be made in her honor to the charities she loved: Bide-a-Wee Home Association of Long Island, The Joslin Diabetes Center and the American Cancer Society.

Moser--Marvin Dr. Marvin Moser, 90, died Thursday, November 13 at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital. He was a world leading expert in hypertension and a clinical professor at Yale Medical School. He leaves behind a loving family: his wife Joy, daughter, Jill (David), sons Stephen (Catherine) and John (Pamela) and his four granddaughters. Services will be held on Monday, November 17 at 9:45AM at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, NY.

CLASTER--Jill Nadell (Midonick) died Nov. 14 at home after a short illness. She was predeceased by her husband Judge Millard Midonick, daughter Elizabeth and brother Randolph Nadell. Scholar, teacher, author, friend, mentor, theatre and opera-lover, aspiring actress, wife, mother, sister, aunt, party-thrower, shoe-collector, world traveler, good neighbor, she will be missed by thousands. Jill was Professor Emerita of Medieval History at New York University and still teaching her course on Renewal and Expansion in Europe in the Twelfth Century until two weeks ago. Brooklyn born and raised, she received her BA and MA from NYU and a PhD from the University of Pennsylvania and taught at the University of Kentucky before coming to NYU in 1964. At NYU she served as dean of the College of Arts and Sciences from 1978 to 1986 and director of the Hagop Kevorkian Center of Near Eastern Studies from 1991 to 1997. Jill served on multiple boards and was a champion of the Elizabeth Claster Lower School Library at Friends Seminary. Funeral services will be at 10:00 AM Monday, November 17 at Riverside Memorial Chapel. A Memorial Service at NYU will be announced later. In lieu of flowers please consider donations to the Elizabeth Claster Library at Friends Seminary, 222 E.16th St., NY, NY 10003 or the Elizabeth Claster Memorial Scholarship Fund c/o Cynthia Young, NYU, 25 W. 4th St., NY, NY 10012.

SELLERS--Peter H. The Rockefeller University mourns the loss of our distinguished colleague and cherished friend Peter Sellers. A brilliant and pioneering mathematician whose research contributed significantly to the first computer search/ matching algorithm for DNA, Dr. Sellers joined the faculty of The Rockefeller University in 1966. Through more than four decades at the University, he conducted research at the intersection of mathematics and biology. During the 1970s and 1980s, work from the Sellers lab led to the development of BLAST, a widely used computerized DNA and protein database search program. Peter was a true Renaissance man, with a broad range of scientific and cultural interests and the rare ability to draw cogent connections across disciplines. With Lucy Bell, his beloved wife of nearly 60 years, Peter enriched the intellectual life of our campus community. Notably, he preserved and enhanced the University's Merrill W. Chase Historic Scientific Instrument Collection, of which he was curator. Beyond Rockefeller, Peter and Lucy Bell contributed to the cultural vibrancy of Mount Desert Island, Maine, where they summered and where they worked to protect the environment and the natural beauty of the coastline. A longtime trustee of the College of the Atlantic in Bar Harbor, Peter was also an accomplished sailor, who designed and built his own sailboat. In recognition of Peter's significant contributions to the biological sciences, the University has established a new lectureship in mathematics in his honor. We will miss Peter's unique blend of scientific brilliance, creativity, and personal warmth, and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to Lucy Bell; to Peter and Lucy Bell's children, Mortimer, Therese, Wanja, and Lucy Bell; and to the entire Sellers family. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair Russell L. Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus Sidney Strickland, Vice President for Educational Affairs Marcelo O. Magnasco, Professor Marnie Imhoff, Senior Vice President for Development 1/3

PEERCE--Lois (Pearlman). From our beginnings at the Pleasant Ridge School to forever, one another's friends confidantes and sisters in every way that matters. You, the embodiment of goodness and loyalty. You are never to be forgotten always to be loved. Irreplaceable. Judith Nadler King Jeannie Minskoff Grant 1/3
PALMER--Edna Leigh Dunn. May 23, 1917--November 8, 2014. In celebration a funeral will be held at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 11am, Wednesday, November 19, 2014. 1/3

MARTIN--Dorothy "Dotsy", beloved wife, mother and grandmother, died on November 13, 2014, after a courageous seven-year battle with Alzheimer's. Dorothy was the only child of Mary and William Martin. She met Buddy, her soul mate and husband of 62 years, at Evander Childs High School. Dorothy and Buddy were inseparable and an inspiration to all as a kind, loving, and deeply devoted couple. Everyone who met Dorothy loved her. Dorothy enjoyed golf, cards, knitting, travel, and the piano. She was a lifelong active volunteer for many charities. Most of all, Dorothy loved spending time with her family. Her family and countless friends admired her sense of humor, wit, intelligence, generosity, and extraordinary beauty inside and out. Dorothy is survived by her adoring husband, Buddy, and their four children Lynn (Mitchell), Steven (Edie), Jamie (Steven) and David, and grandchildren Raquel, Alexis, Alanna, Hank, Morgan and Mia. Dorothy will be greatly missed. Memorial contributions may be made to Alz.org/JudyFund or to the charity of your choice. 1/3

ACKIRON--Lowell, MD. On November 13, 2014, in Stamford, CT. Predeceased by his wife, Susan Ackiron. Loving father of Stephanie Benjamin and Evan Ackiron. Also survived by five loving grandchildren and Susan Joseph, his long time companion. Burial private. Memorials may be made in his memory to The Multiple Sclerosis Association: nationalmssociety.com 1/3

PEERCE--Lois Pearlman, devoted and cherished mother of Pamela Landis, treasured stepmother of Steven Peerce (and Wendy), Margie Peerce Fuerst (and Mark) and the late Carol Peerce, beloved Grandmother to Justin and Kelsey Landis, as well as Ben and Sarah Fuerst and Sam Peerce, lifelong best friend of Judy King and Jean Minskoff Grant, and beloved life partner of Chris Wiseman, died on November 14 after a valiant fight against lung disease. The beloved daughter of the late Sylvia and Nat Pearlman, Lois was an indefatigable presence dressed to the nines, and she blazed with all the charm, character, class and chutzpah of her beloved city of Manhattan. Born on October 18, 1943 Lois devoted the past twenty-plus years to helping other New Yorkers find their homes in the great city as an accomplished and award winning real estate broker with The Corcoran Group. Fiercely loyal to people and canines alike, Lois treated friends like family, treated canines like royalty, and treated family like gold. Friends may call Sunday, November 16th (3pm-7pm) at Frank E Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Services will be held Monday morning, November 17th at Temple Emanu-El, 5th Avenue at 65th Street. Contact Temple Emanu-El for further details. Donations may be made in her honor to the charities she loved: Bide-a-Wee Home Association of Long Island, The Joslin Diabetes Center and the American Cancer Society.
MOSER--Marvin M.D. Marv, the world was a safer and more rational place while you were in it. Thank you for 40 years of letting me think of myself as part of your wonderful family. Linda

MARTEL--Marilee, 83, Beloved wife of Leon, mother to Christopher and Jonathan, and grandmother to Cameron. A memorial service will be held in Low Memorial Library at Columbia University at 4pm, Sunday, November 23.

CLASTER--Jill Nadell (Midonick) died Nov. 14 at home after a short illness. She was predeceased by her husband Judge Millard Midonick, daughter Elizabeth and brother Randolph Nadell. Scholar, teacher, author, friend, mentor, theatre and opera-lover, aspiring actress, wife, mother, sister, aunt, party-thrower, shoe-collector, world traveler, good neighbor, she will be missed by thousands. Jill was Professor Emerita of Medieval History at New York University and still teaching her course on Renewal and Expansion in Europe in the Twelfth Century until two weeks ago. Brooklyn born and raised, she received her BA and MA from NYU and a PhD from the University of Pennsylvania and taught at the University of Kentucky before coming to NYU in 1964. At NYU she served as dean of the College of Arts and Sciences from 1978 to 1986 and director of the Hagop Kevorkian Center of Near Eastern Studies from 1991 to 1997. Jill served on multiple boards and was a champion of the Elizabeth Claster Lower School Library at Friends Seminary. Funeral services will be at 10:00 AM Monday, November 17 at Riverside Memorial Chapel. A Memorial Service at NYU will be announced later. In lieu of flowers please consider donations to the Elizabeth Claster Library at Friends Seminary, 222 E.16th St., NY, NY 10003 or the Elizabeth Claster Memorial Scholarship Fund c/o Cynthia Young, NYU, 25 W. 4th St., NY, NY 10012.

SELLERS--Peter H. The Rockefeller University mourns the loss of our distinguished colleague and cherished friend Peter Sellers. A brilliant and pioneering mathematician whose research contributed significantly to the first computer search/ matching algorithm for DNA, Dr. Sellers joined the faculty of The Rockefeller University in 1966. Through more than four decades at the University, he conducted research at the intersection of mathematics and biology. During the 1970s and 1980s, work from the Sellers lab led to the development of BLAST, a widely used computerized DNA and protein database search program. Peter was a true Renaissance man, with a broad range of scientific and cultural interests and the rare ability to draw cogent connections across disciplines. With Lucy Bell, his beloved wife of nearly 60 years, Peter enriched the intellectual life of our campus community. Notably, he preserved and enhanced the University's Merrill W. Chase Historic Scientific Instrument Collection, of which he was curator. Beyond Rockefeller, Peter and Lucy Bell contributed to the cultural vibrancy of Mount Desert Island, Maine, where they summered and where they worked to protect the environment and the natural beauty of the coastline. A longtime trustee of the College of the Atlantic in Bar Harbor, Peter was also an accomplished sailor, who designed and built his own sailboat. In recognition of Peter's significant contributions to the biological sciences, the University has established a new lectureship in mathematics in his honor. We will miss Peter's unique blend of scientific brilliance, creativity, and personal warmth, and we extend our heartfelt sympathy to Lucy Bell; to Peter and Lucy Bell's children, Mortimer, Therese, Wanja, and Lucy Bell; and to the entire Sellers family. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair Russell L. Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President Torsten N. Wiesel, President Emeritus Sidney Strickland, Vice President for Educational Affairs Marcelo O. Magnasco, Professor Marnie Imhoff, Senior Vice President for Development 1/3
