FARRELL--Vincent dePaul Jr.,age 68, of South Salem, formerly of Katonah, died Sunday, November 16, 2014, at home. He was born November 13, 1946, in Bronx, NY. Vincent was a founding partner at Spears, Benzak, Saloman & Farrell (SBSF), of New York City. SBSF was acquired by KeyCorp in 1995. He held various consultative positions at other firms. He was a regular guest on CNBC and Bloomberg Television. Before joining SBSF in 1982, Vincent was Vice President of Sales at Smith Barney, Inc. From 1969-1974, he taught history and coached football at Iona Preparatory School in New Rochelle, NY. Vincent graduated from Princeton University in 1969. Vincent is survived by his wife of 45 years, Clotilde Bove Farrell, four children: Vincent dePaul Farrell, III, Christopher Bove Farrell, Nina Clotilde Farrell, and Joseph Peter Farrell; daughters-in-law: Gretchen Farrell and Jillian Harris; two granddaughters: Lola Jane and Virginia; a sister: Patricia Farrell and a niece: Molly Savage. COHN--Alan David, 84. Alan D. Cohn passed away after a brief illness on November 17, 2014, in New York City. Born in Paterson, NJ on October 31, 1930 to Bertha and David Cohn, he graduated from Harvard College in 1951 and earned an MBA from the Harvard Business School in 1953. After receiving his MBA, he joined Wertheim & Co. where he worked for many years, becoming a managing director. Alan remained with the firm when it merged to become Wertheim Schroder, and again when Wertheim Schroder merged with Smith Barney, and when Smith Barney merged with Morgan Stanley. He was working as Senior Vice President at Morgan Stanley Smith Barney at the time of his death. An accomplished pianist, Alan was a lifelong enthusiast of jazz. A founding member and Treasurer of the Board of Directors and Chair of the Finance Committee, Alan helped to establish and sustain Jazz at Lincoln Center, receiving an award in honor of his exemplary leadership at its 25th anniversary celebration in 2012. Alan was also a founding member of the Board of Directors and member of the Investment Committee of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum. With his loving wife Betsy, Alan was generous in his support of the New York Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Opera, and many Democratic candidates for public office. For more than 50 years, he served as a Director of the Jewish Foundation for Education of Women. Alan is survived by his adoring wife, Betsy L. Cohn. He is also survived by his devoted brother George L. Cohn. He was predeceased by his loving first wife, Nancy D. Cohn. He was a loving father to daughter Deborah A. Cohn and her wife Charlotte J. Patterson, daughter Susan E. Cohn and her husband Jonathan D. Klein, and an adoring grandfather to Daniel and Amanda Klein, and Sarah, Elizabeth and David Cohn. Friends may call Wednesday, 5:30-7:30pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st St.). Services will be at 11am on Thursday, November 20th, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th St. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Jazz at Lincoln Center or to Harvard College. 1/3

PORTER--Dr. Robert, died October 14, age 95. Child and adolescent psychiatrist affiliated with New York's Mt. Sinai Hospital for more than 60 years. Wife Mary Kay died in 2006. He is survived by his sister, Betty Hussman and nephew, Mark Hussman, of Minden, NV. Highly respected and admired for his intellect, clinical skills, humanity and philanthropic activity, "Bob" is mourned by family, friends, former supervisees and colleagues. 1/3

LEBENTHAL--James A.,86, died November 14 in New York after suffering cardiac arrest. Father of Claudia, Alexandra and James B., father-in-law of Cheryl Lebenthal and Jeremy Diamond, grandfather of Avalon and James Lebenthal and Benjamin, Charlotte and Eleanor Diamond, husband of Betty Wright Landreth. He is predeceased by his first wife, Jacqueline Beymer Lebenthal. Jim was Chairman Emeritus of Lebenthal Holdings, LLC. A man of exceptional energy, talent, intellect and good humor, Jim turned tax-free municipal bonds into household words and the name Lebenthal into a landmark on the business skyline of New York City. Jim was a legendary Princeton Class Agent, and long-time trustee of the Museum of the City of New York. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St on Thursday, November 20 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm with the funeral on Friday, November 21 at 11:30am. Private interment. Contributions may be made to the Museum of the City of New York. 1/3

KALINOSKI--Jack C, October 31, 1941, died September 10, 2014, he is survived by sons Glenn and Kevin, his grandchildren Kathryn and Bryan and Carla Walker his long time companion. Memorial service, 5pm, Sunday, November 23, Thomas M. Quinn & Sons Funeral Home, Long Island City, New York. 1/3
KAHN --Jacqueline. Passed away November 17, 2014. Funeral arrangements are Thursday, November 20, 2014, at 1:00pm., at Mt. Lebanon Cemetery 7800 Myrtle Ave, Glendale, Ny 1/3

GIGLIO--A. Gino, died No vember 12, 2014 after a short illness with daughters Lisa and Nina by his side. Found ing member of SDC, member of ATPAM and Actors Studio, more than 35-year career as manager on Broadway and theater director. His second act included extensive work and research in alternative medicine. He will be missed. 1/3

FREED--Selma (Panoff), formerly of New York City, in her 100th year on Saturday, November 15, 2014. Wife of the late Irving Freed. Mother of Dr. Michael D. Freed of Brookline, MA and Dr. Howard A. Freed of Cambridge, NY. Adored grandmother of Jennifer, Joshua, Steven and Max and great grandmother of Sophia, Margaret, Eli, Jacob and Mia. Cherished daughter of the late Arthur & Mary (Fisher) Panoff. Dear sister of the late Henry Panoff, Edith Goldman and Fred Grill. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to a charity of your choice. 1/3
COREA--Camille. Our dear friend, we will miss you forever. Love, Cindi & Ben 1/3
COHN--Alan. We mourn the loss of a sweet sweet man and send heartfelt condolences to Betsy and all of the family. Love, Laura & Jim 1/3

COHN--Alan David, 84. Alan D. Cohn passed away after a brief illness on November 17, 2014, in New York City. Born in Paterson, NJ on October 31, 1930 to Bertha and David Cohn, he graduated from Harvard College in 1951 and earned an MBA from the Harvard Business School in 1953. After receiving his MBA, he joined Wertheim & Co. where he worked for many years, becoming a managing director. Alan remained with the firm when it merged to become Wertheim Schroder, and again when Wertheim Schroder merged with Smith Barney, and when Smith Barney merged with Morgan Stanley. He was working as Senior Vice President at Morgan Stanley Smith Barney at the time of his death. An accomplished pianist, Alan was a lifelong enthusiast of jazz. A founding member and Treasurer of the Board of Directors and Chair of the Finance Committee, Alan helped to establish and sustain Jazz at Lincoln Center, receiving an award in honor of his exemplary leadership at its 25th anniversary celebration in 2012. Alan was also a founding member of the Board of Directors and member of the Investment Committee of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum. With his loving wife Betsy, Alan was generous in his support of the New York Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Opera, and many Democratic candidates for public office. For more than 50 years, he served as a Director of the Jewish Foundation for Education of Women. Alan is survived by his adoring wife, Betsy L. Cohn. He is also survived by his devoted brother George L. Cohn. He was predeceased by his loving first wife, Nancy D. Cohn. He was a loving father to daughter Deborah A. Cohn and her wife Charlotte J. Patterson, daughter Susan E. Cohn and her husband Jonathan D. Klein, and an adoring grandfather to Daniel and Amanda Klein, and Sarah, Elizabeth and David Cohn. Friends may call Wednesday, 5:30-7:30pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st St.). Services will be at 11am on Thursday, November 20th, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th St. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Jazz at Lincoln Center or to Harvard College. 1/3
WILSON--C. Vaughn. 83, international banker with Citibank and Barclays, died Oct 23, 2014 in Black Mountain NC. Survived by daughter Anne W. Siddens, son David C. Wilson and three grandchildren.
RICH--Gordon A. Nov. 8, 1957 - Nov. 19, 2000 We love and miss you - yesterday, today and tomorrow. Mom and Dad

TWOMEY--Tom. We mourn the loss of our founding Treasurer, Tom Twomey. The Eleanor Roosevelt Legacy Committee was fortunate to have the gift of Tom's intellect, enthusiasm, and friendship. Across New York, women are running for office and finding their voice as leaders because of what Tom made possible. The cause endures, but he will be missed. Our condolences to Judith Hope, his wife and our founder, and to all of Tom's family and friends. The Board of Directors, Eleanor Roosevelt Legacy Committee Hon. Harriet Cornell, Chair

TWOMEY--Thomas A.,Jr. The Board and Staff of the East Hampton Library deeply mourn the untimely passing of our beloved Board Chairman, Thomas A. Twomey Jr. and extend our condolences to his wife, Judith and the family. We will miss his cheerful disposition and his love of learning which he wished for all to share. His warmth, imagination and exemplary clearheaded leadership will have lasting value, serving as a cornerstone for the years ahead.

RACINE--Paulette, peacefully at home on November 15, 2014. Beloved mother of Djenane Racine Duhaney, Rachel Racine Keyo, and Ernst Racine Jr. Devoted grandmother of Ariane, Alexis and Ashley, Alanna, Justin, Elijah and Eremi. Visitation Thursday, November 20, 2-9pm and Funeral service Friday, November 21, 2014, 11:30am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., NYC. Contributions in her memory to www.pih.org/country/haiti would be appreciated.

O'CONNOR--Nancy Fields. December 13, 1929 November 10, 2014. Artist, author, activist, humanitarian, philanthropist and documentary film producer Nancy Fields O'Connor, 84, wife of the legendary actor Carroll O'Connor and instrumental in every aspect of his career, died Monday, November 10, 2014 of complications from Alzheimer's Disease in her Malibu home. Of full Native American heritage from Montana's Crow Indian Tribe, Mrs. O'Connor developed a celebrated exhibition and catalog of her grandfather Fred E. Miller's historic collection of over 600 photographs of the Crow Indian Tribe from 1895-1920. The Fred E. Miller Collection is currently on loan to the Great Plains Museum at the University of Nebraska. Mrs. O'Connor is also the author of Fred E. Miller: Photographer of the Crows (Carnan Vidfilm; 1985) and was executive producer of the 2007 documentary Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer. Mrs. O'Connor was a founding member and long-time supporter of the John Wayne Cancer Institute at Providence St. John's Hospital, Santa Monica, CA. She was also a member of the Board of Trustees of The Actors Fund of America and a member of the Board of Directors for the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of the American Indian. She was also involved with the South Central Los Angeles charity Neighbors of Watts. Mrs. O'Connor was a donor, a member of the Board of Trustees and a member of University of Montana's Fine Arts Advisory Committee and instrumental in the construction of the UM's PAR-TV Center. UM's Center for the Rocky Mountain West was renamed The Carroll and Nancy O'Connor Center for the Rocky Mountain West in recognition of The O'Connor's long-time support and contributions. Born December 13, 1929 in Spokane, WA, Nancy O'Connor is predeceased by husband Carroll O'Connor (1925-2001); son, Hugh O'Connor (1962-1995); and nephew, Jeffery Fields. Survivors include: Angela O'Connor (daughter-in-law); Sean O'Connor (grandson); John and Jo Ann Fields (brother and sister-in-law); Mary Reynolds (cousin) and eleven nieces and nephews: Matthew O'Connor; Deirdre O'Connor; David O'Connor; Elyse O'Connor; Leigh O'Connor; Ann Fields; Matthew Fields; David Fields; Christopher Geller; Jeffrey Geller and Gregory Geller. A Roman Catholic funeral service will be held on Saturday, November 22 at 11:00am at Our Lady of Malibu Church, Malibu, CA. Burial arrangements are pending. In lieu of flowers, a tax-deductible contribution can be made to the following charitable organizations: Melanoma Research, John Wayne Cancer Institute, c/o Providence St. John's Hospital, 2121 Santa Monica Blvd. Santa Monica, CA 90404; The Actors Fund of America, 729 Seventh Avenue, NY, 10019; The Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian, Washington, DC.

MOSER--Dr. Marvin, Third Avenue Management and the Third Avenue Funds mourn the loss of the Funds' esteemed Trustee and cherished friend, Dr. Marvin Moser. Dr. Moser's 17 years of service to our Funds was exemplified by his passion and commitment. He was an active participant in board meetings and his insights were always appreciated. He found board service to be rewarding, and highlighted his experience with our board in a book he published last year entitled "Memoirs of a Very Lucky Guy." Given Dr. Moser's extensive experience as a leading world expert in hypertension and a clinical professor at Yale Medical School, he was instrumental in assisting members of Third Avenue's research team on healthcare related companies, and was always very gracious with his time. It was an honor to have worked with him and we will miss his wisdom, both professionally and personally. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Joy and the entire Moser family. Third Avenue Management and Third Avenue Funds

MILLMAN--Lillian. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Lillian Millman. Lillian leaves behind a loving family who will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Lillian's children, Paul (Tres) and Janet Bienenfeld (Jeff); her grandchildren; her great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

LIDZ--Richard Ira, 81, of Princeton, NJ, passed away peacefully at his home on November 17, 2014. Son of the late Samuel Lidz and Adelaide Baruth Lidz, brother of the late Dr. Doris Lidz Hirsch. Survived by his wife Celia Ussak Lidz, three sons Douglas Lidz (Jane Brown); David Gray (Kyra Gray); Stephen Lidz (Christine Anderson). Adoring grandfather of Anderson, Samantha, Joseph, Ariadne and Cameron. Predeceased by first wife Clara Lidz. He was a graduate of The Darrow School, and Johns Hopkins University. Founder and President, Visual Education Corporation, educational, and reference publisher, Princeton, NJ. Large of heart and generous of spirit; lover of fine foods and fast foods, Mozart, Bach, folk art, folk music, fine books and printing, adventurous travel. Ardent civil libertarian. Services Wednesday, 2pm, at Orland's Ewing Memorial Chapel, 1534 Pennington Road, Ewing, NJ.

KRAMER--Dr. Jeffrey, died peacefully after a long illness. A psychiatrist in private practice for over 40 years, he touched the lives of many. His family and friends remember his smile and his uncanny ability to make connections. He is survived by his wife Esther and his son Tom. A Memorial Service to celebrate his life will take place at a later date.

HYMAN--Morton. Greater New York Hospital Association (GNYHA) mourns the passing of Morton Hyman, the longtime Board Chairman of Beth Israel Medical Center and Continuum Health Partners, and Vice Chairman of the Mount Sinai Health System. He was also a former Chairman of the New York State Public Health Council. A true giant among hospital trustees, Mr. Hyman's decades of service were marked by his leadership, intelligence, compassion, and selfless generosity. He cared deeply about New York's hospital community and the health of his fellow New Yorkers. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Chris, son David, daughter Sarah and son-in-law Andy, grandchildren Henry and Zoe, and his many friends and colleagues. Louis Shapiro, Chairman Kenneth E. Raske, President GNYHA

HYMAN--Morton. We note with sorrow the passing of our member Morton Hyman and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl and President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

HYMAN--Morton P. The Writing Revolution expresses its deepest sympathy to the family of Morton P. Hyman, our devoted President and Chairman. He will leave a substantial void in our organization and will be truly missed by all who knew him. His leadership has impacted thousands of students and his legacy will live on in them. Judith C. Hochman, Founder

HYMAN--Morton. Mort was the guiding force behind Beth Israel Medical Center and Continuum Health Partners and the emergence of many clinical centers for excellence. He was a transformational leader who was committed and unwavering in his goal to provide exceptional healthcare to those in need. He was highly respected and admired by all. I thank him for the unique opportunity to be part of the Head and Neck Institute at Beth Israel. We will always treasure our friendship with Mort and Chris and we extend our heartfelt condolences to Chris and their entire family. Mark and Georgia Persky
HYMAN--Morton P. Our dear and treasured friend for over 60 years. Our family will miss your forever. Judy and Steve Hochman
HYMAN--Morton P. We will always miss our great and true friend Mort. With love, Jill and Howard Sharfstein and Family

HYMAN--Morton P. A lifelong friend who leaves a legacy of decency, philanthropy, professional excellence and compassion. He excelled at so much, but at the top for us was being a great friend: generous in all ways, a skilled story teller, a co-conspirator in playful pranks. We will miss you Mort and are so grateful for you enriching our lives. Our love to the Hyman family who mattered to him above all else. Roz and Stanley, Ariana and Bill, Melissa and Andrew The Komaroffs

HYMAN--Morton P. For almost 40 years, a wonderful friend and inspired and inspiring colleague, totally committed to the hospitals he led and to their patients and staff and the communities they serve. To Chris and the entire family, and to all who loved and admired him, our deepest sympathy. Bob and Seiko Newman

HYMAN--Morton P. The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of Morton P. Hyman, an extraordinary philanthropist and a senior vice chairman of the Mount Sinai Boards of Trustees. Mort supported our hospitals with enthusiasm and distinction for more than 40 years, serving as founding chairman emeritus of Continuum Health Partners for its first 10 years; chairman, board of trustees, Beth Israel Medical Center for 22 years; chairman, board of trustees, St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center; vice chairman, board of directors, New York Eye and Ear Infirmary; and, most recently, as a member of the executive committee and chair of the government affairs committee at the Mount Sinai Health System. Mort and his wife Chris Stern generously supported important initiatives throughout the system, including the Hyman-Newman Institute for Neurology and Neurosurgery at Mount Sinai St. Luke's; the Chris and Morton P. Hyman Patient Care Unit at Mount Sinai Beth Israel; and the Morton and Chris Hyman Operating Room in the Surgical Suite and the Chris and Morton Hyman Audiology Examination Room at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary at Mount Sinai. We are grateful for his leadership, guidance, and commitment. He will be dearly remembered by all, and we extend our deepest condolences to Chris and the entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Steven Hochberg, Senior Vice Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., CEO and President; Dennis S. Charney, M.D., Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System

HYMAN--Morton P. With profound sadness the family of Morton P. Hyman advises of his death on Monday, November 17, 2014 at age 78, following a brief illness and with his beloved family at his side. A loving husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, and devoted friend and colleague to so many, Mort inspired all with his zest for life, his commitment to public service and his generous philanthropy. He will be sorely missed. Mort had an illustrious career in the shipping industry and was deeply involved in many philanthropic organizations. He served as President (1971-1999), President and CEO (1999-2003), and Chairman of the Board of Directors (2000-2003) of Overseas Shipholding Group, Inc. Mort also held the position of Vice Chairman of Discount Bank and Trust Co. Ltd., one of the largest privately owned Swiss banks, and was President of its affiliated investment companies until his retirement in 2003, at which time he founded MPH Enterprises, LLC, a private equity investor. Dedicated to many worthy philanthropic organizations, Mort served as Chairman of the Sabin Institute, Vice Chairman of the Mount Sinai Health System and was a former trustee of The Brearley School. He was the Chairman of the Board of Continuum Heatlh Partners and Beth Israel Medical Center for many years. He served as the Chairman of the New York State Public Health Council from 1985 to 1995. He is survived by his adoring family: his devoted wife of 35 years, Chris Stern Hyman, his son, David, his daughter Sarah, son-in-law Andy Washkowitz and their children, Henry and Zoe Washkowitz, and many beloved friends. We are all devastated by this loss. A funeral service will be held on Thursday, November 20, at 10am at Central Synagogue at 652 Lexington Avenue at 55th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Sabin Vaccine Institute or the Mount Sinai Health System.

HEALY--Philomena R. (nee Silvestri). On October 28, 2014. Of Costa Mesa, CA, formerly of Forest Hills, NY. Retired bookkeeper. Loving wife of Edward (previously deceased). Loved and loving mother of Dennis, Michael, and Rosemary. Loved and loving grandmother of Brett, Andrew, Meredith, Daniel, Benjamin, and Claudia. Loved and loving great grandmother of Isabella. Loved and loving sibling of Anna and Pasquale. Reposing Fox Funeral Home, Forest Hills, NY, Friday, November 21, 5-9. Funeral Mass Our Lady Queen of Martyrs RC Church, Saturday, November 22, at 10:30am. She was much loved in life and will be missed greatly. In lieu of flowers, please donate to a charity of your choice.

FUNT--Evelyn M.,died in New York City on November 15, 2014, at age 94. Beloved mother of Peter, Patricia and John. Adored grandmother of Stephanie, Danny, Katie and Anna. Cherished mother-in-law of Amy Funt, Ken Oxman and Richard Childs. She lived a full life, dedicated to education, environment, progressive politics and, above all, family. Contributions in her memory to Alice Austen House, Staten Island, NY, would be welcomed.

COHN--Alan D. The Atlantic Golf Club mourns the passing of member and friend, Alan D. Cohn. We extend our sincere condolences and heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Betsy, his children, Deborah and Susan and their families. Dennis A. Suskind, President Harvey L. Radler, Vice President

COHN--Alan D. The playwrights, board and staff of New Dramatists mourn the death of Alan D. Cohn. We offer our loving support to Betsy, longtime member of our Board, and to the entire Cohn family. Over the years, Alan and Betsy's support of New Dramatists helped lift our roof when it threatened to come down, and provided an exquisite upright piano, which enabled scores of playwrights and composers to make beautiful music together. We will deeply miss Alan's incredible intelligence, his calm, steady kindness, and his generous spirit as a stalwart supporter of the performing arts and his community at large.

COHN--Alan D. We shed tears that our dear friend Alan D. Cohn has left us, but we also celebrate the memory of the wonderful life he lived of music, accomplishment, and great love for his precious wife Betsy, and his family. We will always cherish the special times we shared--here and abroad. Fredrica and Stephen Friedman Adriana and Robert Mnuchin

COHN--Alan D. The Board and staff of Lincoln Center Theater are deeply saddened by Alan's death. We extend our warmest sympathy to his beloved wife Betsy, our dear friend and Patron Committee Member, and to his entire family. J. Tomilson Hill, Chairman Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director

COHN--Alan D. It is with great sadness that we say goodbye to a beloved member of our Board of Directors, Alan Cohn. Alan was a founding member of Jazz at Lincoln Center's Board of Directors, formed in 1996 when the organization became a constituent of Lincoln Center. He served as Treasurer of the Board, Chair of the Finance Committee, and on the Investment and Audit Committees, bringing rigor and integrity to everything he did. Alan was deeply dedicated to the development of Jazz at Lincoln Center. He had an unshakeable belief in uplifting people through the power of music. As a piano man himself, the music ran through his heart and soul. Together with his beautiful wife, Betsy, he was indefatigable. Alan enriched all our lives and the music. Our thoughts and prayers are with Alan's family, friends and colleagues. Robert J. Appel, Chairman Gordon J. Davis, Founding Chairman Lisa Schiff, Chairman Emeritus Wynton Marsalis, Managing and Artistic Director Greg Scholl, Executive Director Jazz at Lincoln Center Board, Orchestra and Staff

COHN--Alan. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Alan Cohn, beloved husband of Betsy Cohn. ELMALEH--Victor. Concert Artists Guild mourns the loss of Trustee, leader, philanthropist, and visionary Victor Elmaleh. Mr. Elmaleh was a champion of the arts and made an enormous difference to the lives of many young musicians. His life is a lasting inspiration to us all. Our deep condolences to his wife Sono Osato, his sons Niko and Antonio and all members of the Elmaleh family. Richard S. Weinert, President 1/3

COLCHAMIRO--Oscar passed away peacefully with his family by his side. He owned Nancy Manufacturing Co. with his brother, Jesse. Later, he, with Muriel, his beloved wife of 55 years, owned Sandman Originals making beautiful children's pajamas. As a member of the US Army Signal Corps, he rose to the highest enlisted rank and received the Bronze Star while serving in China during WWII. He enjoyed painting and sculpting and those who were lucky recipients of such enjoyed them equally. He leaves his daughters, Joan Smart (Roy Langhamer), Pearl Pappas (son-in-law, Walter), four grandchildren, Julia Visgauss (husband Mikolas), Jason Smart, Jane Pappas and Emmeline Pappas as well as countless nieces and nephews. He embraced life and accepted this final phase gracefully, although he was sad to leave his long time, loving companion, Jean Kurnit. Donations can be made, in his memory, to Kehila Kedosha Janina Synagogue and Museum, 280 Broome Street, NY, NY 10002 where a celebration of his life will take place. He will be missed. 1

COHN--Alan David, 84. Alan D. Cohn passed away after a brief illness on November 17, 2014, in New York City. Born in Paterson, NJ on October 31, 1930 to Bertha and David Cohn, he graduated from Harvard College in 1951 and earned an MBA from the Harvard Business School in 1953. After receiving his MBA, he joined Wertheim & Co. where he worked for many years, becoming a managing director. Alan remained with the firm when it merged to become Wertheim Schroder, and again when Wertheim Schroder merged with Smith Barney, and when Smith Barney merged with Morgan Stanley. He was working as Senior Vice President at Morgan Stanley Smith Barney at the time of his death. An accomplished pianist, Alan was a lifelong enthusiast of jazz. A founding member and Treasurer of the Board of Directors and Chair of the Finance Committee, Alan helped to establish and sustain Jazz at Lincoln Center, receiving an award in honor of his exemplary leadership at its 25th anniversary celebration in 2012. Alan was also a founding member of the Board of Directors and member of the Investment Committee of the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum. With his loving wife Betsy, Alan was generous in his support of the New York Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Opera, and many Democratic candidates for public office. For more than 50 years, he served as a Director of the Jewish Foundation for Education of Women. Alan is survived by his adoring wife, Betsy L. Cohn. He is also survived by his devoted brother George L. Cohn. He was predeceased by his loving first wife, Nancy D. Cohn. He was a loving father to daughter Deborah A. Cohn and her wife Charlotte J. Patterson, daughter Susan E. Cohn and her husband Jonathan D. Klein, and an adoring grandfather to Daniel and Amanda Klein, and Sarah, Elizabeth and David Cohn. Friends may call Wednesday, 5:30-7:30pm, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue (at 81st St.). Services will be at 11am on Thursday, November 20th, at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th St. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to Jazz at Lincoln Center or to Harvard College. 1/3

YORK--Hon. Louis. We are saddened by the loss of our esteemed colleague. His commitment to justice is an example for all. He will be greatly missed. Board of Justices New York County

TWOMEY--Tom. We mourn the loss of our founding Treasurer, Tom Twomey. The Eleanor Roosevelt Legacy Committee was fortunate to have the gift of Tom's intellect, enthusiasm, and friendship. Across New York, women are running for office and finding their voice as leaders because of what Tom made possible. The cause endures, but he will be missed. Our condolences to Judith Hope, his wife and our founder, and to all of Tom's family and friends. The Board of Directors, Eleanor Roosevelt Legacy Committee Hon. Harriet Cornell, Chair

TWERSKY--Rabbi Moshe. SAR joins the Jewish community in mourning the tragic loss of Rabbi Moshe Twersky, brother of our own Tzipporah (and Rabbi Jonathan Rosenblatt). May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jack Bendheim, President

SESSLER--Scott Howard, of Huntington Bay, NY passed away peacefully Wednesday morning November 19th at the age of 57. He was born on July 1st 1957, the son of Anita and Robert Sessler. Scott met his wife Andrea at summer camp at the age of 14. He graduated John Marshall Law School in 1982 and moved back to New York where he practiced law until starting his own firm. In 2007, he started a new venture, Lawfund Capital Group. Scott is remembered by his loved ones for his zest for life and his unmatched spirit on the tennis court. He is survived by his sons Ryan and Jordan; his wife Andrea; and his brother Lee and sister-in-law Madeline. All are welcome to come celebrate Scott's life on Friday November 21st at 10:00am at Gutterman's in Woodbury, Long Island. The ceremony will be led by Rabbi Jonathan Rosenblatt. Shiva will be held at the Sessler family home at 2 Fleetwood Drive, Huntington Bay NY 11743 till sundown on Friday, after sundown on Saturday, and from 12:00pm on, Sunday.

RUBIN--Milton. 94, died November 13, 2014. Born in Brooklyn, March 17, 1920 to Rose and Joe Rubin. He served as a teacher and technical sergeant-radar observer (radar bombardier) in the Army Air Force from December 26, 1941 to September 3, 1945 in New Guinea. Milton was Master Mason, Victoria Lea Gate Lodge No. 1037 from June 14, 1948 to now. A founding father of Temple Hillel In North Woodmere and President of the Men's Club 1969. He graduated NYU Law School and had a distinguished career in international maritime law. He was General Counsel to Argo International. He is survived by his loving wife, Marilyn Rubin of Tamarac, FL, his children Beverly Ehrlich and husband Steve of Manhattan, NY, Martin Rubin and his partner William, of Dallas, TX his grandchildren Nicole Ehrlich and her wife Rosa of Beverly Hills, CA, Justin Ehrlich and his wife Nicole of Manhattan, NY and four great-grandchildren, Jonas, Zach, Max and Gavin. His love and wisdom will be forever in our hearts. Donations to The American Heart Association.

ROSENTHAL--Lillian, Beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, deeply cherished by her extended family and friends. She has been our rock, always there to offer unfailing kindness and devotion. She joins her beloved husband Lawrence, the love of her life. We will love and miss her forever.

MAXWELL--Phyllis Lee Kirsh, passed away on Tuesday, November 18, 2014 at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mrs. Maxwell was born on January 12, 1926 and passed at the age of 88. Mrs. Maxwell was the essence of resilience and reinvention. She married post war to her husband Herbert Maxwell and their union existed for 58 years until her husband's death in 2006. She always found a way to meet her family's needs. In 1991 she founded Phyllis Maxwell's Groups and ran the business until shortly before her death. She was a major force in the sale of Broadway product to clients throughout the nation. She loved her job. She was a woman of power and courage and reckless love. She survived her loving husband Herbert and is survived by her children Richard, Mitchell and Victoria and by her four grandchildren Zachary, Tia, Charlotte and Skyler. The power of our hearts will be dim tonight in memory of her passing. Funeral service at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave. (at 91st St) on Friday, November 21st at 9:30am.

KRAMER--Dr. Jeffrey, died peacefully after a long illness. A psychiatrist in private practice for over 40 years, he touched the lives of many. His family and friends remember his smile and his uncanny ability to make connections. He is survived by his wife Esther and his son Tom. A Memorial Service to celebrate his life will take place at a later date.

HYMAN--Morton. Mort was the guiding force behind Beth Israel Medical Center and Continuum Health Partners and the emergence of many clinical centers for excellence. He was a transformational leader who was committed and unwavering in his goal to provide exceptional healthcare to those in need. He was highly respected and admired by all. I thank him for the unique opportunity to be part of the Head and Neck Institute at Beth Israel. We will always treasure our friendship with Mort and Chris and we extend our heartfelt condolences to Chris and their entire family. Mark and Georgia Persky
HYMAN--Morton P. We will always miss our great and true friend Mort. With love, Jill and Howard Sharfstein and Family

HYMAN--Morton P. A lifelong friend who leaves a legacy of decency, philanthropy, professional excellence and compassion. He excelled at so much, but at the top for us was being a great friend: generous in all ways, a skilled story teller, a co-conspirator in playful pranks. We will miss you Mort and are so grateful for you enriching our lives. Our love to the Hyman family who mattered to him above all else. Roz and Stanley, Ariana and Bill, Melissa and Andrew The Komaroffs

HYMAN--Morton P. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Morton P. Hyman, longtime supporter of UJA-Federation and distinguished chairman of Beth Israel Medical Health Center and its successor, Continuum Health Partners, for many years. Morton leaves behind a loving family to carry on his legacy of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Morton's wife, Chris Stern Hyman; his children, David and Sara (Andy Washkowitz); his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

HYMAN--Morton P. The New York Academy of Medicine community mourns the passing of Mort Hyman, a NYAM Trustee from 2005-2012, Fellow for 26 years, and invaluable supporter deeply committed to the improvement of public health and health care in NYC, NYS and worldwide. We will miss his intelligence, sparkling wit, his warmth and friendship. We send our condolences to Mr. Hyman's family. Jo Ivey Boufford, MD, President George Thibault, MD, Chairman

HYMAN--Morton P. With profound sadness the family of Morton P. Hyman advises of his death on Monday, November 17, 2014 at age 78, following a brief illness and with his beloved family at his side. A loving husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, and devoted friend and colleague to so many, Mort inspired all with his zest for life, his commitment to public service and his generous philanthropy. He will be sorely missed. Mort had an illustrious career in the shipping industry and was deeply involved in many philanthropic organizations. He served as President (1971-1999), President and CEO (1999-2003), and Chairman of the Board of Directors (2000-2003) of Overseas Shipholding Group, Inc. Mort also held the position of Vice Chairman of Discount Bank and Trust Co. Ltd., one of the largest privately owned Swiss banks, and was President of its affiliated investment companies until his retirement in 2003, at which time he founded MPH Enterprises, LLC, a private equity investor. Dedicated to many worthy philanthropic organizations, Mort served as Chairman of the Sabin Institute, Vice Chairman of the Mount Sinai Health System and was a former trustee of The Brearley School. He was the Chairman of the Board of Continuum Heatlh Partners and Beth Israel Medical Center for many years. He served as the Chairman of the New York State Public Health Council from 1985 to 1995. He is survived by his adoring family: his devoted wife of 35 years, Chris Stern Hyman, his son, David, his daughter Sarah, son-in-law Andy Washkowitz and their children, Henry and Zoe Washkowitz, and many beloved friends. We are all devastated by this loss. A funeral service will be held on Thursday, November 20, at 10am at Central Synagogue at 652 Lexington Avenue at 55th Street. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests donations to the Sabin Vaccine Institute or the Mount Sinai Health System.

FUNT--Evelyn M.,died in New York City on November 15, 2014, at age 94. Beloved mother of Peter, Patricia and John. Adored grandmother of Stephanie, Danny, Katie and Anna. Cherished mother-in-law of Amy Funt, Ken Oxman and Richard Childs. She lived a full life, dedicated to education, environment, progressive politics and, above all, family. Contributions in her memory to Alice Austen House, Staten Island, NY, would be welcomed.

COHN--Alan D. Jewish Foundation for Education of Women mourns the loss of Alan D. Cohn. A model of integrity and courtliness, Alan was a cherished Director for 50 years and will be missed terribly. Our condolences to his wife, Betsy, daughters Deborah and Susan, their spouses Charlotte and Jonathan, and his grandchildren. Phyllis G. Korff, President; Elizabeth L. Kraiem, Executive Director

COHN--Alan D. The Hamilton Partnership for Paterson mourns the loss of Alan D. Cohn, who helped launch the new Paterson Great Falls National Park to improve the quality of life in his hometown and honor our city's role in the history of the nation. Leonard A. Zax, President Martin Vergara II, Chairman

BURES--Jean (Harazin), of West Islip, in her 81st year, on Tuesday, November 18, 2014. AARONS--Samuel. The Coplans and Rubels will greatly miss Sam, a most special man. Sincerest sympathy to Pearl and the family.
STUART--James. You live in our hearts forever. All our love, your family. 1/3

ZIMAND--Harvey Folks. Harvey Folks Zimand, passed away on November 10, 2014 peacefully at his home in New York City. He was 86. He was born in NYC and attended Friends Seminary, graduated from Colgate University, received a master's degree in political science at the University of Chicago, and his law degree from Yale University. After law school, he joined Kelley Drye & Warren where he became a partner and specialized as a trusts and estates attorney for over 50 years. He was selected as one of The Best Lawyers in America in the Trusts & Estates and Litigation for over twenty years. He was a lifelong resident of New York City and spent many summers with his family in Randolph, New Hampshire, where he loved to hike and was a member of the Randolph Hiking Club. Mr. Zimand is survived by his two daughters, Patty Carpenter and Stephanie Plexico, his four grandchildren and his stepsons Chris Manfre and Mark Manfre and their two sons. Funeral services will be held on Saturday November 22, 2014 at 1:30pm at Frank E Campbell, The Funeral Chapel. 1/3

TONN--Bernard, on November 17, 2014 of Manhasset, New York, Age 83. Beloved husband of Ann. Loving father of Ronni Sternfeld and Sharon Navre. Cherished grandfather of Amy, Emily, Risa, Melanie and adored great-grandfather of Max. Dear brother of Gloria. Devout Philadelphia Eagles and Boston Bruins fan. 1/3

ROTHSCHILD--Naomi, nee Bloom, died peacefully on Sunday, November 16, 2014 in her home in Englewood, NJ, with her family at her side. Throughout her 94 years, Naomi devoted herself energetically and selflessly to the betterment of others. She is survived by her son Michael, her daughters-in-law Alison and Jennifer, her grandchildren Adrian, Dylan and Madeleine, as well as many, many nieces, nephews, cousins and other relatives, who considered her the matriarch of this extended family. Services Friday 11:15am at The Riverside 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. See more at naomirothschild.com. 1/3

PRENTICE--Mimi Walters, dancer, singer, actress and loving wife, passed away on November 16th in New York City. First dancing professionally at the age of three or four, Ms. Prentice performed on Broadway in "Annie Get Your Gun," and toured with Guy Lombardo and his band. She also acted in television commercials and appeared in Bonanza. In 1968 she became the first woman Account-Executive at the Wilding Firm in New York City, where she worked for two years. Then she met and married the love of her life, the late Spelman Prentice, a grandson of John D. Rockefeller. She is survived by five step-children, sixteen step- grandchildren, and twenty two great-grandchildren. She was a private, perceptive, loyal, feisty, and loving woman with a great deal of presence. She will be missed. A memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 81st Street and Madison Ave on Friday, November 21st at 11am. Donations can be made in in her memory to The Intercollegiate Studies Institute. 1/3

LEDERMAN--Gary 80 years old, died on November 17, 2014. Devoted husband of Elaine. Beloved father of Ricki, Wendy and Beth and father-in-law of Mark and Billy. Cherished grandfather of Melissa, Rachel, Jamie, Joshua and Izabella. 1/3

LATHAM--George Ritchie Jr.,on November 15, Orient. Born East Williston, February 27, 1918, to George and Elizabeth Edward Latham. ZIMAND--Harvey Folks. Harvey Folks Zimand, passed away on November 10, 2014 peacefully at his home in New York City. He was 86. He was born in NYC and attended Friends Seminary, graduated from Colgate University, received a master's degree in political science at the University of Chicago, and his law degree from Yale University. After law school, he joined Kelley Drye & Warren where he became a partner and specialized as a trusts and estates attorney for over 50 years. He was selected as one of The Best Lawyers in America in the Trusts & Estates and Litigation for over twenty years. He was a lifelong resident of New York City and spent many summers with his family in Randolph, New Hampshire, where he loved to hike and was a member of the Randolph Hiking Club. Mr. Zimand is survived by his two daughters, Patty Carpenter and Stephanie Plexico, his four grandchildren and his stepsons Chris Manfre and Mark Manfre and their two sons. Funeral services will be held on Saturday November 22, 2014 at 1:30pm at Frank E Campbell, The Funeral Chapel. 1/3

PRENTICE--Mimi Walters, dancer, singer, actress and loving wife, passed away on November 16th in New York City. First dancing professionally at the age of three or four, Ms. Prentice performed on Broadway in "Annie Get Your Gun," and toured with Guy Lombardo and his band. She also acted in television commercials and appeared in Bonanza. In 1968 she became the first woman Account-Executive at the Wilding Firm in New York City, where she worked for two years. Then she met and married the love of her life, the late Spelman Prentice, a grandson of John D. Rockefeller. She is survived by five step-children, sixteen step- grandchildren, and twenty two great-grandchildren. She was a private, perceptive, loyal, feisty, and loving woman with a great deal of presence. She will be missed. A memorial service will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 81st Street and Madison Ave on Friday, November 21st at 11am. Donations can be made in in her memory to The Intercollegiate Studies Institute. 1/3

KAHN--Abraham. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Abraham Kahn and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl and President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

HYMAN--Morton. The Trustees and staff of the Sabin Vaccine Institute mourn the loss of our friend and colleague, Morton P. Hyman, Chairman of the Institute since 2008 and a Trustee since 2007. Mr. Hyman, age 78, died peacefully on Monday, November 17, in New York City with his family by his side. He is survived by his loving wife of 35 years, Chris Stern Hyman; his son, David; his daughter, Sarah; and son- in-law, Andy; and, his grandchildren, Zoe and Henry. We at Sabin owe a tremendous debt of gratitude to Mr. Hyman for his visionary contributions. He was a tower of strength and energy who provided unparalleled leadership, driven by a deep passion for improving public health. Under his leadership, Sabin enjoyed tremendous growth including new long- term collaborations with Houston's Texas Children's Hospital and Baylor College of Medicine. These led to the creation of a new Center for Vaccine Development, greatly expanding our vaccine development portfolio, and the founding of the National School of Tropical Medicine. Constantly looking for ways to expand Sabin's impact, Mr. Hyman was also instrumental in establishing our sister organization in London, England, Sabin Foundation Europe, for which he also served as Chairman. In addition to his many other philanthropic pursuits supporting public health improvements, Mr. Hyman was an ardent champion for the development of the first vaccine for schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease that plagues 250 million people, led by the Sabin Vaccine Institute Product Development Partnership. Thanks to Mr. Hyman's support, that vaccine candidate currently is entering clinical trials. The Sabin team will strive to repay our debt of gratitude to Mr. Hyman by ensuring that his legacies not only endure, but as rapidly as possible fulfill his hopes of the widespread reduction of needless suffering by the neglected and underserved populations around the world. The Hyman family has asked friends and admirers interested in honoring Mr. Hyman to donate to the Sabin Vaccine Institute or Mount Sinai Health System. Philip K. Russell, M.D. Past Chairman Michael W. Marine Chief Executive Officer Peter J. Hotez, M.D. President 1/3

O'CONNOR--Nancy Fields. December 13, 1929 November 10, 2014. Artist, author, activist, humanitarian, philanthropist and documentary film producer Nancy Fields O'Connor, 84, wife of the legendary actor Carroll O'Connor and instrumental in every aspect of his career, died Monday, November 10, 2014 of complications from Alzheimer's Disease in her Malibu home. Of full Native American heritage from Montana's Crow Indian Tribe, Mrs. O'Connor developed a celebrated exhibition and catalog of her grandfather Fred E. Miller's historic collection of over 600 photographs of the Crow Indian Tribe from 1895-1920. The Fred E. Miller Collection is currently on loan to the Great Plains Museum at the University of Nebraska. Mrs. O'Connor is also the author of Fred E. Miller: Photographer of the Crows (Carnan Vidfilm; 1985) and was executive producer of the 2007 documentary Anita O'Day: The Life of a Jazz Singer. Mrs. O'Connor was a founding member and long-time supporter of the John Wayne Cancer Institute at Providence St. John's Hospital, Santa Monica, CA. She was also a member of the Board of Trustees of The Actors Fund of America and a member of the Board of Directors for the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of the American Indian. She was also involved with the South Central Los Angeles charity Neighbors of Watts. Mrs. O'Connor was a donor, a member of the Board of Trustees and a member of University of Montana's Fine Arts Advisory Committee and instrumental in the construction of the UM's PAR-TV Center. UM's Center for the Rocky Mountain West was renamed The Carroll and Nancy O'Connor Center for the Rocky Mountain West in recognition of The O'Connor's long-time support and contributions. Born December 13, 1929 in Spokane, WA, Nancy O'Connor is predeceased by husband Carroll O'Connor (1925-2001); son, Hugh O'Connor (1962-1995); and nephew, Jeffery Fields. Survivors include: Angela O'Connor (daughter-in-law); Sean O'Connor (grandson); John and Jo Ann Fields (brother and sister-in-law); Mary Reynolds (cousin) and eleven nieces and nephews: Matthew O'Connor; Deirdre O'Connor; David O'Connor; Elyse O'Connor; Leigh O'Connor; Ann Fields; Matthew Fields; David Fields; Christopher Geller; Jeffrey Geller and Gregory Geller. A Roman Catholic funeral service will be held on Saturday, November 22 at 11:00am at Our Lady of Malibu Church, Malibu, CA. Burial arrangements are pending. In lieu of flowers, a tax-deductible contribution can be made to the following charitable organizations: Melanoma Research, John Wayne Cancer Institute, c/o Providence St. John's Hospital, 2121 Santa Monica Blvd. Santa Monica, CA 90404; The Actors Fund of America, 729 Seventh Avenue, NY, 10019; The Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian, Washington, DC.

GREGORY--Mamie Spears Reynolds, Born to United States Senator Robert Rice Reynolds and Evalyn Washington McLean Reynolds on October 15 1942 in Washington, DC, passed on the morning of Saturday November 15 2014 in Louisville, KY. Mamie was the granddaughter of Evalyn Walsh McLean known as the last personal owner of the legendary Hope Diamond and Goddaughter to J. Edgar Hoover and Federal Justice Frank Murphy. Mrs. Gregory had been well-known in the social circles of our nation's Capital, Palm Beach and Asheville, NC and was a member of the Daughters Of The American Revolution. She was also an award winning member of the American Kennel Club where she handled and owned many award winning breeds. As a young woman Mamie was owner and driver for the Reynolds Racing Team of Asheville, NC and she became the first woman to qualify for the Daytona 500. Along with dogs and racing, Mamie was involved in and had successful lines of Miniature Horses Dairy and Pygmy goats. In the late 1960's Mamie and her husband Joseph were the first owners of the ABA Kentucky Colonels. She loved traveling with a passion having been around the world seven times in her lifetime. Mamie has touched the lives and hearts of many and will be truly missed. She is survived by her loving husband Joseph E. Gregory, daughter Evalyn Reynolds Gregory Strange and husband Joshua Strange son Joseph C Gregory and partner Charles Rapp and two special fur babies Snugs and Bibbs. The family is making private arrangements and will gratefully appreciate commemorative donations to the Kentuckiana Humane Society or the Arrow Fund.

MORGENLANDER--Dr. Howard L. Urologist -loving and devoted husband, father and grandfather, passed away this Tuesday, November 18, 2014. His loss is immeasurable to all who knew and loved him. Graveside service will be held at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY, Sunday, November 23, 2014 at 2:30pm. 1/3

DANIELS--Valery F. We honor Valery Daniels, beloved woman and artist, who died November 16, 2014, age 59, encircled by family and friends. She succumbed to a rare cancer after three brave, hard years. Valery was a sculptor, with an MFA from Yale where she won the Tallix Fellowship and Wheedon Award. As an art therapist, she brought deep creativity and compassion to her work at Bellevue Hospital. Mourned by her daughters Annamariah and Claudia, her dear husband Andrew Knox, mother Mary Daniels, sister Leslie, and cherished family and friends. Her valor, originality, and kindness stay with us. 1/3

PASH--Joseph John, Sr.,died in New York City at the age of 93 on November 20. Born in Hampton, Minnesota and raised on a farm, he left at 18 to pursue his education earning a BA from the University of Southern California and a Master's Degree in Economics from the University of California at Berkley. He then traveled east in pursuit of a NYC advertising career working for Doherty, Clifford, Steers & Shenfield, and Needham Harper & Steers responsible for major consumer product advertising campaigns such as Mueller's "It Doesn't Get Lost in The Sauce" and the introduction of one of the first "tight" products on the market for Hellman's. He also played for the agency's softball team as its #

OZIMEK--Richard T.,85, formerly of Rye, NY and Ponte Vedra Beach, Florida died peacefully at his home in Warren, NJ on November 20. Born in Newark, NJ to the late Mary and Peter Ozimek, he graduated from Rutgers University with a bachelor of science in Chemistry. He served as a captain in the air force during the Korean War. He was president of the Ozimek Data Corporation, a management consulting firm in Rye, NY. After retirement, Richard enjoyed playing golf, tennis, following financial markets and spending time with family. Richard is survived by his loving wife of 52 years, Phyllis Blake, and two daughters Kimberley Vessa and husband Paul of Bernardsville, NJ and Elizabeth Crowley and husband Charlie of Ridgewood, NJ. He had seven grandchildren Blake, Taylor, Michael, Claire Colin, Edie, and Ian who will miss him dearly. There will be a memorial service in Rye, NY in the spring.

But for the many farmworkers who have no family here, their status will remain the same.

While there are a significant number of unauthorized workers in this area, much of the focus has been on legal, temporary workers. San Francisco and San Jose are among the top areas that request H-1B visas for highly skilled workers, and the president’s plan disappointed the tech community by not increasing the cap on the number of H-1Bs issued. The plan does help fill science and technology jobs by expanding a program that allows foreign students to remain in the country temporarily for training.

TEICHER--Henry. In loving memory of Henry Teicher who sadly passed on November 12, 2014 at the age of 92. He was the cherished husband of 52 years to Anne Teicher. An incredible role model and father to daughter Rikke Cumberbatch. A formidable chess opponent to son- in-law Glen. A loving pop pop and music teacher to grandson Duncan. An inspiration and teacher to granddaughter Taliah. Henry Teicher received his Ph.D. in statistics from Columbia University in 1950, served in professorial positions at Purdue University until 1967, and joined Rutgers Statistics Department as Professor in 1968. He had been a pillar of the department before his retirement at 1993, and continued to be admired for his outstanding scholarship. His wide recognition led to visiting appointments at Stanford, Columbia, New York University and the University of Perugia. His classic book with Y.S. Chow on probability theory educated generations of graduate students. He was elected fellow of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics in recognition of his seminal research in mathematical statistics and probability. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

STANTON--Gordon Rentschler Died on October 29, 2014 at the age of 55, after a long battle with pulmonary fibrosis. Beloved son of Phoebe R. Stanton and Louis L. Stanton (Berit). He leaves behind his wife Catherine (Kitty), their sons Niles and Henry, his brother Lee (Beth), his sister Susan Benedict (Rod), and half- brother Fredrik. He graduated from The Buckley School, St. Pauls School, Yale, and the NYU Stern School of Business. Gordon was a real estate broker with Brown Harris Stevens. He was a member of the Blue Hill Troupe, The Amateur Comedy Club, Holland Lodge No. 8, and served on the board of The Interfaith Center of New York. Gordon was a devoted father whose greatest joys were spending time with family and friends and his strong commitment to service to others. He will be greatly missed. Memorial Service at St. James Church, Madison Avenue and 71st Street on Monday, November 24, 2014 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Blue Hill Troupe Fund at P. O. Box 286800, Yorkville Station, New York, NY 10128. 1

SCHEIDE--William H. The Council of the Grolier Club is deeply saddened to learn of the death of fellow member and former Councilor William H. Scheide on November 14. A Grolier member since 1951, Scheide rendered distinguished service to the Grolier Club during his term as a Councilor (1976 to 1985), and as a member of our Library Committee, giving generously of his broad knowledge of books and book people, to the Club's great and lasting benefit. In recognition of that service he was created an Honorary Member of the Grolier Club in 1989. We extend our sympathy to his family, and to his many friends and colleagues at the Grolier Club, and in the world of books at large. G. Scott Clemons, President, The Grolier Club 1/3

SALTZMAN--Harriett, 87, died peacefully at home in NYC on November 17, 2014. She was the wife of Howard B. Saltzman, daughter of Eli and Esse Dubrowin and sister of Barbara Prothers. She is survived by her three daughters Donna, Robin and Jane, her sons-in-law Larry Bell and Bob Spaulding, and her grandson Jason. She will be sorely missed by everyone who was privileged to call her a friend, and remembered forever by the original art, drawings and sculptures she left behind. 1/3

PEABODY--Julian. Peabody, Julian Livingston "Pete" died peacefully at the Vintage Coventry in San Francisco on November 16th, 2014, two months after celebrating his 100th birthday. Born August 25, 1914, to Julian L. and Celestine Hitchcock Peabody of Westbury, New York, he was the quintessential gentleman. He graduated from Groton School in 1933, Princeton University in 1937, and Columbia Law School in 1940. Julian practiced law with LeBoeuf, Lamb, Leiby in New York City until 1978 and then pursued his profession in San Francisco until his "retirement," going into the office daily until he was 99 years old. His career was put on hold for two years while he served in the United States Navy from 1943-1945. He married Celia Robinson in 1937 and lived in Huntington, New York. Subsequently he married Grace 'Bo' Willis of New York in 1968 and they moved to San Francisco in 1978. After 'Bo' died in 1990, Julian married Constance Crowley of San Francisco, who survives him. Also surviving him are his sister Daphne Murray of, Hamden, Connecticut; his children Patricia Davies of Ketchum, Idaho, and Julian L. Peabody, Jr. of San Diego; his two grandchildren, Matthew Davies of Missoula, Montana, and Jennifer Davies of Ennis, Montana; and three great- grandchildren, Ellawynn and Zane Morrison, and Sidney Livingston Davies. Aiken, SC, was an important part of Julian's life from childhood. He visited there often and loved to share his stories of his times in Aiken. In 2005 he published a memoir of his grandmother, Louise Hitchcock. Memorial contributions can be made to the Hitchcock Woods Foundation, Box 1702, Aiken, SC, 29802. He will be missed. 1/3

OSTERWEIL--Elaine K.,90, formerly of New York, NY, entered into eternal peace on Thursday, November 20, 2014 at Loomis Lakeside at Reeds Landing in Springfield, MA. The daughter of the late Alfred and Rita (Jacobus) Kuhn, Elaine was born and raised in New York where she lived most of her life. She graduated from both Hunter High School and Hunter College where she made friendships that lasted her lifetime. Elaine was employed as a high school math teacher at Brooklyn Technical High School for 50 years; was a Group Advisor, and was Chairman of the Program Committee. She adored her students, especially the class of 1966. She was widowed by her late husband David Osterweil whom she had been married to for 55 wonderful years and was the love of her life. Elaine enjoyed going to the theater and traveling to Europe and the Caribbean. Her family brought her so much joy and pride. She is survived by her loving daughter Karen Walker and her devoted husband Alan of Somers, CT; her adoring granddaughters, Stephanie Leo and her husband Jaxon of Chicago, IL, and Michelle Walker of New York, NY. Services will be private and held at the convenience of the family. Donations in Elaine's memory, may be made to Loomis Communities designated for Assisted Living Activities at Loomis Lakeside at Reeds Landing, 246 North Main St., South Hadley, MA 01075. Somers Funeral Home is entrusted with the services. To leave online condolences, please visit: somersfuneralhome.com 1/3

OAKES--Margery Hartman, age 98, died peacefully on November 20 at her home in New York City. Born in West Hartford, CT., she was the daughter of Estelle Stein Hartman and Emanuel M. Hartman, a pioneer in the shade-grown tobacco industry in the Connecticut Valley. She graduated in 1938 from Bryn Mawr College. During World War II, she was a writer and editor at the Office of War Information. After the War, she wrote book reviews for the New York Times Sunday Book Review. Part of the burgeoning New York art scene, she worked with the Museum of Modern Art and the League of Women Voters. In the 1950s, she became deeply involved in public education, and remained so for the rest of her life. She first became a board member of the Public Education Association, and then one of the founding members of the New York City School Volunteer Program, now known as Learning Leaders. In 1955, New York State Governor Averell Harriman appointed her a delegate to the New York State Conference on Education. In 1958, Mayor Robert F. Wagner appointed her to the Commission on Vocational Education. In 1986, Mayor Edward I. Koch awarded her a Citation of Merit for her "leadership and commitment to the School Volunteer Program." From 1945 until his death in 2001, she was married to John B. Oakes, former editor of the editorial page of the New York Times. She was a longtime member of the Cosmopolitan Club of New York. She is survived by her children, Andra N. Oakes, of Washington, DC.; Alison H. Oakes, of Glencoe, IL; Cynthia J. Oakes of London; John G. H. Oakes of New York City; and eight grandchildren. A service for immediate family will be held on November 25th at 9:30am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street; a memorial service will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Learning Leaders of New York. 1/3
O'CONNOR--Nancy Fields. Most gracious, loving and gifted friend. Forever in our hearts. Edward and Carol Dudley Katzka 1/3

Dziedzic (deceased), and devoted grandfather of David F., Luke A. and Charlie R. Dziedzic. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue (81st Street). A Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Tuesday, November 25 at 10:00am at St. Monica Church, 413 East 79th Street.
