LIDZ--Richard I. Devoted friend and fellow Hopkins alumnus. He created an innovative packaging- publishing house (VEC) that served as the source for projects in the El-Hi field, distributed by America's major publishers. His success culminated in VEC's 2001 sale to McGraw Hill affording Celia and Richard a decade of world-wide travel. He was the best. Alvin & Davida 1/3

HYMAN--Morton. The Trustees and staff of the Sabin Vaccine Institute mourn the loss of our friend and colleague, Morton P. Hyman, Chairman of the Institute since 2008 and a Trustee since 2007. Mr. Hyman, age 78, died peacefully on Monday, November 17, in New York City with his family by his side. He is survived by his loving wife of 35 years, Chris Stern Hyman; his son, David; his daughter, Sarah; and son- in-law, Andy; and, his grandchildren, Zoe and Henry. We at Sabin owe a tremendous debt of gratitude to Mr. Hyman for his visionary contributions. He was a tower of strength and energy who provided unparalleled leadership, driven by a deep passion for improving public health. Under his leadership, Sabin enjoyed tremendous growth including new long- term collaborations with Houston's Texas Children's Hospital and Baylor College of Medicine. These led to the creation of a new Center for Vaccine Development, greatly expanding our vaccine development portfolio, and the founding of the National School of Tropical Medicine. Constantly looking for ways to expand Sabin's impact, Mr. Hyman was also instrumental in establishing our sister organization in London, England, Sabin Foundation Europe, for which he also served as Chairman. In addition to his many other philanthropic pursuits supporting public health improvements, Mr. Hyman was an ardent champion for the development of the first vaccine for schistosomiasis, a parasitic disease that plagues 250 million people, led by the Sabin Vaccine Institute Product Development Partnership. Thanks to Mr. Hyman's support, that vaccine candidate currently is entering clinical trials. The Sabin team will strive to repay our debt of gratitude to Mr. Hyman by ensuring that his legacies not only endure, but as rapidly as possible fulfill his hopes of the widespread reduction of needless suffering by the neglected and underserved populations around the world. The Hyman family has asked friends and admirers interested in honoring Mr. Hyman to donate to the Sabin Vaccine Institute or Mount Sinai Health System. Philip K. Russell, M.D. Past Chairman Michael W. Marine Chief Executive Officer Peter J. Hotez, M.D. President 1/3

HYMAN--Morton. We mourn the passing of our dear, dear friend, Mort Hyman. A champion of all things good, Mort has left an indelible mark on the many lives that he touched through his philanthropic focus and commitment to family, friends, and colleagues. Our sincere condolences to his beloved family -Chris, Sarah, and David -and countless friends. The Washkowitz Family and Emily & Adam Tarkan 1/3

HIRSCHSON--Albert Martin of New York, NY on November 22, 2014. Born in Brooklyn, NY on April 16, 1936, Al was a successful businessman who enjoyed life in Manhattan. Loving husband of Linda Hirschson. Devoted father of his son and daughter-in-law Jay Hirschson and Nicole Schaffer and his daughter and son- in-law Pamela and Sean Neville. Adoring grandfather of Caitlyn Neville, Lillian Hirschson and Nathan Hirschson. Services to be held on Monday, November 24 at 2pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023. 1/3

HARTLEY--Raymond, OAM, pianist/songwriter, died pea- cefully November 15, 2014 in NYC at 89. Member of the Musicians Union Local 802, and ASCAP. Survived by sisters Shirley Shaw and Thelma Glynn, and their families in Australia. A memorial is planned for March 2015. halcyonee@aol.com 1/3

GRIFFIN--John Barry. Peaceably passed away in his sleep on Sunday, November 9th in Palm City, FL at age 90. He was born on April 23, 1924, in Birmingham, Warwickshire, England to John Anthony Griffin and Hilda Vizetelly. Mr. Griffin voluntarily enlisted in the Royal Air Force on the day he was old enough to join and was part of the Greatest Generation that fought World War II. He served during the Allied Forces invasion of Normandy and was frequently involved in air-to-air combat as he flew night missions in Lancaster bombers. He was a courageous, patriotic man who had an unwavering sense of right and wrong. He met his wife, the late Dr. Alice V. Griffin, while she was studying at Stratford-upon-Avon and he was working nearby as an air traffic controller. A mutual love of Shakespeare brought them together and became a shared passion for the rest of their lives. The couple married in 1952 at City Hall in New York City and soon thereafter began their radio show, "Sidewalk Critics Review," where they would broadcast live reviews after the openings of new plays and musicals on Broadway. He took on the roles of homemaker, community volunteer and soccer organizer as his wife's career accelerated. Mr. Griffin loved soccer, and in the late 1960s was an early organizing force behind the Westchester Youth Soccer League, now one of the nation's largest with over 20,000 registered players. He trained other fathers to become coaches and recruited referees from a pool of new Americans. Mr. Griffin fulfilled a lifelong dream in 1998 when he attended the World Cup final, witnessing France's victory over Brazil. Mr. Griffin is best remembered as witty, humble and proud of a life well-lived. He is survived by his son, John A., and his wife Amy Griffin of New York City, and his four grandchildren. 1/3

GALES--Joyce Linda, 75, on November 8 in New York. Beloved mother of Pamela Kellerman Fox (George) and Elyssa Kellerman. Predeceased by her adoring son Peter R. Kellerman on September 11, 2001. Also survived by six loving grandsons Max, William and Charles Dickstein and Aaron, Matthew and Benjamin Fox and by her brother Robert Steinberg (Muriel). She filled our lives with grace, kindness and love and will live in our hearts forever. 1/3
FURTH--Ruth L. (nee Fischer), died November 16. Predeceased by husband Frank. Survived by daughters Katharine and Suzanne (Jon). 1/3

FREILICH-COHEN--Estelle passed away peacefully on October 24, 2014 after a brave and valiant struggle. Survived by her beloved husband Alan, children Nancy and Steven, twelve grandchildren and twenty-seven great-grandchildren, she led an exemplary life-listener to all and the arbiter of good taste. As Director of Hillside Hospital Family Treatment Program for many years, Estelle provided a haven for those seeking guidance and insight with caring and concern for all. She was also an active and integral member of the North Shore Towers community and will be sorely missed. Her insight, elegance, and joy will be forever remembered by her family and friends, particularly her adoring grandchildren and great-grandchildren. 1

ELMALEH--Victor. The staff and board of the Sports & Arts in Schools Foundation extend condolences to our board member Niko Elmaleh and to the Elmaleh family on the passing of Victor Elmaleh. Victor, a former board member and longtime supporter of SASF, was himself a successful businessman, champion athlete and versatile artist who helped to bring sports and arts education to the children of New York City. The breadth of Victor Elmaleh's interests and accomplishments inspire the Foundation's work in bringing after- school programs to the 25,000 children who participate in SASF's after-school programs. Sports & Arts in Schools Foundation 1/3

DOLCH--Sylvia, 105, beloved wife and mother, devoted grandmother, cherished great-grandmother, aunt, great-aunt, sister, and cousin of all degrees and removes, loved and admired by all her family and friends, passed away Friday night after a rich and full life. Rock of our family, she was an unfailing supporter, cheerleader, letter writer and correspondent throughout her life. Her house was the center of innumerable family gatherings, holiday dinners, and visits by all who knew and loved her: the warmth of those memories will last for all our days. She was blessed with great spirit and an unflagging mind, both strong and sharp until the very end. She was also blessed with devoted family and friends who visited often and were always in touch, and doubly blessed with her devoted sons, who cherished and safeguarded her in her final years. All of us who were loved and cherished by her, are in turn, blessed as well. She will be missed, but she will always be in our hearts. She is survived by her sons Howard and Norman; her daughters-in-law Sylvia and Ada; her grandchildren Peter, Robin, Lauren and Amy; and her great-grandchildren Daniel, Milo, Emmett, Jesse and Jacob. Services: today, Sunday, November 23rd, 11:15am at "The Riverside" Amsterdam Avenue and 76 Street. 1/3

DANIELS--Valery F. We honor Valery Daniels, beloved woman and artist, who died November 16, 2014, age 59, encircled by family and friends. She succumbed to a rare cancer after three brave, hard years. Valery was a sculptor, with an MFA from Yale where she won the Tallix Fellowship and Wheedon Award. As an art therapist, she brought deep creativity and compassion to her work at Bellevue Hospital. Mourned by her daughters Annamariah and Claudia, her dear husband Andrew Knox, mother Mary Daniels, sister Leslie, and cherished family and friends. Her valor, originality, and kindness stay with us. 1/3

CHANG--Helen Chung-Hung (Hsiang), 77, of Appleton, WI, on November 12. Helen was born in Shanghai at the dawn of the Second Sino-Japanese War. After moving to Taiwan, she attended and was the valedictorian of her class at Taipei First Girls' High School. She then emigrated to the United States and received a BA from Mount Mercy University in English and psychology, with coursework at Columbia University, and a BA from Lawrence University Conservatory of Music in piano pedagogy. She was also a certified teacher of the Suzuki Method. Together with her husband Nai Lin and their young family, Helen lived and worked in New York City before moving to Appleton, where she maintained a private piano studio until 2014. Helen was a member of the Music Teachers National Association, the Wisconsin Music Teachers Association and the Suzuki Association of the Americas. During her 42 year career, Helen taught and was devoted to hundreds of students, many of whom earned musical distinctions and several of whom have also gone on to have careers in music. Helen is predeceased by her parents, Cheng-Tze Kiang and Edward Hsiang. She is survived by her husband Nai Lin Chang; her daughters Tai Chang Terry (F. Davis Terry, Jr.), Dr. Huan Justina Chang (Robert Stauffer), Lan Samantha Chang (Robert Caputo) and Dr. Ling Patricia Chang (Joseph Finnin); her grandchildren Rick, Will and Alden Terry, Sophia and Justin Stauffer and Antonia Caputo; and her brothers Harry C. Hsiang (Nancy) and Henry C. Hsiang (Gladys). Her daughters especially will miss her for her drive and determination, wisdom, and sense of humor, as well as her high standards. A Memorial will be held on Sunday, December 7 at 3:30 pm in the Pusey Room, Warch Campus Center, Lawrence University, 711 East Boldt Way, Appleton, WI. For more information, please contact hchang3@uic.edu. 1/3

CARRO--Melvin J, passed away on November 20, 2014 in Scottsdale, AZ. He was born in Revere, MA on January 12, 1923 to Ruth and Leon Carro. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Carol Racoosin Carro, his son Richard S. Carro, daughter-in-law Laura and granddaughters Sabrina Evelyn and Amanda Rose. He was predeceased by his first wife, Evelyn Katz Carro. He is also survived by first cousins Joan Vernick, Barbara VonSchlicht and Audrey Heckler, and nieces and nephews Robert Seid, Andrew Seid, Elizabeth Seid Silber, Kathy Seid-Eriksson, Mitchell and Kathy Racoosin and Tom and Robyn Racoosin Bernitt. Funeral services at Mt. Sinai Cemetery, Scottsdale, on Monday, November 24 at 11am. The family asks that those interested in honoring the memory of Mel Carro consider a donation to the Harvard College Fund, Boston, MA. 1/3

AVERSA KIERSZENBAUM-- Gina, 74. Beloved by her daughter Samantha Berg; son-in-law Steve Berg; grandson Nathaniel Berg; niece Heidi Wein. A great listener, she was compassionate, generous and kind. A firm believer in education she was proud of her University of Maine, M.A. and her status as a Bronx High School of Science alum. Donations in her memory may be made to The Bronx High School of Science, www.bxscience.edu. "And yet a spirit still and bright with something of angelic light." Wordsworth 1/3

WEINSTOCK--Eugene V. Eugene (Gene) V. Weinstock, June 5, 1927-October 8, 2014, age 87, formerly of Brookhaven, New York, died October 8th, 2014, in Lexington, Massachusetts. Gene was born June 5th, 1927 in New York City, the second son of Leon and Rose Weinstock. He graduated from Atlantic City High School, NJ (1945), served one year in the US Navy, and then studied physics at Princeton University (BS, 1950). Gene and Beverly Lucas married in December of 1950. Gene taught for a year at the University of Puerto Rico in Mayaguez, while completing his graduate studies in physics at the University of Pennsylvania (PhD, 1956). Gene was then offered a position at Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, New York, where he worked for the rest of his 36-year career (1956-92), first with the Experimental Reactor Physics Division, and later with the Technical Support Organization for Nuclear Safeguards. From 1989-1991, Gene and Beverly lived in Vienna, Austria, where Gene was assigned to the International Safeguards Project Office and served as liaison officer to the United Nation's International Atomic Energy Agency headquarters. Gene was an expert on the safeguarding of nuclear materials to prevent their diversion from peaceful to non-peaceful uses, and had letters to the New York Times published on this and other topics. In 2005 Gene and Beverly moved to Brookhaven at Lexington, a continuing care retirement community in Lexington, Massachusetts, to be closer to family. Gene's life enthusiasms included playing tennis; listening to classical music; and eating dark chocolate. He enjoyed great literature and read the New York Times every day. Gene's lively, sardonic wit was often expressed in his clear and careful writing. He appreciated intellectual argument, especially reasoned discussion of the tradeoffs associated with peace-time uses of nuclear energy. Gene was pre- deceased by his brother Melvin in 1984. In addition to his wife Beverly, Gene is survived by three children and their spouses as well as nine grandchildren: Deborah Weinstock-Savoy and spouse Robert Savoy of Gloucester, MA, and their children Katherine, Rebecca, and Nathaniel; Judith Weinstock of Medford, MA; and Daniel Weinstock and spouse Karin Weinstock of Napa, CA and their children Isobel, Thomas, Ciera, Liam, Bridie, and Eamonn. See legacy.com for guestbook.

STEPHENSON--Vivian died Friday, November 14, 2014 after a prolonged battle with cancer. She is survived by her wife, Margarita Gandia, a great source of support during their 39-year relationship. She is also survived by Marta and Randal Dieringer (sister and brother-in-law), Carol and T. Ross Stock (niece and nephew) and their three children Daniel, Asher and Loren, as well as Lynn Theile, Whitney Bain and Meredith Francis (cousins). Vivian was born in Havana, Cuba on November 27, 1936 to an American father and Cuban mother. She earned her B.A. in mathematics from New York University and an M.B.A. from the University of Havana. Her professional resume includes serving as Chief Operating Officer for Williams Sonoma Inc., as well as Executive Vice President and Chief Information Officer for Target Corporation. Vivian chaired the Board of Directors of AAA Northern California, Nevada and Utah, and served on the Board of Directors of CarMax Inc. Vivian served as Chair of the Board of the San Francisco AIDS Foundation and on the Pangea Global AIDS Foundation. She was honored by the Academy of Friends for her volunteerism in the fight against HIV/AIDS. She was an honorary trustee of Mills College, having chaired its Board of Trustees from 2000-2009. In 2005, Mills College awarded her an honorary doctor of humane letters. Vivian was also a sculptor and photographer and had a great love of opera. She served on the Board of the San Francisco Opera Association where she was committed to a wide range of efforts to extend opera out to the broadest possible audience. A pioneer in her professional life, an advocate and visionary in her non-profit volunteer engagements, with incredible spirit, tenacity and commitment to social justice, Vivian carried herself with an elegance that was both disarming and powerful. Mentor, friend, colleague, she will be sorely missed. A memorial service will be held Sunday, December 14 at 3:00 PM in San Francisco at the Julia Morgan Ballroom, 465 California Street, 16th floor. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the National AIDS Memorial Grove, http://www.aidsmemorial.org/ or the Clearity Foundation for ovarian cancer research, http://www.clearityfoundation.org/.

SPOOR--William 1923 - 2014. William (Billy) Howard Spoor, retired Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of The Pillsbury Company, died on November 14, 2014 at his home in Salt Lake City, UT, surrounded by family. He died exactly as he lived, with tremendous grace, great dignity and on his own terms. While our hearts are broken by the idea of life without him, he and our mother, who passed before him, are still very much with us. Our father's incredible work ethic, sense of humor and love of life are at the heart of everything he did. We have all been influenced by his values and spirit. Bill was born January 16, 1923 in Pueblo, CO to Doris Slaughter Spoor and Charles Hinchman Spoor. The family eventually moved to Denver, where he was raised. In 1941, Bill was accepted to Dartmouth College on a full athletic scholarship. He was an incredibly gifted athlete and a fierce competitor. He excelled in all sports, especially football and track and field. In 1942, he volunteered for the US Army's 10th Mountain Division. Bill trained at Camp Hale and spent 3 1/2 years in the Army. Even as a young soldier, his leadership abilities were clearly evident. Instead of being sent overseas with his division, Bill was ordered to officer candidate school. After the war, Bill returned to Dartmouth where he received his degree in history and education in 1949. It was at Dartmouth that he met the love of his life Janet Spain, a student at Smith College. From that moment forward, she would become the most important person in his life. He would forever be "Billy" to her. Bill was often heard saying that "I make the living and Jan makes the living worthwhile." They were married in NYC on September 23, 1950 and embarked on what was to become, an extraordinary life. After graduating from Dartmouth, Bill began his career with The Pillsbury Company. For more than 20 years Bill focused on his internationalist vision and values, first as Area Sales Manager of Pillsbury's Export Division (New York) and later as Vice President and General Manager of International Operations. He was transferred from New York to Minnesota in 1962. In 1973, he was named Chairman and Chief Executive Officer at Pillsbury. Bill ran Pillsbury from 1973 until 1985, returning briefly to both positions in 1988. Bill and his team not only brought Pillsbury great profitability, but they ensured it was shared with others. "Our success as a company fueled our ability to give," he said. "This enabled us to fully fund The Pillsbury Company Foundation and routinely contribute four percent of our domestic taxable income." Under Bill's leadership, Pillsbury grew dramatically. Much of the growth came through acquisitions, most significantly Green Giant, Haagen-Dazs, Totino's Pizza, Steak & Ale, Godfather's Pizza, American Beauty Macaroni, Van de Kamps and Bumble Bee Tuna, and through the expansion of Burger King. At the time Bill became Chairman and CEO in 1973, Pillsbury sales were $816 million annually, profits were $20 million and earnings per share were $1.60. When he retired from Pillsbury in 1985, sales had grown more than fivefold to $4.7 billion. Profits were $192 million, and earning per share were $4.42. It was, he said, "a very different company" when he left. Bill was generous with his time and his good fortune. He served as director and executive committee member of the United Negro College Fund. He helped raise $32 million for the Minnesota Orchestral Association. He served on the executive committee of the Minnesota Historical Society, as a director of the Minneapolis based Inner City Tennis and as chairman of the YWCA Tribute to Women in International Industry. He was also a recipient of the Horatio Alger Award in 1986. Bill enjoyed his work as head of the Capitol City Renaissance Program task force, appointed in 1985 by Gov. Rudy Perpich, to develop a plan for redesigning the area around the Minnesota Capitol. He also served on the National Cambodia Crisis Committee, on the board of the Foundation for Management Education in Central America. He served on the boards of directors of Northwest Bancorporation, Northwestern National Bank, Honeywell, Inc., Dayton-Hudson Corporation, Berkley & Company, Inc., Piper, Jaffray incorporated, The Coleman Company and Krispy Kreme Doughnuts - Las Vegas. Bill's degree from Dartmouth College was one of his most treasured accomplishments. He demonstrated his appreciation in a variety of ways. In return, Bill was honored by Dartmouth with its Presidential medal for Outstanding Leadership and Achievement. He was closely involved with the Dartmouth Dialogues on Leadership, a program established by Pillsbury in his name. His work for Dartmouth and other institutions of learning brought election to Phi Beta Kappa. In 2005, Jan and Bill moved from their Wayzata, MN home of 40 years to Salt Lake City to be closer to their children and grandchildren. An avid fisherman, he and Jan spent many happy hours fishing in Colorado, Minnesota and their beloved Saratoga, WY. He enriched the lives of everyone he touched through his generosity, quick wit, integrity and loyalty. Bill was a larger than life presence, ingenious at turning a phrase, clever and funny beyond measure and lived his life honorably. Bill was preceded in death by his beautiful and loving wife of 63 years, Janet Spain Spoor; his parents Doris Slaughter Spoor, Charles Hinchman Spoor; his sister Dorothy Spoor Arnold and brother Charles Hinchman Spoor, Jr. He is survived by his children Melanie Grace Spoor, Cynthia Field Spoor (Douglas Howard), William Lincoln Spoor (Sarah), six grandchildren: Charles Spoor Howard, Anna Grace Howard, Blakely Madison Spoor, Savannah Spain Spoor, William Walker Spoor and Lincoln Campbell Spoor; his brother T. Richard Spoor (Ann) of Lakeville, CT. Memorials may be directed to the donor's choice.

PASH--Joseph John, Sr.,died in New York City at the age of 93 on November 20. Born in Hampton, Minnesota and raised on a farm, he left at 18 to pursue his education earning a BA from the University of Southern California and a Master's Degree in Economics from the University of California at Berkley. He then traveled east in pursuit of a NYC advertising career working for Doherty, Clifford, Steers & Shenfield, and Needham Harper & Steers responsible for major consumer product advertising campaigns such as Mueller's "It Doesn't Get Lost in The Sauce" and the introduction of one of the first "tight" products on the market for Hellman's. He also played for the agency's softball team as its #
MOSER--Marvin, MD, In grateful recognition of contributions by Marvin Moser, MD, FACP, to the field of hypertension. American Society of Hypertension (ASH)

MITTENTHAL--Joyce J.,86, of Longboat Key, FL, died October 27. Born April 2, 1928, Joyce grew up in Detroit and graduated from Vassar College. She was an active promoter for many social causes. She received the Detroit Volunteer of the Year Award in 1966 and was elected President of the Detroit League of Women Voters in 1969. Joyce was a founding member and chair of the Michigan Housing Coalition, the Fair Housing Center of Detroit, and the Michigan Housing Trust Fund. In 2006, she received a service award from the FHC-Detroit for over 25 years of service as an active tester, including service as the first Testing Supervisor in 1977, and as a two term Chairperson of the FHC-Detroit Board of Directors. Joyce enjoyed walking on the beach and in Longboat Key's Durante Park, gardening, bird watching, and reading. She is survived by her husband, Richard Mittenthal; children Marilyn, Robert, John and Peter; and four grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to FHC-Detroit at https://donatenow.networkforgood.org/FHCMetroDetroit
LEBENTHAL--James, The Decorators Club acknowledges the passing of our longtime friend and supporter, James Lebenthal. Our deepest condolences to his devoted family. Victoria Hagan, President

LEBENTHAL--James. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of James Lebenthal, beloved father of Alexandra Lebenthal. Our heartfelt condolences go out to James's wife, Betty Wright Landreth; his children, Claudia, James B., and Alexandra; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

JARVIS--Frederick H.,resident of Naples, Florida and Far Hills, New Jersey, passed away peacefully in Atlanta, Georgia on November 18, 2014 from complications of a stroke suffered a week previously. He was 86. Born on March 26, 1928 to Margaret and Frederick Jarvis, he grew up in West Orange, New Jersey. After graduating from West Orange High School, he registered for military service and was in the Army of Occupation in Japan. He obtained his undergraduate degree in business from Upsala College in New Jersey where he ultimately became Chairman of the Board of Trustees. His post graduate business degree was later earned at University of Buffalo. He began his career with Crum and Forster Insurance Company in the map room, and steadily progressed until he was President and Chief Executive Officer. Subsequent to the Crum and Forster Company being acquired by Xerox Corporation, Mr. Jarvis became President and Chief Executive Officer of Selective Insurance Group, Inc. in Branchville, New Jersey. He enjoyed playing golf at Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, New Jersey and Olde Florida in Naples, Florida. In 1986 he retired to Naples, Florida to work on improving his golf game. He was married for thirty-two years to Margaret Kent Jarvis with whom he had four daughters, Margaret Hathaway (Richard) and Helen Cleveland (Dave) of Atlanta, Georgia, Elizabeth Murphy of Beverly, Massachusetts and New York City, and Nancy Stewart (Greg) of Basking Ridge, New Jersey. Additionally, he is survived by his brother, Robert Jarvis of Summerfield, Florida, eleven grandchildren, and nine nieces and nephews. He was widowed in 1997 by Ann Bentley Jarvis, his wife of ten years. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hospice Atlanta, 1244 Park Vista Drive, NE, Atlanta, Georgia 30319. A family memorial is being planned.

HYMAN--Morton P. The Writing Revolution expresses its deepest sympathy to the family of Morton P. Hyman, our devoted President and Chairman. He will leave a substantial void in our organization and will be truly missed by all who knew him. His leadership has impacted thousands of students and his legacy will live on in them. Judith C. Hochman, Founder

HOUSEPIAN--Edgar. The faculty of the Department of Neurological Surgery at Columbia University Medical Center mourns the death of our colleague, teacher and friend, Dr. Edgar M. Housepian. Affiliated with Columbia his entire life, Dr. Housepian attended its elementary school, college, medical school, and residency. He was a faculty member, Special Advisor to the Dean for International Affiliations, and ultimately Professor Emeritus of Neurological Surgery. A distinguished neurosurgeon, he made early contributions to cerebrovascular and image-guided stereotactic surgery. Loyal to his Armenian heritage, he helped organize relief efforts after the major earthquake in Armenia in the 1990s for which he received several honorary doctorates from that countrys medical institutions, its Presidential Citation, and the Humanitarian Award from the American Association of Neurological Surgeons. Kind, wise and a committed colleague, he will be greatly missed.

GUTWILLIG--Richard Bruce, longtime Rockland Journal-News columnist, New York Times sportswriter, beloved brother of Robert Alan Gutwillig, uncle of Kate, Stephen and Annie, died November 16. Donations may be sent in his honor to UNICEF.

GALLUP--Allyn, 74, Beloved Husband, Father, Grandfather, passed away on November 7, 2014. Received BA from Lehigh University. He worked at Citibank, NY, briefly at Goldome and Bank of America, Buffalo. A lover of art and culture, he re-established himself in 1991 founding Allyn Gallup Contemporary Art in Sarasota, FL. Living among the beauty of the art he loved, Allyn and his gallery became a cultural pillar of the community. Always informed, never without an opinion, tremendously loved by his family, friends and artists. He was a member of the Sarasota County Arts Council, Founding Chair of Sarasota County Arts in Public Places Committee, Executive Committee member of Sarasota Visual Arts Center and Downtown Association, President of Ringling Museum Members Council, member of Community Redevelopment Agency Advisory Board of Sarasota. Survived by wife, Sheila Moore, children and grandchildren. A celebration of his life to be held November 29. Info at www.allyngallup.com.

GREGORY--Mamie Spears Reynolds, Born to United States Senator Robert Rice Reynolds and Evalyn Washington McLean Reynolds on October 15 1942 in Washington, DC, passed on the morning of Saturday November 15 2014 in Louisville, KY. Mamie was the granddaughter of Evalyn Walsh McLean known as the last personal owner of the legendary Hope Diamond and Goddaughter to J. Edgar Hoover and Federal Justice Frank Murphy. Mrs. Gregory had been well-known in the social circles of our nation's Capital, Palm Beach and Asheville, NC and was a member of the Daughters Of The American Revolution. She was also an award winning member of the American Kennel Club where she handled and owned many award winning breeds. As a young woman Mamie was owner and driver for the Reynolds Racing Team of Asheville, NC and she became the first woman to qualify for the Daytona 500. Along with dogs and racing, Mamie was involved in and had successful lines of Miniature Horses Dairy and Pygmy goats. In the late 1960's Mamie and her husband Joseph were the first owners of the ABA Kentucky Colonels. She loved traveling with a passion having been around the world seven times in her lifetime. Mamie has touched the lives and hearts of many and will be truly missed. She is survived by her loving husband Joseph E. Gregory, daughter Evalyn Reynolds Gregory Strange and husband Joshua Strange son Joseph C Gregory and partner Charles Rapp and two special fur babies Snugs and Bibbs. The family is making private arrangements and will gratefully appreciate commemorative donations to the Kentuckiana Humane Society or the Arrow Fund.

EUSTIS--Jack April 14, 1998 - November 16, 2014. Survived by his parents, Oskar and Laurie Eustis, his sister, Kyle Brown, and a large and loving family whose lives he filled with joy. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Jack Eustis Scholarship, Saint Ann's School, Development Office, 129 Pierrepont St., Brooklyn Heights, NY 11201.

ELMALEH--Victor. The Southampton Youth Services family mourns the passing of Victor Elmaleh, a pioneer in the development of the game of Squash and the founder of the Elmaleh - Stanton Squash Center in Southampton, New York. His love and passion for the game will be sadly missed.

DIETZ GREEN--Susan Paula, beloved wife of Thom Green, passed away Friday, November 21, 2012 at the young age of 63, following a brief unsuccessful battle against endometrial cancer. Susan was Born September 13, 1949. She graduated from White Plains High School and received a bachelor's degree from Syracuse University in 1971. Her professional career included serving as the National Director of Stores for Christian Dior Intimate Apparel from Carole Hockman Designs. Susan was the first Female Vice President of the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum in New York City, overseeing the retail operations and visitors' services. At the time of her death she enjoyed her position at Wave Hill Public Garden and Cultural Center in Riverdale, Bronx, NY. There she was able to contribute her knowledge, skills, abilities and artistic taste in procuring, for resale at the Shop at Wave Hill, unique selections of artisanal foods, naturally inspired jewelry, and other unique and hand crafted items, from local and regional artists in a way that reflected Wave Hill's mission of connecting people with nature. Susan was an avid photographer, a gourmet cook, a gardening enthusiast, a world traveler, all in all, a woman of many talents. She is fondly remembered and sorely missed by her friends, associates and devoted husband.

Conheeny--Fernanda Fernanda Gieffers Conheeny died peacefully at her home on Sunday, November 16, 2014. Parents Alma and Henry Gieffers of Palm Beach predeceased her. She is survived by sisters Margherita Guttmann of Washington D.C., Alessandra Gieffers of North Palm Beach, and by nephew Hans Peter Guttmann of Washington D.C. Fernanda was a resident of Palm Beach for 20 years and of North Palm Beach for 10 years. She formerly had homes on Sutton Place, New York City, in Southampton and in Hampton Bays, NY. Fernanda's life will be celebrated with a Mass of the Resurrection at 10:00am at St. Edward Catholic Church on Thursday, December 4, 2014. Her interment will follow at the family plot at St. Joseph Cemetery in Hackensack, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in her honor to Il Circolo, PO Box 2166, Palm Beach, FL 33480.

BRECKER--Joan Rowcliffe. of Vero Beach, FL and Nantucket, MA died on Saturday, November 15, she was 87 years old. Mrs. Brecker was born at the United States Naval Academy in Annapolis, MD, the youngest of three devoted sisters that include the late Caroline Schaible and Marion Howard. Her father, Rear Admiral Gilbert J. Rowcliffe, began his naval career as a White House Aid to Presidents Taft and Theodore Roosevelt and he later held a number of senior posts in the Navy including Judge Advocate General. Her mother, Marion (nee Leutze) was the daughter of Rear Admiral Eugene H.C. Leutze, sister of Rear Admiral Trevor Leutze, and the granddaughter of Emanuel Leutze, the German American history painter, best known for his works, "Washington Crossing the Delaware" and the fresco in the US Capitol Building "Westward the Course of the Empire Takes Its Way." Mrs. Brecker graduated from George Washington University, after which she worked as a special education teacher for the Remedial Education Center in Washington, DC. In 1957, she married Richard Lee Brecker, an advertising executive and former Foreign Service Officer and they resided for over forty years in New York City and Nantucket. In 1990, they sold their New York apartment and moved to John's Island in Vero Beach. In New York, she was an active volunteer as a member of the Junior League. An accomplished pianist and lover of music, Mrs. Brecker served many years as a member of the national Council of the Metropolitan Opera and served on the Auditions Committee. She was also President of the Women of the Church of the Heavenly Rest, a member of the Altar Guild and the first female Warden of the Vestry. For her contributions to the Episcopal Church she was elected a Sister of the Most Venerable Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem in 1974. In Nantucket she was a Governor of the Nantucket Yacht Club, a member of the boards of the Sconset Casino, the Nantucket Historical Association and the Sconset Trust. She was also a Trustee of the Sconset Chapel. In Vero Beach she was President of the John's Island Garden Club. She was predeceased by her husband in 2005 and is survived by three beloved children: Pamela Brecker Hendrickson and her husband Douglas of New York City, Jarvis Rowcliffe Brecker and his wife Jennifer of Portland, OR and Caroline Brecker Yenor and her husband Jon of Riverside, CT; seven grandchildren and five nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be held on July 11, 2015 at 4:30pm in the Sconset Chapel, Siasconset, MA. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be sent to the Sconset Trust, Box 821, Siasconset MA 02564 or to the Naval War College Foundation, 686 Cushing Rd, Newport, RI 02841-1213.

OAKES--Margery Hartman, age 98, died peacefully on November 20 at her home in New York City. Born in West Hartford, CT., she was the daughter of Estelle Stein Hartman and Emanuel M. Hartman, a pioneer in the shade-grown tobacco industry in the Connecticut Valley. She graduated in 1938 from Bryn Mawr College. During World War II, she was a writer and editor at the Office of War Information. After the War, she wrote book reviews for the New York Times Sunday Book Review. Part of the burgeoning New York art scene, she worked with the Museum of Modern Art and the League of Women Voters. In the 1950s, she became deeply involved in public education, and remained so for the rest of her life. She first became a board member of the Public Education Association, and then one of the founding members of the New York City School Volunteer Program, now known as Learning Leaders. In 1955, New York State Governor Averell Harriman appointed her a delegate to the New York State Conference on Education. In 1958, Mayor Robert F. Wagner appointed her to the Commission on Vocational Education. In 1986, Mayor Edward I. Koch awarded her a Citation of Merit for her "leadership and commitment to the School Volunteer Program." From 1945 until his death in 2001, she was married to John B. Oakes, former editor of the editorial page of the New York Times. She was a longtime member of the Cosmopolitan Club of New York. She is survived by her children, Andra N. Oakes, of Washington, DC.; Alison H. Oakes, of Glencoe, IL; Cynthia J. Oakes of London; John G. H. Oakes of New York City; and eight grandchildren. GRIFFIN--John Barry. Peaceably passed away in his sleep on Sunday, November 9th in Palm City, FL at age 90. He was born on April 23, 1924, in Birmingham, Warwickshire, England to John Anthony Griffin and Hilda Vizetelly. Mr. Griffin voluntarily enlisted in the Royal Air Force on the day he was old enough to join and was part of the Greatest Generation that fought World War II. He served during the Allied Forces invasion of Normandy and was frequently involved in air-to-air combat as he flew night missions in Lancaster bombers. He was a courageous, patriotic man who had an unwavering sense of right and wrong. He met his wife, the late Dr. Alice V. Griffin, while she was studying at Stratford-upon-Avon and he was working nearby as an air traffic controller. A mutual love of Shakespeare brought them together and became a shared passion for the rest of their lives. The couple married in 1952 at City Hall in New York City and soon thereafter began their radio show, "Sidewalk Critics Review," where they would broadcast live reviews after the openings of new plays and musicals on Broadway. He took on the roles of homemaker, community volunteer and soccer organizer as his wife's career accelerated. Mr. Griffin loved soccer, and in the late 1960s was an early organizing force behind the Westchester Youth Soccer League, now one of the nation's largest with over 20,000 registered players. He trained other fathers to become coaches and recruited referees from a pool of new Americans. Mr. Griffin fulfilled a lifelong dream in 1998 when he attended the World Cup final, witnessing France's victory over Brazil. Mr. Griffin is best remembered as witty, humble and proud of a life well-lived. He is survived by his son, John A., and his wife Amy Griffin of New York City, and his four grandchildren. 1/3

FISHER--Olga Stone, born June 4, 1919, died November 21, 2014, age 95. Daughter of Joseph P. Bader and Erma Bartos Bader. She was a lifelong resident of New York City and graduated from NYU and the NYU School of Social Work. She had a long and rewarding career as a social worker, working at the Louise Wise Agency and at the Lenox Hill Hospital, retiring in 1984. After retirement, she volunteered as a bereavement counselor. The widow of Bertram M. Stone, Ms. Fisher is survived by her children, Jeffrey B. Stone (Gail A. Weiss) and Margaret S. Brodsky (Richard E. Brodsky). She also leaves three devoted grandchildren: Emily C. Stone, Jane S. Brodsky (M. Jesse Carlson) and Benjamin H. Brodsky (Ilana Brodsky), and a great grandchild, Orly S. Carlson. She also leaves her brother, Robert E. Bader, his wife, Helen K. Bader, and Diane L. Stone, mother of Emily Stone. A private memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. New York Society Library or any charity of the donors choice. 1/3

D'AGOSTINO --Peter C. 20, of Greenwich, Conn.,died suddenly on Thursday, November 20, in Charlottesville, Va. A second-year student at the University of Virginia, Peter graduated in 2013 from St. Andrew's School in Middletown, Del., where he was student body president. Upon graduation from St. Andrew's, he earned the William H. Cameron Award for outstanding service to the school, the highest honor conferred by St. Andrew's. Peter was a serious and highly talented scholar in several disciplines, including English literature, the Classics, and creative writing. Known especially for his humor and wit, he was a loyal and caring friend and mentor to so many. They included those at Camp Winona, an all-boys camp on the shores of Moose Pond, in Bridgton, Maine, to which Peter had returned every year since he was 7. At Camp Winona, Peter spent eight summers as a camper and then the following four summers as a counselor. He became a member of the Winona family, finding a knack for leading younger boys through many of the same traditions and adventures he had enjoyed there growing up. An athlete as well, he was a varsity oarsman on the highly competitive St. Andrew's School rowing team, having learned to row at Brunswick School, where he attended 2nd through 9th grade. More recently, Peter had coached younger rowers in Greenwich. While at UVa, he pursued an American Studies major, had been writing fiction, and was also a member of The Whethermen, an improv group. The third-youngest in a family of four, Peter was born in Manhattan. His family moved to Greenwich when he was 7. He leaves his parents, Mary Beth and Walter D'Agostino, and sisters Alexandra, Jane, and Polly, all of Greenwich. He is also survived by his grandparents, aunts, uncles, cousins, extended family, and friends. A wake will be held from 2 to 4 p.m. and 6 to 9 p.m. on Monday, November 24, at the Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home, 31 Arch St., Greenwich. A funeral mass will be held at 10:30 a.m. on Tuesday, November 25, at St. Mary's Church, 178 Greenwich Ave., Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations in Peters memory to The Winona Camps for Boys, 35 Winona Rd., Bridgton, Maine, 04009. 1/3

BRAINERD --Stanford Howard, 83, died in his sleep November 21, 2014 at home in Old Lyme. Loving husband of Wendy Smith Brainerd, admiring brother of Nancy Foltz, devoted father of Elizabeth (Robert), Brooks (Erin) and Charles (Amanda), adoring grandfather of Cecily and James Burge, Lowell and Mallory Brainerd, Malcolm, Annabelle and Fiona Brainerd; loving stepfather to Hilary Hart and Ward Hart and stepgrandfather to Antony, Alexander and Pamela Hart. Stanford was born September 18, 1931 to Howard and Elizabeth Brainerd of Easton PA, graduated from Lawrenceville, Yale and Harvard Business School, served in the U.S. Army and worked as an investment banker starting at Morgan Guaranty Trust Co and retiring from Yamaichi International. Stanford was active, witty and loving to the end. In lieu of flowers gifts may be made to the Middlesex Land Trust. Funeral service will be held 11:00 on Friday, December 12 at St. Anns Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, CT. 1/3

AMES --Louis B. 98, died peacefully on November 3, 2014 in Tucson, AZ. Born Louis B. Schultz in St. Louis on August 9, 1916, he graduated from Clayton HS and Washington University. He began his career in broadcasting first with NBC's guest relations staff, and then moved on to their radio programming dept. WWII interrupted his career. As a naval lieutenant, Lou spent four years on the USS Core in both Atlantic and Pacific theaters. As a member of the intelligence dept., he served as a " code breaker ". While on leave in NYC he married the stage actress Jettaline Preminger. " Jetti " remained his adoring wife for seventy-one years. Her death in September was a huge loss for Lou. Returning from WW 11, Lou continued upon his distinguished career in TV and Radio. This included: producing live operas for NBC television for which famed composer Carlos Menotti mentored him, co-producing the original " Today Show " with host Dave Garroway (Barbara Walters assisted him) and the " Home Show " with host Hugh Downs, sharing an Emmy for PBC's " Great American Dream Machine ", producing " Firing Line" with William F. Buckley Jr. and finally as an executive with Television Information Office. He loved painting water colors and piano playing in his golden years. Pre-deceased by sisters Ruth and Louise, and beloved wife Jetti , his survivors include: son's Tabor (Kate) and Jonathan (Joanne), niece Alison (Richard), and grandson Ryan. Donation may be made to The Theater Workshop of Nantucket or The Invisible Theater of Tucson. 1

Since the February opening of André Balazs’s Chiltern Firehouse — and its celebrity-packed restaurant — the quiet neighborhood of Marylebone has turned into London’s latest culinary destination. Away from the paparazzi, there’s Fischer’s, a new Viennese-style cafe from the restaurateurs behind the beloved Wolseley and the just-launched Beaumont Hotel. Nearby, at Beast, diners feast on Norwegian crab and Nebraskan steak around candelabra-topped communal tables set underground. For upscale Southern comfort, the Lockhart serves fried chicken with friggitelli peppers, while Carousel is the new headquarters of Shuttlecock Inc, which stages culinary events with themes like Canada Day and the golden age of air travel. And next spring, the crew behind Clerkenwell’s eccentric Zetter Townhouse will unveil a second location in the area, with a curiosity-filled lounge serving molecular cocktails and modern bistro fare.

STRONGWATER--Peter Barclay, beloved life-long best friend to Judith R. King and Vera Wang, along with countless other devoted friends, died peacefully in his sleep late Wednesday night after a valiant battle with cancer. He was 73 years old. Peter was an acclaimed portrait and fashion photographer, including a highly regarded stint as a cover photographer for Andy Warhol's Interview Magazine in the seventies. Among his iconic subjects were Sir Mick Jagger, David Bowie and Diana Ross. A style maven and confidant to many in the creative arts, Peter eventually established the photo production company called Photo-group, which is now being so ably run by his dear friend and business partner, Vail Palmer. Per Peter's request, a small private service is being held next week; a much larger celebration of his life and in his honor, hosted by Judith R. King and Vera Wang, will soon follow. Peter Strongwater was above all a complete gentleman and true mensch. We adored him. 1/3

NICHOLS--Mike. The family of Leonard and Felicia Bernstein is bereft at the prospect of life without their beloved friend, Mike Nichols. We send all our warmest thoughts to Diane and to Mike's family in this unbearably difficult time, as we are all feeling robbed of someone so precious. 1/3

MUKAMAL--Lila. Beloved wife of the late Robert Persky Loving step mother of Steven, Joshua and Laura. Cherished sister of Dr. Ronald, Dr. Harold, Joseph and Dr. Edmond. Interment will take place at New Montefiore Cemetery on November 26. 1/3

MOSER--Marvin, MD The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Marvin Moser, MD, a pioneer in treating and preventing hypertension and a strong supporter of SUNY Downstate. Dr. Moser was a 1947 graduate of the College of Medicine and earlier this year received an honorary Doctor of Science Degree from the State University of New York. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family and friends. John F. Williams, MD, EdD, MPH, FCCM President 1/3

MOLDOVER--Edward D.,on November 23, 2014 after a brief illness. Distinguished attorney practicing over 60 years. Cherished brother of Ruth Zippin. Also survived by his sisters-in-law and brothers-in-law. Dear uncle to many. Graveside service: Tuesday, November 25, 2014, 11am, Mount Hope Cemetery, Westchester. 1/3

LOWENTHAL--Dr. Joseph P.,beloved husband of the late, Shirley, devoted father of Jeffrey and his wife, Linda Anderson, Richard and his wife, Wilhelmina Margalis, loving grandfather of Celia Anne Lowenthal and Noah Benjamin Lowenthal. Dr. Lowenthal was a veteran of WWII. He served as Chief of the Department of Biologics Research at the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research in Silver Spring, Maryland for many years. After retiring from the federal government in 1979, he worked as a Research Grants Administrator at the American Cancer Society in New York City for eight years. Service 12 noon Wednesday at Schwartz Brothers, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, NY. 1/3

KAHN--Abraham L.,on Thursday, November 20, just shy of his 101st birthday. Husband of the late Ruth, father of Randy (Judi) and Barbara (Burr), and grandfather of Stacey, Lisa, Robin and Laurel. A gravesite ceremony was held on November 21 at Old Mt. Carmel Cemetery in Queens, NY. 1/3
HIRSCHSON--Albert. Al was the greatest friend anyone could have. We will never forget the wonderful times we shared with Al and his family. The Belmonte Family 1/3

GREY--Rita (Sachs), died peacefully at home on November 23, 2014. Beloved wife of Stanley for over 70 years. Devoted mother to her four children: Lisa Staff (Ken), Andrea Silverstein (Sal), Melinda Crossman (Doug) and Michael Grey (Cindy). Adored grandmother of Kate (Nick) and Rachel, Molly and Kevin, Stella and Mackenzie. Dear sister of Muriel Saunders. She will also be missed by nieces and nephews and many friends. Rita was the love of Stan's life; a loving caring mother and a gifted sculptor. Funeral service is Tuesday, November 25th at 1pm at The Riverside Chapel at 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, we would welcome donations in Rita's name to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation. 1/3

FOGELMAN--Martin. McGivney Professor of Law, Emeritus, on November 23, 2014, at the age of 86, of Huntington, New York. Beloved husband of Suzanne. Loving father of Henry, Martin Jr. (Patricia) and the late Douglas and Jeffrey. Cherished grandfather of Kimberly Ann and Martin III. AB cum laude, Syracuse University, 1948, JD magna cum laude, 1950. Bar: New York 1950, U.S. District Court. (north district) New York 1953, U.S. Supreme Court 1956, U.S. District Court (south district) New York 1957, U.S. District Court (east district) New York 1958. Confidential law elk. to chief judge New York Court Appeals, Albany, 1950-54; associate Saxe, Bacon, O'Shea & Bryan, N.Y.C., 1955-58; adjunct professor Fordham Law School, N.Y.C., 1956-58, professor, law, 1958-62, Arthur A. McGivney professor, law, 1982-. President university senate, 1980-83, chairman athletic board, 1980-93, board directors University Press, 1978-, chairman. 1987-, also member university trustees academic affairs committee; arbitrator National Association Security Dealers, 1981-, Chicago Board Trade, 1986-; member complaint mediation panel appellate division, 1st department New York Supreme Court. Co-author: Cases and Materials on Mortgages, 1963; author: West's Forms and Text, New York Business Corporation Law, 1965, 2d edition, 1984 and annual supplements; West's Forms and Text, New York Not-For-Profit Corporation Law, 1972, 2nd edition, 1990, and annual supplements. Member ABA, New York State Bar Association, Association of Bar of City of New York. In Lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Feerick Center for Social Justice at Fordham University School of Law. 1/3

DONOHUE--Kevin, 76, of Milford, PA entered into rest on November 17, 2014. He was born June 28, 1938 to Timothy and Kathleen Donohue in Bronx, NY. He attended Cardinal Hayes High School and served in the U.S. Army as a Morse code radio operator in Germany. He earned his BA in English from Fordham University, and worked as a Printing Pressman for The New York Times, in the footsteps of his father. He is survived by his daughter, Mary Donohue, in Philadelphia PA; brothers Timothy (Ellen) of Yonkers, NY, and Brendan of Cape Coral, FL; sisters Kathleen (John) McCoy of Washington, DC and Maureen (Mac) Chryssikos of Ellicott City, MD. He will be reunited with his wife, Bridget (Marguerite) Donohue in Heaven and into the joy of eternal happiness. 1/3
CARRO--Melvin J.,died November 20, 2014. Remembering our dear friend and Maury's longtime law partner with love and respect. Condolences to Carol and family. Maurice & Marion Spanbock 1/3

BRAINERD --Stanford Howard, 83, died in his sleep November 21, 2014 at home in Old Lyme. Loving husband of Wendy Smith Brainerd, admiring brother of Nancy Foltz, devoted father of Elizabeth (Robert), Brooks (Erin) and Charles (Amanda), adoring grandfather of Cecily and James Burge, Lowell and Mallory Brainerd, Malcolm, Annabelle and Fiona Brainerd; loving stepfather to Hilary Hart and Ward Hart and stepgrandfather to Antony, Alexander and Pamela Hart. Stanford was born September 18, 1931 to Howard and Elizabeth Brainerd of Easton PA, graduated from Lawrenceville, Yale and Harvard Business School, served in the U.S. Army and worked as an investment banker starting at Morgan Guaranty Trust Co and retiring from Yamaichi International. Stanford was active, witty and loving to the end. In lieu of flowers gifts may be made to the Middlesex Land Trust. Funeral service will be held 11:00 on Friday, December 12 at St. Anns Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, CT. 1/3
BARRY--Claire. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Claire Barry. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her family. 1/3

BARBER--Marion. FORD--Shirley R. Dear S, More precious was the light in your eyes than all the roses in the world. Eternal love, Your T. Tony

MANDALA--Paul Salvatore, died November 21, 2014. He was the beloved husband of Leslie and father of Caroline, Pauline and Sarah. If you wish, please make a gift in his name to the Good Samaritan Hospital Foundation, West Islip, NY.

BARBER--Marion, Loving matriarch, died peacefully at 93 years of age, surrounded by family and friends on November 21 in Palm Beach, FL. Daughter of Mark and Bessie Isaacs; loving wife to the late Bertram Barber; beloved sister to Renee, Jean and David; doting and cherished step-mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt, great-aunt, and great friend to her devoted caregiver. Fiercely independent with a wondrous, optimistic and energetic heart, an ASID designer, she traveled the world, golfed, and made friends all along the way. As much as we are diminished by her death, we are enriched by her life. Her charm, courage, and warmth of spirit will be greatly missed.

SPILKE--Marilyn (nee Lesnik), 91, on November 22, 2014. A woman of courage, wit, honesty, kindness, and impeccable taste. May her memory be a blessing. Funeral Service 10am, Friday Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home, Dobbs Ferry, NY. Edwardsanddowdle.com 1/3

SCHULZ--Juergen, was born at Kiel, Germany, on August 18, 1927, and died of a stroke in Providence, RI, on November 23, 2014. In 1938 his family fled Nazi Germany and settled in Berkeley, California. A veteran of World War II, he was educated at the University of California at Berkeley and received his doctorate in the history of art under Johannes Wilde from the Courtauld Institute, University of London, in 1958. In that year he joined the art history faculty at the University of California at Berkeley. In 1968 he was appointed professor and chairman of the art department at Brown University, retiring in 1995 as Andrea K. Rosenthal Professor Emeritus. Under his leadership, the department became an important center for both graduate and undergraduate instruction in the history of art and architecture; he was greatly loved by students and colleagues alike. His abundant research focused on Medieval and Renaissance Venice, resulting in books and articles on Venetian Romanesque palaces, painted ceilings of the Renaissance, and printed maps, plans, and views of Venice. He was awarded fellowships by the Guggenheim Foundation, the Fulbright Committee, the NEH, and the Institute for Advanced Studies at Princeton and was a member of the Ateneo Veneto. For his contribution to the rescue of Italian art after the floods of 1966, he was designated Grande Ufficiale of the Ordine della Stella della Solidarieta della Repubblica Italiana. From 1984 he was an active member on the scientific council of the Centro Internazionale di Studi di Architettura "Andrea Palladio" at Vicenza. In 2000-2001 he was Samuel H. Kress Professor at the National Gallery of Art, Washington. His wife, Anne Markham Schulz, his children, Ursula, Catherine and Jeremy Schulz, his son-in-law Michael Apte, daughter-in- law Laura Robinson and four grandsons will cherish his memory. A memorial service will be announced. 1/3

NICHOLS--Mike. The family of Leonard and Felicia Bernstein is bereft at the prospect of life without their beloved friend, Mike Nichols. We send all our warmest thoughts to Diane and to Mike's family in this unbearably difficult time, as we are all feeling robbed of someone so precious. 1/3

McFADDEN--Michael J.,65, of Croton, New York, died suddenly Monday, November 24th at Hudson Valley Hospital. He is survived by his partner of 20 years and spouse Donald Tunnard. His enormous personality, wealth of selflessness and model for the Jewish Community will be sorely missed by all. The staff and Board of Directors of Plaza Jewish Community Chapel will cherish his imprint for generations to come. Harold Handler, Chairman 1/3

MARSHMAN--Ann Chase Lane, of Darien, CT, died peacefully at home on November 21, at age 87. She is survived by her husband, Donald M. Marshman, three sons and their wives, a daughter, and five grandchildren. 1/3

MAHLER--Bernard. Beloved husband of the late Hilda R. Mahler. Cherished father of Edith, Howard and Susan. Adored grandfather of Zachary and great-grandfather of Ruby. Funeral service today, 12 noon at Schwartz Brothers- Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Forest Hills, NY. 1/3

KURZ--Herbert. NYU mourns the passing of Herbert Kurz, champion of academic freedom and constitutional rights, tireless activist, generous friend. We are thankful for his invaluable commitment to Tamiment Library and the Frederic Ewen Center, and for his leadership and vision. 1/3

KAY--Jeanette. The family of Jeanette (Dickie) Kay celebrates her remarkable life of loving and giving. She left us peacefully on November 24th surrounded by her children and grandchildren, who all adored her. Born May 7, 1928 to Mark and Jeanette Sloman, she shared 57 years of marital bliss with Marty Kay, who predeceased her in 2009. Together, they formed a dynamic duo that raised the bar for partnership and affection. Dickie's legacy is the selflessness, compassion, generosity, kindness, respect, and patience she gave unconditionally to everyone she encountered in all the roles she served: wife, mother, Nannie, great-grandmother, friend, volunteer, and acquaintance. The legacy she and Marty were proudest of was their family: children Patty, Peter and Kathy, their spouses, 10 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. While most of her days were devoted to giving time to others, she did manage to squeeze in a few moments for needlepoint, gardening, Judge Judy, Fox News and her collections of antique pillboxes and pitchers. A lifelong volunteer, she was a 2013 inductee into the Westchester County Department of Senior Programs and Services Hall of Fame. Dickie will always be in the hearts and minds of those lucky and blessed enough to have known her. Memorial services will be held on Wednesday, November 26, 2014 at McMahon, Lyon & Hartnett Funeral Home, 491 Mamaroneck Ave., White Plains at 10am. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Dickie's honor may be made to Hospice & Palliative Care of Westchester. 1/3

KAY--Jeanette "Dickie". The Board of Directors and the members of Quaker Ridge Golf Club are saddened by the passing of our beloved friend and esteemed member of more than 35 years, Dickie Kay. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her entire family in their time of sorrow. Marc Friedman, President 1/3

KAHN--Abraham L.,on Thursday, November 20, just shy of his 101st birthday. Husband of the late Ruth, father of Randy (Judi) and Barbara (Burr), and grandfather of Stacey, Lisa, Robin and Laurel. A gravesite ceremony was held on November 21 at Old Mt. Carmel Cemetery in Queens, NY. 1/3
HELLER--Evelyn, 90, nee Andrews, died November 24. Survived by Kathryn Heller Schwyzer, Tom, Peter, Christopher Heller and family. 1/3

FISHER--Olga Stone, born June 4, 1919, died November 21, 2014, age 95. Daughter of Joseph P. Bader and Erma Bartos Bader. She was a lifelong resident of New York City and graduated from NYU and the NYU School of Social Work. She had a long and rewarding career as a social worker, working at the Louise Wise Agency and at the Lenox Hill Hospital, retiring in 1994. After retirement, she volunteered as a bereavement counselor. The widow of Bertram M. Stone, Ms. Fisher is survived by her children, Jeffrey B. Stone (Gail A. Weiss) and Margaret S. Brodsky (Richard E. Brodsky). She also leaves three devoted grandchildren: Emily C. Stone, Jane S. Brodsky (M. Jesse Carlson) and Benjamin H. Brodsky (Ilana Brodsky), and a great grandchild, Orly S. Carlson. She also leaves her brother, Robert E. Bader, his wife, Helen K. Bader, and Diane L. Stone, mother of Emily Stone. A private memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. New York Society Library or any charity of the donors choice. 1/3

FISHER--Debra Kram, died November 24, 2014, born April 22, 1946 in Brooklyn, NY, the daughter of Beatrice and Maurice Greenbaum. A graduate of Bennington College, and holder of a Master's Degree in Film from NYU. An award-winning documentary film-maker and pioneering prime time news producer. A supporter of many charities and a champion of the people of Appalachia. Survived by her beloved husband of 40 years, Robert Fisher, her children Daniel (Ashley) Fisher and Elizabeth Fisher, and her grandchildren Cabot Coleman Fisher, Winston Clark Fisher and Burke Samuel Fisher. Services November 26, 2014, 10am at Temple Beth El of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY. Services handled by Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society. A person of significant accomplishments and strong views; deeply devoted to her husband and family. 1/3

COSTIGLlO--Lawrence U.,98. Died on November 25, 2014. Beloved husband of Isabelle (nee Mahoney), who pre-deceased him. Father of Christina Bernard (Edward), Peter (Barbara), Eugene, Teresa Cantwell (Thomas). Grandfather of nine and great- grandfather of eight. A WW II veteran and a 1941 graduate of Fordham Law School. He worked for many years as Executive Vice President for the Savings Banks Association of New York. He later was a director of the Federal Housing Finance Board. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, Friday, November 28, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue, New York at 10am, Saturday, November 29. 1/3

COLE--Martin S.,82, died peacefully on November 23, 2014, at home with his wife Dionne and his dog Pierre at his side. He was a graduate of Cornell University, 1954 and Cornell Law School, 1956. He is survived by his wife Dionne, his children, Andrew and Pamela, his stepchildren Victoria, James and William, seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. A man of great intellect and wit, an avid stamp collector, traveler and music lover, he practiced law until his death. Much loved by his family, he was a steady hand and guide to us all. He will be greatly missed. 1/3

CALDON--Walter. Walter Caldon, of New York, NY died on Saturday, November 22. He was 92 years old and lived near Lincoln Center. After a brief illness he died peacefully in hospice at Mt. Sinai hospital in Manhattan after sustaining a head injury in a fall at the hospital. Mr. Caldon was born in Staten Island, NY. His parents, Ida Dissen(a), born in Vitebsk, and Samuel Kaldovsky, born in Kiev, emigrated to the U.S. in the first years of the 20th century. He was the youngest of three children that included the late Ruth Levine (1907-1973) and Frances Gold (1916-2000). He is survived by his sisters' children, grandchildren and great- grandchildren. Before the war, Mr. Caldon studied at Brooklyn College and The Art Students League. He then served in the U.S. Army from 1942-1946. In recognition of his academic potential, he was selected to complete a program in Civil Engineering at Rutgers University in 1943-44 under U.S. Army sponsorship. After the war, he completed a B.S. and M.A. in Fine Arts with a minor in Music at Columbia University and subsequently a Diplome at the Ecole Normale de Musique in Paris where he studied under composer Artur Honegger. From 1952-1973, he worked as a Civil Engineer for the New York City Housing Authority. He worked on high-rise construction during a period of great postwar expansion of the Authority. Mr. Caldon lived for over 50 years in a townhouse in Greenwich Village. After he stopped working, he also spent time at a weekend home in Southold, NY. His lengthy retirement included several extended stays in his beloved Paris as well as composing music for performing arts productions and painting. He wrote musical scores for the Living Theater, the Open Theater, The Martha Graham Dance Company and The Actors Studio among others. His paintings were featured in American Artist in August 1975 and in one-man gallery shows in Paris and New York. His work is represented in corporate and private collections in New York, Germany and France. Many of the paintings depict urban scenes, often evoking a sense of the sublime or mysterious in otherwise familiar surroundings. There would be many piquant episodes to relate. In the early 1970s, Mr. Caldon was known to leash- walk his pet capuchin monkey around the Village in diapers. As if that weren't enough, he also enjoyed smuggling the monkey into the movies inside his shirt where she would sleep blissfully until the credits rolled. One week something alarmed the monkey and she went free-range in a crowded Manhattan movie house during the second reel. The rest of the story is perhaps best left to the imagination. He was fiercely independent until the end of his life. He was grateful for the help of friends but he often confounded them by not accepting even the most basic services that make life here less arduous. On the day of his fall, he rode two buses to the hospital when he could have easily paid for the cab ride across town. He was an intense, witty friend whose sense of humor and wonderment at simple details that most of us fail to notice are missed by those fortunate enough to have known him. You could have fun in even the most dismal surroundings if you could only catch his eye. The flaws in our English and French syntax shall hereafter go uncorrected. There will be a Memorial at a future date. 1/3

BREHM--Alvin. American double bass player, conductor and composer; born New York February 8th, 1925, died November 22nd, at age 89. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Alison, his sons, Jon and Marco, nephews Stan, Henry, Steven, Bob, Eric and Bill and their families and generations of musicians whom he taught. A sailer for many years, he sailed the seas on Big Fiddle. 1/3

BLOOM--Alfred, of Boca Raton, FL, on November 24, 2014. Husband of the late Beverly and father of the late Richard. He is survived by his brother Joseph, son Larry, grandchildren Katie, Jake, Jesse and Nicole. Services at Gutterman's, Boca Raton, Friday, November 28, 11am. 1/3

BARRY--Claire. The Yiddish Theatrical Alliance and the Yiddish Artists & Friends Actors Club are deeply saddened by the passing of Claire Barry of the famous Barry Sisters. WALKER--Judy, 81, died peacefully on November 26, 2014. Wife of the late Murry Walker, mother of Jill (Steven), Laura (Jamie), and predeceased by her son Henry. Grandmother to Michael, Sammy, Charlotte, Zachary, William, Jordan, Kendall, Robby, Matthew, Kate and Jack. To a great golf champion, heaven awaits you with your tee time. Cheers. 1/3

STOECKLEIN--David R. 1949-2014. Legendary photographer David R. Stoecklein left his mark on our world in more ways than one. The son of Bernard and Dorothy and brother of Buzzy, Julie, Walter and Debbie Stoecklein, he was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania in 1949. During his early twenties he headed west to pursue his passion for photography. David met Mary Jagger in 1976 and after moving to Sun Valley, Idaho, they married and were blessed with three boys-- Drew, Taylor and Colby. Everyone who knew David also understood that he was completely in love and devoted as a husband, a father and friend to all. David's images dominated the ski and outdoor industry, but his contribution to advertising made him one of the most sought after photographers in the business. He worked with Chevrolet and Jeep to Marlboro and Stetson, Canon USA and Epson, Coca Cola and Bayer to name a few. His passion was in documenting the cowboy way of life and the men and women who knew a thing or two about hard work and making an honest living. David lived by the code of the West. In fact he provided the photographs and publishing for the book Cowboy Ethics. His word was worth gold, and his handshake meant everything. He finished what he started, spoke his peace, but always listened first. He worked hard, played hard, and always made a stranger feel welcome. He was both tough and tender, and his life has inspired countless others. The iconic American Western photographer was much loved and admired for his gregarious character and passion for life. His photographs will forever be a tribute to his talents and his spirit will live on in all those whose lives he graced. He remains legendary. In his honor, Mary and her three sons have established the David R. Stoecklein Memorial and Educational Foundation. It is a charitable organization designed to provide help to causes David cared so much for--such as providing scholarships to aspiring photography students and to helping cowboys and cowgirls in need. The Stoecklein family would like to continue David's legacy of education and generosity for generations to come. Memorial donations in memory of David may be made to the David R. Stoecklein Memorial and Educational Foundation in care of Attorney Brian Barsotti, P.O. Box 370, Ketchum, ID 83340. A celebration of Davids life is being planned for the spring of 2015. www.stoeckleinphoto graphy.com 1/3

COSTIGLlO--Lawrence U.,98. Died on November 25, 2014. Beloved husband of Isabelle (nee Mahoney), who pre-deceased him. Father of Christina Bernard (Edward), Peter (Barbara), Eugene, Teresa Cantwell (Thomas). Grandfather of nine and great- grandfather of eight. A WW II veteran and a 1941 graduate of Fordham Law School. He worked for many years as Executive Vice President for the Savings Banks Association of New York. He later was a director of the Federal Housing Finance Board. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, Friday, November 28, 2-5 and 7-9pm. COONEY--John Joseph, of New York, died September 21, 2014 at the age of 91. He is survived by daughters, Carol Cooney Canavan and Mary Cooney; son, Kevin Cooney; step-daughter Virgina Bing; sisters Joan Cooney Stern and Kathleen Cooney Leo; and brother Peter Cooney. During WW II he served as a gunner on a B-24 Liberator, flying 35 missions for which he was awarded six Bronze Stars and three Air Medals. After the war he graduated from Haverford College and pursued a career in corporate finance. He will be greatly missed by his many friends and colleagues. Memorial Service and reception: 5pm, November 29, the University Club, 1 W. 54th St., New York, NY. Memorial donations may be made to the Long Island State Veterans Home, Stony Brook, NY. 1/3

BERTISCH--Gerald A.,died peacefully, surrounded by his loving family on Monday, November 24, 2014, in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. Born in New York City on December 1, 1933, to Leo and Ruth Bertisch, he is mourned by his beloved wife of 58 years, Carolee, his adored family: sons, Andrew (Charlotte) and Michael (Jennifer), brother, Morton (Emily), grandchildren, Madeleine, Jeremy, Jamie and Kristen, nieces and nephews and many friends. After graduating from Syracuse University, he served in the U.S. Army, then Merchandise Manager of United Whelan Corporation. He founded Automated Personnel International in White Plains, NY, was Vice President of ECPI, and Financial Advisor with Merrill Lynch for 23 years until retirement to Ponte Vedra Beach, FL, in 1997. Former resident of Rye Brook, NY, and Vermont, a skier and avid golfer, he was a member of Marsh Landing Country Club and The Lodge. Donations in his memory may be made to www.K9forWarriors.org at 260 S. Roscoe Boulevard, Ponte Vedra Beach, FL 32082. Services and a Toast to Jerry for friends and family will be at Marsh Landing Country Club on Tuesday, December 2 at 4 pm. 1/3
