REYNOLDS--Beverly Ward. Beverly Reynolds, who was a devoted wife, loving mother, mischievous grandmother and the Founder and Director of the Reynolds Gallery in Richmond, VA, died on November 23 at her home. She was 68. Beverly was a driving force in creating a vibrant contemporary arts community in Richmond and lived a life of style, substance, and spirit. She was gifted, generous, tenacious, tough, curious, opinionated, tender- hearted, compassionate, creative and committed to making a difference and a contribution. She laughed easily and delighted in creating places and opportunities for family and friends to spend time together. Bev loved life and the people in it with her, especially her family. Beverly Lynn was born in Wilmington, DE to Dudley and Alice Ward, both natives of Canada, on July 13, 1946. She was raised in Chicago and Washington. After graduating from the University of Tennessee, the always-adventurous Bev headed to New York City where she met the charming David Reynolds. They were married on December 13, 1969 and were devoted to each other for forty-five years. While living on the Upper East Side of Manhattan for eight years, Bev joined the docent program at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and soon met art dealer Jeanne Frank, who hired Bev to work in her gallery and who became a lifelong mentor. Bev founded Reynolds Gallery in Richmond in 1977. Early sales of works by Alexander Calder, Ellsworth Kelly, and Max Ernst gave her "the courage to dream that a gallery based on a New York model might work in Richmond." And it has. Today, the Reynolds Gallery is one of the most respected contemporary art galleries in the country. Bev was a visionary and tireless leader in the effort to create the Institute for Contemporary Art at Virginia Commonwealth University, designed by Steven Holl and scheduled to open in 2016. The first floor gallery has been named in her honor. While living in Richmond, Beverly always had a second spiritual home in Manhattan. She traveled to New York several times a year for over thirty years, and loved the vibrancy, creativity and constant change of New York. She brought famous New York based artists to Richmond and brought Virginia based artist to world prominence in New York. She rejoiced in the crowded bustle of Madison Avenue and quite contemplation in the Metropolitan Museum, particularly during the holidays. Bev is survived by her husband, David, and her four children: Quentin and his wife, Sarah; Alec and his wife, Laura; Alice Livingston and her husband, Mac; and Margaret Jones and her husband, Will. She is predeceased by their first son, David. She was "Bevie" to her nine beautiful grandchildren (Caldwell, Quinn, Jackson, Pierce, Elliott, Griffin, William, Helen and Lillian), all of whom will carry on her spirit and joy for life. Bev adored her sister Dianne English and her husband, Roger, and her brother, Dr. John A. D. Ward and his wife, Pam. A memorial service will be held at 11am, Saturday, November 29, at St. James's Episcopal Church, 1205 W, Franklin St., Richmond, VA. The family requests gifts be made in memory of Bev to either the Institute for Contemporary Art at VCU (www.ica.vcu.edu) or the Ovarian Cancer Research Fund (www.ocrf.org); in lieu of flowers. 1/3

PASH--Joseph John, Sr.,died in New York City at the age of 93 on November 20. Born in Hampton, Minnesota and raised on a farm, he left at 18 to pursue his education earning a BA from the University of Southern California and a Master's Degree in Economics from the University of California at Berkley. He then traveled east in pursuit of a NYC advertising career working for Doherty, Clifford, Steers & Shenfield, and Needham Harper & Steers responsible for major consumer product advertising campaigns such as Mueller's "It Doesn't Get Lost in The Sauce" and the introduction of one of the first "light" products on the market for Hellman's. He also played for the agency's softball team as its #

MANDEL--Laura Kathleen Brown ("Katie"). Katie passed away peacefully on Tuesday, November 25, 2014 at the age of 72 after a long and courageous battle with Multiple Sclerosis. Born September 18, 1942 and raised in a suburb of Cleveland, Ohio, Katie came to New York City to attend the Tobe'-Coburn School and to pursue a career in the fashion industry. She subsequently worked at the Hemisphere Club and was responsible for Luncheon Club Operations at Rockefeller Center. Soon after her move to New York, Katie met and later married her husband of 50 years, Steve. Her many interests included painting, reading, music, theater and the fine arts. She was particularly passionate about her family and her most precious moments were spent with her children and grandchildren. Katie's courage and determination were truly inspirational as she fought the progressive and debilitating effects of MS. Katie always demonstrated the power of positive thinking and displayed effortless grace throughout her life. She had a terrific sense of humor, an incomparable generosity of spirit and took a sincere interest in others. Anyone who met Katie could not help but be drawn to her. Katie's warmth infused all of our lives and memories of her beautiful smile will be with us forever. Katie is survived by her devoted husband, Stephen; her son, Mark and daughter-in-law, Michele; her daughter, Melissa and son-in-law, John Beaman; and her six grandsons whom she adored. She is also survived by her loving sister, Margaret B. Hannah. A memorial service will be held at 1:30pm on Saturday, December 6, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Katie's memory may be directed to the Tisch MS Research Center of New York. 1/3

LINSCHITZ--Henry, 95, beloved husband, father, teacher, colleague, and friend, passed away at home on November 24. He grew up in New York City, graduated from City College of New York, and earned his Ph.D. in chemistry at Duke University. During World War II, he worked at the Explosives Research Laboratory in Pittsburgh, and then as a Section Leader at Los Alamos. He participated in the first atomic bomb test at Alamogordo, and then served on Tinian with the U.S. Air Force. After the war, he studied with James Franck as a post-doctoral fellow at the University of Chicago, then worked as a professor of chemistry at Syracuse University from 1948 to 1957, and at Brandeis University from 1957 to 1989. Like many veterans of the Manhattan Project, Henry was active in the antinuclear and peace movements. In 1982 he helped found UCAM (United Campuses to Prevent Nuclear War), which had about 50 chapters at schools across the nation. He also served on the board of CCO (Center for Campus Organizing), which fostered student activism at American universities. Henry was a Visiting Scientist at the Brookhaven National Laboratory; a Fulbright Visiting Professor at Hebrew University; a National Institutes of Health Fellow at the University of California, San Diego; a Guggenheim Fellow at the Weizmann Institute; and a long- time consultant to the Eastman Kodak Company. His national service included several government panels, study sections and committees of NASA, NIH, the National Research Council, and the Council of the American Chemical Society. Henry is survived by his wife of 50 years, Suzanne Hodes, his son Joseph Linitz, his daughter- in-law Karen Linitz, and two grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at Levine Chapels, 470 Harvard Street, Brookline, MA, 02446 on Sunday, November 30, 11:00am. 1/3

KURZ--Herbert, founder of Presidential Life Insurance Company, Philanthropist, and Humanitarian died Monday, November 24, 2014. Kurz founded Nyack, NY based Presidential Life Insurance Company. He has received high praise for his business success, philanthropic accomplishments, and humanitarian commitment. Presidential candidate and Senator George McGovern, a friend of Herb, has stated: "Herb is a humanistic, Roosevelt-type Democrat and a committed activist on the war and peace front." "He's a person of deep political convictions, but not in a narrow partisan sense. He's what a businessman ought to be." Kurz was honored by President Bill Clinton at the White House Conference on Corporate Citizenship in 1996. Kurz went on to become the founder of the Kurz Family Foundation through which he endowed a chair in constitutional rights in the political science department of Brooklyn College, his alma matter, and established the Frederic Ewen Center at NYU's Tamiment Library. He also supports numerous organizations in Rockland County, NY, the community where Presidential Life is based. Born in Harlem in 1920 to Max and Molly Kurz, he served in the Army Air Corps during World War II and was a decorated navigator aboard B-26 bombers for his rescue mission over Greenland. He and his wife Edythe moved to Rockland County, NY in the 1950s. He is survived by his son, Leonard, of Piermont, NY; a daughter, Ellen Kurz of Cambridge, MA, and two grandchildren, Tommy Kurz Cosgrove and Sophie Kurz Cosgrove. A service will be held 10am, Friday, November 28 at Temple Beth Torah, 330 North Highland Avenue, Upper Nyack, NY 10960. Donations in his name can be made to the President's Student Support Fund at Rockland Community College, Suffern, NY and the Center for Safety and Change, New City, NY. 1/3

HINKSON JACKSON--Mary of New York, 89, passed peacefully November 26, 2014 at home. A renowned beautiful dancer, an extraordinary teacher, a beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, cousin, aunt and dear friend, she will be missed by many. In lieu of flowers, donations to: garthfagan.org or to: philadanco.org. 1/3

FROMBOLUTI--Sideo. The artist Sideo Fromboluti passed away Sunday, November 23rd from natural causes. He was 94. He was born in Hershey, PA of Italian immigrants during the Great Depression. He was the first of his family to attend college having won the only scholarship offered by his high school to the Tyler College of Art. He subsequently earned a BFA and Masters degree. He was drafted into the Army during WWII completing his service in Junction City, KS. Always a passionate and accomplished painter, he moved with his wife and fellow artist, Nora Speyer to New York City in 1947. He exhibited his work and was involved with the 10th Street art scene, counting as his friends the artists who were major figures of the Abstract Expressionist movement. He had numerous solo shows, one at the Carnegie Museum of Art in 1998. He was represented by the Darthea Speyer Gallery in Paris, France for many years. He was a founding member of the Landmark Gallery in NYC and the Longpoint Gallery in Provincetown, MA. Both institutions were important to their communities, Landmark Gallery in the early days of SoHo and Longpoint Gallery as a center of the Provincetown art scene. He was a member of the National Academy of Design (NA). He leaves behind his wife of 69 years, Nora Speyer, his two children, Christopher Fromboluti, Iona Fromboluti and grandchildren, Sara Fromboluti and Matthew Fromboluti. 1/3

FISHER--Olga Stone, born June 4, 1919, died November 21, 2014, age 95. Daughter of Joseph P. Bader and Erma Bartos Bader. She was a lifelong resident of New York City and graduated from NYU and the NYU School of Social Work. She had a long and rewarding career as a social worker, working at the Louise Wise Agency and at the Lenox Hill Hospital, retiring in 1994. After retirement, she volunteered as a bereavement counselor. The widow of Bertram M. Stone, Ms. Fisher is survived by her children, Jeffrey B. Stone (Gail A. Weiss) and Margaret S. Brodsky (Richard E. Brodsky). She also leaves three devoted grandchildren: Emily C. Stone, Jane S. Brodsky (M. Jesse Carlson) and Benjamin H. Brodsky (Ilana Brodsky), and a great grandchild, Orly S. Carlson. She also leaves her brother, Robert E. Bader, his wife, Helen K. Bader, and Diane L. Stone, mother of Emily Stone. A private memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. New York Society Library or any charity of the donors choice. 1/3

DAVIES--Paul Lewis, Jr. was born in San Jose, California on July 21, 1930 to his parents, Faith Crummey Davies and Paul Lewis Davies. He attended public elementary, middle, and high schools in San Jose, and graduated from Stanford University in 1952. He served in the U.S. Army and then returned to earn his JD from Harvard Law School in 1957. He married Barbara Bechtel in 1955; they had two children, Laura in 1957 and Lew in 1961. He was, above all, a family man, enjoying greatly his children and grandchildren. He also traveled widely, was an avid hunter, and was keenly interested and engaged in public policy and politics. Professionally, he joined Pillsbury Madison & Sutro in San Francisco after graduation from Harvard and quickly achieved prominence in the firms practice; he worked there until his retirement in 1989, serving as General Counsel of Chevron for over five years, during which he led the legal team for Chevrons 1984 acquisition of Gulf, at the time the largest corporate acquisition ever made. He was a valued advisor to many companies, serving as a director of FMC Corporation, Industrial Indemnity, Southern Pacific, and Sumitomo Bank, as well as several private companies. He was also deeply engaged in the community, serving on the boards of the Hoover Institution and the California Academy of Sciences, both of which he chaired; University of the Pacific, Samuel Merritt Hospital, Piedmont Community Church, and the Herbert Hoover Foundation. He was a member and past president of the Bohemian Club, The Pacific-Union Club, and Greenhead Land Company; and a member of many other social clubs. He passed away on November 19, 2014 and was predeceased by his wife of 46 years, Barbara Bechtel Davies, his parents, and his sister, Nancy Davies. He is survived by daughter, Laura Davies Mateo, and son, Paul Lewis Davies III (Pilar); seven grandchildren, Wesley Davies Mateo (Tory), Kenneth Peart Mateo, Robert Hanigan Davies, Gregory Wendell Mateo, Natalie Lynn Davies, Tyler Stephen Davies, and Meredith Mateo; his sister, Judith Davies Washburn, and brother-in-law, Stephen D. Bechtel (Betty), and their families; as well as many other relatives and friends. A memorial service will be held at Memorial Church at Stanford University at 2:00 p.m. on Thursday, December 11, 2014. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Hoover Institution or the California Academy of Sciences. 1/3

COVELL--Julian R.,died suddenly at his home in Rye, NY on November 25 in the presence of his devoted wife, Delphine. He is also survived by his dear sister, Susan Albert and his adored nieces, Dana Neiger and Bari Cessna, all of California. Mr. Covell was a former resident of Brooklyn Heights and the Hamptons. Visitation will take place on Saturday, November 29 at 10am at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580, followed by burial at Greenwood Union Cemetery in Rye. Contributions in his memory may be made to Doctors Without Borders and Save the Children. 1/3

COSTIGLlO--Lawrence U.,98. Died on November 25, 2014. Beloved husband of Isabelle (nee Mahoney), who pre-deceased him. Father of Christina Bernard (Edward), Peter (Barbara), Eugene, Teresa Cantwell (Thomas). Grandfather of nine and great- grandfather of eight. A WW II veteran and a 1941 graduate of Fordham Law School. He worked for many years as Executive Vice President for the Savings Banks Association of New York. He later was a director of the Federal Housing Finance Board. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, Friday, November 28, 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue, New York at 10am, Saturday, November 29. 1/3

RICH--Maryann B. (1958 1996) sculptor, died 18 years ago today from pancreatic cancer. She was possessed of keen intelligence, boundless talent, a delightfully sardonic wit, and a lambent smile. Humanity and the world were robbed of the possibility of all that was to come from this extraordinary human being. I urge of all of those who had the good fortune to study, work with, befriend, know, and love Maryann to join me in making a donation in honor of Maryann's memory to the Skip Viragh Center for Pancreas Cancer of Johns Hopkins, whose groundbreaking research in the development of a vaccine to fight this terrible and insidious cancer, is now in clinical trials. The results are extremely promising. Let us join together and help hasten the demise of pancreatic cancer. Thank you.

Dear sister of Jon and wife Ruth Shavel, Doug and wife Marcie Shavel. Step-sister of Ronnie Shepard, Michael and wife Lauren Shepard. Also survived by sisters-in-law Iris Hudis, Penny Hudis and husband Ira Fink; nieces and nephews Joseph, Gabriella, Aaron, Jacob, Marissa, Julia, Julianne and Devon. Burial will follow at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. The period of mourning will be observed at the Hudis residence in Princeton. RICH--Maryann B. (1958 1996) sculptor, died 18 years ago today from pancreatic cancer. She was possessed of keen intelligence, boundless talent, a delightfully sardonic wit, and a lambent smile. Humanity and the world were robbed of the possibility of all that was to come from this extraordinary human being. I urge of all of those who had the good fortune to study, work with, befriend, know, and love Maryann to join me in making a donation in honor of Maryann's memory to the Skip Viragh Center for Pancreas Cancer of Johns Hopkins, whose groundbreaking research in the development of a vaccine to fight this terrible and insidious cancer, is now in clinical trials. The results are extremely promising. Let us join together and help hasten the demise of pancreatic cancer. Thank you.

YOUNG--Maria-Julia Born November 23, 1939 in Brazil, died in New York on October 11, 2014. Julia was the wife and friend of Phil Young; devoted mother of Beam Laser Spa owners Andrea and Liza Young, devoted mother-in-law of Jeff Fisher, cherished grandmother of Julia and Sofia Fisher. Julia was a dear sister and sister-in-law of Julio (Celina), Eliana (Jacques), Jorge, Orlando, Kica (Horst) and Neusa; aunt to Vanessa, Sandrine, Andre, Serge, Maria-Esther, Alex, Diego, Rafael, Gisela. Julia also leaves many extended family members as well as decades-long friends. Julia was a teacher, but was mostly known for her art, bas-relief wood carvings that hang in various private residences and institutions in Brazil and worldwide. Charismatic and exuberant, Julia was truly selfless and often tended to the needs of others before her own. She will be forever missed. 1/3

TOWNSEND--Kathe Menick. Born to Dr. and Mrs. Frederick Menick. A graduate of Vasser College, social worker, teacher and banker. Beloved mother of Valerie Hansen of Holmdel, NJ and Stephanie McGrory of Menlo Park, CA. Loving grandmother to the Hansen and McGrory children. Loving companion to Robert DiRubio of Holden, MA. STOECKLEIN--David R. 1949-2014. Legendary photographer David R. Stoecklein left his mark on our world in more ways than one. The son of Bernard and Dorothy and brother of Buzzy, Julie, Walter and Debbie Stoecklein, he was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania in 1949. During his early twenties he headed west to pursue his passion for photography. David met Mary Jagger in 1976 and after moving to Sun Valley, Idaho, they married and were blessed with three boys-- Drew, Taylor and Colby. Everyone who knew David also understood that he was completely in love and devoted as a husband, a father and friend to all. David's images dominated the ski and outdoor industry, but his contribution to advertising made him one of the most sought after photographers in the business. He worked with Chevrolet and Jeep to Marlboro and Stetson, Canon USA and Epson, Coca Cola and Bayer to name a few. His passion was in documenting the cowboy way of life and the men and women who knew a thing or two about hard work and making an honest living. David lived by the code of the West. In fact he provided the photographs and publishing for the book Cowboy Ethics. His word was worth gold, and his handshake meant everything. He finished what he started, spoke his peace, but always listened first. He worked hard, played hard, and always made a stranger feel welcome. He was both tough and tender, and his life has inspired countless others. The iconic American Western photographer was much loved and admired for his gregarious character and passion for life. His photographs will forever be a tribute to his talents and his spirit will live on in all those whose lives he graced. He remains legendary. In his honor, Mary and her three sons have established the David R. Stoecklein Memorial and Educational Foundation. It is a charitable organization designed to provide help to causes David cared so much for--such as providing scholarships to aspiring photography students and to helping cowboys and cowgirls in need. The Stoecklein family would like to continue David's legacy of education and generosity for generations to come. Memorial donations in memory of David may be made to the David R. Stoecklein Memorial and Educational Foundation in care of Attorney Brian Barsotti, P.O. Box 370, Ketchum, ID 83340. A celebration of Davids life is being planned for the spring of 2015. www.stoeckleinphoto graphy.com 1/3

He carried himself through life with such grace and dignity, kindness and compassion, brilliance, and wit. "The rest is silence." 1/3

PALMER--Della Marie Critelli, November 27, 1935-- November 23, 2014. Della Marie Critelli Palmer passed peacefully in her home in Essex, Connecticut on November 23rd 2014. She is survived by her husband of 57 years, William L. Palmer, Jr, her brother Frank L (Pete) Critelli of Red Lodge, Montana, her three children: daughter Mary Elizabeth (Betsy) Palmer Post and husband James M. Post of Newtown, Connecticut; son William L. (Tad) Palmer, III and wife Shannon of Newport Beach, California; and daughter Muir Palmer of San Francisco and New York City; and her four grandchildren James M. Post, Lydia M. Post, Adele V. Palmer, and William L. Palmer, IV. She also leaves her faithful golden retriever, Annie. Della was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania on November 27, 1935. Her parents were Frank Louis Critelli and Mary Elizabeth McKillop Critelli. She attended schools in Mount Lebanon, PA and Bucknell University, class of 1957, where she was a member of Pi Beta Phi sorority. Moving to San Francisco with her husband in 1961, they later settled in Newport Beach where they were long-time residents of Lido Isle. Della was very active in National Charity League and, with her husband, in the Newport Harbor and Lido Isle yacht clubs. In recent years she and her husband returned to their long-time summer home in Essex, Connecticut to live full time. Services will be private and in lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Shoreline (CT) Soup Kitchens and the Yankee Golden Retriever Rescue. To share a memory of Della or send a condolence to her family please visit www.rwwfh.com. Services by the Robinson, Wright & Weymer Funeral Home in Centerbrook, Connecticut. 1/3

MANDEL--Katie, passed away peacefully on Tuesday, November 25, 2014 at the age of 72 after a long and courageous battle with Multiple Sclerosis. Born September 18, 1942 and raised in a suburb of Cleveland, Ohio, Katie came to New York City to attend the Tobe'-Coburn School and to pursue a career in the fashion industry. She subsequently worked at the Hemisphere Club and was responsible for Luncheon Club Operations at Rockefeller Center. Soon after her move to New York, Katie met and later married her husband of 50 years, Steve. Her many interests included painting, reading, music, theater and the fine arts. She was particularly passionate about her family and her most precious moments were spent with her children and grandchildren. Katie's courage and determination were truly inspirational as she fought the progressive and debilitating effects of MS. Katie always demonstrated the power of positive thinking and displayed effortless grace throughout her life. She had a terrific sense of humor, an incomparable generosity of spirit and took a sincere interest in others. Anyone who met Katie could not help but be drawn to her. Katie's warmth infused all of our lives and memories of her beautiful smile will be with us forever. Katie is survived by her devoted husband, Stephen; her son, Mark and daughter-in-law, Michele; her daughter, Melissa and son-in- law, John Beaman; and her six grandsons whom she adored. She is also survived by her loving sister, Margaret B. Hannah. A memorial service will be held at 1:30pm on Saturday, December 6, Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Katie's memory may be directed to the Tisch MS Research Center of New York. 1/3

LIGHTFOOT WALKER-- Amber. The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn the passing of Amber Walker, beloved mother of her cherished son Christopher Lightfoot Walker, and widow of Angus Walker. Literature and the literary world played an important role in Amber's life and she generously shared her passion for great literature with new generations. We are deeply grateful for her support and her friendship. Stuart Ellman, President Thomas S. Kaplan, Chairman Henry Timms, Executive Director Catherine Reed, Associate Exec Director Bernard Schwartz, Director, Unterberg Poetry Center 1/3

LIGHTFOOT WALKER-- Amber, 95, passed away peacefully on November 27, 2014 at home. She came to New York from Australia as a bride and quickly embraced her adopted home. She was a woman of impeccable taste and unfailing high standards. Amber was the beloved wife of Angus Lightfoot Walker and the devoted mother of Christopher Lightfoot Walker. Both predeceased her. 1/3

LAWNER--Mordecai, 86, actor, died peacefully on Thanksgiving. He played the father of Alvy Singer, Woody Allen's character in "Annie Hall;" living beneath the Coney Island Cyclone rollercoaster. A member of Actors Equity, SAG and AFTRA. On Broadway, he played Stanley alongside George C. Scott's Willie Loman in "Death of a Salesman." He often shared the stage with his beloved wife Eugenia Thornton, who died in 2005. He continued to perform at Ensemble Studio Theatre. In 1986, The New York Times quoted his advice to a young actor "Do you know what job you signed up for? It's looking for work. If you don't like looking for work, find another job." He is survived by Carol Hershman, Bruce Birnbaum, Francine Falk Ross, Pamela Falk, Deborah Birnbaum, and Sarah and Mitchell Langbert, along with many loving great-nephews and nieces. Memorial service: Saturday, December 6, 4:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street. 212-288-3500. 1/3

KATZ--Paul. September 27, 1957 -November 20, 2014. Deeply mourned by the Wolfsohn family. Our love and condolences to Ziva, Jonathan, Hannah, Walter, Esther and Shmuel. Si monumentum requiris, circumspice. 1/3

HOURWICH--Kennan, died New York City November 26, 2014, age 76. Survived by wife Rolly, stepchildren Willy and Abby, sisters Andria and Abby, brother-in-law Mark and niece Elizabeth. 1/3

HINKSON JACKSON--Mary of New York, 89, passed peacefully November 26, 2014 at home. A renowned beautiful dancer, an extraordinary teacher, a beloved wife, mother, grandmother, sister, cousin, aunt and dear friend, she will be missed by many. In lieu of flowers, donations to: garthfagan.org or to: philadanco.org. 1/3

HERO--Alexander Byron, died suddenly on Thanksgiving Day. He is survived by his parents, Byron and Camille, and sister, Gabrielle. Born March 10, 1991, he was a 2010 graduate of The Hill School, where he was President of the School, winner of the Award for Excellence in Leadership, and Captain of the Varsity Soccer and Baseball teams. He graduated from Amherst College in 2014, where he majored in religion and helped lead the Amherst baseball team to four record-setting seasons. Alexander's life was defined by emotion. He was passionate about sports, fought for fairness and railed against injustice, cherished his many friends and teammates, and, most of all, was lovingly devoted to his father, mother and sister. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held at noon on Saturday, December 6, at The River Club, 447 East 52nd Street, NY, NY 10022. In his memory, contributions to the Alexander B. Hero Scholarship Fund at The Hill School, 717 East High Street, Pottstown, PA 19464, would be welcome. 1/3
HELLER--Evelyn, 90, nee Andrews, died November 24. Survived by Kathryn Heller Schwyzer, Tom, Peter, Christopher Heller and family. 1/3

GOODMAN--Hugh Elder Gardiner, of New Castle, NH, passed away on November 28, 2014, in his 95th year. He was born on May 14, 1920, in Dumfries, Scotland and was raised in the Glasgow suburb of Renfrew. He joined The Royal Navy in 1940, and attended Greenwich Naval College. At sea, he was a navigation officer and was part of British operations in the North Atlantic, Arctic Sea, Mediterranean and the west coast of Africa. He attained the rank of Lieutenant RNVR and left the service in 1946. The same year he emigrated to America and became a US citizen in 1950. He was an advertising executive until retiring in 1982. He is survived by Polly, his loving wife of 68 years (nee Mary Parvin), two daughters, Barrie M. Pickering and Wendy M. Siegfried, both of New York, NY, four grandsons and two great- grandsons. A private memorial service will be held in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Hugh's name to Northern New England Westie Rescue Inc. nnewestierescue.org. 1/3

GOLDEN--Joyce. In the words of Albert Einstein, "A life lived for others is the only life worth living." Joyce Golden was the personification of this. She helped make my life a happy and rewarding one. Her company, her ideas and, above all, her extended hand of friendship made life special for me. Doris Blau 1/3

GOLDEN--Joyce, passed away peacefully at home on November 16 at age 84. A consummate New Yorker, she loved and supported the arts throughout the city and culturally took advantage of the best it offers. Formerly president of Joyce Golden & Associates where her passion for and knowledge of antiques inspired her advertising genius in the field and enriched her life daily. She was most happy when attending the the theater, a classical concert, the opera, ballet or a movie as well as visiting clients when they exhibited at various antique shows. Joyce was a member of many museums where she could be found often. Her kindness and generosity were felt by all who knew her. Joyce most certainly will be missed. Donations in her name may be made to the East Side House Settlement. 1/3

GOLDBERG--Robert I.,Ph.D. passed away on November 25, beloved husband of Leah for 62 years, cherished father of daughter, Marsha, and son, Mark and devoted brother of Harold and sister-in-law Rose. Award winning water- color artist and internationally known industrial designer. Emeritus Professor of Management at St. Francis College, Professor of Art at Pratt Institute, the New School University, and Adjunct Professor of Packaging and Advertising at New York University. Author of over 200 articles in books and business publications, the popular novel, "End Run on Madison Avenue" and a monthly newspaper column in the Berkshires. President of Associated Industrial Designers Inc. for 50 years. International consultant to businesses, governments, and colleges in Europe, the Middle East, China, Russia, South America, and nations in the South Pacific. Funeral Services will be Sunday, November 30 at 11am at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY. Those who would like to donate to a charity in his name or to reach the family please contact Mark: 646-391-5019 or mark.g.goldberg@gmail.com 1/3

GOLDBERG--Jack, beloved husband of Betty Goldberg, father of Dr. Renee JG Arnold and Michael Goldberg, father-in-law of Michael Arnold, and grandfather of Marc Arnold, died November 23, 2014, due to complications from a hip fracture he suffered approximately two months ago. He was born May 10, 1925 in Bronx, New York, attended school in Brooklyn, New York and then graduated from George Washington University School of Pharmacy in Washington, DC, receiving the prestigious Merck award and graduating number one in his class. He and his wife were married for 61 years and have lived in the Saint Petersburg area of Florida for 31 years. He was the consummate professional pharmacist--"Doc" to everyone who sought his advice. His daughter garnered her love of pharmacology from him. He owned his own pharmacy, together with his wife, for approximately 26 years in Silver Spring, Maryland and then again in Glassell Park, Los Angeles, California for three years, before relocating to Florida, where he worked for multiple pharmacy chains in various supervisory capacities. He was an avid tennis player and formidable opponent until about age 75, where he had nicknames such as "get-em-back-Jack" and "crazylegs". His favorite line --nothing ventured, nothing gained --has been a Goldberg family mantra; this simple saying has often borne fruit for the family. Jack was a decorated Veteran with the US Army Air Force, having served during World War II and received the American Theater Service Ribbon, Good Conduct Medal and the World War II Victory Medal. Three words that sum up his life are integrity, honesty and empathy. The Funeral was held on Tuesday, November 25th at 9:30am at David C. Gross Funeral Home, 6366 Central Avenue, St. Petersburg. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that any donations be made in his honor to the US Holocaust Museum. 1/3

GERACI--Madeline J.,of Bronxville, NY, on November 28, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Carl W. Geraci. Loving mother of Joanne Zach, Phillip Geraci, and Christopher Geraci. Devoted grandmother of six. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son, Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY, from 3pm to 7pm Sunday. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Joseph Church, Bronxville, NY, on Monday, December 1 at 10am. 1/3

FROMBOLUTI--Sideo. The artist Sideo Fromboluti passed away Sunday, November 23rd from natural causes. He was 94. He was born in Hershey, PA of Italian immigrants during the Great Depression. He was the first of his family to attend college having won the only scholarship offered by his high school to the Tyler College of Art. He subsequently earned a BFA and Masters degree. He was drafted into the Army during WWII completing his service in Junction City, KS. Always a passionate and accomplished painter, he moved with his wife and fellow artist, Nora Speyer to New York City in 1947. He exhibited his work and was involved with the 10th Street art scene, counting as his friends the artists who were major figures of the Abstract Expressionist movement. He had numerous solo shows, one at the Carnegie Museum of Art in 1998. He was represented by the Darthea Speyer Gallery in Paris, France for many years. He was a founding member of the Landmark Gallery in NYC and the Longpoint Gallery in Provincetown, MA. Both institutions were important to their communities, Landmark Gallery in the early days of SoHo and Longpoint Gallery as a center of the Provincetown art scene. He was a member of the National Academy of Design (NA). He leaves behind his wife of 69 years, Nora Speyer, his two children, Christopher Fromboluti, Iona Fromboluti and grandchildren, Sara Fromboluti and Matthew Fromboluti. 1/3

FISHER--Debra Kram, died November 24, 2014, born April 22, 1946 in Brooklyn, NY, the daughter of Beatrice and Maurice Greenbaum. A graduate of Bennington College, and holder of a Master's Degree in Film from NYU. An award-winning documentary film-maker and pioneering prime time news producer. A supporter of many charities and a champion of the people of Appalachia. Survived by her beloved husband of 40 years, Robert Fisher, her children Daniel (Ashley) Fisher and Elizabeth Fisher, and her grandchildren Cabot Coleman Fisher, Winston Clark Fisher and Burke Samuel Fisher. Services November 26, 2014, 10am at Temple Beth El of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Road, Great Neck, NY. Services handled by Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society. A person of significant accomplishments and strong views; deeply devoted to her husband and family. 1/3

FEUERSTEIN--Albert. The Judges of the Eastern District of New York and the entire Court family are deeply sadden by the loss of Albert Feuerstein, beloved husband of Judge Sandra J. Feuerstein and friend to many in the District. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire Feuerstein family. 1/3

EVERETT--Kenneth Liberty, 84, died in New York City on Thanksgiving Day. He was a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Law School and, for many years, practiced law in New York. He had many friends and many interests. He will be missed. He leaves as a survivor his long- time partner Marie Driscoll. Visitation: Krtil Funeral Home, 1297 First Avenue, between 69th and 70th St. on Monday, December 1, 2-4pm and 6-8pm. Krtil Funeral Home, 212-744-3084. 1/3

DAVIS--John G. of Charleston, SC died Friday, November 21, 2014 surrounded by family and friends. John Gay Davis was born on September 11th, 1936 in Southampton, NY to Dwight Filley Davis Jr and Dorothea Gay Davis. John was educated at the Harvey School and St. Marks School in Massachusetts and graduated from Harvard in 1959, where he captained the baseball team and was an all- American catcher. After graduating from Harvard he was rated top ten on the USA National squash circuit. His passion for racquet sports led him to the International Tennis Hall of Fame where he was the principal designer for the Davis Cup room and eventually became Vice President. It was while in Newport, RI that he undertook the publishing of the America's Cup Magazine. John moved to South Carolina in 1992. He engaged his new community on a philanthropic level for over two decades with the charities Darkness to Light, the Concert Association, Kids with Cameras, and the Miracle League. John started a company called Celebration Books where he created many fine brochures, annual reports for the Fresh Air Fund in New York as well as many other charitable marketing materials, all pro- bono. John was also a Coastal Community Foundation's Malcolm Haven Award for Selfless Community Giving recipient. John is survived by his son and daughter-in-law, Ian and Karen Davis of Bozeman, Montana and their children Hillary, 11, Maggie, 9, and Sophie, 7. 1/3

CUNNINGHAM--Louise Mills, age 91, died peacefully on November 20 at Meadow Ridge in Redding, CT. She was devoted to her family and organized many large family reunions. She is survived by her three sons, Tod, Dudley, and Seth, and three grandchildren, John, Julia and Michael, a daughter-in-law Pamela, Dudley's fiance Margo, her sister Lee, and brothers, Brad and Gordon. Her beloved husband of 67 years, Thomas, died in May 2013. Born in New York City, she attended Greenvale School and graduated from Chapin and Vassar College. In her childhood, always with her large family, she summered in Bar Harbor ME, or in Europe with her grandfather, who was Ambassador to Belgium. She was a member of the Colony Club, Junior League and Bedford Golf and Tennis Club. A longtime resident of Bedford NY, she was a very active member of St. Matthew's Church and officer of the Altar Guild for over 30 years. She was an avid gardener, an early advocate of organic gardening, and an extremely active member of the Bedford Garden Club, being an officer including President for over 30 of 36 years of membership. For her extraordinary inspirational and effective leadership, she was awarded the highly prestigious Medal of Merit by the National Garden Club of America. Her mother, a Vanderbilt descendant, Louise Morris Mills was a founding member of the Girls Scouts of America, and Board member of Engender Health, and her father, Dudley Mills, was President of the Discount Corporation, a firm founded by J.P. Morgan, and was President of the National Audubon Society. With exquisite manners and sense of protocol, she exuded warmth, kindness and constant consideration to all who encountered her. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Friday, December 5 at St. Matthew's Church, 382 Cantitoe St (Route 22), Bedford, NY 10506. 914-234-9636. stmatthewsbedford.org. Louise was a strong advocate for women's education and memorial gifts may be sent to Chapin School, 100 East End Ave., NYC 10028 phone 212-744-2335. Louise Mills Cunningham was Class of 1941. www.chapin.edu 1/3

BRAINERD --Stanford Howard, 83, died in his sleep November 21, 2014 at home in Old Lyme. Loving husband of Wendy Smith Brainerd, admiring brother of Nancy Foltz, devoted father of Elizabeth (Robert), Brooks (Erin) and Charles (Amanda), adoring grandfather of Cecily and James Burge, Lowell and Mallory Brainerd, Malcolm, Annabelle and Fiona Brainerd; loving stepfather to Hilary Hart and Ward Hart and stepgrandfather to Antony, Alexander and Pamela Hart. Stanford was born September 18, 1931 to Howard and Elizabeth Brainerd of Easton PA, graduated from Lawrenceville, Yale and Harvard Business School, served in the U.S. Army and worked as an investment banker starting at Morgan Guaranty Trust Co and retiring from Yamaichi International. Stanford was active, witty and loving to the end. In lieu of flowers gifts may be made to the Middlesex Land Trust. Funeral service will be held 11:00 on Friday, December 12 at St. Anns Episcopal Church in Old Lyme, CT. 1/3

BODOFF--Lippman. May 28, 1930 -November 28, 2014. Retired corporate counsel for Lucent (formerly Western Electric Company) died of cardiac arrest following a long illness. Lippman was born in Brooklyn, eldest of three brothers. He graduated from City College of New York and Yale Law School. Most of his legal career was devoted to preventing the break-up of AT&T. Judge Harold Greene once suggested that Lippmans piece of the case was succeeding. When AT&T voluntarily broke itself up, Lippman went on to study history and literature in graduate school, which led to the publication of his book "The Binding of Isaac Religious Murders and Kaballah..." In addition he served as Assistant Editor of Judiasm Magazine, and lectured on Abraham and Isaac at Bergen Community College Institute for Learning in Retirement. For about 30 years Lippman was a serious amateur Cantor for two different congregations, and widely known as a teacher of his own cantorial style, which incorporated classical historical cantorial literarure with other classical music which illustrated the liturgy. On the lighter end, he directed productions of Gilbert and Sullivan, Fiddler on the Roof, and others for his congregation. Survivors include former wife Joan Krauss, brother Fred Bodoff, children Miriam Ben Yashar (Jerusalem), David Bodoff (Tel Aviv), grandchildren Ken and Adi Ben Yashar, Liam and Noam Bodoff, dearly loved nieces and nephews, and in particular his adored and adoring wife, Psychiatrist Meri Schachter Bodoff. Shiva will be at his home. Funeral Home: Robert Schoems Menorah Chapel, 150 W. State Street, Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ on Monday, December 1, 2014 at 11am. Cemetery: Beth David Cemetary, 300 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY 11003. 1/3

BIENEN--Ronald A.,passed away at the age of 77, on November 23 in Tucson, AZ. Son of the late Herbert and Hortense Bienen. Loving husband of Lynn. Brother of Jane Meshel. Devoted father of James (Polly) and Jonathan (Tracy). Stepfather of Peter (Andrea) and Michael. Grandfather of Owen, Carl Jason, Christopher, and Brandon. Uncle of Dale Bekesha. Graduate of Wharton School of Business and Horace Mann. 1/3

RICH--Maryann B. (1958 1996) sculptor, died 18 years ago today from pancreatic cancer. She was possessed of keen intelligence, boundless talent, a delightfully sardonic wit, and a lambent smile. Humanity and the world were robbed of the possibility of all that was to come from this extraordinary human being. I urge of all of those who had the good fortune to study, work with, befriend, know, and love Maryann to join me in making a donation in honor of Maryann's memory to the Skip Viragh Center for Pancreas Cancer of Johns Hopkins, whose groundbreaking research in the development of a vaccine to fight this terrible and insidious cancer, is now in clinical trials. The results are extremely promising. Let us join together and help hasten the demise of pancreatic cancer. Thank you.
FORD--Shirley R. Dear S, More precious was the light in your eyes than all the roses in the world. Eternal love, Your T. Tony

RYON--Mortimer, of Chestertown, MD, born July 15, 1929, in Scranton, PA, died at home surrounded by family on November 22, 2014. Beloved husband of Sandra L. Ryon, devoted father of Kathleen P. Savageau, Carolyn R. Mayers, Jennifer R. Mazza, Mortimer Ryon, Jr., loving step-father of Katharine C. Gorka, James K. Cornell, Eleanor C. Gottwald, and Andrew H. Cornell, and proud grandfather of 11. He was a graduate of Lawrenceville Lafayette, and Cornell Law School. A funeral service will be held at Emmanuel Church, Chestertown, MD, on December 5th at 11:30am. For those who wish, contributions may be made to Trinity Episcopal Church, PO Box 377, Solebury, PA 18963 or Emmanuel Church, 101 n. Cross St., Chestertown, MD 21620.

PUGH--William Saint Clair 92, passed away peacefully at the Mary Manning Walsh Home on November 22nd after a long illness. He is survived by a cousin, Elizabeth Holsten, a niece, Carla Pugh and nephew, Carl Pugh, as well as a great niece, Jennifer Pugh and a great nephew, Grant Hernandez. Saint graduated from the University of North Carolina, Phi Beta Kappa, with an AB in Journalism in 1942. He served in the Navy during World War II. He came to New York after the war, first working as a model and then in publicity and journalism, spending two years as the Paris rep for Doubleday in the 50s and public relations account executive for Fiat, Vat 69, Harry Winston and Revbekkah Harkness over the next 20 years. In the late 70s, he became the administrative assistant to Liz Smith and retired from that position in the mid 1990s. Saint was the consummate gentleman and will be missed by all who were fortunate enough to know him. A small memorial gathering of family and close friends will be scheduled at a future time.

DETMOLD--John Hunter, died November 9, 2014 in Leeds, MA. Born December 22, 1918 in New York City, John was a lifelong Giants fan, from the Polo Grounds to San Francisco. He had a distinguished career in college development. A wonderful husband and father, he is survived by his wife Bess; his children Michael, Peter, David, Hilary, and Todd; and his former wife Jane Fennelly. Memorial service at Forbes Library in Northampton, MA at 2pm on Sunday, December 14.

BARBER--Marion, Loving matriarch, died peacefully at 93 years of age, surrounded by family and friends on November 21 in Palm Beach, FL. Daughter of Mark and Bessie Isaacs; loving wife to the late Bertram Barber; beloved sister to Renee, Jean and David; doting and cherished step-mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, aunt, great-aunt, and great friend to her devoted caregiver. Fiercely independent with a wondrous, optimistic and energetic heart, an ASID designer, she traveled the world, golfed, and made friends all along the way. As much as we are diminished by her death, we are enriched by her life. Her charm, courage, and warmth of spirit will be greatly missed.

PATTEK--Harold, died peacefully at home on November 27. Born to Martha and Jack on April 15, 1929, Harry was a graduate of Cooper Union, and Yale University School of Fine Arts. He was heralded as a graphic designer in both his own practice, and as a retired professor of graphic design at the University of Massachusetts. He is survived by his loving children, Ezra, Anna Kent, and Simone Ortiz, his adored grandchildren Dillan and Alec Perez, and Mikaela Ortiz, his former wife Nina Pattek, and his beloved, Karen Bush. His passion for his art, adventure, and for capturing life to its fullest was an inspiration to all he touched. Our hearts are broken. 1/3

McNALLY--Rev. Vincent M.,S.J., on November 29, 2014. Loving uncle of Jean McNally of Carlsbad, CA. Reposing at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 E. Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY on Monday, 3-5pm and 7-8:30pm. Funeral Mass in the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 E. Fordham Rd. on Tuesday at 11:30am. Interment at the Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the NY Province, Society of Jesus, 39 E. 83rd St., NY, NY l0028. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors (718)654-0500. 1/3

MARSHALL--Ambassador Anthony Dryden. A very great man has died today. Patterning his life after his beloved grandfather, General John H. Russell, 16th Commandant of the Marine Corps, Tony was first and always a Marine. Tony loved animals as much as people and was a talented wildlife photographer working for both for National Geographic magazine and World Books Encyclopedia in the 1950's and 1960's, an early conservationist, author of seven books and a highly respected three- time United States Ambassador. Tony very much loved his three stepchildren, Arden, Inness and Robert and three step-grandchildren James, Lyon and Weston who showered him with love, affection and respect particularly his stepson Robert with whom he formed an everlasting and most loving bond. During the course of his life, he helped countless young people get their own start in life by introducing them to those who could provide internships or jobs or sometimes he would write a check to tide one over until they could make it on their own. And then he relished in their success. Tony served his country all his life beginning as a young Marine leading his platoon onto Blue Beach on Iwo Jima earning him a Purple Heart, followed by a job as a decoder at the State Department, Consulate General to Turkey stationed in Istanbul, then 40+ years with the CIA and the U.S. Ambassador to Madagascar, the Seychelles, Trinidad and Tobago, and Kenya where he was beloved by President Kenyatta. Until his death, he remained a member of the prestigious Racquet & Tennis Club, The Brook, The Explorers' Club and was Founding Chairman of the Marine Corps University Foundation as well as a recipient of the General John H. Russell Leadership Award. Tony had the tenderest of hearts, a brilliant mind and an outrageous sense of humor. It was my honor to love and be loved so tenderly by Tony for more than 25 years. Semper Fi my Tonyness, Your beloved Charlene 1/3

LEVY--Alan Marcus. Born April 8 1925, Died November 27, 2014. He is survived by his loving wife Alison, his daughter Fiona, his son Ian, his daughter-in-law Michelle and several nieces and nephews. He will be cremated and there will be a private celebration of his life to follow. Any gifts in his memory can be made to the ASPCA. 1/3

Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

LAWNER--Mordecai, 86, actor, died peacefully on Thanksgiving. He played the father of Alvy Singer, Woody Allen's character in "Annie Hall;" living beneath the Coney Island Cyclone rollercoaster. A member of Actors Equity, SAG and AFTRA. On Broadway, he played Stanley alongside George C. Scott's Willie Loman in "Death of a Salesman." He often shared the stage with his beloved wife Eugenia Thornton, who died in 2005. He continued to perform at Ensemble Studio Theatre. In 1986, The New York Times quoted his advice to a young actor "Do you know what job you signed up for? It's looking for work. If you don't like looking for work, find another job." He is survived by Carol Hershman, Bruce Birnbaum, Francine Falk Ross, Pamela Falk, Deborah Birnbaum, and Sarah and Mitchell Langbert, along with many loving great-nephews and nieces. Memorial service: Saturday, December 6, 4:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue, at 81st Street. 212-288-3500. 1/3

KAUFMAN--Caryl Ann, on November 28, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Jack. Devoted mother of Michael, Charles and the late David. Dear sister of Philip and "Ethel". Proud grandmother of Ava Rose, Jack and Will. Reposing at the Martin A Gleason Funeral Home 10-25 150th Street Whitestone, NY. Visiting Sunday and Monday 2-5 and 7-10pm. Service Tuesday 11:00am at the Funeral Home. Funeral Tuesday 11:30am. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park. 1/3

HERO--Alexander Byron, died suddenly on Thanksgiving Day. He is survived by his parents, Byron and Camille, and sister, Gabrielle. Born March 10, 1991, he was a 2010 graduate of The Hill School, where he was President of the School, winner of the Award for Excellence in Leadership, and Captain of the Varsity Soccer and Baseball teams. He graduated from Amherst College in 2014, where he majored in religion and helped lead the Amherst baseball team to four record-setting seasons. Alexander's life was defined by emotion. He was passionate about sports, fought for fairness and railed against injustice, cherished his many friends and teammates, and, most of all, was lovingly devoted to his father, mother and sister. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held at noon on Saturday, December 6, at The River Club, 447 East 52nd Street, NY, NY 10022. In his memory, contributions to the Alexander B. Hero Scholarship Fund at The Hill School, 717 East High Street, Pottstown, PA 19464, would be welcome. 1/3

GOODMAN--Hugh Elder Gardiner, of New Castle, NH, passed away on November 28, 2014, in his 95th year. He was born on May 14, 1920, in Dumfries, Scotland and was raised in the Glasgow suburb of Renfrew. He joined The Royal Navy in 1940, and attended Greenwich Naval College. At sea, he was a navigation officer and was part of British operations in the North Atlantic, Arctic Sea, Mediterranean and the west coast of Africa. He attained the rank of Lieutenant RNVR and left the service in 1946. The same year he emigrated to America and became a US citizen in 1950. He was an advertising executive until retiring in 1982. He is survived by Polly, his loving wife of 68 years (nee Mary Parvin), two daughters, Barrie M. Pickering and Wendy M. Siegfried, both of New York, NY, four grandsons and two great- grandsons. A private memorial service will be held in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Hugh's name to Northern New England Westie Rescue Inc. nnewestierescue.org. 1/3

GOLDEN--Joyce. Christies mourns the passing of our colleague and longtime friend, Joyce Golden, a member of the team which launched Christies saleroom in New York in 1976. Stephen S. Lash, Chairman Emeritus 1/3

DAVIES--Paul Lewis, Jr. was born in San Jose, California on July 21, 1930 to his parents, Faith Crummey Davies and Paul Lewis Davies. He attended public elementary, middle, and high schools in San Jose, and graduated from Stanford University in 1952. He served in the U.S. Army and then returned to earn his JD from Harvard Law School in 1957. He married Barbara Bechtel in 1955; they had two children, Laura in 1957 and Lew in 1961. He was, above all, a family man, enjoying greatly his children and grandchildren. He also traveled widely, was an avid hunter, and was keenly interested and engaged in public policy and politics. Professionally, he joined Pillsbury Madison & Sutro in San Francisco after graduation from Harvard and quickly achieved prominence in the firms practice; he worked there until his retirement in 1989, serving as General Counsel of Chevron for over five years, during which he led the legal team for Chevrons 1984 acquisition of Gulf, at the time the largest corporate acquisition ever made. He was a valued advisor to many companies, serving as a director of FMC Corporation, Industrial Indemnity, Southern Pacific, and Sumitomo Bank, as well as several private companies. He was also deeply engaged in the community, serving on the boards of the Hoover Institution and the California Academy of Sciences, both of which he chaired; University of the Pacific, Samuel Merritt Hospital, Piedmont Community Church, and the Herbert Hoover Foundation. He was a member and past president of the Bohemian Club, The Pacific-Union Club, and Greenhead Land Company; and a member of many other social clubs. He passed away on November 19, 2014 and was predeceased by his wife of 46 years, Barbara Bechtel Davies, his parents, and his sister, Nancy Davies. He is survived by daughter, Laura Davies Mateo, and son, Paul Lewis Davies III (Pilar); seven grandchildren, Wesley Davies Mateo (Tory), Kenneth Peart Mateo, Robert Hanigan Davies, Gregory Wendell Mateo, Natalie Lynn Davies, Tyler Stephen Davies, and Meredith Mateo; his sister, Judith Davies Washburn, and brother-in-law, Stephen D. Bechtel (Betty), and their families; as well as many other relatives and friends. A memorial service will be held at Memorial Church at Stanford University at 2:00 p.m. on Thursday, December 11, 2014. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the Hoover Institution or the California Academy of Sciences. 1/3
LEEDS--Rhoda. June 5, 1921-Dec. 1, 2013. Beloved mother of Douglas and Robert, wife of the late Richard. We miss you Mom

BODOFF--Lippman. May 28, 1930 -November 28, 2014. Retired corporate counsel for Lucent (formerly Western Electric Company) died of cardiac arrest following a long illness. Lippman was born in Brooklyn, eldest of three brothers. He graduated from City College of New York and Yale Law School. Most of his legal career was devoted to preventing the break-up of AT&T. Judge Harold Greene once suggested that Lippmans piece of the case was succeeding. When AT&T voluntarily broke itself up, Lippman went on to study history and literature in graduate school, which led to the publication of his book "The Binding of Isaac Religious Murders and Kaballah..." In addition he served as Assistant Editor of Judiasm Magazine, and lectured on Abraham and Isaac at Bergen Community College Institute for Learning in Retirement. For about 30 years Lippman was a serious amateur Cantor for two different congregations, and widely known as a teacher of his own cantorial style, which incorporated classical historical cantorial literarure with other classical music which illustrated the liturgy. On the lighter end, he directed productions of Gilbert and Sullivan, Fiddler on the Roof, and others for his congregation. Survivors include former wife Joan Krauss, brother Fred Bodoff, children Miriam Ben Yashar (Jerusalem), David Bodoff (Tel Aviv), grandchildren Ken and Adi Ben Yashar, Liam and Noam Bodoff, dearly loved nieces and nephews, and in particular his adored and adoring wife, Psychiatrist Meri Schachter Bodoff. Shiva will be at his home. Funeral Home: Robert Schoems Menorah Chapel, 150 W. State Street, Rt. 4, Paramus, NJ on Monday, December 1, 2014 at 11am. Cemetery: Beth David Cemetary, 300 Elmont Road, Elmont, NY 11003. 1/3
FORD--Shirley R. Dear S, More precious was the light in your eyes than all the roses in the world. Eternal love, Your T. Tony

VARON--Robert Isaac. Born March 11, 1928, died November 27, 2014. He was pre-deceased by his son Samuel and is survived by his daughter Rachel and son-in-law David, his son Maurice (Darlene), his grandchildren Sarah (Jack), Bradley, Lauren (Daniel), Tara (Gregory) Lydia, Alex, his dearest friend Zoila as well as his sister Pauline and many nieces and nephews all of whom will miss him dearly. We will remember the "Mayor of Amsterdam Avenue" whose passion for life brightened the day for so many of his friends. Graveside services were held Sunday, November 30 with his closest family and friends in attendance. 1/3

STOECKLEIN--David R. 1949-2014. Legendary photographer David R. Stoecklein left his mark on our world in more ways than one. The son of Bernard and Dorothy and brother of Buzzy, Julie, Walter and Debbie Stoecklein, he was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania in 1949. During his early twenties he headed west to pursue his passion for photography. David met Mary Jagger in 1976 and after moving to Sun Valley, Idaho, they married and were blessed with three boys-- Drew, Taylor and Colby. Everyone who knew David also understood that he was completely in love and devoted as a husband, a father and friend to all. David's images dominated the ski and outdoor industry, but his contribution to advertising made him one of the most sought after photographers in the business. He worked with Chevrolet and Jeep to Marlboro and Stetson, Canon USA and Epson, Coca Cola and Bayer to name a few. His passion was in documenting the cowboy way of life and the men and women who knew a thing or two about hard work and making an honest living. David lived by the code of the West. In fact he provided the photographs and publishing for the book Cowboy Ethics. His word was worth gold, and his handshake meant everything. He finished what he started, spoke his peace, but always listened first. He worked hard, played hard, and always made a stranger feel welcome. He was both tough and tender, and his life has inspired countless others. The iconic American Western photographer was much loved and admired for his gregarious character and passion for life. His photographs will forever be a tribute to his talents and his spirit will live on in all those whose lives he graced. He remains legendary. In his honor, Mary and her three sons have established the David R. Stoecklein Memorial and Educational Foundation. It is a charitable organization designed to provide help to causes David cared so much for--such as providing scholarships to aspiring photography students and to helping cowboys and cowgirls in need. The Stoecklein family would like to continue David's legacy of education and generosity for generations to come. Memorial donations in memory of David may be made to the David R. Stoecklein Memorial and Educational Foundation in care of Attorney Brian Barsotti, P.O. Box 370, Ketchum, ID 83340. A celebration of Davids life is being planned for the spring of 2015. www.stoeckleinphoto graphy.com 1/3

PEARLMAN--Emily, nee Pletman, 82, died in New York City on November 28, 2014. She is survived by her children, David, Karen and Janet. Mother, potter and political activist, Emily grew up in New York City on the Upper West Side and attended LREI. She earned a degree in economics from University of Michigan where she met and married Leonard Pearlman. They later divorced. During a stay in Japan she fell in love with pottery. While raising her three children, she earned a Masters in Urban Planning from Hunter College. She worked for New York City's Department of City Planning, then took up pottery full time. In 1977 she met her partner-for-life, Chip Greenberg (1920-2010), and shared his love of books and boating. She worked tirelessly for social justice and political change. The world is an emptier place without her. 1/3

WIER--Lewis Edward, of Fairfield, CT, a devoted husband and father passed away on Friday, November 28, 2014 at the age of 85. He was predeceased by his wife Phyllis Wier, his parents, Harry and Helen Wier and his brother, Mel Wier. He is survived by his two children, Sherrie Wier Howey of Scarsdale, New York and Greg Wier of Mason, Ohio, his four grandchildren, Laura Howey, Katie Howey Taylor (Matt), Bradley Wier and Cristina Wier and his son-in-law, Bud Howey and daughter-in-law, Sandra Wier. Ed was a successful business executive working at Procter and Gamble, Playtex, RJ Reynolds and Glendinning Associates. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, December 13, 2014 at 11am at Greenfield Hill Congregational Church, 1045 Old Academy Road in Fairfield, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to The Center for Family Support, 333 Seventh Avenue, 9th floor, New York, NY 10001. 1/3

STRAND--Mark. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our colleague, the distinguished poet. He was a master of the eerie sublime, the magnificent deadpan--a lyric mixture of passion and irony he made entirely his own. 1/3

Graduated St. Catherine's School of Nursing, Brooklyn, NY. She was loved by eight children, Joe Stork of Washington, DC., Gerry Stork of Las Cruces, NM, Mary Ann Stork O'Connor of Hanover, NH, Tom Stork of Asheville, NC, Peter Stork of Basking Ridge, NJ, Richard Stork of Winston-Salem, NC, Rob Stork of Shelburne, NS, and Gretchen Stork of Atlanta, GA, 19 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Funeral Mass at 11am, December 3 at Forest Hills, 4901 Connecticut Ave., NW, Washington, DC. Interment 12pm, December 5 at St. John's Cemetery, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Josephs House, at: www.josephshouse.org 1/3

MELOY--Ada, 64, died suddenly on Thanksgiving. A brilliant, generous, caring person, she leaves her beloved children Austin and Blythe Muller and cherished companion Richard Werber. Ada was General Counsel for the American Council on Education, previously Deputy General Counsel at NYU. A graduate of Wellesley College and NYU Law School, she will be missed by so many whose lives she touched. Visitation Wednesday, December 3rd, 7 to 9pm, Funeral Thursday, December 4th, 10am at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hudson Link for Higher Education in Prison or The Sentencing Project. 1/3

MARSHALL--Ambassador Anthony Dryden. A very great man has died today. Patterning his life after his beloved grandfather, General John H. Russell, 16th Commandant of the Marine Corps, Tony was first and always a Marine. Tony loved animals as much as people and was a talented wildlife photographer working for both for National Geographic magazine and World Books Encyclopedia in the 1950's and 1960's, an early conservationist, author of seven books and a highly respected three- time United States Ambassador. Tony very much loved his three stepchildren, Arden, Inness and Robert and three step-grandchildren James, Lyon and Weston who showered him with love, affection and respect particularly his stepson Robert with whom he formed an everlasting and most loving bond. During the course of his life, he helped countless young people get their own start in life by introducing them to those who could provide internships or jobs or sometimes he would write a check to tide one over until they could make it on their own. And then he relished in their success. Tony served his country all his life beginning as a young Marine leading his platoon onto Blue Beach on Iwo Jima earning him a Purple Heart, followed by a job as a decoder at the State Department, Consulate General to Turkey stationed in Istanbul, then 40+ years with the CIA and the U.S. Ambassador to Madagascar, the Seychelles, Trinidad and Tobago, and Kenya where he was beloved by President Kenyatta. Until his death, he remained a member of the prestigious Racquet & Tennis Club, The Brook, The Explorers' Club and was Founding Chairman of the Marine Corps University Foundation as well as a recipient of the General John H. Russell Leadership Award. Tony had the tenderest of hearts, a brilliant mind and an outrageous sense of humor. It was my honor to love and be loved so tenderly by Tony for more than 25 years. Semper Fi my Tonyness, Your beloved Charlene. The funeral service will be held at St. James Church, Madison Ave. and 71st St., 2pm Thursday December 4th. In lieu of flowers we suggest donations to The Marine Corps University Foundation, PO Box 122, Quantico, VA, 22134 1/3

LEEDS--Gerard. We mourn the loss of Gerard Leeds, a true humanitarian and philanthropist, and extend our condolences to his family. The Board and Staff of North Shore Child & Family Guidance Center 1/3

KURZ--Herbert. Herbert Kurz, founder of Presidential Life Insurance Company, Philanthropist, and Humanitarian died Monday, November 24, 2014. Kurz founded Nyack, NY based Presidential Life Insurance Company. He has received high praise for his business success, philanthropic accomplishments, and humanitarian commitment. Presidential candidate and Senator George McGovern, a friend of Herb, has stated: "Herb is a humanistic, Roosevelt-type Democrat and a committed activist on the war and peace front." "He's a person of deep political convictions, but not in a narrow partisan sense. He's what a businessman ought to be." Kurz was honored by President Bill Clinton at the White House Conference on Corporate Citizenship in 1996. Kurz went on to become the founder of the Kurz Family Foundation through which he endowed a chair in constitutional rights in the political science department of Brooklyn College, his alma matter, and established the Frederic Ewen Center at NYU's Tamiment Library. He also supports numerous organizations in Rockland County, NY, the community where Presidential Life is based. Born in Harlem in 1920 to Max and Molly Kurz, he served in the Army Air Corps during World War II and was a decorated navigator aboard B-26 bombers for his rescue mission over Greenland. He and his wife Edythe moved to Rockland County, NY in the 1950s. He is survived by his son, Leonard, of Piermont, NY; a daughter, Ellen Kurz of Cambridge, MA, and two grandchildren, Tommy Kurz Cosgrove and Sophie Kurz Cosgrove. A service will be held 10am, Friday, November 28 at Temple Beth Torah, 330 North Highland Avenue, Upper Nyack, NY 10960. Donations in his name can be made to the President's Student Support Fund at Rockland Community College, Suffern, NY and the Center for Safety and Change, New City, NY. 1/3

HERO--Alexander Byron, died suddenly on Thanksgiving Day. He is survived by his parents, Byron and Camille, and sister, Gabrielle. Born March 10, 1991, he was a 2010 graduate of The Hill School, where he was President of the School, winner of the Award for Excellence in Leadership, and Captain of the Varsity Soccer and Baseball teams. He graduated from Amherst College in 2014, where he majored in religion and helped lead the Amherst baseball team to four record-setting seasons. Alexander's life was defined by emotion. He was passionate about sports, fought for fairness and railed against injustice, cherished his many friends and teammates, and, most of all, was lovingly devoted to his father, mother and sister. A memorial service celebrating his life will be held at noon on Saturday, December 6, at The River Club, 447 East 52nd Street, NY, NY 10022. In his memory, contributions to the Alexander B. Hero Scholarship Fund at The Hill School, 717 East High Street, Pottstown, PA 19464, would be welcome. 1/3

GOLDEN--Joyce. The Board and staff of East Side House Settlement express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our good friend and supporter, Joyce Golden. Sanchez, Executive Director East Side House Settlement 1/3

ENGEL--Nina Phillips, died peacefully at he age of 100 on Thanksgiving, November 27th, also the birthday of her late husband Louis Engel. The daughter of Dr. John C. Phillips of Boston and Eleanor Hyde Phillips of Bath ME, Nina was born on August 21, 1914, the month made famous by "The Guns of August" at the beginning of World War I. A descendant of a distinguished Boston family, Nina was the quintessential grande dame, but one with as much substance as style. She graduated from St. Timothy's School in Stevenson MD and studied at the Sorbonne and Sarah Lawrence before her first marriage, in 1937, to Stanley Washburn, Jr., an airline pilot. They had three children, Nancy, Nina and Stanley, III ("Brodie"). Nancy, of Gymea Bay, NSW, Australia and Brodie, of Eugene, OR survive her as do four grandchildren and two great grandchildren. She also leaves three stepsons, James (Tucumcari, NM), Thomas (New York City) and Jonathan Engel (Austin, TX). Nina returned to Sarah Lawrence in her 70s to gain her Bachelor's degree in sociology and three years later, at the age of 79, was awarded her Master's degree, also from Sarah Lawrence, in health advocacy. Active in public health her entire adult life she worked in patient screening and advocacy at many hospitals and community organizations, including St. Luke's-Roosevelt, Phelps Memorial Hospital, Westchester County Medical Center, the Ossining Drug Addiction Center and the Ossining Open Door Family Medical Center. Her long life will often be recalled by those she served for her energy in addressing the urgent public health issues of her time and her devotion to the many patients who were lucky enough to come her way. And to her family, her many younger friends and those who knew her best she will be remembered for her steady enthusiasm and sense of fun and for an elegance, ebullience and charm that will outlive her for many, many years. A memorial service will be held at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough NY at a date yet uncertain in the early part of next year. Contributions in Nina's memory may be made to the Open Door Family Medical Center, 165 Main Street, Ossining, NY 10562. 1/3

DUBOWY--Jerome, MD, of Floral Park New York passed away November 30 at age 98. Born in New York City, he graduated from NYU and NYU Medical School. He served in the army medical corp in World War II and was stationed throughout the Pacific Theater. Following the war, he trained as a radiologist and practiced full time until the age of 92, most recently at the Brooklyn Hospital Center. Jerry enjoyed work and travel, and he was family oriented to the core. His wise counsel was often sought. He is survived by his beloved wife of 72 years, Evelyn, three sons, Dr. Alan (Maria), Dr. Ronald (Patricia) and Dr. Earl (Stefania), grandchildren Dr. Rebecca Dubowy Posten, Joel, Brielle Baron, Jenna, Pietro and Allesandro, and great-grandchildren Samuel and Madeline Posten and Zachariah and Zoie Dubowy. Service on December 2, 1:00pm at Temple B'nai Israel, 471 Elmont Road, Elmont. Interment at Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale. Memorial contributions may be made to Temple B'nai Israel. 1/3
FRIEDMAN--Natalie Scharlin Gone a year, but in our hearts every day. We really miss you. Love, Bud, Andi, Nancy, Linda, John & our families

SILVERMAN--Arthur. The employees of Senator Investment Group mourn the passing of Arthur Silverman, beloved father of our managing partner Douglas. We extend our deepest condolences to Arthur's loving wife Sherie, sons Doug and David, daughter Danielle, son-in-law Adam, daughters-in-law Fabienne and Jennifer, and his seven adoring grandchildren. Our thoughts and prayers are with the Silverman family.

SAYPOL--Ronald Deitz, 85, died in Jackson Hole, WY, after many years conquering the seemingly impossible, he died with love in his heart and a fight in his spirit. He is the son of Irving and Adele Saypol. He is predeceased by his twin brother, Roger. He is survived by his long term partner, Florence, sister, Barbara, daughters, Cathy, Amy, Natasha and son, RD. He graduated from Dickinson College and Brooklyn Law. He was President of the Lionel Corporation. Later in Jackson Hole he became a conservationist/developer. He loved people, the outdoors, dogs and food, not necessarily in that order. A teller of stories and a giver of avuncular advice, Ron always made an entrance and exit with his presence being felt wherever he went. Contributions can be made to Jackson Hole Land Trust or the Center of the Arts. A memorial service will be held on January 7, 2015. For more details please email: rememberronsaypol@ gmail.com Florence Lemle

RIO DE JANEIRO — Former President Juan Peron of Argentina flew here today from Madrid in a move to return later to Buenos Aires. But he was taken off the plane by Brazilian soldiers and told he would have to return to Spain. The Brazilian Foreign Ministry said it acted against Mr. Peron ‘‘because Argentina considers him highly undesirable.’’ Mr. Peron had planned to fly on to Montevideo and transfer there to a plane for Asuncion, Paraguay. There were reports that the Spanish state-owned Iberia Airlines had refused to fly Mr. Peron back to Madrid in order to avoid further involvement in the politically controversial case. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Dec. 3, 1964
