WEINER--Edith Axel (Chase), 93 years old died on December 2, 2014. Beloved and devoted wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, sister and friend. Graveside services 2:00pm Wednesday December 3, 2014 at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York. 1/3

WALLIS--Marjorie Bomart. "MBW" as she liked to call herself died peacefully after a short illness, at Southampton Hospital on November 26, just 16 days before her 90th birthday. She lived her life with gusto, enjoying good times and good food, and scores of good friends she made in New York City, Fire Island, Southampton and Puerto Vallarta. Everyone will miss her friendship, wit, intelligence and beauty. MBW was a compassionate and caring psychotherapist, graduating from Hunter College, Case Western Reserve and finishing her training at the Post Graduate Center for Mental Health in NYC. Marjorie will be sorely missed by her beloved daughter, Wendie, her dear sister Shirley Dinitz, and nieces, nephew, and cousins. She also leaves behind her tireless caregivers and friends Karen Flanagan, Ellissa Eleazer, and Sheila Haley, as well as her cherished poodles, Lanna and Ginny. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations in her honor may be made to ARF in Wainscott, NY or The Assistance Fund in Orlando, FL. 1/3

TEIGER--David. The Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art and MoMAPS1 mourn the death of Trustee David Teiger. David joined MoMA's Committee on Drawings in 2001 and became an Honorary Trustee in 2004. He served on the Committee on Painting & Sculpture, Conservation Committee and the Fund for the 21st Century. A member of the Committee on Drawings for nearly 14 years, David was a champion of contemporary drawing, making possible the acquisition of hundred of works on paper by artists such as Paul Chan, John Currin, Peter Doig, Mark Grotjahn, Takashi Murakami, Yoshitomo Nara, Ernesto Neto, Chris Ofili, Elizabeth Peyton, Lari Pittman, Neo Rauch, Jim Shaw and Lisa Yuskavage, among others. Additionally, David was a dedicated and longtime Trustee of MoMAPS1. David's deep and broad devotion for contemporary art and artists made him a leader in our field. Contemporary art was the air he breathed. He loved giving young curators the opportunity to take big risks. His enthusiasm, generosity and passion for collecting will be greatly missed as will his affection for the staff. We extend our deepest sympathies to his children. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art and MoMAPS1 1/3

STORK--Mary Beatrice, nee Killilea, on November 30 in Washington, DC. She was 95. Predeceased by her beloved husband of 61 years, Gerard J. Stork, M.D. Born in Leominster, MA., she was the daughter of Winifred Gallagher and Michael Killilea, and earlier resided in Manhasset, NY and St. Michael's, MD. Graduated St. Catherine's School of Nursing, Brooklyn, NY. She was loved by eight children, Joe Stork of Washington, DC., Gerry Stork of Las Cruces, NM, Mary Ann Stork O'Connor of Hanover, NH, Tom Stork of Asheville, NC, Peter Stork of Basking Ridge, NJ, Richard Stork of Winston-Salem, NC, Rob Stork of Shelburne, NS, and Gretchen Stork of Atlanta, GA, 19 grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Funeral Mass at 11am, December 3 at Forest Hills, 4901 Connecticut Ave., NW, Washington, DC. Interment 12pm, December 5 at St. John's Cemetery, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Josephs House, at: www.josephshouse.org 1/3
SAYPOL--Ron. A man of grace, grit, generosity, and unfailing good humor. And how he loved our dear friend Florence. We will remember him and we will miss him. Becca and Peter 1/3

SATYANARAYANA--Madhu. Loving father, beloved husband, adored son and brother. Died Saturday at age 33. Born in Ft. Worth, TX to Madapura and Bhavani Satyanarayana. Attended Trinity Valley School and Harvard University. Worked at J. Goldman & Co. Survived by his wife, Andrea (Federici) Satyanarayana, two beautiful daughters, his parents and sister. He will be missed. Memorial: Wednesday, December 3, 2pm, Alpine Country Club, 80 Anderson Ave., Demarest, NJ. 1/3

PHELAN--Dorothy Franks, on November 28, 2014. Born September 21, 1926. Dorothy died peacefully in Columbus, OH. She was the beloved wife of the late Francis Phelan and the devoted mother of the late Francis Phelan, 3rd. She is survived by her sisters, Sister Margaret Franks, S.C. Sister Joan Franks, O.P; and brothers, Henry (Jacqueline) and Francis (Judy). Dorothy was born in New York City and lived in Woodside, NY. After retiring from the Equitable Life Assurance, Co., she moved to Winter Park, FL where she was a member of St. Margaret Mary Catholic Church. Family will receive friends at the Kennedy-Roth Funeral Home, 41-45 58th St. Woodside, NY on Thursday December 4 from 2-5 and 7- 9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Friday, December 5 at 10:30am at St. Sebastian Catholic Church. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery. 1/3

MURPHY--Barbara. Barbara Murphy, 62, passed away on November 30, 2014 in Westerly, Rhode Island. She was born March 17, 1952 in St. Louis, Missouri to Dorothy Shapleigh and Dr. John Shapleigh. She is survived by her husband of 31 years, Arthur Murphy of Westerly, Rhode Island, her children, Leigh Murphy and Jake Murphy, both of New York City, her sisters Katharine Kolowich of Concord, Massachusetts and Louise Shapleigh of Ballwin, Missouri, her brother John Shapleigh and his wife Anne of St. Louis, Missouri, her stepmother Mrs. John B. (Kimmy) Shapleigh, and stepsisters Melissa Hummel of St. Louis and Holly Eggert of Boulder, Colorado as well as 22 nieces and nephews. Barbara grew up in Ladue, Missouri and graduated from John Burrough's School in 1970. She graduated from Smith College in 1974. She worked on the staff and eventually served as the Executive Director of The Girls Club of New York from 1976-1980. She received an MBA from Columbia University in 1982. Her career in finance started at Blyth Eastman Paine Webber in New York City and continued in Albany, NY at the New York State Science and Technology Foundation, and finally at Norstar Venture Capital in Albany, NY where she was a partner. Barbara was active in many community service organizations in Albany, NY. She served as President of the Interfaith Partnership for the Homeless. She also served on the board of the New York State Communities Aid Association advocating policies concerning child welfare, infant health and early childhood learning. After moving to Bronxville, NY in 1996, she served as a board member of the Greyston Foundation in Yonkers, NY which provides job training, low-income housing, HIV health care, and childcare to an underserved community. In addition she served on the boards of Community Fund of Bronxville, Eastchester, and Tuckahoe, and the Concordia College Conservatory of Music and Art in Bronxville, NY. Barbara impacted the lives of many family members, friends and business associates. However, her greatest Joy was her children, her face lit up in a way unlike any other in their presence. She brought great intellect and energy to her many endeavors, it was so important for her to reach out to those less fortunate in our community. Barbara did this with a special grace and kindness that preserved the dignity of all those she served. In this way she provided a lesson for us all. There will be visitation at the Buckler-Johnson Funeral Home in Westerly, RI on Friday, December 5, 2014 from 5-8pm and a funeral mass at St. Mary's Church in Stonington, CT on Saturday, December 6, 2014 at 9:30am. Barbara was committed to many charitable organizations big and small but the one closest to her heart was the Greyston Foundation. Donations in Barbara's name can be sent to the Greyston Foundation in Yonkers, NY (greyston.com) or Home and Hospice Care of Rhode Island (hhcri.net). 1/3

MELOY--Ada, 64, died suddenly on Thanksgiving. A brilliant, generous, caring person, she leaves her beloved children Austin and Blythe Muller and cherished companion Richard Werber. Ada was General Counsel for the American Council on Education, previously Deputy General Counsel at NYU. A graduate of Wellesley College and NYU Law School, she will be missed by so many whose lives she touched. Visitation Wednesday, December 3rd, 7 to 9pm, Funeral Thursday, December 4th, 10am at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hudson Link for Higher Education in Prison or The Sentencing Project. 1/3

MENDELSOHN--Richard S. "Dick". On November 29, 2014. Beloved husband of Maryanne, adored father of Michael and Nancy, loving uncle of Bruce (Abby) and Ronald (Cathy) and their children as well as the extended Coleman family. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial service Sunday, December 7th at 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, New York City. 1/3

MAHONEY--Janet F.,died November 29, 2014 after a long illness. She was a resident of Manhasset, NY for 79 years and worked with Hearst publications for 35 years. She will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved her. In lieu of flowers, donations to your favorite animal rescue group would be welcomed. 1/3

MAHONEY--Janet. February 23, 1928 - November 29, 2014. Remarkable friend and caregiver to all living things, whom she now is watching over. Marilyn, Janet W, Frances P, Frannie C, Pam, Pat, Evelyn, Jolanta, Sue, Bob, The Dog Project, and all very grateful dogs, cats and people. 1/3

ENGEL--Nina Phillips, died peacefully at he age of 100 on Thanksgiving, November 27th, also the birthday of her late husband Louis Engel. The daughter of Dr. John C. Phillips of Boston and Eleanor Hyde Phillips of Bath ME, Nina was born on August 21, 1914, the month made famous by "The Guns of August" at the beginning of World War I. A descendant of a distinguished Boston family, Nina was the quintessential grande dame, but one with as much substance as style. She graduated from St. Timothy's School in Stevenson MD and studied at the Sorbonne and Sarah Lawrence before her first marriage, in 1937, to Stanley Washburn, Jr., an airline pilot. They had three children, Nancy, Nina and Stanley, III ("Brodie"). Nancy, of Gymea Bay, NSW, Australia and Brodie, of Eugene, OR survive her as do four grandchildren and two great grandchildren. She also leaves three stepsons, James (Tucumcari, NM), Thomas (New York City) and Jonathan Engel (Austin, TX). Nina returned to Sarah Lawrence in her 70s to gain her Bachelor's degree in sociology and three years later, at the age of 79, was awarded her Master's degree, also from Sarah Lawrence, in health advocacy. Active in public health her entire adult life she worked in patient screening and advocacy at many hospitals and community organizations, including St. Luke's-Roosevelt, Phelps Memorial Hospital, Westchester County Medical Center, the Ossining Drug Addiction Center and the Ossining Open Door Family Medical Center. Her long life will often be recalled by those she served for her energy in addressing the urgent public health issues of her time and her devotion to the many patients who were lucky enough to come her way. And to her family, her many younger friends and those who knew her best she will be remembered for her steady enthusiasm and sense of fun and for an elegance, ebullience and charm that will outlive her for many, many years. A memorial service will be held at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough NY at a date yet uncertain in the early part of next year. Contributions in Nina's memory may be made to the Open Door Family Medical Center, 165 Main Street, Ossining, NY 10562. 1/3

DREWRY--Henry N.,died November 21, at age 90, at home in Skillman, NJ. Pioneering black educator. Founding Director of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation's Mellon Mays Undergraduate Fellowship Program (MMUF), first Director of Teacher Preparation Program at Princeton University. He taught history at Princeton High School and Princeton University, co-authored seven books including "Stand and Prosper: Private Black Colleges and Their Students," (2001) and served on numerous school and college boards. Survived by spouse, Annette Liberson-Drewry, a nephew and two grandnephews. Memorial gathering to be announced. Donations can be made to the United Negro College Fund (UNCF) at 1805 7th Street NW, Washington, DC 20001; the NAACP Legal Defense Fund (LDF) at 40 Rector Street, 5th floor, NYC, NY 10006; and Talladega College, 627 West Battle Street, Talladega, AL 35160. 1/3

BELL--Ellis. May 28, 1923 - November 28, 2014. Ellis Bell, loving husband of Phyllis (died 2013), father of Bob (Eileen) and Ilene (Paul), and grandfather of Daniel and Jeremy Koegel. A man of passion and integrity, his family came first. As a CPA, he built a thriving practice on hard work, strength of character, flexible problem-solving, and sensitivity to how finances are embedded in lives. He was a committed secular Jew and an avid tennis player. A World War II Veteran, he believed in reason, learning, and negotiation; Ellis abhorred war. 1/3

SILVERMAN--Arthur. The employees of Senator Investment Group mourn the passing of Arthur Silverman, beloved father of our managing partner Douglas. We extend our deepest condolences to Arthur's loving wife Sherie, sons Doug and David, daughter Danielle, son-in-law Adam, daughters-in-law Fabienne and Jennifer, and his seven adoring grandchildren. Our thoughts and prayers are with the Silverman family.

SAYPOL--Ronald Deitz, 85, died in Jackson Hole, WY, after many years conquering the seemingly impossible, he died with love in his heart and a fight in his spirit. He is the son of Irving and Adele Saypol. He is predeceased by his twin brother, Roger. He is survived by his long term partner, Florence, sister, Barbara, daughters, Cathy, Amy, Natasha and son, RD. He graduated from Dickinson College and Brooklyn Law. He was President of the Lionel Corporation. Later in Jackson Hole he became a conservationist/developer. He loved people, the outdoors, dogs and food, not necessarily in that order. A teller of stories and a giver of avuncular advice, Ron always made an entrance and exit with his presence being felt wherever he went. Contributions can be made to Jackson Hole Land Trust or the Center of the Arts. A memorial service will be held on January 7, 2015. For more details please email: rememberronsaypol@ gmail.com Florence Lemle

BARTWINK--Theodore S. The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn the passing of Ted Bartwink, former Executive Director and Trustee of the Harkness Foundation for Dance. As a devoted friend and supporter of 92Y, he was the visionary behind the creation of the Harkness Dance Festival and helped ensure 92Y's Harkness Dance Center flourished as a vibrant home for dance. We will miss his dedication and enthusiasm for dance and are deeply grateful for all he did for the community. Stuart Ellman, President Thomas S. Kaplan, Chairman Jody Gottfried Arnhold, Chair 92Y Harkness Dance Henry Timms, Executive Director 1/3

BARTWINK--Theodore S. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Joyce Theater mourn the passing of Theodore S. Bartwink, who served The Joyce for 21 years and, with great devotion, intelligence, and humility, served The Harkness Foundation for Dance and the entire dance community. We will miss him and extend condolences to his wife Barbara. Kerry Clayton, Chair Linda Shelton, Executive Director 1/3

BADILLO--Herman. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Herman Badillo, former Chairperson of CUNY's Board of Trustees. A 1951 graduate of The City College of New York, Mr. Badillo, orphaned in Puerto Rico at a young age, exemplified the power of public education to transform lives of hardship. He graduated from Haaren High School in Manhattan, then magna cum laude from City College before graduating first in his class from Brooklyn Law School and embarking on a long career as a lawyer, accountant, Bronx Borough President, Congressmember and New York City Deputy Mayor among other prominent positions. He served on CUNY's Board of Trustees for a total of 13 years including two as Vice Chairperson and two as Chairperson. With deepest appreciation for Mr. Badillo's numerous contributions to the resurgence of CUNY, we express our sincerest condolences to his wife, Gail, son David, and his extended family. Benno Schmidt, Chairperson James B. Milliken, Chancellor 1/3

BADILLO--Herman, on December 3, 2014. Beloved and devoted husband of Gail. Loving father of David and his wife Millie. Cherished son- in-law. Treasured brother-in- law and uncle. A true champion and pioneer for many. A private service to be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. 1/3
GILLIAM--Jeffrey E. 9/23/82-12/4/84 Love always, Mom

SILVERMAN--Arthur. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Arthur Silverman, beloved father of Douglas Silverman. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Arthur's beloved wife, Sheryl; his children, Danielle Roffman (Adam), Douglas (Fabienne), and David (Jennifer); his sister, Marilyn Berkowitz (Alan); his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO

SAYPOL--Ronald Deitz, 85, died in Jackson Hole, WY, after many years conquering the seemingly impossible, he died with love in his heart and a fight in his spirit. He is the son of Irving and Adele Saypol. He is predeceased by his twin brother, Roger. He is survived by his long term partner, Florence, sister, Barbara, daughters, Cathy, Amy, Natasha and son, RD. He graduated from Dickinson College and Brooklyn Law. He was President of the Lionel Corporation. Later in Jackson Hole he became a conservationist/developer. He loved people, the outdoors, dogs and food, not necessarily in that order. A teller of stories and a giver of avuncular advice, Ron always made an entrance and exit with his presence being felt wherever he went. Contributions can be made to Jackson Hole Land Trust or the Center of the Arts. A memorial service will be held on January 7, 2015. For more details please email: rememberronsaypol@ gmail.com Florence Lemle
STEINBERG--Meyer (Mike), 6/19/19-12/4/03. Missed and loved everyday. Jean, Bonnie, Carol and Lois 1/3

TISSERA--Herbert Winston, of Carmel, NY on November 26, 2014. Beloved husband of Irene. Reposing Harmon Home For Funerals, 571 Forest Ave., Staten Island, NY 10301, Friday 2-4pm and 7- 9pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Saturday, 10am, Blessed Sacrament Church, Staten Island. Interment Silvermount Cemetery. 1/3

TEIGER--David. The Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art and MoMAPS1 mourn the death of Trustee David Teiger. David joined MoMA's Committee on Drawings in 2001 and became an Honorary Trustee in 2004. He served on the Committee on Painting & Sculpture, Conservation Committee and the Fund for the 21st Century. A member of the Committee on Drawings for nearly 14 years, David was a champion of contemporary drawing, making possible the acquisition of hundred of works on paper by artists such as Paul Chan, John Currin, Peter Doig, Mark Grotjahn, Takashi Murakami, Yoshitomo Nara, Ernesto Neto, Chris Ofili, Elizabeth Peyton, Lari Pittman, Neo Rauch, Jim Shaw and Lisa Yuskavage, among others. Additionally, David was a dedicated and longtime Trustee of MoMAPS1. David's deep and broad devotion for contemporary art and artists made him a leader in our field. Contemporary art was the air he breathed. He loved giving young curators the opportunity to take big risks. His enthusiasm, generosity and passion for collecting will be greatly missed as will his affection for the staff. We extend our deepest sympathies to his children. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art and MoMAPS1 1/3
TEIGER--David, died peacefully on November 30, 2014 at age 85. He will be missed by all who knew him. 1/3

STIMMEL--Barry. It is with extreme sadness that we learned of the passing of Dr. Barry Stimmel, one of the founding members of the Sackler School of Medicine New York State/American Program of Tel Aviv University. From his earliest volunteer days in 1976, to the present, where he served as Chairperson of the Board of Trustees, he helped guide this school to a position of prominence in medical education. His contributions to the school and student body were exemplary. He will be very sorely missed. We send our sincere condolences to his wife, Barbara, and the entire Stimmel family. Dr. Stephen H. Lazar Executive Dean Dr. Raymond R. Sackler For the Board of Trustees 1/3

RAZZETTI--Richard A.,of Rye, NY, died in Homestead, FL on November 29, 2014. He was a graduate of Chaminade High School and Georgetown University. Dick and Marlene Schwarz Razzetti were married August 12, 1961. Dick was Georgetowns Athlete of the Year in 1960. He competed in the US Open in 1959, was ranked nationally in the USTA. He and his son Richard were ranked as high as 4th in the National Father and Son Competition in 1988. Dick was a member of the Westchester Country Club, The Union League Club, Talbot Country Club, The Sky Club, Ocean Reef Club and Card Sound Club. He was a partner of Kidder Peabody as well as Senior VP at Paine Webber and UBS. He served on the Board of Governors of the Union League and was a Trustee of the School of the Holy Child in Rye. Surviving family members are his wife, Marlene, their children, Richard Razzetti Jr., Dina Razzetti Clemmer, Douglas Razzetti, his brother Captain Eugene A. Razzetti USN (ret) and his grandchildren Richard A. Razzetti III, Lauren Razzetti, John Clemmer, Lindsey Clemmer and Miles Clemmer. Dick leaves behind many friends who admired his wit, intelligence and his friendliness. There will be a memorial Mass at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, NY at 11:00am Thursday, December 18. In lieu of flowers the family would appreciate donations to the School of the Holy Child in Rye, NY. 1/3

PALMER--Lynne, of Sleepy Hollow, NY on December 2. Born and raised in New York City. Founder and longtime owner of Lynne Palmer Executive Recruitment Inc. and the Lynne Palmer Agency, a publishing search firm. Former board member Association of Personnel Consultants of New York (APCNY), 3- time recipient of APCNY's Best in Advertising award and Annual Overall Excellence award. Her agency was referred to by the New York Times as the gateway to careers in the New York publishing world. Following retirement, Lynne mentored young people looking to advance their careers and, as a longtime member of Alcoholics Anonymous, worked with recovering alcoholics. After retirement she attended and subsequently endowed a scholarship fund at Sarah Lawrence College. Former Board member of Westchester SPCA. Survived by a number of good friends. Donations in Lynne's memory may be made to Westchester SPCA, Briarcliff, NY. 1/3

MARCUS--Bruce W. Died December 1, 2014, at age 89. He was the founder of the renowned MarcusLetter.com and author of many books on professional services marketing. A resident of Branford, CT, he was the son of Pauline and Louis Marcus; beloved husband of wife Mana; father of David, Michael, Jonathan, Joseph, Lucy; grandfather of Maree, Ariel, Robert, Samantha, Rebecca, Leah, Benjamin, and Max; and great- grandfather of Tait. Bruce was a graduate of The New School of Social Research. 1/3

MENDELSOHN--Richard S. "Dick". On November 29, 2014. Beloved husband of Maryanne, adored father of Michael and Nancy, loving uncle of Bruce (Abby) and Ronald (Cathy) and their children as well as the extended Coleman family. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Memorial service Sunday, December 7th at 3:30pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St, New York City. 1/3

MALIN--Irving. On December 3 the Viking of the printed page sailed away from home, age 80. Professor Emeritus, CCNY. Stanford PhD (at age 24) by way of Thomas Jefferson High School, Jamaica High School and Queens College. Brilliant, fearless literary critic; wise- cracking, soft-spoken recluse, generous patron of periodicals and foundations. Championed neglected, new and off beat writing. Won time at Yaddo and Huntington Library. Author of books on Faulkner, Bellow, Styron, Capote and others. Co-editor of books on Pynchon,Gass, Garrett, and others. Prolific reviewer. Unforgettable character who never learned to swim, type, drive or tie his shoes properly. Survived by wife Ruth Lief Malin, son Mark Charles (Rina) Malin, grandson Andrew, Charles and James, daughter Leila Chintaman, sister-in-law Nancy Kelley Hunter, son in spirit Rodney Ramirez, good friend Nicholas Birns, dedicated aides Tajewattie Bridgepaul and Shelly Ann Robinson, and devoted physician William M. Duke, MD. Funeral 10:30am 12/5/2014, Schwartz Brothers- Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills, New York 11375. (718) 263 7600. 1/3

MAHONEY--Janet. February 23, 1928 -November 29, 2014. Remarkable friend and caregiver to all living things, whom she now is watching over. Mass for Janet on Friday, December 5th, 1pm at St. Mary's Church, Northern Blvd., Manhasset. Marilyn, Janet W, Frances P, Dana, Jeannie, Frannie C, Pam, Pat, Evelyn, Jolanta, Sue, Bob, The Dog Project, and all very grateful dogs, cats and people. 1/3

LIVINGSTON--William Curtis III. Of Nantucket and New York City died December 2, 2014 of pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his son, William Livingston IV, daughter, Molly L. Paiement and their children, William and Elizabeth Livingston and Morgan and Posey Paiement. His sister, Ann Wainscott, also survives. His wife of 40 years, Pamela, predeceased him in 2010. Curt's business career was in the investment management world. He managed institutional fixed-income portfolios at the Ford Foundation and Fischer Francis Trees and Watts, both in NYC, and at Fidelity Investment Management Services in Boston. As chairman and CEO of Western Asset Management, Pasadena CA, he helped define and build-out the model for independent institutional international fixed-incomemanagement firms. Western Asset grew much larger and broader under his leadership and, more than 10 years after his retirement, remains one of the major global firms in its business. His avocation was financial management at not-for-profits and he served for a number of years in various financial leadership roles for the Los Angeles Philharmonic Association, Third Street Music School Settlement, NYC, the League of American Orchestras, NYC and the Nantucket Atheneum. He was also a long- standing director of Legg Mason Inc. and served as chair of the Trustees of Reservations Nantucket Committee and of the Collections Committee of the Smithsonian National Postal Museum. He had also been a board member of the Theatre Workshop of Nantucket and of the Nantucket Arts Council and a member of the Wauwinet Yacht and Westmoor Clubs. He was a world traveler, having visited all seven continents and more than 80 countries. He loved his family, his friends, design, gardening, color and life in general. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Nantucket Atheneum, One India Street, Nantucket 02554 or the Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 East 11th Street, New York 10003. 1/3

KARP--Justin, 94, on December 2 in Boynton Beach, FL. Born in New York City, he earned his B.S. in 1940 and M.S. in chemical engineering in 1942 from New York University. He became one of the youngest scientists working on the Manhattan Project, at Columbia University and Argonne National Laboratory. He spent the rest of his long career working to further the peaceful and safe use of nuclear energy and other alternative energy sources. Married for 67 years, he adored his wife, the former Gloria Spielberger, three children: Judith Kurnick of Houston, Ellen (James) Markus of Dallas, Eric (Betsy Weiser) Karp of Scarsdale; seven grandchildren, and their spouses, who treasured his warmth, gentle wit, intellect, and musical talent on the piano. Services will be at 11am Westchester Reform Temple Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Union of Concerned Scientists, 2 Brattle Square, Cambridge, MA 02138 or the National Cancer Institute. 1/3

DRISCOLL--Marguerite, 102, nee Marshall, passed away peacefully on November 30, 2014. A graduate of Brooklyn College (1933) and retired teacher of English with the NY Department of Education. Beloved wife of late Daniel, devoted mother of Marguerite (Don), Connor and Clare Jordan (Warren). Loving grandmother of Gregory, Matthew, Connor, Kathleen Senituli and Julia Jordan. Adoring great-grandmother of Benjamin, Duncan, Danielle, Scarlett, Leilani, Jeremiah. Visiting Friday 2-4 & 6-8 PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 10 AM at St. Ephrem R.C. Church. 1/3

BARTWINK--Theodore S.,86 - The Harkness Foundation for Dance deeply mourns the passing of its longtime beloved Executive Director and Trustee Ted Bartwink. A graduate of Long Island University and Brooklyn Law School, he accepted a position as business manager for Rebekah Harkness and assisted in establishing the Foundation, which he led from 1968 until his retirement last year in significant projects and grant making to support the dance field. During his tenure, he oversaw operations of the Harkness Ballet, the Harkness Theatre, and Harkness House for Ballet Arts, and initiated programs such as the Harkness Center for Dance Injuries at NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases, and the 92Y Harkness Dance Festival. He was a board member of the Joyce Theater Foundation and board president of the Early Stages Program for Children of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theatre and Broadcasting; held numerous dance organization advisory board positions; and was a member of the National Association of Schools of Dance and the League of American Theaters and Producers. Mr. Bartwink received honors from Ballet Hispanico, the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Career Transition for Dancers, the Dance Library of Israel, the 92nd Street Y, and NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases, and will be honored by Dance Theatre of Harlem in February. The Foundation extends sincerest condolences to Ted's wife Barbara and his family. His wisdom, humor, kindness and dedication to the dance art form will be profoundly missed. Funeral services will be held Thursday, December 4 at 1:00pm, Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel in Forest Hills, Queens, 114-03 Queens Boulevard. William A. Perlmuth, Chairman Jody Gottfried Arnhold and Etta Brandman, Trustees Joan Finkelstein, Executive Director 1/3

BARTWINK--Theodore S. The entire New York City Center family extends our heartfelt sympathies at the passing of Ted Bartwink. Ted was a lifelong champion of dance and the arts. Through his leadership of The Harkness Foundation for Dance, he made an indelible impact not only on City Center's dance and education programs, but on the entire dance community of New York City. Our staff and Board of Directors join his wife and family in mourning the loss of this great and generous man. Ted's warmth, wisdom, and commitment will be deeply missed. 1/3

The Guggenheim Abu Dhabi will be 12 times the size of the landmark Guggenheim museum in New York. To fill it with art, the curators first plan out the space with scaled-down models and tiny silver people.
The architect Frank Gehry talks about his asymmetrical design for the planned 450,000-square-foot Guggenheim Abu Dhabi and his inspiration for the museum’s huge, cooling cones.

Reem Fadda, an associate curator, says that while there are institutions that honor Arab and Middle Eastern art, the Guggenheim Abu Dhabi will place the work of Arab artists side by side with that of their international counterparts.

2015 is still ours to see any way we want to, so enjoy it while you can.

WILMOT--Irvin G. Irvin G. Wilmot, chief executive and administrator of NYU Medical Center (1961-1981), passed away on November 22, 2014. He was 92. Irv served the hospital and health care administration field with a lifetime of extraordinary leadership, innovation and contributions delivered with a keen intelligence, sparkling humor, a genuine kindness and interest in every person he met. He possessed an ability to quickly envision essentials, foresee creative solutions and bring them into existence. With an acute perception of others' talents, he provided an incubator for great managers. A true gentleman, in his career and throughout his life this quality of kindness, care and respect for others was always present. He held senior executive management positions at the University of Chicago Hospitals and Clinics, New York University Medical Center, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New York and Montefiore Medical Center during his 38 years in hospital and health care administration. While chief executive of University Hospital in New York, it evolved into a major teaching facility of New York University. Among countless contributions, he smoothly moved the Post Graduate Hospital into the new University Hospital building on First Avenue in 1963. He originated the Cooperative Care concept for inpatients, and built the first 100-bed facility in the nation. His emphasis on patient education and family involvement resulted in charges 40% below average, provided an element of care only a loved one can give, and strengthened family relationships. Its unqualified success received national and international acclaim and resulted in eighteen more Cooperative Care facilities across the country. Throughout his career he actively participated in local, state and national health associations and forums including the N.I.H. General Clinical Research Centers Committee, the Liaison Committee on Graduate Education (A.C.G.M.E.), and the New York State Hospital Review and Planning Council. He was chairman of the Greater New York Hospital Association, the Hospital Association of New York State, and the Council of Teaching Hospitals of the AAMC and was a director of the New York Blood Center, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York and the American Hospital Association. Mr. Wilmot was a Life Fellow of The American College of Healthcare Executives and a Professor of Health Care Management at New York University. Born in Nanking China on June 30, 1922, and raised in California, he was the son of Dr. Frank A. Wilmot and Ethel Ranney Wilmot, missionaries who built the Drum Tower Hospital in China which still operates today. He served in the US Navy from 1940-1946 as an Aviation Chief Machinists Mate. A graduate of Northwestern University (1955) he held a Master's degree in Business Administration from the University of Chicago (1957). Beloved and devoted husband and father he married his life's partner of 69 years Dorothy Agnes Wilmot on February 6, 1943. Residents of Rye, NY for 50 years, Irv and Dorothy (who passed in March 2012) were the love of each other's lives, true partners, devoted parents and keen world travelers. Irv was an avid golfer, and enjoyed some painting and sculpting in retirement years. A gifted architect, he created solutions for anything needed at home. Together they raised two children who survive them: Marcia B. Wilmot of Port Washington, NY and David M. Wilmot of Las Vegas, NV. Also surviving are two nephews, Stephen Warshauer of Manning, SC and Michael Warshauer of Bend, OR. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580, on Saturday December 6, 2014 from 9am to 12:30pm. A religious service will be held there at 12:30pm with interment to follow at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to the Raymond E. Brown Endowment in Health Administration Studies, The University of Chicago, School of Social Service Administration, 969 East 60th Street, Chicago, Illinois 60637, Attn: Steve Gilmore. 1/3

WHITE--Arden James, 89, died in Riverdale on December 1, 2014. Adored mother of Eliot, Penelope, and Richard Rowlands; beloved grandmother of four. Funeral at St. James's, 865 Madison Ave., New York, on Tuesday at 10am. In lieu of flowers, a donation to the Humane Society or the Hunter College Mother's Day Scholarship Fund. 1/3

WELLS--Jean Burchell, 87, of North Palm Beach and St. Louis, died peacefully at home on November 30. She loved her family, music, travel, singing and dancing. She was born in Malone, NY, graduated from St. Lawrence University, and worked at Young and Rubicam in New York City. She met Wayne Wells, her husband of 58 years, in New York; he predeceased her last year. She is survived by her children Jeffrey (Serena) of New Canaan, Linda of Manhattan, Jennifer of Novato CA, and David (Anne) of Darien, along with eight grandchildren. A memorial service will take place at St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Palm Beach Gardens, FL on January 2. 1/3

WEISS--Jo Ann. Passed away in a peaceful sleep Monday December 1st, 2014. Adoring husband of Nathan Weiss. Loving mother of Leslie and husband Michael, and Stephanie and husband Wayne. Loving grandmother of Roni, Russell, Racquel, R.J. and Vanessa. She also had a special place in her heart for her extended family. The sons of Nathan, Larry and his wife Melissa and Alan and his wife Kim, and their children Hannah, Isabella, Zachary, Max and Gabriel. Jo Ann was the most giving of individuals and faced whatever she encountered with optimism. She had a special place in her heart for a group of women named The Owls. Who played golf for years in Boca West and were always caring for each other. Jo Ann graduated from Boston University with a B.A. and had a Masters Degree from Hofstra in Reading. She was employed for over 20 years with AHRC on Long Island. Her final position was the Director of Vocational training services. She will be missed by everyone that met her. 1/3

STIMMEL--Barry, MD. We, at the Mount Sinai Health System, are profoundly saddened by the passing of our longtime colleague and friend, Barry Stimmel, MD, former Dean for Graduate Medical Education, Ombudsperson, and Dean Emeritus for Medical Education at the Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai. He also served as the Katherine and Clifford Goldsmith Professor of Medicine (Cardiology) at the Zena and Michael A. Wiener Cardiovascular Institute at Mount Sinai. During Dr. Stimmel's 50 years of service at Mount Sinai, he played a pivotal role in developing our medical school curriculum. He was a leader in internal medicine and cardiology, and internationally acclaimed for his pioneering work in the field of addiction medicine, having founded and led Mount Sinai's former Narcotics Rehabilitation Center, the first program in New York City to use methadone solely in an ambulatory care setting, which became a model treatment program for New York State. He is the author of eight books, numerous book chapters, and more than 140 articles, and was a frequent lecturer. Mount Sinai is grateful for his outstanding leadership, dedication, and passion. We extend our deepest condolences to Dr. Stimmel's wife Barbara, his sons, Alexander and Matthew, his extended family, friends, and colleagues. Peter W. May, Chairman Boards of Trustees Mount Sinai Health System Kenneth L. Davis, MD Chief Executive Officer and President Mount Sinai Health System Dennis S. Charney, MD Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai President for Academic Affairs Mount Sinai Health System Valentin Fuster, MD, PhD Director, Mount Sinai Heart Physician-in-Chief The Mount Sinai Hospital 1/3

TEIGER--David. The Trustees and Staff of The Museum of Modern Art and MoMAPS1 mourn the death of Trustee David Teiger. David joined MoMA's Committee on Drawings in 2001 and became an Honorary Trustee in 2004. He served on the Committee on Painting & Sculpture, Conservation Committee and the Fund for the 21st Century. A member of the Committee on Drawings for nearly 14 years, David was a champion of contemporary drawing, making possible the acquisition of hundred of works on paper by artists such as Paul Chan, John Currin, Peter Doig, Mark Grotjahn, Takashi Murakami, Yoshitomo Nara, Ernesto Neto, Chris Ofili, Elizabeth Peyton, Lari Pittman, Neo Rauch, Jim Shaw and Lisa Yuskavage, among others. Additionally, David was a dedicated and longtime Trustee of MoMAPS1. David's deep and broad devotion for contemporary art and artists made him a leader in our field. Contemporary art was the air he breathed. He loved giving young curators the opportunity to take big risks. His enthusiasm, generosity and passion for collecting will be greatly missed as will his affection for the staff. We extend our deepest sympathies to his children. The Board of Trustees of The Museum of Modern Art and MoMAPS1 1/3

ROSS--Julius L.,82, died peacefully on December 4th, 2014. Born in the Bronx, Jules was a proud graduate of Columbia University, retired Air Force officer, avid sports fan, and voracious reader. Following a successful business career, Jules devoted his time to reading, playing bridge, attending Torah study, and enjoying the company of his wife, family and friends. Jules leaves behind his wife of 36 years, Carole; three beloved children, Jennifer (Michael), Peter (Barbra) and David (Jessica); five grandchildren Larry, Josh, Steven, Jacob and Susanna; and his brother David Rosensweig. Services will be held at Temple Israel, 112 East 75th St., at 12pm today. 1/3

ROSS--Jules. The Officers and Clergy of Temple Israel of the City of New York mourn the passing of long- time member Jules Ross. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Andrew Hoffman, President David J. Gelfand, Rabbi 1/3

PALMER--Lynne, of Sleepy Hollow, NY on December 2. Born and raised in New York City. Founder and longtime owner of Lynne Palmer Executive Recruitment Inc. and the Lynne Palmer Agency, a publishing search firm. Former board member Association of Personnel Consultants of New York (APCNY), 3- time recipient of APCNY's Best in Advertising award and Annual Overall Excellence award. Her agency was referred to by the New York Times as the gateway to careers in the New York publishing world. Following retirement, Lynne mentored young people looking to advance their careers and, as a longtime member of Alcoholics Anonymous, worked with recovering alcoholics. After retirement she attended and subsequently endowed a scholarship fund at Sarah Lawrence College. Former Board member of Westchester SPCA. Survived by a number of good friends. Donations in Lynne's memory may be made to Westchester SPCA, Briarcliff, NY. 1/3

KNAPP--Dr. Richard, MD. October 17, 1933 to November 29, 2014. Dr. Knapp was the son of the late Hilda and Jack Knapp of New York City. He is survived by Harriett Knapp, RN, his wife of 61 years; his daughters Carolyn Green, RN, and Pamela Townsend Jenkins, PE, grandchildren Leah Townsend and Charles Townsend, all of North Carolina; son, Dr. Benjamin Knapp, Ph.D. of Blacksburg, VA; brother, Dr. Robert Knapp, MD of NYC and Florida. He is preceded in death by his daughter Laurie. Richard graduated from Columbia College, New York Medical College, and completed his residency in anesthesia at Cornell-New York Hospital. His distinguished medical career included Professor and Chairman of Anesthesiology at West Virginia University Medical Center. Richard served throughout his life in many ways. He was a Medical Naval Officer in the Cuban Missile Crisis. He and Harriett started, and maintained for 13 years, a medical program on the Caribbean island of Barbuda. Richard was the author of: "The Gift of Surgery to Mankind: A History of Modern Anesthesiology." He enjoyed teaching medical students, residents and other physicians for which he received the Distinguished Alumni Medal from New York Medical College. Richard loved to travel with Harriett. A sports enthusiast, he was an avid Yankees, Indianapolis Colts, and West Virginia University athletics fan. Richard enjoyed his retirement years with the wonderful Woodland Terrace Community. Burial will be in New York. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the Lymphoma and Leukemia Society. 1/3

KARP--Justin, 94, on December 2 in Boynton Beach, FL. Born in New York City, he earned his B.S. in 1940 and M.S. in chemical engineering in 1942 from New York University. He became one of the youngest scientists working on the Manhattan Project, at Columbia University and Argonne National Laboratory. He spent the rest of his long career working to further the peaceful and safe use of nuclear energy and other alternative energy sources. Married for 67 years, he adored his wife, the former Gloria Spielberger, three children: Judith Kurnick of Houston, Ellen (James) Markus of Dallas, Eric (Betsy Weiser) Karp of Scarsdale; seven grandchildren, and their spouses, who treasured his warmth, gentle wit, intellect, and musical talent on the piano. Services will be at 11am Westchester Reform Temple Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Union of Concerned Scientists, 2 Brattle Square, Cambridge, MA 02138 or the National Cancer Institute. 1/3

GRIDLEY--William G.,died November 29, age 85, at home in Norfolk, CT. Survived by wife of 60 years, Barbara G. Gridley; children, Katharine M. and William W. Gridley and spouses; four grandchildren. Attended St. Bernards School, Phillip Exeter Academy and Yale. Supporter of civil rights; vice chairman, board of Tuskegee University, Tuskegee, AL. An investment banker, worked at Chase Manhattan Bank, then American Express International Bank. Managed investments for Olayan Group, president of Brandywine Investors. Interests: art, literature, music, geography, science, the outdoors. Trustee of the Ellen Battell Stoeckel Estate, home of the Yale Summer School of Music and Art. Memorial service: January 10, 2015, 11am, Church of Christ Congregational, Norfolk, CT. 1/3

DRISCOLL--Marguerite, 102, nee Marshall, passed away peacefully on November 30, 2014. A graduate of Brooklyn College (1933) and retired teacher of English with the NY Department of Education. Beloved wife of late Daniel, devoted mother of Marguerite (Don), Connor and Clare Jordan (Warren). Loving grandmother of Gregory, Matthew, Connor, Kathleen Senituli and Julia Jordan. Adoring great-grandmother of Benjamin, Duncan, Danielle, Scarlett, Leilani, Jeremiah. Visiting Friday 2-4 & 6-8 PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Ave., Brooklyn. BARTWINK--Theodore S.,86 - The Harkness Foundation for Dance deeply mourns the passing of its longtime beloved Executive Director and Trustee Ted Bartwink. A graduate of Long Island University and Brooklyn Law School, he accepted a position as business manager for Rebekah Harkness and assisted in establishing the Foundation, which he led from 1968 until his retirement last year in significant projects and grant making to support the dance field. During his tenure, he oversaw operations of the Harkness Ballet, the Harkness Theatre, and Harkness House for Ballet Arts, and initiated programs such as the Harkness Center for Dance Injuries at NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases, and the 92Y Harkness Dance Festival. He was a board member of the Joyce Theater Foundation and board president of the Early Stages Program for Children of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theatre and Broadcasting; held numerous dance organization advisory board positions; and was a member of the National Association of Schools of Dance and the League of American Theaters and Producers. Mr. Bartwink received honors from Ballet Hispanico, the Brooklyn Academy of Music, Career Transition for Dancers, the Dance Library of Israel, the 92nd Street Y, and NYU Hospital for Joint Diseases, and will be honored by Dance Theatre of Harlem in February. The Foundation extends sincerest condolences to Ted's wife Barbara and his family. His wisdom, humor, kindness and dedication to the dance art form will be profoundly missed. William A. Perlmuth, Chairman Jody Gottfried Arnhold and Etta Brandman, Trustees Joan Finkelstein, Executive Director 1/3

BARTWINK--Theodore S. The entire New York City Center family extends our heartfelt sympathies at the passing of Ted Bartwink. Ted was a lifelong champion of dance and the arts. Through his leadership of The Harkness Foundation for Dance, he made an indelible impact not only on City Center's dance and education programs, but on the entire dance community of New York City. Our staff and Board of Directors join his wife and family in mourning the loss of this great and generous man. Ted's warmth, wisdom, and commitment will be deeply missed. 1/3

BARTWINK--Ted. The NYU Langone Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Hospital for Joint Diseases administration and the Harkness Center for Dance Injuries mourn the loss of Ted Bartwink, longtime executive director of the Harkness Foundation for Dance. We remember Ted for his compassion, friendship and support for the Harkness Center over the past 25 years. He will be profoundly missed by the entire Harkness Center for Dance Injuries' staff and the dance community at large. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Barbara, and his family. Joseph Zuckerman, MD, Chair of the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, NYU Langone Medical Center Donald Rose, MD, Founding Director, Harkness Center for Dance Injuries David Dibner, Senior Vice President Hospital for Joint Diseases, Musculoskeletal and Rusk Rehabilitation 1/3

BARTWINK--Theodore S. The 92nd Street Y Board and staff mourn the passing of Ted Bartwink, former Executive Director and Trustee of the Harkness Foundation for Dance. As a devoted friend and supporter of 92Y, he was the visionary behind the creation of the Harkness Dance Festival and helped ensure 92Y's Harkness Dance Center flourished as a vibrant home for dance. We will miss his dedication and enthusiasm for dance and are deeply grateful for all he did for the community. Stuart Ellman, President Thomas S. Kaplan, Chairman Jody Gottfried Arnhold, Chair 92Y Harkness Dance Henry Timms, Executive Director 1/3

BARTWINK--Theodore S. Career Transition For Dancers Board of Directors, staff, patrons, friends, volunteers and our more than 6,400 dancer-clients nationwide mourn the loss of our dear friend and advocate. Our deepest condolences to his beloved wife Barbara, the Bartwink family, and the Trustees of the Harkness Foundation for Dance. Career Transition For Dancers Angela Lansbury, Honorary Chairwoman Cynthia G. Fischer, Chairman Alexander J. Dube, President 1/3

BARTWINK--Theodore S. The Board and staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts are saddened by the passing of Theodore (Ted) Bartwink, a towering figure in the New York dance world. He and the Harkness Foundation for Dance, which he led for 45 years, were committed supporters of dance at Lincoln Center. The loss of his wisdom and enthusiasm leaves a void, but his legacy--professional and personal--will remain. We extend our sympathies to his wife Barbara, his family, and the Board and staff of the Harkness Foundation at this sad time. Katherine Farley, Chair Jed Bernstein, President Nigel Redden, Director, Lincoln Center Festival Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts 1/3

BARTWINK--Theodore S. The New York City Ballet family mourns the passing of Ted Bartwink. The dance community has lost an irreplaceable spirit and we are grateful for the many years we were fortunate to know him as a benefactor, advocate and, most of all, dear friend. His joyful and lively presence will be missed more than words can say. Our hearts go out to Barbara and his family. 1/3

BADILLO--Herman. The Brooklyn Law School community mourns the loss of political giant and trailblazer Herman Badillo, Class of 1954. Mr. Badillo held longstanding ties to Brooklyn Law School. He was valedictorian of his class, awarded numerous prizes for his academic talents, was the student Commencement Speaker, and a member of the Law Review. He served as a member of the Board of Trustees for nearly 20 years, from 1994 to January 2014, adding immeasurably to the Law School's progress during this period. A civil rights champion, Mr. Badillo was the nation's first Puerto Rican-born Congressman, as well as the first Puerto Rican City Commissioner and Bronx Borough President. In addition to serving four terms in Congress, his rich career in politics also included serving as Deputy Mayor for Management and Deputy Mayor for Policy under Ed Koch, and later serving Mayor Rudolph Giuliani as Special Counsel for the Fiscal Oversight of Education. He was a true public service icon and will be missed greatly, but his legacy is enduring. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Gail, his son, David, and the entire family. Stuart Subotnick, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Nicholas W. Allard, President Joseph Crea, Dean 1/3

BARTWINK--Theodore S. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Joyce Theater mourn the passing of Theodore S. Bartwink, who served The Joyce for 21 years and, with great devotion, intelligence, and humility, served The Harkness Foundation for Dance and the entire dance community. We will miss him and extend condolences to his wife Barbara. Kerry Clayton, Chair Linda Shelton, Executive Director 1/3

BADILLO--Herman. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Herman Badillo, former Chairperson of CUNY's Board of Trustees. A 1951 graduate of The City College of New York, Mr. Badillo, orphaned in Puerto Rico at a young age, exemplified the power of public education to transform lives of hardship. He graduated from Haaren High School in Manhattan, then magna cum laude from City College before graduating first in his class from Brooklyn Law School and embarking on a long career as a lawyer, accountant, Bronx Borough President, Congressmember and New York City Deputy Mayor among other prominent positions. He served on CUNY's Board of Trustees for a total of 13 years including two as Vice Chairperson and two as Chairperson. With deepest appreciation for Mr. Badillo's numerous contributions to the resurgence of CUNY, we express our sincerest condolences to his wife, Gail, son David, and his extended family. Benno Schmidt, Chairperson James B. Milliken, Chancellor 1/3

BADILLO--Herman, on December 3, 2014. Beloved and devoted husband of Gail. Loving father of David and his wife Millie. Cherished son- in-law. Treasured brother-in- law and uncle. A true champion and pioneer for many. A private service to be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. 1/3

WILMOT--Irvin G. Irvin G. Wilmot, chief executive and administrator of NYU Medical Center (1961-1981), passed away on November 22, 2014. He was 92. Irv served the hospital and health care administration field with a lifetime of extraordinary leadership, innovation and contributions delivered with a keen intelligence, sparkling humor, a genuine kindness and interest in every person he met. He possessed an ability to quickly envision essentials, foresee creative solutions and bring them into existence. With an acute perception of others talents, he provided an incubator for great managers. A true gentleman, in his career and throughout his life this quality of kindness, care and respect for others was always present. He held senior executive management positions at the University of Chicago Hospitals and Clinics, New York University Medical Center, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New York and Montefiore Medical Center during his 38 years in hospital and health care administration. While chief executive of University Hospital in New York, it evolved into a major teaching facility of New York University. Among countless contributions, he smoothly moved the Post Graduate Hospital into the new University Hospital building on First Avenue in 1963. He originated the Cooperative Care concept for inpatients, and built the first 100-bed facility in the nation. His emphasis on patient education and family involvement resulted in charges 40% below average, provided an element of care only a loved one can give, and strengthened family relationships. Its unqualified success received national and international acclaim and resulted in eighteen more Cooperative Care facilities across the country. Throughout his career he actively participated in local, state and national health associations and forums including the N.I.H. General Clinical Research Centers Committee, the Liaison Committee on Graduate Education (A.C.G.M.E.), and the New York State Hospital Review and Planning Council. He was chairman of the Greater New York Hospital Association, the Hospital Association of New York State, and the Council of Teaching Hospitals of the AAMC and was a director of the New York Blood Center, Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York and the American Hospital Association. Mr. Wilmot was a Life Fellow of The American College of Healthcare Executives and a Professor of Health Care Management at New York University. Born in Nanking China on June 30, 1922, and raised in California, he was the son of Dr. Frank A. Wilmot and Ethel Ranney Wilmot, missionaries who built the Drum Tower Hospital in China which still operates today. He served in the US Navy from 1940-1946 as an Aviation Chief Machinists Mate. A graduate of Northwestern University (1955) he held a Master's degree in Business Administration from the University of Chicago (1957). Beloved and devoted husband and father he married his life's partner of 69 years Dorothy Agnes Wilmot on February 6, 1943. Residents of Rye, NY for 50 years, Irv and Dorothy (who passed in March 2012) were the love of each other's lives, true partners, devoted parents and keen world travelers. Irv was an avid golfer, and enjoyed some painting and sculpting in retirement years. A gifted architect, he created solutions for anything needed at home. Together they raised two children who survive them: Marcia B. Wilmot of Port Washington, NY and David M. Wilmot of Las Vegas, NV. Also surviving are two nephews, Stephen Warshauer of Manning, SC and Michael Warshauer of Bend, OR. The family will receive friends at the Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580, on Saturday December 6, 2014 from 9am to 12:30pm. A religious service will be held there at 12:30pm with interment to follow at Greenwood Union Cemetery, Rye. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in his memory to the Raymond E. Brown Endowment in Health Administration Studies, The University of Chicago, School of Social Service Administration, 969 East 60th Street, Chicago, Illinois 60637, Attn: Steve Gilmore. 1/3

WEISS--Jo Ann. Passed away in a peaceful sleep Monday December 1st, 2014. Adoring husband of Nathan Weiss. Loving mother of Leslie and husband Michael, and Stephanie and husband Wayne. Loving grandmother of Roni, Russell, Racquel, R.J. and Vanessa. She also had a special place in her heart for her extended family. The sons of Nathan, Larry and his wife Melissa and Alan and his wife Kim, and their children Hannah, Isabella, Zachary, Max and Gabriel. Jo Ann was the most giving of individuals and faced whatever she encountered with optimism. She had a special place in her heart for a group of women named The Owls. Who played golf for years in Boca West and were always caring for each other. Jo Ann graduated from Boston University with a B.A. and had a Masters Degree from Hofstra in Reading. She was employed for over 20 years with AHRC on Long Island. Her final position was the Director of Vocational training services. She will be missed by everyone that met her. 1/3

VARON--Robert I. On November 27, 2014, our "Uncle Bob," Robert I. Varon, (born March 11, 1928), died gracefully after a long and challenging illness. Uncle Bob was refined, elegant, kind, generous, thoughtful, talented, multilingual, highly literate and a cultured gentleman. We will always remember him most, sitting at the piano and playing duets with us. His perfect pitch and ability to perform anything by ear and instruct was a dazzling inspiration. We, his nieces and nephews, honor his life and thank him for infinite cherished memories. With eternal love, respect and admiration, the many Kassimirs, Joel, Robin, Maurice, Sharon, Jon, Rachelle, Richard, Linda, Spencer, Dale, Jason, Remy, Charlotte, Evan, Brandon, Matthew, Lauren, Alex, Shelly, Jack and, his adoring younger sister and lifetime best friend, Pauline, whose hand he would hold each night as a child, as she would fall asleep. Bon Voyage to a "swell guy." 1/3

SQUIRES--Fitz Allen. January 21, 1920 -December 5, 2014. Served honorably four years during WWII with the Tuskeegee Airmen in North Africa and Sicily. Predeceased by his late wife, Sophie Weeman, the mother of his sons, David, Donald, and Peter who survive him. Loving grandfather to their sons, Scott, Drew, Si, and Itai. Shared the past 37 years of friendship and love with his wife Myra Mahoney Goggins. Visitation at John J. Fox & Sons, 203 E. 201st St., Bronx, NY 10458 on Sunday, December 7th and Monday, December 8th from 2-5 and 7-9pm. Cremation at Woodlawn Cemetery Tuesday, December 9th. 1/3

PALMER--Lynne, of Sleepy Hollow, NY on December 2. Born and raised in New York City. Founder and longtime owner of Lynne Palmer Executive Recruitment Inc. and the Lynne Palmer Agency, a publishing search firm. Former board member Association of Personnel Consultants of New York (APCNY), 3- time recipient of APCNY's Best in Advertising award and Annual Overall Excellence award. Her agency was referred to by the New York Times as the gateway to careers in the New York publishing world. Following retirement, Lynne mentored young people looking to advance their careers and, as a longtime member of Alcoholics Anonymous, worked with recovering alcoholics. After retirement she attended and subsequently endowed a scholarship fund at Sarah Lawrence College. Former Board member of Westchester SPCA. Survived by a number of good friends. Donations in Lynne's memory may be made to Westchester SPCA, Briarcliff, NY. 1/3

MURRAY--Virginia. Virginia Donchian Murray. May 5, 1922 November 28, 2014. Gina was born in Pasadena California to Bessie Gertmenian Donchian and Paul Dikran Donchian. Gina was raised a Quaker with her brother Dikran in New York City and educated at Riverdale Country School, Swarthmore and Barnard (1943). She was a member of the Society of Friends, an educator with a passion for theater, the symphony and world travel. Gina and her husband, the artist Jack Murray, raised five children, Margaret, Kathryn, Nicholas, Peter and Paul at the Groton School in Massachusetts, where her husband set up the arts program under the Reverend Jack Crocker. Gina continued in theatre and education after Jacks death. She resided at 2501 Palisades Ave in Riverdale, NY and later at Thornton Oaks in Brunswick Maine, and summered on Matinicus, Gotts and Great Cranberry Islands, where Jack painted until his death in 1969. Gina enjoyed, entertained and hosted friends and acquaintances spanning generations, cultures and continents. She leaves eight grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. She was a life-enhancing and wise, iconic presence in many lives. (photo by Jack Murray). 1/3

MILLER--Richard M.,passed away at the age of 89, peacefully, at his home in Hanover, NH. He was the son of Robert Miller and Bessie Dine Miller of Boston and New York. He is survived by his loving wife of 37 years, Marie Miller, his brother, David Miller, and his adoring children, Susan Miller Lloyd (Dr. William Lloyd) of Marblehead, MA and Stephen Miller of South Hero, VT. He was a devoted grandfather to Jessica Lloyd Mandelbaum, David Lloyd and Allison Miller. His first wife, Nina Ackerland Miller died in 1978. Dick was president of American Ecology from 1977 to 1993. He was a graduate of Harvard College '49 where he played varsity football, Horace Mann and Phillips Exeter Academy '43, where he held the shot put record from 1945 to 1964 and was affectionately called, Chief. He served in World War II overseas for two years during college. Dick ran the first New York City Marathon in 1970 and many after that. While in New York, he was an active member of the City Athletic Club and later in Hanover, NH served as a volunteer at Dartmouth Hitchcock Hospital for ten years. Dick enjoyed watching football, travel, his family, photography and Photoshop. He will be greatly missed by all of us and remembered for his strength, athleticism, optimism and good humor. A private memorial service will be held in New York in the spring. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to BAYADA Hospice, Norwich, VT. 1/3

LIVINGSTON--William Curtis III. Of Nantucket and New York City died December 2, 2014 of pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his son, William Livingston IV, daughter, Molly L. Paiement and their children, William and Elizabeth Livingston and Morgan and Posey Paiement. His sister, Ann Wainscott, also survives. His wife of 40 years, Pamela, predeceased him in 2010. Curt's business career was in the investment management world. He managed institutional fixed-income portfolios at the Ford Foundation and Fischer Francis Trees and Watts, both in NYC, and at Fidelity Investment Management Services in Boston. As chairman and CEO of Western Asset Management, Pasadena CA, he helped define and build-out the model for independent institutional international fixed-incomemanagement firms. Western Asset grew much larger and broader under his leadership and, more than 10 years after his retirement, remains one of the major global firms in its business. His avocation was financial management at not-for-profits and he served for a number of years in various financial leadership roles for the Los Angeles Philharmonic Association, Third Street Music School Settlement, NYC, the League of American Orchestras, NYC and the Nantucket Atheneum. He was also a long- standing director of Legg Mason Inc. and served as chair of the Trustees of Reservations Nantucket Committee and of the Collections Committee of the Smithsonian National Postal Museum. He had also been a board member of the Theatre Workshop of Nantucket and of the Nantucket Arts Council and a member of the Wauwinet Yacht and Westmoor Clubs. He was a world traveler, having visited all seven continents and more than 80 countries. He loved his family, his friends, design, gardening, color and life in general. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Nantucket Atheneum, One India Street, Nantucket 02554 or the Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 East 11th Street, New York 10003. 1/3

KOENIGSBERG--Allan M.,on December 4, at home surrounded by his family. Dear partner of Rochelle Krause. Loving father of Nancie (Brandon Sullivan) and Jedediah (Christine Ferguson). JONES--Bertha K. 96, passed away on December 2, 2014 in New York City. She was born in Detroit, MI on November 25, 1918. Beloved wife of Justice Thomas R. Jones and mother of Margaret J. DeLaCour, who both predeceased her, and David R. Jones, Esq., who survives her along with five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Bertha was a social activist and progressive from the time she graduated from Brooklyn College in 1935. Meeting her future husband Thomas R. Jones in the anti- fascist youth leagues formed before World War II, they married in 1938 becoming one of the few interracial couples of their time. Together they help found numerous organizations including the Unity Democratic Club in Central Brooklyn, which led to the election of Thomas Jones as Assemblyman and ultimately the election of Shirley Chisholm. As a professional she worked as a social worker for the City of New York and then for many years as co-coordinator of adult education for Brooklyn College. In addition to her many philanthropic efforts, she served on the Board of the Citizens Committee for Children, and with her husband, created a non-for-profit childrens advocacy publication called The Children's Times. She was a world traveler and passionately devoted to her husband, children, her daughter-in-law Dr. Valerie King, son-in-law Willis S. DeLaCour Jr, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She will be sincerely missed by all who knew her. The family prefers, in lieu of flowers, that contributions be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation in memory of Bertha K. Jones, either online at www.alzfdn.org/donation or by mail to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America, 322 Eighth Ave., 7th floor, New York, NY 10001. 1/3

HELM--John R.,84, Montclair, NJ, died on November 29. Memorial Service: Monday, December 8, 2pm, Central Presbyterian Church, 46 Park St., Montclair. Graduate of Princeton '52. Donations to Cope Montclair or Central Presbyterian Church Mission Fund. 1/3

CAFFREY--Philip C.,88, on December 4 after a long battle with Alzheimer's Disease. He is preceded in death by his wife of 64 years, Jeanne (nee Quinn). He is survived by his children and their spouses: Patricia, Maureen and David Ayres, Cathleen and Dennis Murphy, Philip Jr. and Kathleen and grandchildren, Matthew and Kevin Murphy, David Ayres, Kathryn and Krisanne Caffrey, Melissa Sipes and Ken Ayres. He is also survived by his sister Elizabeth Lapine. Phil was a wonderful husband, father and a true gentleman. He will be sorely missed but we are comforted by the thought that he is finally at peace together with Jeanne. Reposing at Horne Dannecker, 445 West 43rd Street, Saturday 7-9pm and Sunday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass at the Church of Saint Michael, 424 West 34th Street, Monday l0am. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Church of Saint Michael. 1/3

BRENNAN--Eileen Ann, of Kent, NY and Sailfish Point, FL, on December 4, 2014. Predeceased by her father, John J. Brennan. Survived by her mother, Eileen F. Brennan of Manhasset, NY. Mother of Nell Timmer (Ted) of Beacon, NY, Kate Lofgren (Kris) of Washington, DC and Mary Okner (Dillon) of Mountain View, CA. Grandmother of Henry, Jasper, Emmet, Mira and Graham Timmer and "Dazzle" Lofgren. Sister of John (Joan) of Ardmore, PA, Edward (Julia) of Sea Cliff, NY, Beatrice Wall (Robert) of Lloyd Harbor, NY, Michael (Lisa) of Manhasset, NY, Virginia (James Waechter) of Nashville, TN, Stephen (Patricia) of Irvington, NY, Peter (Bernadette) of Bronxville, NY, Thomas of Philadelphia, PA and William (Margaret) of Yorktown Heights, NY. Graduate of St. Mary's Girls High School class of 1967, Manhattanville College class of 1971 and Fordham Law School class of 1976. Associate at Shea, Gould, and Managing Director at Lehman Brothers and GMAC Commercial Mortgage. Visitation at McGrath's Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY on Sunday, December 7 from 1:00pm to 4:00pm. THE FOX WENT OUT ON A CHILLY NIGHT Illustrated by Peter Spier. 44 pp. Doubleday. $17.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 7) 
 
Spier’s take on the boisterous — and completely merciless — folk song about a goose-killing fox has been not just reissued but revivified: When this Caldecott Honor book was published in 1961, half the pages were in black and white. Now Spier has added color to those, to wonderful effect. His finely detailed, ­action-packed New England autumn vistas are almost startlingly beautiful. As for the fox, he’s only trying to feed his pups.

RITTER--Patricia Kingsley, 84, a pioneer civil and human rights leader and educator, died of acute leukemia on December 10, 2004, in Hartford, CT. She was a woman of uncommon grace and quiet intensity with a lifelong commitment to social justice. As a 16-year-old freshman at the University of Iowa, she organized a sit-in at a segregated restaurant and headed south to become an early freedom rider. In post-war 1947, she assisted Margaret Mead at the first Salzburg Seminar in American Studies. In 1950, she was the first woman appointed to the Connecticut Civil Rights Commission. In the early 1960's, she co-founded with her husband, George, and headed a national model for integrated, affordable housing, still going strong. With heart and innovation, she championed integrated housing as board chair of the Mutual Real Estate Investment Trust in New York City in the 1970's, and as an appointee of President Carter's to the National Housing Partnership board in the 1980's. Among the first foreign teachers invited to China at the close of the Cultural Revolution, she taught English at universities there for years, established several libraries, and created a foundation that forged an early educational link with the country. She taught English, humanities and sociology at various U.S. schools, including the Loomis Chaffee School in Windsor, CT, where she pioneered women's studies in high school. Ms. Ritter studied education (M.A.) and philosophy and ethics at Yale. One of her honorary degrees--from Heilongjiang University in Harbin, China, where she taught--was bestowed at her lecture on Harriet Beecher Stowe from an outdoor balcony before a throng of admirers. She was a direct descendant of Pastor John Robinson, who coordinated his congregation's migration from Holland on the Mayflower. For 58 years she was married to George Ritter, an attorney, entrepreneur, state legislator and fellow social activist. She was a passionate, wise and devoted presence for her children Martha, Scott, Thomas, Penn and John, and their families. See courant.com/obituaries. See also 151 Congressional Record E4, Honoring Ritter. 1/3

WEISS--Jo Ann. Passed away in a peaceful sleep Monday December 1st, 2014. Adoring husband of Nathan Weiss. Loving mother of Leslie and husband Michael, and Stephanie and husband Wayne. The sons of Nathan, Larry and his wife Melissa and Alan and his wife Kim, and their children Hannah, Isabella, Zachary, Max and Gabriel. WALLIS--Marjorie Bomart. "MBW" as she liked to call herself died peacefully after a short illness, at Southampton Hospital on November 26, just 16 days before her 90th birthday. She lived her life with gusto, enjoying good times and good food, and scores of good friends she made in New York City, Fire Island, Southampton and Puerto Vallarta. Everyone will miss her friendship, wit, intelligence and beauty. MBW was a compassionate and caring psychotherapist, graduating from Hunter College, Case Western Reserve and finishing her training at the Post Graduate Center for Mental Health in NYC. Marjorie will be sorely missed by her beloved daughter, Wendie, her dear sister Shirley Dinitz, and nieces, nephew, and cousins. She also leaves behind her tireless caregivers and friends Karen Flanagan, Ellissa Eleazer, and Sheila Haley, as well as her cherished poodles, Lanna and Ginny. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Donations in her honor may be made to ARF in Wainscott, NY or The Assistance Fund in Orlando, FL. 1/3

VORHAUS--Dr. Louis Jack II. Dr. Louis Jack Vorhaus II, died peacefully at the age of 91 on Saturday, October 18th, 2014, attended by his daughter Meg. He was a dedicated physician and a great lover of life. He loved railroads, mountains, all animals (especially dogs), classical music, Harvard, ballet, orchids, children's books, the Supreme Court, Gilbert and Sullivan, good grammar.... the list goes on and on. Above all, he loved his children, Kathie, Meg, Niki and David, and his grandchildren and great grandchildren. He was kind and loyal and dependable. He was witty and opinionated. In his last years, he suffered from dementia, but was unfailingly optimistic, cheerful, and uncomplaining. He recognized his loved ones until the end, and though he couldn't remember what happened two minutes ago, he ranged in his last months through his distant past, singing songs, reciting poems, and recalling people. Born to Pauline Grossman Vorhaus and David Vorhaus, Louis grew up in Manhattan, and attended Birch Wathen School, where he was elected student council president. He was admitted to Harvard's class of 1944, and awarded an honorary academic scholarship. He went on to attend medical school at Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, where he graduated Alpha Omega Alpha. He specialized in Internal Medicine. Louis Vorhaus served as a Captain in the Army Medical Nutrition Laboratory where he earned a Presidential Citation and during which time he served in the US Department of Health and Welfare, stationed in Turkey. He had a long, successful practice as an internist affiliated with Lenox Hill Hospital and Cornell Medical Center. A celebration of Dr. Louis J Vorhaus' life will be held Saturday, December 13, 2014 at noon at the Riverdale Yacht Club, 800 W254th St., Riverdale, NY. Additional remembrances can be shared at legacy.com. Contributions in Louis's memory can be made to Wynne Friends of Animals, PO Box 1365, Wynne AR 72396. 1/3

VARON--Robert I. On November 27, 2014, our "Uncle Bob," Robert I. Varon, (born March 11, 1928), died gracefully after a long and challenging illness. Uncle Bob was refined, elegant, kind, generous, thoughtful, talented, multilingual, highly literate and a cultured gentleman. We will always remember him most, sitting at the piano and playing duets with us. His perfect pitch and ability to perform anything by ear and instruct was a dazzling inspiration. We, his nieces and nephews, honor his life and thank him for infinite cherished memories. With eternal love, respect and admiration, the many Kassimirs, Joel, Robin, Maurice, Sharon, Jon, Rachelle, Richard, Linda, Spencer, Dale, Jason, Remy, Charlotte, Evan, Brandon, Matthew, Lauren, Alex, Shelly, Jack and, his adoring younger sister and lifetime best friend, Pauline, whose hand he would hold each night as a child, as she would fall asleep. Bon Voyage to a "swell guy." 1/3

TAPPIN--Anthony G. of Tucson, AZ, formerly a resident of Oak Brook, IL died at home on November 29, 2014 at the age of 89, due to complications of Alzheimer's disease and cancer. He is survived by his wife, Mary; daughters Cynthia Gilbert (Kevin), Amy Greening (John); three grandchildren and three step-children, and a step-granddaughter. He is also survived by his brother, Michael Tappin, and predeceased by his wife, Nancy Tappin and brother, Paul Tappin. He was born in London, England and emigrated to the U.S, in 1940; served in the U.S Army in WWII in Europe, and in the Philippines, and received an A.B. degree in Chemistry from Cornell University; a member of Phi Gamma Delta fraternity; completed the Advanced Management Program at Harvard Business School. His business career was with FMC Corporation starting in 1950 in New York City, retiring as Vice President of Marketing for FMC in Chicago. He was a member of the Cornell Clubs of Fairfield County, CT, Chicago and Tucson, a former member of Butterfield Country Club in Oak Brook, and the Capilano Golf and Country Club in Vancouver, BC, and presently a member of the Tucson Country Club. He was an avid golfer and fly fisherman. His integrity, humor and strength will be greatly missed. A memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, December 6th at St. Thomas the Apostle Church in Tucson, AZ., at 9am. Donations in his memory may be made to Cornell University, Ithaca, NY; Alzheimer Association of Arizona or to Casa de la Luz Hospice of Tucson. 1/3

TANNENBAUM--Rita, passed away on November 28th, 2014 at Prescott House Rehabilitation in North Andover, MA. She was born in the Bronx and later moved to Eastchester, NY. She and her late husband Mike moved to Tamarac, FL where they lived for many years enjoying their friends and family. Three years ago she moved to Andover, MA where she enjoyed life in New England.
