STERNFELD--Leon, MD, PhD, MPH, died at his home in Oakland, CA., on Monday, November 24. Born in Brooklyn, NY on June 15, 1913 to Jewish immigrant parents, Leon spent his earliest years in a Labor Zionist agricultural community in Clarion, Utah. After the outbreak of World War I, with economic opportunities opening up in the big cities, Leon and his parents moved to Chicago, IL, where he grew up. He attended college and medical school at the University of Chicago, where he also earned a doctoral degree in biochemistry. As a teenager in Chicago, he met his future wife, Ruth Schwartz, to whom he was married for 73 years, and with whom he raised two daughters, Kay and Barbara. After completing an internship in pediatrics and communicable diseases at Johns Hopkins and a residency in pediatrics at Brooklyn Jewish Hospital, Leon took a Public Health Traineeship with the New York State Department of Health; during that time, he completed a Masters of Public Health in Maternal and Child Health at Columbia University. He then worked as Director of the Bureau of Medical Rehabilitation in the NY State Department of Health until 1950 when he took a position as Assistant Director, Tuberculosis Control, in the Massachusetts Department of Public Health. After a tour of active duty as Chief of the Public Health Administration in South Korea, Leon returned to Massachusetts, serving first as Commissioner of Health in Cambridge and then as Deputy Commissioner in the state Department of Public Health. In 1970, Leon and Ruth moved to New York City where he served as the Medical Director of the United Cerebral Palsy Association and United Cerebral Palsy Research and Educational Foundation until he retired in 1993. In 1991, he was recognized by the American Academy for Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine with a Distinguished Service Award, and in 1998, he was honored with the Research and Public Health Leadership award from Life Services for the Handicapped. Leon was the patriarch and anchor for the extended Sternfeld clan, full of wisdom and practical advice and always ready with his infectiously positive attitude, quick wit, humor and contagious laugh. He is survived by his daughter, Barbara, of Kensington, CA, his brother-in-law, Leo Sreebny of Seattle, WA, his son-in-law, Virgil Vickers of Newton, MA, his granddaughter, Rani Vickers Dalton, and great-granddaughter, Kayley Dalton, of Waltham, MA, as well as his step-grandson and family, Michael and JoLynn Carroll and their children, Julia and Phillip, of Tromso, Norway, and many loving nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his wife, Ruth, and daughter, Kay. Donations in his memory may be sent to the American Museum of Natural History in New York or the United Cerebral Palsy Associations. 1/3

SIRAGUSA--Ross D.,Jr., Ross D. Siragusa, Jr, died peacefully at his home in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL on Thursday, November 27, 2014. Son of the late Ross D. Siragusa (founder, Admiral Corporation) and late Irene O'Brien Siragusa; beloved husband of Alison Siragusa for 62 years; devoted father of Irene S. Phelps (Charles J. Eastman), Alisa S. Perrotte and Ross D. Siragusa III (Susan K. Siragusa); cherished grandfather of Andrew A. Perrotte, Isabel K. Siragusa and J. Marco Siragusa; and dear brother of John R. Siragusa (Jack), Richard D. Siragusa (Dick) and Mary Irene Siragusa Hicks (deceased). Ross grew up in Barrington, IL and graduated from Phillips Academy in Andover, MA in 1949 and Yale University in 1953. He married Alison F. Fennelly in June 1952 and they raised their three children in Lake Forest, IL. Ross joined his father's television company Admiral Corporation in 1953, holding several executive positions over the years. He succeeded his father as president from 1969 to 1974, when Admiral was acquired by Rockwell International. He was elected to the Board of Directors and served until 1995. In 1976, Ross and his brothers Jack and Dick bought Game Time, a manufacturer of commercial outdoor playground equipment and in 1981 they moved the company to Fort Payne, Alabama. Ross served as president until his retirement in 1997, when Game Time was acquired by Swing-N- Slide Corp. In 1981 Ross and Alison moved to Fort Payne, AL and established Straight Creek Farm, a successful 500 acre cow/calf operation with Limousine cattle. He grew up on a farm and always wanted to live on one again. Like his father before him, Ross was an astute businessman, a thoughtful problem solver and an innovator. He held several patents for equipment, and inspired those around him with his deep curiosity and passion for education and life-long learning. A modest man who preferred to work quietly behind the scenes, Ross leaves a remarkable philanthropic legacy though his personal giving to educational institutions, nonprofits serving youth and advancing educational opportunities, as well as through his father's charitable entity The Siragusa Foundation, on which he served as board member from 1980-1981 and 1991-2007. He was instrumental in leading the foundation to make the largest grant in its history --$6 million to Lurie Childrens Hospital, saying that the transplant program at Lurie was cutting edge, much like the work of his father and Admiral Television. Ross was a major benefactor of the Yale University Art Gallery and along with Alison a loyal member of its Patrons group for many years. Ross and Alison had a passion for traveling. Together, they visited all seven continents and encouraged their children and grandchildren to see the world. He was a gourmet cook and enjoyed sharing new recipes with family and friends. Colleagues, friends and family remember Ross as generous and caring in all his endeavors, a gracious host, an engaging conversationalist, and a gentleman of great integrity with a wonderful sense of humor. He valued people and his family above all else. Ross has passed on a steadfast legacy and will be dearly missed. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to The Yale University Art Gallery, 1111 Chapel St, New Haven, CT 06510. A memorial service will be held February 21, 2015 at the Sawgrass Country Club, 10034 Golf Club Drive, Ponte Vedra Beach, FL at 4pm. Condolences and more information at rdsiragusamemorial@gmail.com. See more at: http:// bit.ly/1AtKqNY Services are under the direction of Hardage-Giddens Greenlawn Funeral Home. 1/3

SINANIAN--Edward J.,born December 1st, 1932, died on December 3rd, 2014. Ed grew up in Bridgeport, Connecticut and attended Fairfield Prep and Fairfield University, majoring in Physics, before receiving a full academic scholarship from Fordham University and graduating with a MA in Mathematics. Ed then went on to be at the forefront of computer technology working at IBM from 1957 through 1996, starting as a Software Engineer, then as Technical Support for several large companies and clients, as well as serving as Technical Liaison and Speechwriter for IBM World Trade. He loved to travel and was an avid skier, spending most winters after retirement at his house in Vermont. Ed was a wonderful, caring, charming, funny man, father and husband. He leaves behind two brothers, Jerry and Souren, several nephews, as well as wife Donna and daughter Ruth. He is greatly missed. 1/3

SIEGMAN--Felix, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the death of Dr. Felix Siegman. He was a surgeon associated with Maimonides Medical Center for 69 years. He did his training here and continued his lifetime work at Maimonides He was a surgeon par excellence. He taught the interns and residents how to become surgeons. He was the Division Chairman of the Vascular Surgery Department for many years. He was President of the Medical Staff in the late seventies. He was always available to give his wisdom to others. Everyone at the Medical Center had such respect for him because he always treated others with respect and a smile. He will be sorely missed by all his colleagues and friends. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. George Neiderman, M.D. President Edward Chapnick , M.D. President-Elect Harry Adler, M.D. Secretary Abraham Taub, M.D. Treasurer 1/3

SIEGMAN--Dr. Felix, died this week at age 93, peacefully, at home, in the company of people he loved, listening to "Proust's Remembrance of Things Past." It was a fitting end to a life well lived. Felix started as a surgical resident at Maimonides after service as a Captain in WWII. At a time when surgical specialization was uncommon, he helped create and advance the field of vascular surgery. His affiliation with Maimonides lasted nearly 70 years. A natural teacher, he adored working with residents at Maimonides Medical Center, Downstate Hospital, and Kings County Hospital, where he helped them explore the science and the art of medicine. Until a few weeks ago, he still regularly attended 7am teaching conferences. His colleagues there were his second family. At home, Felix was a voracious reader, an enthusiastic cyclist and swimmer, and a discerning eater. He, and his wife Judith --an actress, poet, teacher, classical music scholar, and gourmet cook, who died last year --are survived by Felix's sister, loving children, grandchildren, a great-grandchild, and friends, who miss his brilliance, humor, insight, and, most of all, his humanity. Services are private. In lieu of gifts, his family requests that donations be made in his memory to the Brooklyn Botanical Gardens and Tulane Medical School. 1/3

Donations may be made in her name to the American Heart Association. 1/3

ROBERTS--Wayne, 92, died peacefully on November 24, 2014 in New York City. Devoted husband of the late Doris. Beloved father of Jim and Laurie. Loving father-in-law of Patricia. Adored "Poppy" of Alexandra and Justine Rose. Lifelong political activist and champion of progressive causes. Passionate advocate for racial, social and economic justice. An insurance agent for 50 years, his open manner and honest reputation earned the respect of his many clients. A jazz lover who listened tirelessly to Pete Jolly, Pete Seeger, Nina Simone and the Gipsy Kings. Unfailingly generous to and well loved by family and friends alike, Wayne was regarded by all who knew him as a real mensch. 1/3

PUTNAM--Thea Convissar, of Essex, CT, died November 23, 2014 of complications from pulmonary fibrosis. Born in Brooklyn August 5, 1944 to Gussie and Murray Convissar. She is survived by her husband of 28 years Philip Putnam stepdaughter Andrea her granddaughter Zoey Putnam Boyd and a brother, Michael Convissar. Before retiring to Essex in 2004, she owned and managed MGT Services, which for 18 years provided office support services to businesses and individuals who lived and worked in the Columbus Circle area. In Essex she became an active member of the community serving on the boards of the Essex Historical Society and the Essex Land Trust as well as volunteering for the local Child and Family Agency. She will be missed by the many friends she made in the community who appreciated her warmth, wit and generous nature. Most of all she will be missed by her beloved husband Philip, her stepdaughter Andrea and granddaughter Zoey. Funeral services will be private. Memorial contributions in her memory may be made to "Yale University with a designation to support the Yale-ILD Center," or The North Shore Animal League. 1/3

PALMER--Lynne, of Sleepy Hollow, NY on December 2. Born and raised in New York City. Founder and longtime owner of Lynne Palmer Executive Recruitment Inc. and the Lynne Palmer Agency, a publishing search firm. Former board member Association of Personnel Consultants of New York (APCNY), 3- time recipient of APCNY's Best in Advertising award and Annual Overall Excellence award. Her agency was referred to by the New York Times as the gateway to careers in the New York publishing world. Following retirement, Lynne mentored young people looking to advance their careers and, as a longtime member of Alcoholics Anonymous, worked with recovering alcoholics. After retirement she attended and subsequently endowed a scholarship fund at Sarah Lawrence College. Former Board member of Westchester SPCA. Survived by a number of good friends. Donations in Lynne's memory may be made to Westchester SPCA, Briarcliff, NY. 1/3
PALLADINO--Wendy Gordon, on November 30, 2014. Beautiful, gentle Wendy. She had more fans than the Jets and the Knicks. Loved and missed by more than she would have ever realized. JRN 1/3

OLSTEIN--Elliot M. Attorney Elliot M. Olstein, 75, of Kinnelon, NJ died on November 27, 2014. He was born in the Bronx, NY on August 15, 1939 and attended DeWitt Clinton High School. Mr. Olstein graduated from Columbia University with a B.S. in Chemical Engineering in 1961, earned a J.D. degree from Georgetown University in 1965 and an LL.M. in Taxation from NYU in 1977. He was a partner in the firm of Carella, Byrne, Cecchi, Olstein, Brody & Agnello, P.C. in Roseland, NJ. Mr. Olstein had broad experience in intellectual property law and was an expert in chemical and biochemical inventions; with particular emphasis on their medical applications. He is survived by his wife Joan, sons Erik (Kathleen) and Jon (Laura) and grandchildren Ryan, Kevon, Hunter, Bronwyn, and Shawn. 1/3

MURRAY--Virginia. Virginia Donchian Murray. May 5, 1922 November 28, 2014. Gina was born in Pasadena California to Bessie Gertmenian Donchian and Paul Dikran Donchian. Gina was raised a Quaker with her brother Dikran in New York City and educated at Riverdale Country School, Swarthmore and Barnard (1943). She was a member of the Society of Friends, an educator with a passion for theater, the symphony and world travel. Gina and her husband, the artist Jack Murray, raised five children, Margaret, Kathryn, Nicholas, Peter and Paul at the Groton School in Massachusetts, where her husband set up the arts program under the Reverend Jack Crocker. Gina continued in theatre and education after Jacks death. She resided at 2501 Palisades Ave in Riverdale, NY and later at Thornton Oaks in Brunswick Maine, and summered on Matinicus, Gotts and Great Cranberry Islands, where Jack painted until his death in 1969. Gina enjoyed, entertained and hosted friends and acquaintances spanning generations, cultures and continents. She leaves eight grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. She was a life-enhancing and wise, iconic presence in many lives. (photo by Jack Murray). 1/3

MORRISSEY--Clovene N.,on November 26th, 2014. Loving aunt of numerous nieces and nephews. Mrs. Morrissey was preceded in death by her husband Thomas J. Mrs. Morrissey was a fashion designer, teacher of design at Fashion Institute Technology. A longtime volunteer for the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. She was a parishioner of Church of the Holy Family. Funeral Services Friday, December 12, 2014 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st. Visitation 3:00-4:00pm, Prayer Service 4:00-5:00pm. In lieu of flowers, Contributions can be made to the Visiting Nurses of New York, 107 East 70th Street, New York, NY, 10021 or visit: www.vnsny.org/donate. 1/3

MORAES--Clelia, on December 4, 2014. Clelia Moraes was born in Soa Paulo, Brazil where she spent the first two decades of her life. In 1960 she moved to New York to continue her professional activities at the headquarters of Ibec, a subsidiary of the Rockefeller Group with extensive activity in Brazil, where she had been employed for six years. Ms. Moraes was a close assistant to Richard Aldrich and Nelson Rockefeller. From 1978 to 1993, Ms. Moraes was General Manager of the Brazilian American Chamber of Commerce where she greatly contributed to the advancement of relations between Brazil and the United States. Over the course of her career at the Chamber, Ms. Moraes organized many programs, including the Brazil Economic Conference held in Berlin, Madrid, Hong Kong, and Bangkok, as well as the annual Person of the Year Awards Gala Dinner and traditional Holiday Gala Dinner Dance; all of which attested to to her great executive, diplomatic, and leadership skills. Following her retirement from the Chamber, she continued to be highly involved in its activities and, up until her passing, was a regular attendee at Chamber events. Outside of the Chamber, Ms. Moraes had a busy life divided between Brazil, where she was born and lived until 1960, and the United States, where she resided for over 55 years. Ms. Moraes lived in Manhattan and regularly took trips to visit different corners of the world -over 70 countries, in fact -in great part with Tom Bartlett, her loyal companion of over 40 years. Ms. Moraes will be greatly missed by all at the Chamber. Her contributions to this organization and to society were far-reaching and her legacy will greatly impact those who follow in her footsteps. Ms. Moraes is survived by her nephews Alexandre Zocchi, Paulo Leite Moraes Zocchi, Roberto Leite Moraes Zocchi, Mario de Toledo Leite Moraes Jr. and Roberto de Toledo Leite Moraes. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, December 10, 2014, 10:30am at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, 869 Lexington Ave., NYC. 1/3

MITCHELL--Rowland Lippincott, Ph.D.,of Kingston, NY, 92, died December 2nd. Born in Longmont, CO. Grew up in Pomona, CA. Yale Class of 1944, on full academic scholarship. Served U.S. Army Air Corps, radio/navigation instructor, WWII. Earned Ph.D., at Yale, in American History. Was Associate professor at University of Michigan and. M.I.T. Staff Associate Social Science Research Council, N.Y.C., 1960- 81. Published "Mitchell Guides" to non-profit foundations. Scarsdale School Board 1972-78. Westchester-Rockland BOCES Board 1979-88. Member New York Metropolitan Opera Guild. Love of his life, wife of 48 years, Sarah Matteson Mitchell, M.D. died 2005. Memorial Service Saturday December 13th, 12pm Fair St. Church, Kingston. 1/3

MILLER--Richard M.,passed away at the age of 89, peacefully, at his home in Hanover, NH. He was the son of Robert Miller and Bessie Dine Miller of Boston and New York. He is survived by his loving wife of 37 years, Marie Miller, his brother, David Miller, and his adoring children, Susan Miller Lloyd (Dr. William Lloyd) of Marblehead, MA and Stephen Miller of South Hero, VT. He was a devoted grandfather to Jessica Lloyd Mandelbaum, David Lloyd and Allison Miller. His first wife, Nina Ackerland Miller died in 1978. Dick was president of American Ecology from 1977 to 1993. He was a graduate of Harvard College '49 where he played varsity football, Horace Mann and Phillips Exeter Academy '43, where he held the shot put record from 1945 to 1964 and was affectionately called, Chief. He served in World War II overseas for two years during college. Dick ran the first New York City Marathon in 1970 and many after that. While in New York, he was an active member of the City Athletic Club and later in Hanover, NH served as a volunteer at Dartmouth Hitchcock Hospital for ten years. Dick enjoyed watching football, travel, his family, photography and Photoshop. He will be greatly missed by all of us and remembered for his strength, athleticism, optimism and good humor. A private memorial service will be held in New York in the spring. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to BAYADA Hospice, Norwich, VT. 1/3

LIVINGSTON--William Curtis III. Of Nantucket and New York City died December 2, 2014 of pancreatic cancer. He is survived by his son, William Livingston IV, daughter, Molly L. Paiement and their children, William and Elizabeth Livingston and Morgan and Posey Paiement. His sister, Ann Wainscott, also survives. His wife of 40 years, Pamela, predeceased him in 2010. Curt's business career was in the investment management world. He managed institutional fixed-income portfolios at the Ford Foundation and Fischer Francis Trees and Watts, both in NYC, and at Fidelity Investment Management Services in Boston. As chairman and CEO of Western Asset Management, Pasadena CA, he helped define and build-out the model for independent institutional international fixed-incomemanagement firms. Western Asset grew much larger and broader under his leadership and, more than 10 years after his retirement, remains one of the major global firms in its business. His avocation was financial management at not-for-profits and he served for a number of years in various financial leadership roles for the Los Angeles Philharmonic Association, Third Street Music School Settlement, NYC, the League of American Orchestras, NYC and the Nantucket Atheneum. He was also a long- standing director of Legg Mason Inc. and served as chair of the Trustees of Reservations Nantucket Committee and of the Collections Committee of the Smithsonian National Postal Museum. He had also been a board member of the Theatre Workshop of Nantucket and of the Nantucket Arts Council and a member of the Wauwinet Yacht and Westmoor Clubs. He was a world traveler, having visited all seven continents and more than 80 countries. He loved his family, his friends, design, gardening, color and life in general. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Nantucket Atheneum, One India Street, Nantucket 02554 or the Third Street Music School Settlement, 235 East 11th Street, New York 10003. 1/3

LINDE--Elizabeth. The Board of Directors and staff of Plaza Jewish Community Chapel wish to express their sincere condolences to board member Frank Linde on the loss of his mother Elizabeth Linde. May her memory forever be a blessing. Harold Handler, Chairman 1/3

LENCEK--Nina A.,(nee Lovrencic), died two months short of her 91st birthday, at dawn on November 25, in the arms of her daughters Bibi and Lena Lencek. Born prematurely on January 18, 1924 in Ljubljana, Slovenia, Nina Antonia Hedvika was the fourth of five children of Antonietta Manzoni and the poet/writer Joza Lovrencic, and the grandniece of Italian novelist Alessandro Manzoni. Gifted with beauty, a philosophical cast of mind, mischievous humor, a vast talent for languages, music, and art, Nina had boundless energy, courage, good judgment, and a fierce intelligence that helped her survive the trauma of World War II, the rigors of post-war displacement to Italy, and eventual resettlement in the United States. Adaptable and inventive, she excelled in every profession in which she worked: as interpreter/secretary for the British Red Cross and the Allied Military Government for Occupied Forces in the aftermath of WW II; radio broadcaster in Trieste; EKG technician in Chicago; in various areas of library science at the libraries of Harvard Museum of Comparative Zoology; University of Illinois; and, until her retirement in 1989, as Slavic and East European Bibliographer, Columbia University. She had studied Slavic philology at the University of Ljubljana, where she met her future husband, Dr. Rado L. Lencek (1921-2005), Professor Emeritus of Slavic Languages and Cultures, Columbia University. They married in Gorizia, Italy, in May 1946. Her account of the Allies' forced repatriation of thousands of captured anti-Communist Yugoslavs and Russians in the spring 1945 -among them members of her own family - was included in the historian Nikolai Tolstoy's expose of the ensuing atrocities and in the BBC documentary "A British Betrayal." Moving easily among six languages, she peppered her speech with citations from Greek and Latin writers; was a discriminating reader; and, in the last years of her life, relished drawing the Tuscan countryside. An inspired cook, she was celebrated for producing the Platonic ideal of apple strudel. Her memory is lovingly honored by her daughters Bibi and Lena; grandchildren Bianca Lencek Bosker (Nguyen), Misko and Katrina Lencek-Inagaki, relatives, friends, and colleagues. She lived the motto: "Quidquid agis, prudenter agas et respice finem!" and exhorted us to love as fully and as well as we can. She will be buried in Ljubljana in May 2015. A celebration of her life is scheduled for January 22, 2015 in Butler Library, Columbia University. 1/3

KRIM-GRAHAM--Alaine, on December 4, 2014. aged 90. She is survived by her husband Dr. Harold N. Graham, sons Jonathan and Don Krim, daughter-in-law Joyce Gemperlein, son-in-law David T. Russell, granddaughter Jocelyn Krim, sister Gilda Weissman. She is also survived by step-daughters Margaret Shultz, Vicki Graham (Nathaniel Hart), and Emily Graham, step-son Robert Graham (Marjie) and step- daughter-in-law Lewraine Graham. A native of Manhattan, Alaine was a gifted childrens therapist who had a private practice for many years. She was also employed by the Jewish Board of Guardians until her retirement in 1990. Her writings include discussions of adolescent emotional issues, and of non-verbal communication. While at the Jewish Board one of her latest responsiities was the care of families made homeless by fire. She oversaw not just their housing but also childcare, counseling, and nutritional support. She both worked to care for those families and wrote papers analyzing aspects of their situations with emphasis on the effects on children. A special project was the publication of a book of poems written by homeless women, The Women of the Regent Hotel. In retirement she traveled extensively with her husband but also acted as a consultant to a troupe led by theater director David Glass to Vietnam. This group produced a theater piece conceived and acted by deaf children. She also provided volunteer counseling for 9/11 survivors. A private service will be scheduled. 1/3

KRATKA--Joseph M.,born June 14, 1919, died December 3, 2014. Beloved husband of Ruth Markowitz for 65 years. Devoted father to Peter Kratka, MD and Judith Pentland. Father-in-law to Suzanne Kratka, David Pentland, and great father-in-law to Peter Tirado, Kevin Debraganca, and Nicole Kratka. Beloved grandfather of Jennifer Tirado, Alexis DeBraganca, Harris Kratka; predeceased by grandson Ben Kratka. Great-grandfather to Max, Isabella, and Aiden Tirado. Joseph fough in World War II in the European theatre, with an honorable discharge from the first Combat Infantry Brigade. He was awarded the Silver Star for bravery in action, and two purple hearts. In the Army he served capably as a weapons expert, and expert marksman. Senior Vice President of R & S Strauss Stores at retirement. Past President Flushing Civic Association, and Mitchell Gardens Cooperative Board. Kind, smart, generous, beloved by all. Aspiring amateur artist and sculptor. He will be dearly missed. 1/3

KRAMER--Joel M.,passed away suddenly Wednesday morning, December 3, 2014 at the age of 71. Joel was born in the Bronx, as younger son of Arthur G. Kramer and Clara Kramer (nee Spiegel). Joel pursued an acting career his entire life, having appeared on Broadway, Off Broadway, in many national touring companies, as well as appearing overseas. Joel is survived by Carole Merring Kramer, his wife of almost 50 years, by his older brother Sidney Kramer and wife Susan, and by his cousins Louise May, Karen Broner, Linda Keller, Ruth Broch, and Debbie Moore, their husbands and children. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 36-46 Bell Blvd. Bayside, NY 11361. Visiting Sunday 2-5pm and 7-10pm and Monday 11-1pm. Interment Salem Fields Cemetery. 1/3

KOENIGSBERG--Allan M.,on December 4, at home surrounded by his family. Dear partner of Rochelle Krause. Loving father of Nancie (Brandon Sullivan) and Jedediah (Christine Ferguson). Devoted brother of Marvin. Beloved husband of the late Minna. Respected educator for over 45 years. Amateur radio operator AE2J. KNAPP--Frederick J.,of New York City and East Hampton. Beloved husband of Penny Knapp, passed away November 13, 2014. He was well- known for his fine singing, his TV commercials and his lead narrator roles in company industrial shows. He later founded his speaking company on Madison Avenue and trained hundreds of executives and over thirty CEO's of top corporations. He is also survived by the families of his late brother and sister. A memorial service will be held at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Ave., at 2pm on Saturday, January 10, 2015. 1/3

JONES--Bertha K. 96, passed away on December 2, 2014 in New York City. She was born in Detroit, MI on November 25, 1918. Beloved wife of Justice Thomas R. Jones and mother of Margaret J. DeLaCour, who both predeceased her, and David R. Jones, Esq., who survives her along with five grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Bertha was a social activist and progressive from the time she graduated from Brooklyn College in 1935. Meeting her future husband Thomas R. Jones in the anti- fascist youth leagues formed before World War II, they married in 1938 becoming one of the few interracial couples of their time. Together they help found numerous organizations including the Unity Democratic Club in Central Brooklyn, which led to the election of Thomas Jones as Assemblyman and ultimately the election of Shirley Chisholm. As a professional she worked as a social worker for the City of New York and then for many years as co-coordinator of adult education for Brooklyn College. In addition to her many philanthropic efforts, she served on the Board of the Citizens Committee for Children, and with her husband, created a non-for-profit childrens advocacy publication called The Children's Times. She was a world traveler and passionately devoted to her husband, children, her daughter-in-law Dr. Valerie King, son-in-law Willis S. DeLaCour Jr, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She will be sincerely missed by all who knew her. The family prefers, in lieu of flowers, that contributions be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation in memory of Bertha K. Jones, either online at www.alzfdn.org/donation or by mail to the Alzheimer's Foundation of America, 322 Eighth Ave., 7th floor, New York, NY 10001. 1/3

HERMEL--Norma R.,on December 5, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Sidney. Devoted mom of Louise and Jeff Leitman. Cherished grandmother of Ellen, Amy, Jason and Marc and great grandmother of Samantha, Sloane and Ethan. Service Sunday, December 7, 2014, 11:30am at the Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Paramus, NJ. Donations in her memory to The Alzheimer's Association would be appreciated. 1/3

HELM--John R.,84, Montclair, NJ, died on November 29. Memorial Service: Monday, December 8, 2pm, Central Presbyterian Church, 46 Park St., Montclair. Graduate of Princeton '52. Donations to Cope Montclair or Central Presbyterian Church Mission Fund. 1/3

GURKIN--Steven Charles, M.D.,passed November 16, 2014. Survived by three daughters; Nicole Gurkin, Lesley Schulhof (Gurkin) and Danielle Gurkin, one granddaughter, and former partner of 42 years, Adrienne Gurkin. Graduated from the Horace Mann School, Bronx, NY, 1961. Earned B.A. in history from Cornell University cum Laude, 1965. Graduated from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, 1969, M.D. Board Certified in Diagnostic Radiology and Nuclear Medicine, State of California. Born in Manhattan, NY to the late Vivian and Alfred Gurkin on November 17, 1944. Passionate for jazz music. Founding partner of the Friendly Hills Medical Group. Relocated under the leadership of Dr. Alan D. Dauer. Remembered by former colleagues for his exhaustive diagnostic reports and sense of humor. Medical publications entail early stage development studies for devices in the field of radiation oncology. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests if desired donations to the Simon Wiesenthal Foundation. 1/3
FINE--Ralph Adam, Judge Wisconsin District Court of Appeals, on December 4. Survived by wife Kay, son Matthew and brother Burton M. 1/3

ENGEL--Nina Phillips, died peacefully at the age of 100 on Thanksgiving, November 27th, also the birthday of her late husband Louis Engel. The daughter of Dr. John C. Phillips of Boston and Eleanor Hyde Phillips of Bath ME, Nina was born on August 21, 1914, the month made famous by "The Guns of August" at the beginning of World War I. A descendant of a distinguished Boston family, Nina was the quintessential grande dame, but one with as much substance as style. She graduated from St. Timothy's School in Stevenson MD and studied at the Sorbonne and Sarah Lawrence before her first marriage, in 1937, to Stanley Washburn, Jr., an airline pilot. They had three children, Nancy, Nina and Stanley, III ("Brodie"). Nancy, of Gymea Bay, NSW, Australia and Brodie, of Eugene, OR survive her as do four grandchildren and two great grandchildren. She also leaves three stepsons, James (Tucumcari, NM), Thomas (New York City) and Jonathan Engel (Austin, TX). Nina returned to Sarah Lawrence in her 70s to gain her Bachelor's degree in sociology and three years later, at the age of 79, was awarded her Master's degree, also from Sarah Lawrence, in health advocacy. Active in public health her entire adult life she worked in patient screening and advocacy at many hospitals and community organizations, including St. Luke's-Roosevelt, Phelps Memorial Hospital, Westchester County Medical Center, the Ossining Drug Addiction Center and the Ossining Open Door Family Medical Center. Her long life will often be recalled by those she served for her energy in addressing the urgent public health issues of her time and her devotion to the many patients who were lucky enough to come her way. And to her family, her many younger friends and those who knew her best she will be remembered for her steady enthusiasm and sense of fun and for an elegance, ebullience and charm that will outlive her for many, many years. A memorial service will be held at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Scarborough NY at a date yet uncertain in the early part of next year. Contributions in Nina's memory may be made to the Open Door Family Medical Center, 165 Main Street, Ossining, NY 10562. 1/3

DREWRY--Henry N.,died November 21, at age 90, at home in Skillman, NJ. Pioneering black educator. Founding Director of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation's Mellon Mays Undergraduate Fellowship Program (MMUF), first Director of Teacher Preparation Program at Princeton University. He taught history at Princeton High School and Princeton University, co-authored seven books including "Stand and Prosper: Private Black Colleges and Their Students," (2001) and served on numerous school and college boards. Survived by spouse, Annette Liberson-Drewry, a nephew and two grandnephews. Memorial gathering to be announced. Donations can be made to the United Negro College Fund (UNCF) at 1805 7th Street NW, Washington, DC 20001; the NAACP Legal Defense Fund (LDF) at 40 Rector Street, 5th floor, NYC, NY 10006; and Talladega College, 627 West Battle Street, Talladega, AL 35160. 1/3

COHEN--Alfred Lewis, on December 6, 2014. Devoted cousin of Charles and Robert Cummings. Beloved significant other of Linda Saidel. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Service Monday, December 8, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. 1/3

CABASSO--Israel, passed away on December 2, 2014 at age 72. Dr. Cabasso was an accomplished faculty member of the chemistry department of SUNY-ESF for 34 years. His eclectic research was recognized internationally. His vibrant personality and talent as a painter stood out to all who had the good fortune to know him. He will be deeply missed. He is survived by his wife, Youxin; sister, Yael Kombor; nephews and niece, Elon Kombor, Qing Guo and Hillary Yuan and brothers and sisters-in-law. He returned to his birth place Jerusalem as his final resting place with his beloved wife and family members. 1/3

BRY--Doris, leading authority on the works of Alfred Stieglitz and Georgia O'Keeffe, passed away at her home in New York on December 3rd, just two days before her 94th birthday. During her long life she worked for Time-Life as a science researcher, established her own publishing imprint, Atlantis Editions, and acted as agent for Georgia O'Keeffe. She was intensely interested in photography and the challenges of reproducing it in ink. Publications with which she was involved are noted for their high level of visual quality. Bry collaborated with Nicholas Callaway on a three-volume set of Georgia O'Keeffe's paintings and was currently working with Thomas Palmer on what was to be the final work on her experiences with O'Keeffe in New Mexico. Bry wrote the exhibition catalogue for "Alfred Stieglitz" at the National Gallery of Art (Washington, DC, 1958) and authored the monograph, "Alfred Stieglitz: Photographer" at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston (1965). She published "Georgia O'Keeffe: Some Memories of Drawings," a study of O'Keeffe drawings, in 1988 (Atlantis Editions). A dignified and intensely private person who often worked alone, in 2008 Bry was honored at a symposium at Yale University with the publication of a student- curated exhibition entitled "From Any Angle: Photographs from the Collection of Doris Bry" -she greatly enjoyed her interactions with the students. Her many accomplishments included organizing, along with O'Keeffe, the estate of Alfred Stieglitz. Together they arranged for many institutions across the United States to receive gifts from Stieglitz's private collection of works by John Marin, Marsden Hartley, Arthur Dove, Charles Demuth and Georgia OKeeffe. Along with Lloyd Goodrich, Bry helped curate the major 1970 O'Keeffe exhibition at the Whitney Museum of Art, The Art Institute of Chicago and the San Francisco Museum of Art. For decades, while acting as O'Keeffe's exclusive agent, auction houses, art dealers, curators and collectors relied on her expertise, generously and freely given, to authenticate and properly catalogue works by O'Keeffe that entered the marketplace. As the price of works escalated, authenticity issues arose and Bry was asked to help on more and more occasions. Doris Bry influenced at least two decades of scholars, curators, dealers and collectors in the field of photography. She worked with the finest museums in the country, helping to build their photography collections with her early pioneering efforts in that field; she had a particularly rich relationship with the Amon Carter Museum of American Art in Fort Worth, Texas. Doris Bry is survived by her sister, Marcia Kaplan, of Chevy Chase, MD. 1/3

BRENNAN--Eileen Ann, of Kent, NY and Sailfish Point, FL, on December 4, 2014. Predeceased by her father, John J. Brennan. Survived by her mother, Eileen F. Brennan of Manhasset, NY. Mother of Nell Timmer (Ted) of Beacon, NY, Kate Lofgren (Kris) of Washington, DC and Mary Okner (Dillon) of Mountain View, CA. Grandmother of Henry, Jasper, Emmet, Mira and Graham Timmer and "Dazzle" Lofgren. Sister of John (Joan) of Ardmore, PA, Edward (Julia) of Sea Cliff, NY, Beatrice Wall (Robert) of Lloyd Harbor, NY, Michael (Lisa) of Manhasset, NY, Virginia (James Waechter) of Nashville, TN, Stephen (Patricia) of Irvington, NY, Peter (Bernadette) of Bronxville, NY, Thomas of Philadelphia, PA and William (Margaret) of Yorktown Heights, NY. Graduate of St. Mary's Girls High School class of 1967, Manhattanville College class of 1971 and Fordham Law School class of 1976. Associate at Shea, Gould, and Managing Director at Lehman Brothers and GMAC Commercial Mortgage. Visitation at McGrath's Funeral Home, Bronxville, NY on Sunday, December 7 from 1:00pm to 4:00pm. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Connie Hogarth Center for Social Action at Manhattanville College. www.conniehogarth.org 1/3

BELL--Ellis. May 28, 1923 - November 28, 2014. Ellis Bell, loving husband of Phyllis (died 2013), father of Bob (Eileen) and Ilene (Paul), and grandfather of Daniel and Jeremy Koegel. A man of passion and integrity, his family came first. As a CPA, he built a thriving practice on hard work, strength of character, flexible problem-solving, and sensitivity to how finances are embedded in lives. He was a committed secular Jew and an avid tennis player. A World War II Veteran, he believed in reason, learning, and negotiation; Ellis abhorred war. 1/3

BARTWINK--Ted. The NYU Langone Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, Hospital for Joint Diseases administration and the Harkness Center for Dance Injuries mourn the loss of Ted Bartwink, longtime executive director of the Harkness Foundation for Dance. We remember Ted for his compassion, friendship and support for the Harkness Center over the past 25 years. He will be profoundly missed by the entire Harkness Center for Dance Injuries' staff and the dance community at large. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Barbara, and his family. Joseph Zuckerman, MD, Chair of the Department of Orthopaedic Surgery, NYU Langone Medical Center Donald Rose, MD, Founding Director, Harkness Center for Dance Injuries David Dibner, Senior Vice President Hospital for Joint Diseases, Musculoskeletal and Rusk Rehabilitation 1/3

BARNUM--Dr. Barbara. Dr Barbara Stevens Barnum, RN, PhD, FAAN, nurse educator and author, passed away at age 77, October 29th in New York. Her career began in Chicago with various Nursing Directorships at the University of Illinois and University of Chicago. Moving to New York City, she became a Professor of Nursing at Columbia School of Nursing, Columbia University, Director of the Division of Health Services, Sciences and Education at Teachers College, and held a professorial position at NYU. Her nursing education books include: Nurse as Executive; Nursing Theory; and Spirituality in Nursing. She edited Nursing Leadership Forum and Nursing & Health Care. Recent work included private psychotherapy and past life regression, writing paranormal fiction, and lecturing on brain physiology. Dr Barnum was preceded in death by her husband Dr Howard James Barnum, owner of Barnum Communications and Rear Admiral in the US Navy. Surviving are her daughter Lauren, sister Lynda, nieces, stepchildren, and many friends. 1/3

ALESSANDRONI--Venan J.,a former senior partner of the Manhattan law firm of Wormser, Kiely, Alessandroni, Mahoney & McCann (predecessor to the present law firm of Wormser, Kiely, Galef & Jacobs, LLP) died on November 20, 2014 at his home in Old Greenwich, CT. He was 99 years old. Specializing in estate planning, Mr. Alessandroni joined the firm of Wormser, Kiely in 1946 and became full partner in 1949. Throughout his career, he lectured and wrote extensively on estate planning. He lectured at New York University, the University of Miami Law School and its Institute on Estate Planning, the Practicing Law Institutes of New York and New Jersey, and numerous estate planning councils in the United States. In 1974, he became an adjunct visiting professor at the University of Miami Law School. He was the Estate Tax and Gift Tax Editor of The Journal of Taxation, and has been published in The Banking Journal, the Journal of Taxation and the Journal of the University of Miami Institute on Estate Planning. His clients have included the Morgan twins, Gloria Morgan Vanderbilt and Lady Thelma Furness, Lord Furness, the Earl of Carnarvon, Sir Osbert Sitwell and Jules Stein, founder of MCA. During World War II, Mr. Alessandroni served from 1943 to 1944 as a member of the Board of Economic Warfare, stationed at Leopoldville (Kinshasa) in the Belgian Congo. Its mission was to expedite the delivery of raw materials from the Belgian Congo essential to the war effort, including uranium for the atom bomb. He remained in the Congo for 14 months and traveled extensively throughout Central Africa. From 1945-1946, as a First Lieutenant in the Army, Mr. Alessandroni was appointed Chief Military Judge in Seoul, Korea. There he presided over the trial of approximately 50 members of the Communist Party accused of inciting a riot which resulted in the loss of life. It was the first trial of communists in an area controlled by the United States. The trial lasted three months and was a feature story in The New York Times. In recognition of this service, he was awarded the Army Commendation Ribbon by the American Military Government. Mr. Alessandroni graduated from Columbia College in 1936 and Columbia Law School in 1939. He is survived by his wife of 35 years, the former Adelle Lincoln. 1/3

SIEGMAN--Dr. Felix, died this week at age 93, peacefully, at home, in the company of people he loved, listening to "Proust's Remembrance of Things Past." It was a fitting end to a life well lived. Felix started as a surgical resident at Maimonides after service as a Captain in WWII. At a time when surgical specialization was uncommon, he helped create and advance the field of vascular surgery. His affiliation with Maimonides lasted nearly 70 years. A natural teacher, he adored working with residents at Maimonides Medical Center, Downstate Hospital, and Kings County Hospital, where he helped them explore the science and the art of medicine. Until a few weeks ago, he still regularly attended 7am teaching conferences. His colleagues there were his second family. At home, Felix was a voracious reader, an enthusiastic cyclist and swimmer, and a discerning eater. He, and his wife Judith --an actress, poet, teacher, classical music scholar, and gourmet cook, who died last year --are survived by Felix's sister, loving children, grandchildren, a great-grandchild, and friends, who miss his brilliance, humor, insight, and, most of all, his humanity. Services are private. In lieu of gifts, his family requests that donations be made in his memory to the Brooklyn Botanical Gardens and Tulane Medical School. 1/3

KATSIVELOS--Dr. Speros P.,devoted husband, father and grandfather passed away peacefully on December 5, 2014 surrounded by his beloved wife Elizabeth and sons Nicholas and Stephan. He will be remembered for his love of great music and literature. Viewing Monday at the Riverdale Funeral Home 2-4pm and 7- 9pm. Funeral Tuesday at St. Spyridon Church at 10:00am. Donations in his memory may be made to St. Michaels Home for the Aged or Friends of PS 187. 1/3

KARP--Claire, of New York, NY passed away on Sunday, December 7, 2014. Claire was the daughter of the late Jacob and Dora (Tindel) Rosenbaum. She was a poet and a certified clinical social worker. She is survived by her devoted daughter, Jessica Leighton and her husband, Wayne Turett, her son Robert Leighton and his wife, Maureen Weaver and by her adoring grandchildren, Cara Turett, Alexandra Leighton, Erica Turett and Deanna Leighton. She will be remembered for her strength and decency and for imparting a devotion to family above all. 1/3

HANTGAN--George, beloved professional Jewish communal leader for seven decades, died December 6th at 98. Executive Director Emeritus of the Kaplen JCC on the Palisades. Donations to JCC, Temple Emanuel of Closter, NJ and Jewish Home Foundation, Rockleigh, NJ. Shiva will be held at the Jewish Home at Rockleigh, 10 Link Drive, Rockleigh, NJ. guttermanandmusicant.com. 1/3

WEED--William Henry, 1930-2014 died peacefully after a long struggle with congestive heart failure on December 6th. Bill graduated from Carleton College and Harvard Business School after which he began his career at Proctor & Gamble. He joined Ogilvy & Mather as a disciple of David Ogilvy in 1959, where he was a member of the Executive Committee and on the board and became Chairman of Europe in 1980. He also served on the board of the American Academy of Rome. In 2000 he became President of the executive search firm Ray & Berendtson, retiring in 2005 to Roxbury, CT. In 2010, Bill joined the board of Schools That Can, a non-profit network of high performing schools in low income cities throughout the US. Bill is survived by his wife Bette, his two children, Speed (Leslie) and Elisabeth Weed Mitchell (Matt) and his five grandchildren, Harrison, Jasmine, Skye, Willow and Poppy. Funeral will be held on December 13th at 11am at St John's Episcopal Church on the Green in Washington, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations to School That Can: www.schoolshatcan.org would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

STEINBERG--Dr. Morton, of Eastchester, NY died at the age of 88 on December 7, 2014. Beloved husband of Anne for 63 years and loving father of Jo (Barry), Lynn (Bill), Michael, Brenna (Russell) and Peter (Caroline). Loving grandfather of Orrly, Adi, Emma, Sean, Jacob, Justin, Emma, Corina, Kali and Natalie. A graduate of Syracuse University and Temple University School of Dentistry, he practiced in New Rochelle for almost fifty years and was beloved by his patients. A champion of the rights and needs of people with developmental disabilities, Dr. Steinberg was co- founder and former president of Alternate Pathways and Group Residences of Westchester (GROW) and a board member of Westchester ARC. He was a founder of The Observer, a local weekly alternative newspaper during the 1970s. With his wife Anne he loved to dance, go to the theater, listen to classical and jazz music, travel throughout the world, and put their thoughts into action. He will be deeply missed by all who had the honor of knowing him. Contributions in his memory may be made to GROW, PO Box 1692, White Plains, NY 10602. Services will be held at 11:30 AM on Wednesday, December 10 at Garlick Funeral Homes, 14 Lecount Place, New Rochelle, NY. 1/3

SILVER--David, 84, passed away December 7 with his adored daughter and wife, Nicole and Linda, at his side. He leaves a devoted family, including his brother, Michael, in-laws Ronnie, Saad and Alan, daughter Valerie, and the many loyal friends who shared in his distinctive and colorful life. A lifelong New Yorker, he was a Korean War Air Force veteran, a skilled labor law litigator, an accomplished photographer, jazz aficionado, wit and raconteur. He will be forever missed and remembered. Friends and family will gather at Linda's home this week to celebrate his life. 1/3

SALOMON--William R. We, the surviving senior partners of Salomon Brothers at the time of his retirement in 1978, are greatly grieved by the loss of our leader, William R. Salomon, better known to all as Billy. His father was one of the three brothers who had founded the firm in 1910. When Billy became the Managing Partner in 1963, the firm was predominantly a money market and bond house. When he retired, Salomon Brothers was well on the way to becoming a dominant investment banking house, recognized widely for its competence in trading, underwriting and research. To Billy, our varied backgrounds did not matter. He encouraged us to persist and succeed, to compete fiercely but to deal fairly with our clients, and to do so with an overriding objective- to protect the integrity of Salomon Brothers. John H. Gutfreund J. Ira Harris Gedale B. Horowitz Henry Kaufman Richard J. Schmeelk James D. Wolfensohn 1/3

SALOMON--William Roger, age 100, died peacefully in his home on December 7, 2014 after a slow decline in health and a long and bountiful life. Managing Partner of Salomon Brothers from 1963-78, he joined the firm started by his father, Percy, his two uncles, and Morton Hutzler in 1933, becoming a partner in 1944. He was a member of the board of the New York Stock Exchange from 1970-1972, on the Board of Trustees of NYU, and a long standing and devoted member of the board of trustees of the Hospital for Special Surgery. He was predeceased in 2008 by his beloved wife of 71 years, Virginia Foster Salomon and his brother, Robert Salomon. Loving and loved father of Peter F. Salomon MD (Patricia Morgan), Tucson, Arizona, and Susan Salomon Neiman (Phil), Los Angeles, California, grandfather of Wendy N. Salomon, Liza S. Byrne, Jillian Whelan, and Heather Shapiro, and great-grandfather of three. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Hospital for Special Surgery, 535 East 70th Street, New York, New York 10021 or the charity of your choice. A memorial service will be held at a later date. 1/3

REISEL--Philip, we will miss our longtime friend and traveling buddy. We shared many a good time and many a sad time together but a lifetime of memories with you and Adrian. We hope this last trip will be filled with peace and free of pain. You will forever be in our hearts. Our love goes out to Adrian, Jill, Leslie, and Jason. Bonnie and Bob Konigsberg 1/3

JALON--Cyril. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Cyril Jalon, and extend sincere condolences to his family. James Dreyfus, President 1/3

JALON--Cyril, on December 7, 2014 at the age of 95. He reveled in all that life offered- skiing, tennis, music, bridge and good wine. Beloved husband of the late Elena Jalon, loving father of Stephan and Allan, adored father-in-law of Rose and Mary, cherished grandfather of Pnina and Damion Armour, Arnon, Hillary and Hedi Jalon, great-grandfather of Lily Marie, Rena Day and Dena Elena. Dear brother of Phyllis Guenzburger and dear uncle of Corinne, Eric, Bertin and Fabian Guenzburger. Funeral services December 9th, 11:30am, Bet Am Shalom Synagogue, 295 Soundview Avenue, White Plains. 1/3

HANTGAN--George. Beloved professional Jewish communal leader for seven decades, died December 6th at 98. Executive Director Emeritus of the Kaplen JCC on the Palisades. Founding director of the local UJA Federation. Former president of Englewood Board of Education among many other civic endeavors. Listed in "Who's Who in World Jewry". Survived by his wife of 65 years, Ida ("Hon"), his three children, two daughters-in-law and four grandchildren. Service at the Kaplen JCC, Tenafly, NJ 1pm, Monday, December 8th. Donations to JCC, Temple Emanuel of Closter, NJ and Jewish Home Foundation, Rockleigh, NJ. Shiva will be held at the Jewish Home at Rockleigh, 10 Link Drive, Rockleigh, NJ. guttermanandmusicant.com. 1/3

GEMMILL--John Henry, Architect, of Guilford, CT, Southwest Harbor, and Franklin, ME. 6 December 2014 in New Haven, CT. Born 25 March 1943, Yale B.A. 1965, Lt. JG U.S. Navy 1965-67. Yachtsman, beloved husband last forty years of Stacey McGlone Gemmill. Grateful for contributions to Partners in Health, Doctors without Borders and/or the Henry Gemmill Scholarship c/o Franklin Maine Historical Society .FH 04634. 1/3

FRISH--Irwin Albert, son of Jacob and Fanye, born October 15, 1927, passed away peacefully on December 7, 2014. Married lovingly to Arline Baar Frish for Sixty years. Adored father of, William (Rhonda), Robert (Kathryn) and Ilene (Jeffrey) Levin. Beloved Grandfather of Jennifer, David, Daniel, Brittany, Rachel, Jonathon, Allison and Julie. His warmth and humor will be missed but not forgotten. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Jupiter Medical Center Jupiter, FL 33477 or Palm Beach Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. 1/3
COHEN--Alfred. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Alfred Cohen. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family. 1/3

LIPMAN--Margaret Josephine. (Josie) Jaretzki 97, died peacefully on December 6, 2014 in Chevy Chase, MD. She was the daughter of the late Alfred Jaretzki, Jr., a senior partner with Sullivan & Cromwell and the late Edna Merson, a prominent Civil Rights Advocate. Her marriage to the late Henry T. Lipman ended in divorce. She is survived by her two children, Dr. Tim Lipman (Hannah) and Ruth Simon Anderson (Frank Anderson), five grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Needlechasers of Chevy Chase (Needlechasers.org) or to House of Ruth houseofruth.org.

FORTI--Dr. Annette D.,of Brooklyn, NY, on November 20, 2014. Daughter of Tessie (nee Arangio), beloved cousin and "Auntie Net" to nephews and nieces. Noted educator, scholar, and mentor, graduated NYU. Ph.D. Fordham University, Alumni Award for Lifetime Achievement. Professor Emeritus, SUNY Old Westbury, a founder of its business degree. Founder/Director of COPE, Director Eastern Economic Association, advisor to U.S. Department of Transportation, Evaluator-Commission on Higher Education. She will live on in the memories of the many colleagues and students whose lives she enriched.

BRADT--Morris Jr. The Troubh, Belsky, Doyle, and Polikoff families send their thoughts and love to the family of Morris Bradt, Jr. Peggy, George and Meg, Rick and Marty, George, Peter, Avery, Serena, Reid, and Ward, We will always remember "Pops" with a welcoming smile, a firm handshake and a funny story; he was everyone's Buddy. We will miss him dearly, but we also know that his was a "life, well-lived."

The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our deepest sympathy at the passing of William Salomon, who made extraordinary contributions to the hospital's work and mission with more than 35 years of service on our Board of Trustees. His exceptional philanthropy improved the lives of countless patients through his support of The Virginia F. and William R. Salomon Rehabilitation Department and the endowed research chair in his name. Over the course of nearly half a century, he participated in the growth and evolution of the hospital with exceptional service and dedication. This year, we had the privilege of honoring him on his 100th birthday at the hospital's Annual Tribute Dinner, saluting the incredible life of this vibrant, kind, and generous man. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Kendrick R. Wilson, III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO; Todd J. Albert, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief and Medical Director, Hospital for Special Surgery 1/3

BRODEUR--Lester. Lester Brodeur, age 75 of Rockwall, TX, passed away December 5, 2014. He was born January 28, 1939, in Brooklyn, NY, to Lester and Kathleen (Dockerty) Bullene. Born to poverty, Lester was the oldest of six children and soon became the breadwinner for his younger brothers, sisters and mother. He enlisted in the U.S. Coast Guard in 1956 and after his discharge in 1959 attended college at night, after work. Lester earned two bachelors degrees on the GI Bill from the University of Massachusetts at Lowell, one in Mathematics and the other in Aerospace Engineering. From there, he pursued his passion in electronics and computers and soon became a renowned inventor. Lester possessed a genius level IQ and was gifted in aerospace, computer technology, guidance systems, micro-chip engineering, medical inventions and applied science. Among his more famous inventions are the final stages of the MRI, the fetal heart monitor, the microprocessor-controlled LORAN C (precursor to GPS), the electrical waveform generator, many military jet counter-measure systems, the Air Force One guidance system and NASAs Space Shuttle guidance system. He held 35 U.S. patents and dozens of foreign patents. In 1976, at the young age of 37, Lester was nominated by his peers for the Nobel Prize in Science. A hard worker and creative inventor, he rose to the prestigious positions of Chief Scientist of Lockheed Martin Corporation and Principal Senior Engineer of BAE Systems. According to his fellow engineers, though, Lesters greatest gift was his friendly and down to earth manner. He was a dedicated husband and father, an avid sailor and pilot, and a man who loved life. Lester is survived by his wife of 56 years: Kate Brodeur of Rockwall, TX; sons: Mark Brodeur of Rockwall, TX, and David Brodeur of Eliot, ME; daughter: Jennifer Pachico of Hudson, NH; brothers: James Wallace Brodeur and Robert Brodeur, both of Medford, OR, and Donald Brodeur of St. Pete Beach, FL; sisters: Cathleen Cudd of Walnut Creek, CA, and Michelle Latourette of Mesa, AZ; ten grandchildren and one great grandchild. He was preceded in death by his sister: Diane Smith. The family will hold a memorial service to honor Lester this Spring on Martha's Vineyard Island, where he and his wife Kate enjoyed their first years of marriage. 1/3

REPETTI--Joan Campbell. Joan Campbell Repetti of Spring Lake and Short Hills, N.J., passed away on December 9, 2014. Mrs. Repetti graduated from Immaculate Conception High School in Montclair, N.J. and attended Immaculata College. Mrs. Repetti completed her undergraduate degree at Fairleigh Dickinson University and obtained a Master of Fine Arts Degree from the New School for Social Research. Mrs. Repetti had a lifelong passion for the arts, regularly sponsoring and attending the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and the American Ballet Theater. She enjoyed making furniture as well as designing/executing fine needlework. She was an avid bridge player, intrepid traveler, New York Times crossword fanatic and a member of the Spring Lake Golf Club and Spring Lake Historical Society. Mrs. Repetti is predeceased by her husband of over 50 years, Peter J. Repetti, a former partner with the law firm of Fulbright & Jaworski , and her sister Patricia Reiss Campbell. LIEBOWITZ--Murray, of Boca Raton, Florida and South Egremont, Massachusetts, died at home surrounded by family on Monday, December 1st, 2014. He was 86. Mr. Liebowitz was born in Manhattan on September 4th, 1928 to Lena and Henry Liebowitz. His father ran a hotel in the Catskills, The Pine Grove Hotel in Loch Sheldrake, New York, and Murray spent many summers helping him do so. His business acumen came naturally and he had great successes in his career through a variety of activities ranging from selling eggs (Jersey June Eggs) to commercial real estate (MSL Management) to trading on the stock market. (He always said the best eggs to buy were large and brown -never white or extra large.) Murray and his wife Patti (1934-2013) had an appreciation for good food and memorable parties. Together, they dined in restaurants throughout Europe and ate meals prepared in their homes by world-renowned chefs and Murray was a certified member of the food and wine society called the Chaine des Rotisseurs. The parties they hosted on many special occasions--at Blantyre in Lenox, Massachusetts, and at their homes in the Berkshires and south Florida--were always memorable. Their New Year's Eve parties, with the best champagne from Murray's extensive cellar and caviar from Zabar's, annually kicked off the years in style for their family and friends. But they also sat down every night at 6:30, with each other and often other family members, to a home-made meal in their kitchen that followed the "rules of the Chaine" on a properly set table. Murray was proud of his Jewish heritage and embraced its tradition of philanthropy throughout his life. Patti and he supported many worthy causes, including American Friends of Torah B'Yisrael -affiliated with a New Jersey synagogue that educated his children when he was just starting out, the Anti-Defamation League, and Women in Distress of Broward County. He was deeply committed to the value of higher education, and his greatest support was devoted to his daughter Suzanne's alma mater, Simon's Rock College of Bard in the Berkshires, where he served for thirty years, first as a member and then as vice-president of the Board of Overseers; and to Bard College in New York, where he was a member of the Board of Trustees for more than twenty years. His many gifts to Simon's Rock provided essential support to its annual fund, scholarship, endowment, and building projects-- including the construction of the Liebowitz Arts and Humanities Center and the Liebowitz Center for International Studies, establishment of the Murray Liebowitz and the Lena Liebowitz Scholarships. His support of Bard College and the initiatives of its president, Leon Botstein, were also extensive. Murray developed and nurtured numerous friendships throughout his life -many lasting a lifetime. Their support and love for Murray enriched his life immensely, just as his life has enriched theirs. He leaves them behind along with a family that loves him. He is survived by his children, Howard Liebowitz, Sheldon Liebowitz, Susan Rindner, Suzanne Klimek and Pamela Palumbo; and his grandchildren Bryan, Justin and Lauren Rindner; Nicole Liebowitz; and Zachary and Michael Palumbo. Arrangements for a spring memorial are pending. Mourners may honor his memory through an act of philanthropy to any of the organizations listed above or one of their choosing. 1/3

JOSEPHY--Warren S.,died on Tuesday at 97. Beloved husband of Joanne for 72 years, father of Jennifer and Andrea (Paul) Leiman, grandfather of Lauren, David and Jonathan. A World War II hero, he served as Captain in the field artillery. He landed on Omaha Beach, took part in the Liberation of Paris, and fought in four subsequent battles, including the Battle of the Bulge and the Battle of the Huertgen Forest, during which he performed acts of bravery for which he was awarded the Silver Star. He founded the textile firm Forte Fabrics. In retirement, he served on the the board of the Lexington School for the Deaf and was a long-standing and devoted member of the Metropolitan Museum. 1/3

HARTWELL--Anne V.,died on December 9 at home in Framingham, MA of pancreatic cancer discovered only three weeks earlier. We who are writing this, her children and husband of 59 years, can only say she was, quite simply, the light of our lives. She was loving, caring and funny in about equal proportions. She also set an example for us by her own accomplishments in the fields of politics and work for disadvantaged persons. Being the daughter of a Rhode Island governor, William H. Vanderbilt, her first love was politics. She worked in the campaigns of John F. Kennedy (president 1960); Robert Kennedy (New York Senate 1964); Adlai Stevenson III (U.S.Senate 1970); Dan Walker (Illinois Governor 1972); Ruth Messinger (Manhattan Borough President 1989); and Paul Tsongas (president 1992). Her interest in helping the disadvantaged was focused on low income housing in New York City. From the early 1970's to the 1990's, she held senior volunteer positions with Mobilization for Youth Legal Services (tenant management); Association for Neighborhood Housing Development (tenant co-ops for purchasing fuel, insurance, etc.); and Bronx Heights Neighborhood Community Corporation (housing related community organizing). Upon moving to Boston in the early 1990's, she became a volunteer with Dudley Street Neighborhood Initiative located south of the city. At other times, she was a participant in the founding of radio station WMCA's Call For Action in New York; Chicago Journalism Review; New York based Women's World Banking; and The New York Women's Foundation. Board memberships included Paul Newman's Hole in the Wall Gang Camp, Citizens Committee for New York, and Adlai Stevenson Institute. Her enjoyment of skiing and mountain trekking caused all of us to take up these sports and make them the center of family vacations. Anne is survived by three daughters, Ellen Blais, Charlotte Gesten, and Anne MacNair; a son, Samuel Hartwell, Jr.; eight grandchildren; and her husband, Samuel Hartwell, Sr. Among her parting words she said that misbehavior by any of us would result in corrective visitations by her from above. A reception will be held for family and friends at 10:30am on Saturday December 13, 191 Clyde Street, Chestnut Hill, MA 02467. 1/3

GERSHBERG--Dr. Myron R. Gershberg, 80, of Brooklyn, Manhattan, and Pawling, NY, died suddenly Tuesday, December 9. Dr. Gershberg retired from private practice & North General Hospital in Harlem, where he was Head of Psychiatry; he designed and managed addiction and child abuse programs among others. He graduated from Cornell University; trained at the Univ. of Buffalo, Bellevue Hospital, and the White Institute; and was faculty at NYU School of Medicine. He was an avid birder, loved nature, reading biographies and performing Shakespeare with The Pawling Shakespeare Club. Dr. Gershberg's sense of social justice and his dedication to the mental health of others were his true calling and gift. He is survived by his wife of 37 years, Raquel Salvande Gershberg; three sons: Alec, Richard, and Nicholas of Brooklyn; and grandchildren C.C. and Milo Servon. A private funeral will be held on Friday. A public memorial service will be held at The Brooklyn Society for Ethical Culture, 53 Prospect Park West at 11am Saturday December 13. In December 1971, Yoko Ono presented a conceptual work at the Museum of Modern Art – sort of. The typically prankish piece purported to be a solo exhibition by Ms. Ono at the museum. But though she advertised the show and printed a catalog for it, the show was unauthorized, and none of Ms. Ono’s work was on display, except for a sign she posted at the entrance telling visitors that she had released flies at the museum, and that everyone was invited to track them down throughout the city.

During the 1960 presidential election, the writer Norman Mailer saw in John F. Kennedy the embodiment of the “hipster” values he believed could revitalize a stagnant America. Consequently, Mailer penned a lyrical 14,000-word paean to Kennedy entitled “Superman Comes to the Supermarket,” published in Esquire that same year. ROBERTS--Flora. December 12, 1998. You would be very proud of the graduates of your literary agency (you know who you are). One of your favorite words -aspiration -has been fulfilled. WEINBERGER--Beulah, wife of the late Herbert Weinberger, mother of Nancy Isserlis and the late Marc Weinberger, grandmother to Drew Isserlis Kramer, Michael Isserlis, Arielle Weinberger Papadam and Scott Weinberger, mother-in-law to Maurice Miller, sister to Mildred Morse and Estelle Gold, died on December 11, 2014, after a long and brave battle with a rare form of lymphoma. She was a beautiful, vibrant, loving and generous person with an amazing sense of style who will be greatly missed by all who knew her. Funeral services will be held Sunday, December 14, 2014 at 10am at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. SALOMON--William R. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our deepest sympathy at the passing of William Salomon, who made extraordinary contributions to the hospital's work and mission with more than 35 years of service on our Board of Trustees. His exceptional philanthropy improved the lives of countless patients through his support of The Virginia F. and William R. Salomon Rehabilitation Department and the endowed research chair in his name. Over the course of nearly half a century, he participated in the growth and evolution of the hospital with exceptional service and dedication. This year, we had the privilege of honoring him on his 100th birthday at the hospital's Annual Tribute Dinner, saluting the incredible life of this vibrant, kind, and generous man. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his entire family. Kendrick R. Wilson, III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO; Todd J. Albert, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief and Medical Director, Hospital for Special Surgery 1/3

REPETTI--Joan Campbell. Joan Campbell Repetti of Spring Lake and Short Hills, N.J., passed away on December 9, 2014. Mrs. Repetti graduated from Immaculate Conception High School in Montclair, N.J. and attended Immaculata College. Mrs. Repetti completed her undergraduate degree at Fairleigh Dickinson University and obtained a Master of Fine Arts Degree from the New School for Social Research. Mrs. Repetti had a lifelong passion for the arts, regularly sponsoring and attending the Metropolitan Opera, the New York Philharmonic and the American Ballet Theater. She enjoyed making furniture as well as designing/executing fine needlework. She was an avid bridge player, intrepid traveler, New York Times crossword fanatic and a member of the Spring Lake Golf Club and Spring Lake Historical Society. Mrs. Repetti is predeceased by her husband of over 50 years, Peter J. Repetti, a former partner with the law firm of Fulbright & Jaworski , and her sister Patricia Reiss Campbell. She is survived by her children Grace, Joan, Charles, and Christina, together with many step- grandchildren, nieces, nephews, grand nephews and grand nieces. Relatives and friends are invited to the visitation on Friday, December 12, 2014 from 4-8pm at the O'Brien Funeral Home, 2028 Rt. 35, Wall, NJ, followed by a Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, December 13 at 9am at St. Margaret Church, 3rd and Ludlow Avenues, Spring Lake, NJ. Burial to follow at St. Catharine Cemetery, Sea Girt, NJ. The family suggests donations be made to The Spring Lake Historical Society, P.O. Box 703, Spring Lake, NJ 07762 or Saint John's Soup Kitchen, P.O. Box 200147, Newark, NJ 07102. For more info, please visit obrienfuneralhome.com. 1/3

KREDITOR--Lawrence "Larry," 85 years of age, on December 10th. Beloved husband of Marlene for 64 years. Cherished father of Sheila Lobel (Ira), Alise Kreditor (Jeffrey Englander), Mark Kreditor (Carol). Adored grandfather of nine and great- grandfather of Juliet. JACOBSON--Florence Johnson, 86, Naples FL, formerly of Spring Lake and Verona, NJ died from complications of Parkinson's Disease on Tuesday, December 9, 2014 in Naples, FL. Florence was a graduate of Montclair Kimberly Academy and Caldwell College. She received a Master's degree in Gerontology from the Graduate School of the College of New Rochelle. Florence was an intelligent, energetic and caring woman who enjoyed an active and busy life. As everyone knows, she was an avid Yankee fan her entire life. She also enjoyed golf and shot a spectacular hole in one in September, 2000, at Bel-Aire Golf Course in Spring Lake using a driver on the 14th hole. She loved retirement at the shore, especially with memories of her childhood in Spring Lake. She worked in many ministries in the Archdiocese of Newark, including The Catholic Advocate newspaper, interfaith youth group, and hospice of Union County. She was an editor, lector and Eucharistic minister. She provided 35 years of dedicated service to Our Lady of the Lake Parish in Verona. Florence held leadership roles in Renew International, Cursillo, Pastoral Council, liturgy planning, Verona Interfaith Religious Council, and Family Life for which she developed programs for seniors. Sudie, as she was known to family, was born on August 15, 1928 in North Bergen, NJ to Florence Endler Johnson and Rupert Harris Johnson. She is survived by brothers and sisters: Frances Furlong, Reverend Father Andrew Johnson, Charles (Ann) Johnson, Rupert (Maryellie) Johnson Jr., Bonnie Sacerdote and Suzanne (David) Razor; children: Susan (Pat) Forber, Jeffrey (Kathy) Jacobson, Mary (Lynn Gretkowski) Jacobson, Anne Pignatiello, and Elizabeth Jacobson; 12 grandchildren and one great grandchild, numerous cousins, nieces, nephews, and dear friends. Florence was preceded in death by her son, Stephen Jacobson, sister Dorothy McGuire, sister-in-law Mary Ann Johnson, brothers- in-law Charles McGuire, Robert Furlong, Peter Sacerdote, and son-in-law Steven Bertucci. A Funeral Mass will be held at Our Lady of the Lake Church, 32 Lakeside Avenue, Verona, NJ on Monday, December 15 at 10am. The wake will be held at Prout Funeral Home: proutfuneralhome.com, 370 Bloomfield Avenue, Verona, NJ on Sunday from 1 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: Michael J. Fox Parkinson's Association or HHSNE (Haiti) c/o Father John Martin, Monsignor Kelly Residence, 247 Bloomfield Avenue, Caldwell, NJ, 07006. 1/3

HICKMAN--J. Kenneth. 86, of Summit, NJ passed away December 10, 2014. Graduated Regis High School (1946), Fordham University (1951). Korean War Veteran. Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Regis and Trustee Emeritus of Fordham. Served on Advisory Committees at Rutgers Graduate School of Business and Seton Hall University. After 37 years with Arthur Andersen, Ken retired as a Senior Partner having opened the Newark office and served as Director of International Business Practice in New York. Ken served on National Foreign Trade Council, Foreign Policy Association, Business Council for International Understanding, Ireland- US Council, and US-USSR Trade and Economic Council. Founder and chairman of the US Industry Coordinating Group on European Union matters, member of American Council on Germany, National Committee for US-China Relations, Economic Club of New York, and Industry Advisory Committee to the Office of the US Trade Representative. Member of American Institute of CPAs and NY and NJ Societies of CPAs. Ken had strong convictions and held everyone to the highest standards, yet he was humble and accessible. Quick-witted, he was a wonderful story teller. He was a loyal, thoughtful and easy friend, freely giving of his time and counsel. Ken is survived by his wife Irene (Davis), daughters Trish, Carolyn and Beth, four granddaughters and a great-grandson. Ken is also survived by his brother Wallace and his family. Services will be held on Tuesday, December 16th, 10:45am at St. Teresa of Avila Church, 306 Morris Ave, Summit, NJ. Relatives and friends are invited to visit on Monday, December 15, 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Bradley Brough & Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave, Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial donations be made to Alzheimer's Association of America or Fordham University. For further info, please visit: bradleyfuneralhomes.com 1

HAZAN--Jane Freilicher, nee Niederhoffer, 90, of New York City and Water Mill, NY, on December 9, of complications from pneumonia. Beloved wife of Joseph Hazan, who predeceased her. Survived by her daughter Elizabeth, son-in-law, Stephen Hicks and grandchildren, Benjamin, Katharine and Lucian Hicks. FREILICHER--Jane. Tibor de Nagy Gallery mourns the loss of beloved painter Jane Freilicher. An extraordinary artist and exceptional friend, Jane will be profoundly missed. We will never forget her incisive humor, her acute intelligence, her integrity and poise. 1/3

EICHLER--Paul. The staff and trustees of the Feinstein Institute for Medical Research and the North Shore- LIJ Health System mourn the loss of Paul Eichler, a member of the Feinstein Institute's board of directors and associate trustee of the health system. Paul was a persistent and tireless benefactor whose quiet demeanor belied a passion for advancing research and medicine. Thanks to his generous support, the Feinstein Institute has become an international leader in biomedical research. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife Estelle; children Ken, Allyson and Jackie and their respective spouses Ira, Martin and Kurt. Barbara Hrbek Zucker, Chair of the Board, The Feinstein Institute for Medical Research Mark L. Claster, Chairman, Board of Trustees, North Shore-LIJ Health System Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, North Shore-LIJ Health System 1/3

BYE--Theodore S.,of Boca Raton, FL, Woodmere, NY, and Brooklyn, NY on December 10 at age 88. Son of Harry and Mildred Bye, brother of Elaine Bye. Ted graduated with a PhD in Organic Chemistry from Ohio State University in 1951. After an accomplished career in chemistry, he pursued a career in Real Estate. Beloved husband of 62 years to Davida, loving father to daughters Helen Wagner (Robert Wagner), Francine Bye, and Alice Bye, adored grandfather of Melissa (Adam), Michael, Jeffrey, Lindsay, Steven, and Richard. Hello Times Insiders.

What do U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara and global ride-sharing company Uber have in common? Both powerhouses just had a Terrible, Horrible, No Good, Very Bad week. In New York, Attorney Bharara saw the insider trading convictions of two former hedge fund traders overturned in a case likely to spur challenges to guilty pleas his office has already obtained. Meanwhile Uber, no stranger to controversy, saw its services banned, curtailed, or challenged in at least half a dozen cities, while two of its drivers were placed under investigation for allegedly raping their passengers.
More than half of New Yorkers approve of the job that Bill de Blasio is doing in his first year as mayor, according to the poll.
