During the week, Times reporters and contributors gave television and radio interviews about top news stories. Highlights below:

For the brand agency Chandelier Creative, eccentric and outsize parties are nothing new: last year’s holiday bash featured sexy angels, devils and nuns, plus a scantily clad Adam and Eve. Tonight, Chandelier throws a celebration dedicated to another object of worship (for a certain kind of die-hard fan, anyway): Dolly Parton, who will be honored in various ways throughout the evening, from tribute performances by artists including Rufus Wainwright and Jake Shears of Scissor Sisters, to an exhibition of the Iron Butterfly’s costumes. The agency also tapped the young director Nathaniel Brown to create a trippy datamoshed video, set to a remix of “Jolene” by the buzzy Norwegian producer Todd Terje. An exclusive preview — featuring kaleidoscopic visuals, a cameo by Paul Reubens and lots and lots of sequins — premieres here. A silent auction at Gavel & Grand, now live online, accompanies the exhibition; proceeds will benefit Dolly Parton’s Imagination Library.

Alexander Calder may be best known for his kinetic mobiles, but the sculptor himself was also in constant motion. His oeuvre suggests an attention that shifted effortlessly across art and objects — from elaborate stage sets to jewelry worn by intellectual icons such as Simone de Beauvoir and Georgia O’Keeffe. Now, a capsule collection by the Tokyo-based stationer Postalco highlights the artist’s graphic work, in the form of embossed travel wallets and a spiral notebook punctuated by Calder’s own sketches and jottings. One quote, from 1951, seems to offer advice for how one might fill the interspersed blank pages: “That others grasp what I have in mind seems unessential, at least as long as they have something else in theirs.”

Their work couldn’t be more different, but Jack Kirby and Charles M. Schulz belong in the same breath as two of the most significant comics artists of the 20th century. Both were veterans of World War II and shared as heroes cartoonists like Milton Caniff (“Terry and the Pirates”), Alex Raymond (“Flash Gordon”) and Hal Foster (“Prince Valiant”). And upon their deaths, both left behind a trove of characters that continue to resonate and thrive. To name just a few: Captain America, the Mighty Thor, the Incredible Hulk (Kirby); Snoopy, Charlie Brown, Linus and Lucy (Schulz).
The making of “Dukhtar,” Pakistan’s submission for the Oscar for best foreign-language film, is almost as compelling a story as the one the movie tells.

At his new eponymous restaurant on the Left Bank in Paris, the Japanese chef Shinsuke Nakatani entitles his menu “An Homage to France.” It speaks to the growing reverence for Gallic gastronomy among the new generation of Japanese chefs — three of whom have recently opened some of the French capital’s best and most original new restaurants.

The 92nd Street Y has announced its first Latin jazz festival, Latin on Lex, to be held March 12 to 14. Organized by the trumpeter Brian Lynch, it will feature artists eminent and up-and-coming in three theme concerts. The kickoff, on March 12, is a showcase for the pianist and bandleader Eddie Palmieri, with whom Mr. Lynch shared a Grammy for best Latin jazz album in 2006. They’ll perform together in Mr. Palmieri’s Afro-Caribbean Jazz Octet.

It is a full year until Frank Sinatra’s centenary – Friday would have been his 99th birthday – but the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts is starting its celebration early. In a collaboration with the Grammy Museum of Los Angeles and the Sinatra family, the library will present “Sinatra: An American Icon,” an exhibition that will recognize Sinatra’s work as a singer and as an actor. The exhibition opens on March 4 at the library’s Donald and Mary Oenslager Gallery and will run through Sept. 4.

As the creative director of Bottega Veneta, Tomas Maier has consistently sought to protect the brand’s heritage of craftsmanship. In this same spirit, Maier is now taking on a new kind of preservation project. ROGERS--William B.,94, a generous philanthropist who founded American Trans Coil Corporation, died in his New York home on December 8. He leaves behind his wife of 70 years, Mollie, and daughters Patricia, Jill (Stuart), Merily (Mark) and five grandchildren. Funeral services will take place on December 14 at Temple Sinai in Roslyn Heights, NY at noon. Donations in his memory may be made to The Dr. R. Shlofmitz Cardiac Research Fund at St. Francis Hospital or the William B. Rogers Fund at Vanderbilt Museum. 1/3

LoGUIDICE--Frank C.,died on December 10, 2014 in New York surrounded by his family. He was 88 years old. Frank's beloved wife, Rosalind, and his son, James, pre- deceased him. Frank is survived by his son, Frank M. LoGuidice; his daughters, Karen Murphy and Marion LoGuidice; and four grandchildren, Skye, Jim, Kelly, and Jamie. He was a Professional Engineer, whose innovative structural designs and expertise as a construction manager formed the basis for some of the most important construction projects in the United States. His legacy includes: the 1950 White House renovation, the United Nations General Assembly Building, the Union Carbide Building, the South Mall Project Albany, the Jones Beach Amphitheater, Hunts Point Market, Stony Brook University, and the United Airlines Terminal at JFK. Frank was Deputy Commissioner of Nassau County Public Works from 1976 to 1979 and he served his country honorably in the Army Air Force in World War II. Visitation on Saturday 7pm-9pm Sunday 2pm-4pm and 7pm - 9pm and at Donza Funeral Home, 333 Atlantic Avenue, East Rockaway, L.I. Funeral mass Monday 9:15am Sacred Heart RC Church, Island Park. Interment at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. 1/3

JACOBSON--Florence Johnson, 86, Naples FL, formerly of Spring Lake and Verona, NJ died from complications of Parkinson's Disease on Tuesday, December 9, 2014 in Naples, FL. Florence was a graduate of Montclair Kimberly Academy and Caldwell College. She received a Master's degree in Gerontology from the Graduate School of the College of New Rochelle. Florence was an intelligent, energetic and caring woman who enjoyed an active and busy life. As everyone knows, she was an avid Yankee fan her entire life. She also enjoyed golf and shot a spectacular hole in one in September, 2000, at Bel-Aire Golf Course in Spring Lake using a driver on the 14th hole. She loved retirement at the shore, especially with memories of her childhood in Spring Lake. She worked in many ministries in the Archdiocese of Newark, including The Catholic Advocate newspaper, interfaith youth group, and hospice of Union County. She was an editor, lector and Eucharistic minister. She provided 35 years of dedicated service to Our Lady of the Lake Parish in Verona. Florence held leadership roles in Renew International, Cursillo, Pastoral Council, liturgy planning, Verona Interfaith Religious Council, and Family Life for which she developed programs for seniors. Sudie, as she was known to family, was born on August 15, 1928 in North Bergen, NJ to Florence Endler Johnson and Rupert Harris Johnson. She is survived by brothers and sisters: Frances Furlong, Reverend Father Andrew Johnson, Charles (Ann) Johnson, Rupert (Maryellie) Johnson Jr., Bonnie Sacerdote and Suzanne (David) Razor; children: Susan (Pat) Forber, Jeffrey (Kathy) Jacobson, Mary (Lynn Gretkowski) Jacobson, Anne Pignatiello, and Elizabeth Jacobson; 12 grandchildren and one great grandchild, numerous cousins, nieces, nephews, and dear friends. Florence was preceded in death by her son, Stephen Jacobson, sister Dorothy McGuire, sister-in-law Mary Ann Johnson, brothers- in-law Charles McGuire, Robert Furlong, Peter Sacerdote, and son-in-law Steven Bertucci. A Funeral Mass will be held at Our Lady of the Lake Church, 32 Lakeside Avenue, Verona, NJ on Monday, December 15 at 10am. The wake will be held at Prout Funeral Home: proutfuneralhome.com, 370 Bloomfield Avenue, Verona, NJ on Sunday from 1 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: Michael J. Fox Parkinson's Association or HHSNE (Haiti) c/o Father John Martin, Monsignor Kelly Residence, 247 Bloomfield Avenue, Caldwell, NJ, 07006. 1/3
FREILICHER--Jane. We mourn the loss of Jane Freilicher, 1996 recipient of Guild Hall's Academy of the Arts Lifetime Achievement Award for Visual Arts. The Guild Hall Board of Trustees 1/3

EICHLER--Paul. The Board of Trustees and the entire Hospital for Special Surgery community extend our heartfelt sympathy at the passing of Paul Eichler, a long-time friend of the Hospital. Through his generous support as a trustee of the Leonard Wagner Charitable Trust, Mr. Eichler played a critical role in advancing research and education focused on improving the lives of all those affected by arthritis and other autoimmune and inflammatory illnesses. We are grateful for Mr. Eichler's commitment to HSS and extend our deepest condolences to his family. Kendrick R. Wilson, III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO; Todd J. Albert, M.D., Surgeon-in-Chief and Medical Director, Hospital for Special Surgery 1/3

Sirow--Melvin, 90, passed away on Friday one year after his wife and love of his life Doris died. As a graduate of NYU Dental School he completed an internship at Harlem Hospital but never practiced. He worked with his late brother-in-law Selig Burrows for over 40 years at Central Linen. Mel was an exceptionally civic minded individual, involved in many community and charitable activities. He and Doris were longtime residents of Kings Point, NY where he was a Trustee as well as at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, LIJ Hospital, North Shore Hospital and Gurwin Rehab Center. He loved to play tennis and golf as a member of Fresh Meadows Country Club and Glen Oaks Country Club. In Florida, he and Doris were members for over 35 years at The Palm Beach Coutry Club and he was a trustee of the Art Armory, Morse Geriatric Center, and President of his condo board. He was VP of the Chemotherapy Foundation for over 30 years. He adored Doris, they danced through life for 66 years. Mel was a loving father of Richard (Lynn), Linda (Harold) and Dan (JoAnn) and a devoted grandfather of Michael (Jessica) and Stacey Sirow, Joshua, Adam (Zaneta) and Sam Koplewicz, and Gabrielle, Sarah and Arianne Sirow, adoring great grandfather of David Sirow and beloved brother of Lila Levy. Services: Sunday, December 14 at 11:30am, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Doris and Melvin Sirow Art Fund at the Child Mind Institute, 445 Park Ave., NY, NY 10022.

SUNDAY PUZZLE — People often ask me how constructors get ideas for themes, and the truth is that it’s simply a matter of being observant. Add a letter, syllable or phrase to a word or phrase that exists and see if it makes another real word or phrase. If you can do the same thing a few more times, you’ve got yourself a theme set. Now all you have to do is set it in a grid, fill it with lively and familiar entries without getting yourself stuck anywhere and then write a mass of brilliant clues that have no possibility of being wrong or offending anyone. Easy peasy.

WEINBERGER--Beulah, wife of the late Herbert Weinberger, mother of Nancy Isserlis and the late Marc Weinberger, grandmother to Drew Isserlis Kramer, Michael Isserlis, Arielle Weinberger Papadam and Scott Weinberger, mother-in-law to Maurice Miller, sister to Mildred Morse and Estelle Gold, died on December 11, 2014, after a long and brave battle with a rare form of lymphoma. WEED--William Henry, 1930-2014 died peacefully after a long struggle with congestive heart failure on December 6th. Bill graduated from Carleton College and Harvard Business School after which he began his career at Proctor & Gamble. He joined Ogilvy & Mather as a disciple of David Ogilvy in 1959, where he was a member of the Executive Committee and on the board and became Chairman of Europe in 1980. He also served on the board of the American Academy of Rome. In 2000 he became President of the executive search firm Ray & Berendtson, retiring in 2005 to Roxbury, CT. In 2010, Bill joined the board of Schools That Can, a non-profit network of high performing schools in low income cities throughout the US. Bill is survived by his wife Bette, his two children, Speed (Leslie) and Elisabeth Weed Mitchell (Matt) and his five grandchildren, Harrison, Jasmine, Skye, Willow and Poppy. Funeral will be held on December 13th at 11am at St John's Episcopal Church on the Green in Washington, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations to School That Can: www.schoolshatcan.org would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

SMITH--Henry J.,91, born August 31, 1923 in New York City, died November 24 in Boston and was for many years a part-time resident of North Haven, ME. He served in the United States Army during WWII and graduated from Princeton (class of 1945). He had a nearly 40-year career with Mobil Oil. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Judith Adams Smith, and by daughters Nicola Smith (Geoff Hansen) of Vermont and Abigail Porter (Jim) of Maine and granddaughter Emma Hansen of Vermont. 1/3

SIROW--Melvin. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Chemotherapy Foundation mourn with deep sorrow the passing of Melvin Sirow, Trustee, Vice President, distinguished benefactor and friend of over 30 years. His sophisticated understanding, humanitarian concern, generosity and dedicated efforts profoundly influenced the expansion and scope of the Foundation's grant programs. His staunch support has been instrumental in advancing chemotherapy research and clinical science for the control, cure, and prevention of cancer through innovative medical therapies. Progress acheived through aggressive research efforts will forever remain a tribute to his vision and encouragement. His warmth and kindness and his steadfast loyalty will be remembered with gratitude and affection always. Franco M. Muggia, M.D. Chairman/Medical Director Barry Richter, President Chemotherapy Foundation 1/3
SIROW--Melvin. A kind, gentile and special friend of ours for many many years. We will miss you. Joan and Jerry 1/3

SILVER--David, 84, passed away December 7 with his adored daughter and wife, Nicole and Linda, at his side. He leaves a devoted family, including his brother, Michael, in-laws Ronnie, Saad and Alan, daughter Valerie, and the many loyal friends who shared in his distinctive and colorful life. A lifelong New Yorker, he was a Korean War Air Force veteran, a skilled labor law litigator, an accomplished photographer, jazz aficionado, wit and raconteur. He will be forever missed and remembered. Friends and family will gather at Linda's home this week to celebrate his life. 1/3

SCHIFF--Gerald I. Architect, of Larchmont, NY passed away November 28, 2014 at 88. Beloved husband of Selma for 65 years. Cherished father of Peter, Margaret and Michael. Adored grandfather of Sarah, Jenny and Elizabeth. Loving father- in-law of Alice, Thad and Terry. Gerry Schiff was a project designer at Harrison and Abramovitz and managing partner at Abramovitz, Kingsland, Schiff. His innovative designs include the U.S. Steel Building, Pittsburgh, PA, AT&T Bell System Pavilion, 1964-65 New York World's Fair, and work at major universities: Assembly Hall (Illinois), Farber Library, Rosenstiel Medical Sciences Laboratory, and Sachar International Center (Brandeis), Rosenstiel Oceanographic Institute (Miami), Centers for Molecular Medicine (SUNY Stony Brook) and John and David Rockefeller Laboratory (Rockefeller). In his memory, donations may be made to support basic science cancer research at the Perlmutter Cancer Center, NYU School of Medicine. 1/3

SALOMON--William Roger, age 100, died peacefully in his home on December 7, 2014 after a slow decline in health and a long and bountiful life. Managing Partner of Salomon Brothers from 1963-78, he joined the firm started by his father, Percy, his two uncles, and Morton Hutzler in 1933, becoming a partner in 1944. He was a member of the board of the New York Stock Exchange from 1970-1972, on the Board of Trustees of NYU, and a long standing and devoted member of the board of trustees of the Hospital for Special Surgery. He was predeceased in 2008 by his beloved wife of 71 years, Virginia Foster Salomon and his brother, Robert Salomon. Loving and loved father of Peter F. Salomon MD (Patricia Morgan), Tucson, Arizona, and Susan Salomon Neiman (Phil), Los Angeles, California, grandfather of Wendy N. Salomon, Liza S. Byrne, Jillian Whelan, and Heather Shapiro, and great-grandfather of three. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Hospital for Special Surgery, 535 East 70th Street, New York, New York 10021 or the charity of your choice. A memorial service will be held at a later date. 1/3

RUSSELL--Cynthia L.,88, of Chapel Hill, died on December 8 surrounded by family. Born in New York City. Raised five children with lifelong husband, John, in Rumson, NJ. ROTTENBERG--Phyllis, peacefully on November 30, 2014. Beloved wife of the late Sigmunt Rottenberg, loving mother of Lana (Piers Knight) and Eta, devoted grandmother of Amanda. ROSENBERG--Robert, died peacefully Saturday, December 13, 2014 at the age of 92. He is survived by his beloved wife of 44 years, Mildred, his son John (Fern) of Kansas, daughter Nancy Sutherland of Ohio and adopted son John (Whitney) of Greenwich as well as nine grandchildren: William Sutherland, Joyce Marvine, Amy Allshouse, Adam and Arielle Mandelson, Michael and David Abramowitz, and Hadley and Lucas Rosenberg as well as six great-grandchildren: Josh, Alex, Eli Marvine; and Noah and Grace Nemicolo; and Jacob Allshouse. Robert was formerly married to the late Joyce Kane Rosenberg. Robert was the son of James and Bessie Rosenberg and grew up in New York City. He attended the Hotchkiss School, Rollins College, Cornell University and Columbia University. Robert served in the Second World War, in the Army Aircorps, first as copilot and later a pilot in the 280th squadron, 15th Airforce, flying B24's. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and Silver Star for his service. After the war Robert worked on Wall Street and joined Modell Roland and Stone becoming a partner. Throughout his life Robert was an avid sportsman engaging in hunting, fishing, golf, tennis, and skiing as well as piloting his private plane. Additionally he volunteered with the Retired Men's Association of Greenwich CT and delivered food to the homebound as well as other charitable pursuits. Donations may be made to the Bruce Museum of Greenwich, CT. A service will be held Friday at Congregation Emanu El of Westchester at 10 am. 1/3

ROGERS--William B.,94, a generous philanthropist who founded American Trans Coil Corporation, died in his New York home on December 8. Funeral services will take place on December 14 at Temple Sinai in Roslyn Heights, NY at noon. Donations in his memory may be made to The Dr. R. Shlofmitz Cardiac Research Fund at St. Francis Hospital or the William B. Rogers Fund at Vanderbilt Museum. 1/3

POSNER--Norman, died December 12 at age 93. He was predeceased by Ruth, his wife and best friend, from whom he was inseparable for 67 years. Survived by children Henry, Michael, and Lillian, daughters-in-law Virginia and Andria, and grandchildren Rachel, Alyssa and Josh. Norman met Ruth in medical school. married in 1947 they raised their family in New Rochelle, NY. He was an OB/ GYN in The Bronx for 30+ years delivering more than 4000 babies. He was a fellow of the Am Col of OB/GYN, active in the Bronx County Med Society and Beth-El synagogue. Donations in his memory to Beth-El Synagogue, New Rochelle, NY. 1/3

OAKLEY--Robert B. The Board of Directors, Overseers and staff of the International Rescue Committee (IRC) are saddened by the loss of our dear friend Bob Oakley. A distinguished career diplomat, Bob served as a member of our Board or as an Overseer for most of the last two decades. His insights, guidance and counsel were invaluable, and he gave freely of his time, including participation in delegations that visited our international relief and development programs in some of the world's most troubled regions. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife, Phyllis, and their family. International Rescue Committee Sarah O'Hagan and Thomas Schick, Co-Chairs of the Board; Glenda Burkhart and Scott Pelley, Co-Chairs, IRC Overseers; David Miliband, President 1/3

MILCHMAN--Ernest, of Boca Raton, Florida on November 30th at age 86. Son of Henry and Anna Milchman, formerly of The Bronx and New Rochelle, Ernie graduated from Brooklyn College and New York Law School and became an accomplished lawyer and then found his true calling as a sophisticated real estate investor, much respected and revered in the industry. He was a former Commander of the Peter Minuet Post and a true Blackjack aficionado. Beloved and loving father to Scott, Gary and Mindy, grandfather to Brian, Brett and Alexa, brother to Estelle Samuels and friend to countless others lucky enough to cross his path. Ray was a singer-songwriter (raykorona.com) active in environmental, peace, and labor movements. As a housing attorney, he defended New Jersey tenants against gentrification and authored the book, Landlord and Tenant Law (New Jersey Practice). Ray will be missed by many people whose lives he made brighter. 1/3

KOBELT--Werner A. (90) - Chairman and Owner of Nipkow & Kobelt Textile, passed away on December 5. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Eleonora vanReekum, two sons; Arnold and Peter, daughter; Brenda, 12 grandchildren and four great- grandchildren. He was predeceased by his daughter Sandra. Of Swiss nationality, born in Japan, attended school in Switzerland and graduated from Aurora French Jesuit University in Shanghai. Served in the U.S. Army including tour at the Pentagon. Over 50 year Member of Rotary International, serving in various capacities, and 17 years Bank of Tokyo Trust Co., Board of Directors. A hardworking and respected business man, loving husband and father. Celebration of life will be held at a later date. JOSEPHY--Warren S.,died on Tuesday at 97. Beloved husband of Joanne for 72 years, father of Jennifer and Andrea (Paul) Leiman, grandfather of Lauren, David and Jonathan. A World War II hero, he served as Captain in the field artillery. He landed on Omaha Beach, took part in the Liberation of Paris, and fought in four subsequent battles, including the Battle of the Bulge and the Battle of the Huertgen Forest, during which he performed acts of bravery for which he was awarded the Silver Star. He founded the textile firm Forte Fabrics. In retirement, he served on the the board of the Lexington School for the Deaf and was a long-standing and devoted member of the Metropolitan Museum. 1/3

JACOBSON--Florence Johnson, 86, Naples FL, formerly of Spring Lake and Verona, NJ died from complications of Parkinson's Disease on Tuesday, December 9, 2014 in Naples, FL. Florence was a graduate of Montclair Kimberly Academy and Caldwell College. She received a Master's degree in Gerontology from the Graduate School of the College of New Rochelle. Florence was an intelligent, energetic and caring woman who enjoyed an active and busy life. As everyone knows, she was an avid Yankee fan her entire life. She also enjoyed golf and shot a spectacular hole in one in September, 2000, at Bel-Aire Golf Course in Spring Lake using a driver on the 14th hole. She loved retirement at the shore, especially with memories of her childhood in Spring Lake. She worked in many ministries in the Archdiocese of Newark, including The Catholic Advocate newspaper, interfaith youth group, and hospice of Union County. She was an editor, lector and Eucharistic minister. She provided 35 years of dedicated service to Our Lady of the Lake Parish in Verona. Florence held leadership roles in Renew International, Cursillo, Pastoral Council, liturgy planning, Verona Interfaith Religious Council, and Family Life for which she developed programs for seniors. Sudie, as she was known to family, was born on August 15, 1928 in North Bergen, NJ to Florence Endler Johnson and Rupert Harris Johnson. She is survived by brothers and sisters: Frances Furlong, Reverend Father Andrew Johnson, Charles (Ann) Johnson, Rupert (Maryellie) Johnson Jr., Bonnie Sacerdote and Suzanne (David) Razor; children: Susan (Pat) Forber, Jeffrey (Kathy) Jacobson, Mary (Lynn Gretkowski) Jacobson, Anne Pignatiello, and Elizabeth Jacobson; 12 grandchildren and one great grandchild, numerous cousins, nieces, nephews, and dear friends. Florence was preceded in death by her son, Stephen Jacobson, sister Dorothy McGuire, sister-in-law Mary Ann Johnson, brothers- in-law Charles McGuire, Robert Furlong, Peter Sacerdote, and son-in-law Steven Bertucci. A Funeral Mass will be held at Our Lady of the Lake Church, 32 Lakeside Avenue, Verona, NJ on Monday, December 15 at 10am. The wake will be held at Prout Funeral Home: proutfuneralhome.com, 370 Bloomfield Avenue, Verona, NJ on Sunday from 1 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to: Michael J. Fox Parkinson's Association or HHSNE (Haiti) c/o Father John Martin, Monsignor Kelly Residence, 247 Bloomfield Avenue, Caldwell, NJ, 07006. 1/3

HOLLISTER--David. Composer and teacher, he received a post-doctoral grant for study in Poland, His string orchestra piece "Corronach" based on the Holocaust, was performed by the New Orleans Symphony Orchestra. Two string quartets were recorded on Opus One records. Commissions include music for Paul Taylor, choreographer, for avant-guard film maker Hilary Harris, and for musical theatre. His life and work were imbued with brilliance, humor, gentleness and a deep humanism. He is survived by his wife Barbara, sister Susan Paltauf, his brother Fredrick Bryant Hollister and sister Elizabeth Hollister. Memorial concert upcoming. 1/3

HICKMAN--J. Kenneth. 86, of Summit, NJ passed away December 10, 2014. Graduated Regis High School (1946), Fordham University (1951). Korean War Veteran. Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Regis and Trustee Emeritus of Fordham. Served on Advisory Committees at Rutgers Graduate School of Business and Seton Hall University. After 37 years with Arthur Andersen, Ken retired as a Senior Partner having opened the Newark office and served as Director of International Business Practice in New York. Ken served on National Foreign Trade Council, Foreign Policy Association, Business Council for International Understanding, Ireland- US Council, and US-USSR Trade and Economic Council. Founder and chairman of the US Industry Coordinating Group on European Union matters, member of American Council on Germany, National Committee for US-China Relations, Economic Club of New York, and Industry Advisory Committee to the Office of the US Trade Representative. Member of American Institute of CPAs and NY and NJ Societies of CPAs. Ken had strong convictions and held everyone to the highest standards, yet he was humble and accessible. Quick-witted, he was a wonderful story teller. He was a loyal, thoughtful and easy friend, freely giving of his time and counsel. Ken is survived by his wife Irene (Davis), daughters Trish, Carolyn and Beth, four granddaughters and a great-grandson. Ken is also survived by his brother Wallace and his family. Services will be held on Tuesday, December 16th, 10:45am at St. Teresa of Avila Church, 306 Morris Ave, Summit, NJ. Relatives and friends are invited to visit on Monday, December 15, 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the Bradley Brough & Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Ave, Summit, NJ. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial donations be made to Alzheimer's Association of America or Fordham University. For further info, please visit: bradleyfuneralhomes.com 1

HAZAN--Jane Freilicher, nee Niederhoffer, 90, of New York City and Water Mill, NY, on December 9, of complications from pneumonia. Beloved wife of Joseph Hazan, who predeceased her. GOLDBERG--Dr. Morton Edward, 82, a distinguished pharmaceutical scientist and executive, died on December 8, 2014 in Glen Mills, PA. His wife Janet, children Shellie Winkler, Ellen Goldstein and David Goldberg and grandchildren Danny Goldstein, Ben Goldberg, Ethan Goldstein and Sarah Goldberg survive him. Mort, as he was affectionately known by family, friends and colleagues will be remembered for his keen intellect, dry sense of humor, dedication to science and deep belief in the uplifting power of education. He was a beloved mentor and role model to many. Along with fellow scientists Mort developed several significant therapies that successfully treated central nervous system disorders, cardiovascular disease and cancer and positively impacted millions of patients and their loved ones. Dr. Goldberg retired in 1991 from ICI as its head of R&D. Donations in his honor may be made to the National Parkinson Foundation: www.parkinson.org. 1/3

James Anthony, MD one of the world's great child and adolescent psychiatrists and husband of our dear friend, Virginia Anthony, former executive director of the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry. Sirow--Melvin, 90, passed away on Friday one year after his wife and love of his life Doris died. As a graduate of NYU Dental School he completed an internship at Harlem Hospital but never practiced. He worked with his late brother-in-law Selig Burrows for over 40 years at Central Linen. Mel was an exceptionally civic minded individual, involved in many community and charitable activities. He and Doris were longtime residents of Kings Point, NY where he was a Trustee as well as at Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, LIJ Hospital, North Shore Hospital and Gurwin Rehab Center. He loved to play tennis and golf as a member of Fresh Meadows Country Club and Glen Oaks Country Club. In Florida, he and Doris were members for over 35 years at The Palm Beach Coutry Club and he was a trustee of the Art Armory, Morse Geriatric Center, and President of his condo board. He was VP of the Chemotherapy Foundation for over 30 years. He adored Doris, they danced through life for 66 years. Mel was a loving father of Richard (Lynn), Linda (Harold) and Dan (JoAnn) and a devoted grandfather of Michael (Jessica) and Stacey Sirow, Joshua, Adam (Zaneta) and Sam Koplewicz, and Gabrielle, Sarah and Arianne Sirow, adoring great grandfather of David Sirow and beloved brother of Lila Levy. Services: Sunday, December 14 at 11:30am, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Doris and Melvin Sirow Art Fund at the Child Mind Institute, 445 Park Ave., NY, NY 10022.

The case of Steven Salaita has been hotly debated both in and out of academic circles in the past few months. Salaita is the Palestinian-American professor and scholar whose offer of a tenured teaching position in the American Indian Studies Program at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign was rescinded by the school’s chancellor because of some very strongly worded tweets he published regarding Israel’s attack on Gaza this summer. That attack followed a series of events that had heightened tension between the Israeli government and Hamas, the de facto ruling party in Gaza, culminating in Hamas’s launching rockets into Israel and then Israel’s mounting a huge aerial assault and ground invasion against Gaza. On September 11 of this year, the university’s board of trustees voted to uphold the chancellor’s decision.

MONTEVIDEO — Trapped and battered in an all-day battle with three British cruisers off the coast of Uruguay, the Admiral Graf Spee, German 10,000-ton pocket battleship, lay in the inner harbor of Montevideo today [Dec. 14] while two of its attackers, the Achilles and Ajax, were patrolling the outer harbor, ready to resume the combat as soon as it attempts to put to sea. The third British cruiser, the 8,300-ton Exeter, was damaged and forced to drop out of the fighting four hours after contact was made. There was reported to be several dead and wounded aboard the Exeter, which is putting in to Montevideo tonight with a slight list.

BERLIN — Influenza claims Berlin for its own. The schools are gradually becoming deserted. In some, such as that founded by Queen Louisa, many teachers and half the scholars are down with it, so that it has been suggested to let the Christmas holidays begin now. The course of justice has been interrupted by the plague. Absent witnesses, ‘‘Schoeffen’’ (Associate Judges), or lawyers, plead influenza as an excuse.

SKLAR--Sybil. A beloved mother, grandmother, aunt and great friend, Sybil Sklar passed away peacefully on December 13th at age 93. Born 1921 in New York City, she was graduated from Hunter College with a BA Degree in 1941. A World War II Veteran she was a member of the Women's Army Corps from 1943-1945, serving in Australia, New Guinea and the Southern Philippines, earning a Philippines Liberation Ribbon, Asiatic-Pacific Service Medal with three bronze service stars and a Distinguished Unit Badge. After the war she taught deaf and hard of hearing children. In 1947 she received an MA Degree in Special Ed from Columbia University. A dedicated teacher, she worked with elementary through high school children at Bellevue Hospital, teaching remedial reading, math and other subjects in the public school there and with Bellevue's prison population (ages 18-21) for twenty years. She also taught English as a volunteer and was active as a real estate agent in Westchester County from 1976-1988. Married 1940 to Harold Sklar (deceased 1984), she is survived by three children: Pamela (Michael), Paul and Peter; her grandson Ari, a nephew and three nieces. 1/3
SCOTT--Lucretia Lee, died peacefully in December 12, 2014 following a long illness. A private memorial will take place in the New Year. 1/3

ROSENBERG--Robert, died peacefully Saturday, December 13, 2014 at the age of 92. He is survived by his beloved wife of 44 years, Mildred, his son John (Fern) of Kansas, daughter Nancy Sutherland of Ohio and adopted son John (Whitney) of Greenwich as well as nine grandchildren: William Sutherland, Joyce Marvine, Amy Allshouse, Adam and Arielle Mandelson, Michael and David Abramowitz, and Hadley and Lucas Rosenberg as well as six great-grandchildren: Josh, Alex, Eli Marvine; and Noah and Grace Nemicolo; and Jacob Allshouse. Robert was formerly married to the late Joyce Kane Rosenberg. Robert was the son of James and Bessie Rosenberg and grew up in New York City. He attended the Hotchkiss School, Rollins College, Cornell University and Columbia University. Robert served in the Second World War, in the Army Aircorps, first as copilot and later a pilot in the 280th squadron, 15th Airforce, flying B24's. He was awarded the Distinguished Flying Cross and Silver Star for his service. After the war Robert worked on Wall Street and joined Modell Roland and Stone becoming a partner. Throughout his life Robert was an avid sportsman engaging in hunting, fishing, golf, tennis, and skiing as well as piloting his private plane. Additionally he volunteered with the Retired Men's Association of Greenwich CT and delivered food to the homebound as well as other charitable pursuits. Donations may be made to the Bruce Museum of Greenwich, CT. A service will be held Friday at Congregation Emanu El of Westchester at 10 am. 1/3

MILCHMAN--Ernest, of Boca Raton, Florida on November 30th at age 86. Son of Henry and Anna Milchman, formerly of The Bronx and New Rochelle, Ernie graduated from Brooklyn College and New York Law School and became an accomplished lawyer and then found his true calling as a sophisticated real estate investor, much respected and revered in the industry. He was a former Commander of the Peter Minuet Post and a true Blackjack aficionado. Beloved and loving father to Scott, Gary and Mindy, grandfather to Brian, Brett and Alexa, brother to Estelle Samuels and friend to countless others lucky enough to cross his path. Ernie, Ern 1, Ernesto, and big Ern will be sorely missed but never forgotten. 1/3

LEVIN--Natalie, on December 9, 2014, in her 101st year. "Nickie" to almost everyone, especially as Grandma Nickie to her family. Wife of the late Samuel Levin, mother of Jack and Joan, mother-in-law of Carol, grandmother of Daniel and Naomi, great-grandmother of Jaden, Aaron and Zachary. Born in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, she married and moved to Newark and Millburn, NJ and to Greenwich Village for the last 25 years. Fiercely loyal, she put her family above all. One of a kind, she spoke the truth as she saw it. Contributions may be made to God's Love We Deliver, 630 Flushing Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11206 or visit: glwd.org/give/donate. 1/3

HURWITZ--Uri (Uriel), died on Saturday, December 13, 2014. Age 83. He was born in Berlin and grew up in Palestine/Israel. He leaves behind his wife of 53 years, Johanna, two children, Nomi and Benjamin (Kimberly), three grandchildren, Ethan Richardson, Juliet and Fiona Hurwitz and hundreds of friends. Retired as a lecturer of Hebrew from Queens College (CUNY), he continued as an independent scholar researching Hebrew names and history. He also was a published novelist, a linguist fluent in several languages. He always asked people where they came from so he could learn a few new words and phrases in their native tongue, He loved classical music, nature, dogs, cats and donkeys and the state of Vermont. Everyone who knew him realized he was sui generis (if they knew that phrase). In recent years he discovered the TV series Everybody Loves Raymond. What we hope he knew was that everybody loved Uri. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd., Woodbury, NY 11797. 1/3

GOLDBERG--Dr. Morton Edward, 82, a distinguished pharmaceutical scientist and executive, died on December 8, 2014 in Glen Mills, PA. His wife Janet, children Shellie Winkler, Ellen Goldstein and David Goldberg and grandchildren Danny Goldstein, Ben Goldberg, Ethan Goldstein and Sarah Goldberg survive him. Mort, as he was affectionately known by family, friends and colleagues will be remembered for his keen intellect, dry sense of humor, dedication to science and deep belief in the uplifting power of education. He was a beloved mentor and role model to many. Along with fellow scientists Mort developed several significant therapies that successfully treated central nervous system disorders, cardiovascular disease and cancer and positively impacted millions of patients and their loved ones. Dr. Goldberg retired in 1991 from ICI as its head of R&D. Donations in his honor may be made to the National Parkinson Foundation: www.parkinson.org. 1/3

ROTHMAN--Flora May, nee Spetalnick, 84. Bayside NY. BA City College with honors, Ph.D CUNY. Flora was an advocate for juvenile justice reform. She was appointed to commissions by President Ford, Mayor Koch and Governor Carey on which she pressed for humane treatment of juveniles. She taught courses in criminal justice and public policy at John Jay College. Beloved mother of Allen and Paul, mother-in-law of Carolyn and Frances, grandmother of Alissa, Daniel, Sophia and Eric, wife of Jessel (deceased), companion of Morty and sister of Victor.

DOYLE--Stanley Bodkin, Jr.,died Saturday, at 91. Beloved husband of the late Jeanne (McManus) Doyle, father of Nancy and James, delighted grandfather of Nicholas Macy Doyle and Elizabeth Winslow Doyle of Brookline, Massachusetts and father-in-law of Margaret VanDeusen and Philip Morrongiello. He landed in Normandy with the Fourth Cavalry Reconnaissance Squadron and as a tank commander fought in battles from the Falaise Pocket through the Hurtgen Forest (where he was wounded), the Bulge, and the Rhineland, taking part in the liberation of subcamps at Mauthausen. He was awarded the Silver Star for dismounting his tank under intense machine gun fire to rescue a wounded soldier two weeks before VE Day. A longtime trust officer and vice-president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust and later the Chase bank, he was a graduate of New York Law School. Services will be private.

RICHTER--Barry. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Chemotherapy Foundation mourn with deep sorrow the passing of Barry Richter, Trustee, President and Chief Executive Officer for the past 35 years. His leadership, sophisticated insight, conviction and tenacity profoundly influenced the expansion and scope of the Foundation's research and educational programs. He was a pragmatist whose dedication, distinguished generosity and humanitarian concern were instrumental in advancing and expanding chemotherapy research and clinical science for the control, cure, and prevention of cancer through innovative medical therapies. Progress achieved through aggressive research efforts will forever remain a tribute to his vision and commitment. His steadfast loyalty and loving spirit will be remembered always with affection and gratitude. Franco M. Muggia, M.D. Chairman/Medical Director 1/3

LUKE--David L.,III, a retired business leader prominent in the U.S. paper industry, died at his New York City home on December 13, 2014. Fanny C. Luke, his beloved wife of nearly sixty years, predeceased him in October. A brother, John A. Luke, and a sister, Priscilla Vail, also predeceased him. A sister, Melinda, as well as many nieces and nephews survive him. Mr. Luke attended the Hotchkiss School before entering Yale University, but left after Pearl Harbor for Naval Aviation Flight Training. He received his Naval Aviator's Wings and a commission in the Marine Corps in June 1943. He saw combat in the Pacific over the Marianas and Okinawa. After military service, Mr. Luke returned to graduate from Yale in 1948, and then joined American Research and Development Corporation. Three years later he returned to New York City where he began a distinguished career with Westvaco Corporation, steadily advancing through the executive ranks to become President in 1962 and also Chief Executive Officer in 1963. He became Chairman in 1980, retiring from that position in 1996. Mr. Luke's other board memberships included service on the boards of B.F. Goodrich, Bank of New York, The McGraw-Hill Companies, Grumman Corporation and the New York Stock Exchange. He also served on the board of the American Museum of Natural History and as a trustee of the Hotchkiss School and the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory where he was named Chairman from 1992 until 1998. A private burial service will be held in Locust Valley, New York, with a memorial service to be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, it is requested that memorial gifts be directed to the Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, 1 Bungtown Road, Cold Spring Harbor, NY 17714, or to the Hotchkiss School, 11 Interlaken Road, Lakeville, CT 06039-2141. 1/3

HALMAN--Talat Sait. Talat Sait Halman, 83, Bilkent (Ankara), Turkey, and New York City, died from a heart attack at Bilkent University on December 5. Halman was born in Istanbul in 1931 in the first decade of Ataturk's Republic. He studied at the country's leading institution, the American Robert College of Istanbul. In 1952 he came to New York for graduate studies at Columbia University. A year and a half later he was hired to teach Turkish there. While a graduate student he worked as a clerk at the Record Hunter, New York's famed classical music store; a year later he became the general manager when the owner died suddenly, and he brought the company out of bankruptcy within three years. After graduate studies, Halman stayed in the United States for the next four decades and had a distinguished career at Columbia, Princeton, the University of Pennsylvania, and New York University, where he served as chairman of the Department of Near Eastern Languages and Literatures. He returned briefly to Turkey to serve as his country's first Minister of Culture (1971); in the 1980s he served as Turkey's first and only Ambassador for Cultural Affairs, stationed in New York. At this time he also served as Deputy Permanent Representative to the United Nations. Halman was appointed as a delegate to UNESCO in 1989 and later was elected to the Executive Board and served with distinction as president of its primary commission, Programme and External Relations; since 2003 he served as president of the Turkish National Committee for UNICEF. Among myriad awards, Halman received the Knight Grand Cross, G.B.E, from Queen Elizabeth during her 1971 state visit to Turkey. After 45 years in the United States, Halman joined Bilkent in 1996 as founding chairman of the university's Department of Turkish Literature and most recently had also been serving as Dean of Humanities and Letters. It was Halman's humanism and cross-cultural approach that is his most lasting legacy. In 1976 he arranged a Middle Eastern Literature symposium that took place both at the New York Public Research Library and Princeton University. It was the first such conference that included both Israeli and Arab writers. He opened the way for the teaching of Turkish literature and culture at major universities in the U.S. Before that, Middle Eastern studies departments concentrated primarily on Arab and Persian studies. Halman published nearly 3,000 articles, essays, newspaper columns, and reviews in English and in Turkish. He translated over 10,000 poems from English into Turkish and Turkish into English, and wrote over 80 books, including 11 volumes of his own poetry. He was William Faulkner's first Turkish translator. This publication of "Knight's Gambit" had a tremendous impact on the nascent short-story and novel genres in the Turkish Republic. For his work as a translator he won Columbia University's Thornton Wilder Prize. Among his books in Turkish are a massive volume of the poetry of ancient civilizations, the poetry of ancient Anatolia and the Near East, Eskimo poems, ancient Egyptian poetry, the rubais of Rumi, the quatrains of Baba Tahir Uryan, several collections of Yunus Emre poetry, two anthologies of modern American poetry, and books of selected poems of Wallace Stevens and Langston Hughes. He also translated works by Mark Twain and Eugene O'Neill. Translations of Shakespeare's "Complete Sonnets" count among his major achievements and have been published in many editions. This was the first time that the sonnets had been translated into Turkish using meter and rhyme. Earlier this year his translations of Shakespeare's long narrative poems, again into meter and rhyme, were published in Istanbul. Halman also wrote an original play about Shakespeare, his plays, and Turkish productions; the play was produced to the acclamation of Turkish theater audiences. Halman saw culture as a "unifying force; when a nation develops itself culturally, humanism begins," he always said. It is Turkey's cultural plurality, the recognition of the inherent power of the cultural synthesis that the Turkish nation has fostered over the past fifteen centuries, combined with the numerous and diverse civilizations in the area that is now Turkey, that Halman sought to encourage and promote. The world's literary and cultural stage has lost a truly unique and irreplaceable talent--poet, translator, columnist, belletrist, accomplished academic, diplomat, charismatic public speaker, social and cultural critic, writers' activist, and much more. All of these contributions plus his willingness to share his wisdom and knowledge will be remembered by the countless audiences he enlightened, the numerous students he inspired and encouraged, and future generations who will benefit from this legacy. Talat Halman is survived by his wife Seniha, daughter Defne, son Hur (from a former marriage), and grandchildren Melissa, William, and Olivia. His son Sait predeceased him in 1983. Jayne L. Warner Colleague and family friend 1/3

GEUSIC--Joseph Edward. Joseph Edward Geusic a 56 year resident of Berkeley Heights, NJ passed away Saturday, December 13, 2014 at the age of 83. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the visitation, Wednesday December 17th from 4-8 pm at Paul Ippolito Berkeley Memorial, 646 Springfield Ave, Berkeley Heights, NJ. The funeral will be held Thursday, December 18th with a Funeral Mass to be offered at 10am at Our Lady of Peace Church, South St, New Providence, NJ. Interment will be private. For additional information or to express online condolence please visit www.ippolito funeralhomes.com. Born in Nesquehoning, PA Joseph moved to Berkeley Heights, NJ in 1958, joining AT&T Bell Laboratories where he began his distinguished 37 year career. He attended Lehigh University, achieved a B.S. in Engineering Physics in 1953, and later attended Ohio State University where he received a MS in Physics in 1955. In 1958 Joseph achieved a Ph.D. in Physics. Some of his notable achievements were in 1958-1962 he was a MTS. Traveling Wave Maser for Echo and Telstar projects. Solid State Laser, from 1962-1966 Joseph was a Supervisor, Laser Group Solid State Lasers and Electro-Optic Modulators, in 1964 he invented: ND/YAG Laser (with L.G. VanUitert), in 1966-1970 he was a Department Head, Solid Optical Device Department, Completion of ND/ YAG development and exploration of other material systems and in 1984 Joseph was Department Head, Semiconductor Laser Development Department, developed high frequency, reliable FP and DFB lasers to terrestrial NS undersea cable communications. Mr. Geusic and his colleagues were responsible for the birth of the fiber optics industry. During his 37 distinguished years at AT&T Bell Laboratories, Mr. Geusic published more than 62 scientific papers and held 27 patents. Retiring in 1994 Mr. Geusic joined Micron where he worked in their Advanced Research Institute. He is responsible for an estimated 200 patents while consulting there. He retired from Micron in 2005 after 10 years of service as a consultant. His works are cited in: Who's Who in Technology, Who's Who in Science and Engineering, American Men in Science and Leaders in Technology. During his professional career Joseph received four significant awards/honors; in 1989 the Fellow IEEE for contribution to: Masers, Laser, Nonlinear Optics and Magnetic Bubbles, in 1992 he received the Quantum Electronics Award for IEEE Laser and E/O Society Inventions and Development of the ND/ YAG Laser, in 1993 he received the R.W. Wood Prize for the Optical Society of America, Inventions and development of the ND/YAG Laser and also in 1993 he was awarded the AT&T Patent CJ Davis Trophy for AT&T Patents Attaining Significant Commercial Value. Joseph is survived by his devoted wife of 60 years Irene J. Geusic (nee Hosak) and his children: Patricia, Mark (Luann), Michael (Victoria), Mary Ellen Taylor (Matthew), Robert and Joseph (Lisa). He is also survived by his five grandchildren Gregory, Aaron, Minh, Jennifer Geusic and Kaitlin Taylor. He was predeceased by his parents Mary (nee Koch) Geusic and Joseph Geusic. Joe will be missed by his family, friends and colleagues. In lieu of flowers, the family wishes donations be made to Ohio State University in Joseph Geusic's memory to the Physics Department to provide scholarship funding to aspiring young scientists. 1/3

ENGELKE--George L.,Jr., 75, on December 13, 2014. Retired President, CEO and Chairman of the Board of Astoria Financial Corporation, presently Astoria Bank. He previously served as Chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York, Chairman of the Community Preservation Corporation and Chairman of the Community Bankers Association of New York State. A Certified Public Accountant, he served as a member of the Board of Trustees of Long Island University and was a long time supporter of Lehigh University, his Alma Mater. He was also an avid golfer. Survived by his wife of more than 20 years Sandra, his children Jennifer Engelke Skyrm and Courtenay Engelke, step- children Suzanne Blair and Steven Jaenichen, his brother Roger Engelke and nine grandchildren. Visitation Wednesday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Avenue, Garden City. Funeral Service Thursday 10am at the Community Church of East Williston. Interment Locust Valley Cemetery. 1/3

CRABTREE--Richard Clarke. Richard "Dick" Clarke Crabtree, died peacefully on December 12 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx with his family by his side. Dick was born in New Rochelle, NY and was raised there by his parents Joseph and Irene. He attended Iona Prep where he excelled in sports, especially track, setting multiple records including in the 440 yard and 220 yard dashes which stood for many decades. He attended both Notre Dame and Georgetown Universities where he studied business, and in 1952 he married Marjorie (Mimi) Hannon, a model, his childhood sweetheart, and dedicated wife until his death. Dick served in the U.S. Coast Guard from 1953 to 1954 before entering the family automobile business, Crabtree Motors, where he took charge of the used car division and introduced the concept of 'certified pre- owned vehicles.' Dick was hired by Ford Motor Company as Northeast Manager of Edsel Car Dealership Sales, and despite the short term of the project, was proud that each of the dealerships that he established survived the Edsel debacle to become thriving businesses. Dick worked as a bank executive at both Citibank and Marine Midland Bank, but eventually realized his true calling was to utilize his prolific people skills in the restaurant business. He opened his first restaurant, Crabtree's Plaza Inn in Crestwood, NY in 1974 to great critical acclaim, and then in 1981 he purchased a popular landmark in Chappaqua, NY, the Kittle House, and completely restored the building and the business as the preeminent Restaurant and Inn in Westchester County. Amongst his numerous community positions, Dick served as a Commissioner of the Westchester County Police Board, 1978-1986, as Chairman of the Business School Advisory Board at Westchester Community College, as Trustee of the New Castle Historical Society, as president of Chappaqua Rotary, as a Director of Westchester/Putnam Girl Scouts of America, as president of the Boys and Girls Club, Myrtle Beach, and as Prior to the Sovereign Military Order of the Knights Templar. Dick also served in the New York Guard from 1992 until he retired in 1999 as a Brigadier General. In 1984 Dick received the Westchester County Distinguished Service Award. Dick will be greatly missed by the multitudes whose lives he touched. No matter how many hats he wore, and uniforms he donned, Dick never lost his energy for life and compassion for the people around him, and wherever he walked, the world was at least a little bit brighter. He will be forever remembered as a man 'larger than life' with a charm, wit, humor, and compassion that were truly remarkable. He is predeceased by his brother Robert and sister Joan Mackin. He is survived by his wife Mimi, seven children, eighteen grandchildren, one great grandson, and many loving cousins, nieces and nephews. The family will receive friends and family at Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home in Mt. Kisco, NY Thursday 7- 9pm, and Friday 2-4pm and 7- 9pm, A funeral service will take place at St. Patricks Church in Bedford on Saturday at 9:45am. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Boys and Girls Club of Northern Westchester, the Salvation Army, and the Graymoor Spiritual Life Center, Garrison, NY. 1/3

DOYLE--Stanley Bodkin, Jr.,died Saturday, at 91. Beloved husband of the late Jeanne (McManus) Doyle, father of Nancy and James, delighted grandfather of Nicholas Macy Doyle and Elizabeth Winslow Doyle of Brookline, Massachusetts and father-in-law of Margaret VanDeusen and Philip Morrongiello. He landed in Normandy with the Fourth Cavalry Reconnaissance Squadron and as a tank commander fought in battles from the Falaise Pocket through the Hurtgen Forest (where he was wounded), the Bulge, and the Rhineland, taking part in the liberation of subcamps at Mauthausen. He was awarded the Silver Star for dismounting his tank under intense machine gun fire to rescue a wounded soldier two weeks before VE Day. A longtime trust officer and vice-president at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust and later the Chase bank, he was a graduate of New York Law School. Services will be private.

SZATMARI--Sandor Laszlo 76, of New York, NY, passed away in his home on December 13th, 2014. Born in Mako, Hungary, on March 25th, 1938, he escaped during the 1956 Revolution to find freedom in America. After graduating with a BA in History from Monmouth College, he served in the United States Army for three years, stationed in Germany. He worked for 37 years at Little, Brown & Company as National Accounts Manager before retiring in 2005. Sandor is survived by his five children, Robert, Elizabeth, Sandor Jr., Phebe, and Nicholas, and his four grandchildren, Eli Krasnoff, and Talia, Anastazia, and Abigail Szatmari. LUKE--David L.,III. The Trustees, Faculty, students and staff of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory mourn the passing of David L. Luke III. David joined the Board of Trustees in 1986 and championed fundraising in celebration of the Lab's 100-year anniversary in 1990. He served as Chairman from 1992-1997 and was elected an Honorary Trustee in 1998. David is remembered for his keen interest in securing the financial future of CSHL and his outstanding abilities as a spokesperson who communicated the latest in biology and genetics research to friends and colleagues in the business community. Together with his wife Fanny, David was a strong supporter of plant biology and genome sequencing technology. Under his chairmanship, the Lab built the CSHL Genome Center in Woodbury and in 1999 welcomed the first class of Ph.D. candidates to the Watson School of Biological Sciences. The Luke Building stands today in his honor. Our deepest sympathy to the entire Luke family. Jamie C. Nicholls, Chairman Robert D. Lindsay, Vice Chairman Marilyn H. Simons, Vice Chairman Bruce Stillman, President James D. Watson, Chancellor Emeritus, W. Dillaway Ayres, Jr. , COO 1/3

KURZ--Anton Jacob, 86. Died December 12, 2014. Beloved husband of 60 years of Janice (nee Elliott). Devoted father of Susan and Adam. Proud grandfather of Jeremy and Rebecca. Holocaust and cancer survivor, who always reveled in the simple beauty of life and for whom no task for others was ever too great. He will be remembered as a man of infinite kindness and was a blessing to all who knew him. Services will be held on Thursday, December 18th, 2:30pm at The Masonic Grand Lodge of New York, American Room, 19th Floor, 71 West 23rd Street. In lieu of flowers, a tribute donation can be made to The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, www.ushmm.org. 1/3

HOAGLAND--Anne Rowe, beloved sister and aunt, died peacefully on December 14 after a valiant battle with cancer. Anne was born in Cleveland, OH in 1952 to George W. and Jeanette Gunn Hoagland. After graduating from the Laurel School in Shaker Heights, she attended Wellesley College and later transferred to the University of Pennsylvania. She graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree summa cum laude in Art History and English literature in 1975 and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She also studied Italian at Georgetown University and English Literature at Worcester College, Oxford. She was a member of the Kappa Kappa Gamma sorority at Penn. Anne moved to New York in 1975 with an internship at the Whitney Museum of American Art. For the last 30 years, her professional career was in the real estate investment management industry. Anne first became interested in real estate as a paralegal at Shearman & Sterling. From 1979-1998 she was with two real estate investment banking firms, Eastdil Realty and The O'Connor Group. In 1998, she joined the Global Real Assets Group at JPMorgan Asset Management, where she served as an Executive Director at the time of her death. Anne was a member of the National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York, the Cosmopolitan Club, the Brick Presbyterian Church, and the Center Harbor Yacht Club in Brooklin, ME. She enjoyed traveling, visiting art museums, reading biographies, and collecting Chinese Export porcelain and European antiques. She was always eager to retain her connections to Ohio and Maine and maintained residences in Cleveland, OH, and Sargentville, ME as well as in Manhattan. Anne is survived by her brother Leigh W. Hoagland, sister-in-law Eleanor T.M. Hoagland, niece Georgina G. Hoagland, and nephew Nicholas G. Hoagland, all of Manhattan. A memorial service will be held at the Brick Presbyterian Church on Friday, January 23 at 4pm. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Restoration Fund for the Sedgwick First Baptist Church, c/o the Sedgwick- Brooklin Historical Society, PO Box 171, Sedgwick, ME 04676. 1/3

HARTZELL--Arthur R.,Jr., 89, died on Saturday, December 13, 2014. Arthur, a Wharton School MBA, had been Director of Traffic for Pfizer, retiring in 1987. He Lived at the Churchill on East 40th. During WWII he was a USN Seabee in the Pacific. He will be remembered lovingly as a kind and thoughtful brother, uncle and friend by all who knew him. To leave a condolence for the family please visit: poulsonvanhise.com 1/3

GOLDFARB--Arlene, age 88, of Brooklyn, Franklin Square and Delray Beach, FL, passed away peacefully on December 15, 2014. Arlene is survived by her children Lynn (Peter), Sam (Judy), David (Sharon), her grandchildren Bret (Carolyn), Mindi (Josh), Jen, Mitchell, Bennett, Matt and Molly and her great-grandchildren Alyson and Joshua. She was predeceased in 2001 by Max, her loving husband of 50 years. Arlene proudly graduated from Penn State at 19 and spent the rest of her long life building a loving network of family and friends that will miss her deeply. 1/3
GARTH--David. A mensch for all seasons. We all loved him and he knew it. Carol Opton and Family 1/3

EVERETT--Eleanor Delafield, died peacefully on December 14, 2014 in Ashburn, Virginia, of complications from Parkinson's disease. She is survived by her life- long husband Francis D. Everett, Jr., her son John, his wife Jeannine and their son Jonah, of Great Falls, Virginia, and by her sister Harriet D. Smith of Stonington, Connecticut. A long time resident of New York City, she was active in the residential real estate market for many years. She was involved with various city charities and for a number of years served on the Board Of Directors of the Sheltering Arms Children Services. Her passion was the theatre and she was a member of the Snarks, an amateur theatrical group. She was a lovely lady all her life. 1/3

DALIS--Irene. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of mezzo-soprano Irene Dalis who sang 22 roles and 274 performances here from 1957 to 1976. She is remembered for a powerful dramatic voice that allowed her to take on a wide range of demanding parts from Amneris in Aida, her most frequent role, to Kundry in Parsifal and the Nurse in the Met premiere of Die Frau ohne Schatten. A consummate professional, she was admired by audiences and colleagues alike. We extend our sincerest condolences to her family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director 1/3

BUCHMAN--George, on December 15, age 84. Beloved husband of Jean and the late Rosalind. Loving father of Deborah, Barry (Dara) and the late Meyer. Proud grandfather of Rebekah and Eliana. Services Thursday, 11am at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn. www.shermanschapel.com 1/3

BARNETT--Harold Walter George Of Pelham Manor, NY, died on December 15, 2014. He was 98. Mr. Barnett was born in Manhattan, NY, on August 13, 1916 and moved to New Rochelle, NY, at an early age. He was an only child. He graduated from Iona Grammar School in 1931 and Iona Preparatory School in 1935. He was a graduate of Fordham University, BS, Class of 1940. Mr. Barnett was commissioned as an officer in the United States Navy in 1941, shortly before World War II. He was commissioned as an Ensign and achieved the rank of Lieutenant by the end of his service in 1945. He was traveling in uniform in the New York City subway system when word came of the Pearl Harbor attack and people came up to him in the subway car and wished him well, the first way he heard about the start of the War. He served in both the Atlantic and Pacific theaters. He was on a Patrol Craft ship, PC 462, doing convoy duty between Brazil and North Africa and was stationed at various times in Boston and Cape Ann in Massachusetts; in Hollywood, FL; and in Panama, Bermuda and Cuba. He served in the Naval Intelligence branch in Seattle, WA. He was stationed for a short time in Pearl Harbor, HI. Later he was onboard a destroyer escort, USS Brackett DE-41, near the Marshall Islands, the Mariana Islands near Saipan, Taroa Island, and Australia. He was then transferred to a mine sweeper in the North Atlantic right before the War ended. After the War, Mr. Barnett worked as a chemist in New York and New Jersey for more than 30 years with the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company in Manhattan, Montvale, N.J. and Horseheads, NY. After he retired from the A&P in 1982, he did consulting work for Clairol Co. in Stamford, CT. He married Mary Theresa Harkins of Brooklyn, NY, whom he met at the A&P, on his birthday in 1949. They were married for 60 years; she died on September 9, 2009. A Celebration of Harold's life will be held at the Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue from 2pm to 4pm and 7pm to 9pm on Thursday, December 18th. There will be a Requiem Mass on Friday, December 19th at 10am at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church in Pelham Manor. Interment will follow at Kensico Cemetery. For more information, or to write a condolence, please visit: pelhamfuneral.com 1

SAXE--Dr. David H.,M.D. Peacefully passed on December 13, 2014 at the age of 101. Alumnus of University of Michigan medical school and clinical professor of surgery at New York University. Served bravely as a medical officer during WWII in Cuba, the Arctic, and Europe, and in the Battle of the Bulge. Served his profession faithfully; he prized a certificate from New York State honoring 50 years of clinical practice. Predeceased by Caroline, his wife of 68 years, and survived by children Andrew Saxe and Elizabeth Andoh, and grandchildren Rena Andoh, and Adam, Benjamin and Sarah Saxe. Tributes may be sent to The University of Michigan.
HENDRIX--Holland Lee, Age 66. Died suddenly of lung cancer in Albuquerque, NM on November 26.

Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO
