GABEL--Faye. You are missed, loved, and remembered, Happy Birthday. Iris, Michele, Suzie, Monica, Randi and all your Great-Grandchildren 1/3

WILK-HARRIS--Ellen, 74, died on December 16th. Her own profile in courage, Ellen fought a heroic 2-year battle with breast cancer, achieving some mighty victories before eventually succumbing. She was a true force of nature, lighting up any room she entered. She deeply cared about people and it showed in all her actions. Renowned for her lively curiosity and her torrent of questions on any given topic-large or small-she will be sorely missed. Adored and adoring wife of 37-years of Roger Harris, theirs was a love that defied description; devoted sister of Susan Berger (Michael); caring sister- in-law of Linda Russak (Marshall) and Barbara Pafundi (Ted); proud aunt of Eric Berger, Michele Berger, Jason Pafundi (Kirstin), Brian Pafundi (Deanna); excited great aunt of the newly arrived Nathaniel; loving daughter of the late Hans and Edith Wilk. A unique and gifted advertising sales rep, Ellen had a storied 35-year career in magazine publishing, working for the best magazines in the business: Her "A" list included The Atlantic, Harper's, Vanity Fair, The New Yorker, Bon Appetit, Playbill, Shop, Etc. and New York Magazine (thank you Larry). In the days of our lives, she will always be remembered and cherished. Funeral service on Friday, December 19 at 12:45 at The Riverside 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Interment will be at Temple Beth El Cemetery in Oneonta, New York on Sunday, December 21st. A memorial service will take place in early January. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Hospice and other worthy causes. 1/3

SILAS--C. J. "Pete." The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA) wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of our dear friend and colleague Pete Silas. Pete's legacy with the Clubs goes back to his boyhood in Miami, FL, where he was an active member of the Boys' Club. He never stopped giving back throughout this life, supporting education through the Phillips 66 scholarship program for Club members, and serving 30 years on the BGCA Board of Governors, including two as chairman. He became a Life Member in 2000. Pete was awarded BGCA's highest honor, the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award, and was one of the first inductees into BGCA's National Alumni Hall of Fame. He played a vital role in helping BGCA relocate its national headquarters to Atlanta in 1994. Pete's passion for helping kids and his generous spirit will always be remembered by all who had the privilege to know him. Our heartfelt condolences and prayers go out to his wife Theo and their children and family. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Ron Gidwitz, Chairman James Clark, President 1

ROTH--Michael, on December 16, 2014 at the age of 83. Beloved husband of Jeanny (nee Macoir), loving father of Micheline and Bart Dinardo, Catherine and Michael Zimmerman and Jeffrey Roth, cherished grandfather of Bart, Erica, Beau, and Micheline, and dear brother of the late Alan. Funeral service Friday, December 19, 2014, 11:00am, from Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to either Hebrew Union College or to Yale University Silas Spengler Class of 1953 Memorial Scholarship Fund. 1/3

SHARP--Penelope Chester, of Northford, CT and Fishers Island, NY died peacefully at home on December 14 at age 76. Born and raised in Greenwich, CT, Penni graduated from Miss Porter's School, Sarah Lawrence College and earned a Master of Forest Science degree from the Yale School of Forestry. An accomplished botanist and wetland biologist, she worked as a consultant for municipal and private clients and held leadership positions in numerous environmental organizations in Connecticut. On Fishers Island she served as president of the Henry L. Ferguson Museum and its Land Trust from 2003 until her death and shared her considerable knowledge of the natural world with all who knew her. Fond of music, she also sang with Cappella Cantorum. A devoted mother and grandmother, she loved being with her son and daughter and her four beloved grandchildren. She is survived by her husband, Gregory A. Sharp, her son, Stephen M. McPherson, Jr., her daughter, Eugenie McPherson Trevor, her grandchildren, Ashlyn and Alexa McPherson, and John B. Trevor V and Eliza T. Trevor, her sister Clare Stone, her brothers Colby M. Chester, IV and Geoffrey Chester, five nieces, a nephew and her Labrador. A celebration of Penni's life will be held at a later date. Donations, in lieu of flowers, may be made to Cappella Cantorum or the Henry L. Ferguson Museum. 1/3

REIF--Natalie Wilder, 91, died December 16. Beloved wife to the late Dr. Irving Reif, beloved mother to Karla Reif- Teitler; Robin Reif; Henry Reif; Jessica Reif Cohen and Nancy Reif. Mother-in-law to Jay Teitler, Robert Cohen and Wendy Lewis; adored grandmother to Amanda, Joshua, Kara, Marisa, Sophia, AJ, Vanessa and Adam. Her intelligence, beauty and competence were upstaged only by her capacity to love. Among her great passions were her family, the Democratic Party, culture and any creature in trouble. She came to local media attention at 88 when a pit bull killed her beloved dog Rosie and she called every outlet to warn pet owners beware. Beyond being an active doctor's wife and raising five children, her prodigious energy led to work, subsequently, as HS teacher, dance instructor and long time docent at the Brooklyn Museum where her fluency ranged from Bernini to Basquiat. Great art brought sublime pleasure and more than once her children found her weeping over a libretto while Tosca, Aida or Tannhauser blared from the sound system. The family will deeply miss her and strive to live out her great spirit. There will be a private service. 1/3

ORZACK--Mildred, nee Levin, passed away peacefully on December 15, 2014 surrounded by family at age 98. Predeceased by her husband, Everett, and her brother, Edwin Levin, she was born and raised in Manhattan. A long time resident of River Edge, NJ, she lived in recent years at Whitney Center in Hamden, CT. Mildred was a graduate of Hunter College High School and a summa cum laude graduate of Hunter College (Phi Beta Kappa) majoring in Greek and Latin. She received her M.A. in English Literature from Columbia University. She leaves her devoted and loving daughters, Susan Orzack Posen (Stephen Posen) and Karen Orzack Moore (Dr. Daniel C. Moore), her four splendid and adoring grandchildren: Alexandra Posen (Nils Folke Anderson), Zac Posen (Christopher Niquet), Ari David Moore and Nathaniel Moore and her great grandchildren: Cyrus Everett Anderson and Celeste Lucia Anderson and nieces and nephews. Mildred, a lifelong supporter of liberal causes, was devoted to literature and the arts. She actively encouraged the members of her family to follow their passions and her love for them was absolute. She led us with dignity and we were privileged to have her with us for so long. She will be deeply missed and never forgotten. Contributions in Mildred's memory to the Hunter College High School Scholarship Fund (https://www.hchsaa.org) or to Planned Parenthood (www.plannedparenthood.org) are appreciated. 1/3

NADLER--Jack, died Tuesday, December 16, 2014 at the age of 85. He is survived by his wife, Rita Koslow Nadler, his daughter Jennifer Wright and her husband Roy of Jersey City, N.J; and his sons, Matthew Nadler and his wife Ann of Plymouth, Mass.; and Evan Nadler and his wife, Tina of Washington, D.C. He is also survived by his grandchildren, Abigail and Sydney Wright, Aaron and Jeremy Nadler, and Owen and Sabrina Nadler. He married Rita Nadler in 1953 and they raised their children in Montclair, N.J. Jack was born in Passaic, N.J. on July 19, 1929. He graduated from Passaic High School, then Brown University. He received a master's degree in mathematics from the University of Chicago. Jack started his career in military research at Bell Labs, then he moved onto corporate research at AT&T where he worked for over 25 years. He also spent a year at the Center for Advanced Studies in the Behavioral Sciences at Stanford University. After the breakup of AT&T, he became a stockbroker. Jack was the son of David and Esther Nadler. He was predeceased by his sisters, Sonny Bergen, Mimi Weissman and Jean Mechanic. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Grand Central Station PO Box 4777, NY NY 10163-4777. 1/3

MATES--Estelle, 94, of New York City, passed away peacefully at home on December 15. Beloved wife of 70 years of the late Irving Mates; loving mother of Sharon, Amy and her husband Billy Mencow, and Carol; grandmother of Deena Kennedy and her husband Sean, Noah Hichenberg and his wife Shira, and Jesse Mencow; great-grandmother of Brody Kennedy and Jonah Hichenberg. Estelle graduated from Hunter College and achieved her dream of becoming a teacher, received a Master's degree in Guidance and became one of the first elementary school guidance counselors, in the New York City public schools. She will be sorely missed. Contributions may be sent to MJHS Foundation, an affiliate of the Metropolitan Jewish Health System MJHS), www.MJHS.org 1/3

LUKE--David L, III. On behalf of the Board and Staff of the Josiah Macy Jr. Foundation we extend our heartfelt sympathies to David Luke's family. Mr. Luke gave the Foundation 19 years of wise and insightful service as a Board member. We will miss his intellect and good humor. William H. Wright II Chairman George E. Thibault, MD President 1/3

LEVINE--Steven Alan, PhD, 48, of Brooklyn NY, died peacefully on Tuesday, December 16, 2014 following a long and courageous battle with a cancer that robbed the world of an uncommonly kind man with rare depth. Steve was the Coordinator for Educational Programs at La Guardia and Wagner Archives/CUNY and his passion for New York City and history was infectious. He was an unapologetic socialist who was never afraid to call out hypocrisy. A man of many enthusiasms, we will forever associate the NY Mets, Star Trek, and folk music with Steve. He was an avid bicyclist and ride leader. Spending time with friends and bragging about his son were his greatest joys. Steve's legacy lives on in his wife of 23 years, Michele Mark Levine, son Nate Levine, parents Melvin and Vera Levine of Port Washington NY, brother David & his wife Joanna Levine of San Diego CA, in-laws, nieces, nephews, aunts, uncles, cousins and many, many lifelong friends. Goodbye and Shalom dear Steve. The world is a better place because you fought for it, and sadder now that you're gone. Please direct memorial gifts to: Carcinoid Cancer AwarenessNetwork www.carcinoiaware ness.org and AmericanJewish World Service: ajws.org. Please direct memorial gifts to Service: Thursday December 18, 2014 at 11:30am Funeral Home: Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Manhattan. Cemetery: Mount Carmel Cemetery Glendale, NY. 1/3
KAHN--Jason. Beloved husband of Karen Kirshenbaum. Loving father of Simon and Joshua Kahn. Cherished son of Miles and Paula Kahn. Loving brother of David Kahn. Regarded editor and writer. 1/3

JOHNSON--Jill Gretchen, of Locust Valley and Manhattan, NY on December 10, 2014 age 59. Former fashion model with the Ford Modeling Agency. Beloved daughter, sister and aunt. Service at St. John's of Lattingtown, Saturday, December 20, 2014 at 11am. DodgeThomas.com 1/3

HOAGLAND--Anne Rowe, beloved sister and aunt, died peacefully on December 14 after a valiant battle with cancer. Anne was born in Cleveland, OH in 1952 to George W. and Jeanette Gunn Hoagland. After graduating from the Laurel School in Shaker Heights, she attended Wellesley College and later transferred to the University of Pennsylvania. She graduated with a Bachelor of Arts degree summa cum laude in Art History and English literature in 1975 and was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She also studied Italian at Georgetown University and English Literature at Worcester College, Oxford. She was a member of the Kappa Kappa Gamma sorority at Penn. Anne moved to New York in 1975 with an internship at the Whitney Museum of American Art. For the last 30 years, her professional career was in the real estate investment management industry. Anne first became interested in real estate as a paralegal at Shearman & Sterling. From 1979-1998 she was with two real estate investment banking firms, Eastdil Realty and The O'Connor Group. In 1998, she joined the Global Real Assets Group at JPMorgan Asset Management, where she served as an Executive Director at the time of her death. Anne was a member of the National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York, the Cosmopolitan Club, the Brick Presbyterian Church, and the Center Harbor Yacht Club in Brooklin, ME. She enjoyed traveling, visiting art museums, reading biographies, and collecting Chinese Export porcelain and European antiques. She was always eager to retain her connections to Ohio and Maine and maintained residences in Cleveland, OH, and Sargentville, ME as well as in Manhattan. Anne is survived by her brother Leigh W. Hoagland, sister-in-law Eleanor T.M. Hoagland, niece Georgina G. Hoagland, and nephew Nicholas G. Hoagland, all of Manhattan. A memorial service will be held at the Brick Presbyterian Church on Friday, January 23 at 4pm. The family requests that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Restoration Fund for the Sedgwick First Baptist Church, c/o the Sedgwick- Brooklin Historical Society, PO Box 171, Sedgwick, ME 04676. 1/3

GURALNICK--Rita, died on December 17, 2014 at the age of 89. Beloved daughter of Bennett and Jeanne Glick. Loving Mother, Grandmother, Sister and Aunt. Service will be held on Friday, 1pm at "The Riverside," Amsterdam Ave and 76th Street. 1/3

EVERETT--Eleanor Delafield, died peacefully on December 14, 2014 in Ashburn, Virginia, of complications from Parkinson's disease. She is survived by her life- long husband Francis D. Everett, Jr., her son John, his wife Jeannine and their son Jonah, of Great Falls, Virginia, and by her sister Harriet D. Smith of Stonington, Connecticut. A long time resident of New York City, she was active in the residential real estate market for many years. She was involved with various city charities and for a number of years served on the Board Of Directors of the Sheltering Arms Children Services. Her passion was the theatre and she was a member of the Snarks, an amateur theatrical group. She was a lovely lady all her life. 1/3

ENGELKE JR.--George L. The Board of Directors, officers and staff of Astoria Financial Corporation and Astoria Bank extend our deepest sympathies on the passing of our distinguished former Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer George L. Engelke, Jr. For 40 years, George was an extraordinary business leader and beloved member of the Astoria family. His vision made it possible to grow from a mutually owned thrift into a premier community bank on Long Island, with a reputation for extensive community involvement. George's vision for building a better bank was evident as he converted the bank to public ownership in 1993, and then acquired Fidelity New York Savings Bank, Greater New York Savings Bank and Long Island Savings Bank, building a retail banking franchise which would serve the banking needs of a region with a population greater than that of 38 states. George's business acumen was invaluable to the bank's growth and expansion, and his kindness toward all those he met was inspirational. A hard-working executive and Certified Public Accountant by trade, he believed in the value of education. His professional skills were matched only by his larger than life personality, and genuine interest in the welfare of the bank's customers and staff. An advocate for affordable housing, homeownership and community revitalization, George was a former Chairman of The Federal Home Loan Bank of New York and a member of the Board of Directors of the Community Preservation Corporation, as well as Chairman of the Savings Bank Association of New York State. He was also a former member of the Board of Directors of the New York Bankers Association and served as a member of the Financial Accounting Standards Advisory Council. He was an active member of the Board of Trustees of Long Island University and the Advisory Board of Directors of Neighborhood Housing Services of New York City, Inc. In addition, George was an active supporter of Lehigh University where he graduated with a Bachelor of Science Degree in Business Administration. We offer our deepest condolences to his loving family and extend our gratitude for George's leadership and friendship. His warmth and compassion will never be forgotten. 1/3
DIAMOND--Beverly, on December 15, 2014. Devoted daughter of the late Carl and Eva Diamond. Beloved wife of Michael Dreizen. Contributions in her memory made to City of Hope would be appreciated. 1/3

COLLINS--Eileen M.,on December 13, 2014. Retired Executive Secretary at Exxon. Loving sister of Michael, John, the late Stephan and the late Joseph. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass Thursday 10:30am Notre Dame Church 405 West 114 Street NY, NY. Interment Co. Clare, Ireland. 1/3

BUCHMAN--George, on December 15, age 84. Beloved husband of Jean and the late Rosalind. Loving father of Deborah, Barry (Dara) and the late Meyer. Proud grandfather of Rebekah and Eliana. Services Thursday, 11am at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn. www.shermanschapel.com 1/3

BRABEC--Claire. Claire Brabec passed away peacefully at her home in New York on December 4, 2014. Claire (whose professional name was Claire Monette) was an interior decorator by profession and was also responsible for designing and decorating the sets for the new product industrial shows produced by her beloved husband Erv Brabec and his company Marketing Concepts, Inc. Prior to that, she had a career as a singer and dancer. Claire and Erv married, travelled the world together and there could not have been two people who were more suited for each other as their love was an inspiration to everyone who knew them. No one will ever forget how the two of them celebrated the joys of Christmas and the sharing of presents with family and friends. It was always a truly remarkable, happy and very special day. After her husband's death in 2000, Claire continued her designer activities, participated as a co-op board member and continued to be active in the Catholic Church as well as the Turtle Bay Association. Claire, who was the daughter of Mildred and Murray Marcus and sister of Barbara Koenig, is survived by her two sons, Jeff and Todd, her nieces Meri and Jill, her grand nephews Richie and David, her cousin Marge and her sister-in-law Irene. Claire had wonderful friends, doctors and care givers who adored her and helped her. She touched all who knew her. Life is measured by what you give and not by what you get. Claire lived by those words. She lives in our hearts forever. 1/3

BARNETT--Harold Charles, 89, of Bronxville, NY passed away on December 11th of natural causes. Mr. Barnett was born on December 30, 1924 in Yonkers, NY to Charles and Catherine Watson Barnett. He was the youngest and last to pass away of eight brothers, all of whom served simultaneously in World War II. Mr. Barnett served in the USN from 1942 to 1945, including a posting in the Aleutian Islands. He married, Rita Caruso, also a native of Yonkers on June 15, 1946 in Mt Carmel Church in Yonkers. He graduated from Pace College with a degree in Accounting and went to work for the Conover-Mast Company in Manhattan. Later he worked for the Hearst Magazines Division of Hearst Corporation for over 20 years, from which he retired in 1991. He was a long time usher at the Church of St Joseph in Bronxville, and a member of the New York Athletic Club where he was an avid swimmer. Mr. Barnett was an avid golfer and was the genealogical expert for his entire extended family. He is survived by two children, Paula Kennedy of Weaverville, NC, and Christopher Barnett of Kansas City, and two grandchildren Juliet 11 and Evan 9. 1/3

ACKART--Robert C.,age 93, of Wilmington, DE passed away in his sleep on Sunday, December 14, 2014 at the Methodist Country House. Robert was a longtime volunteer with The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, was stage manager of Central City's work premiere of Douglas Moore's "The Ballad of Bay Doe" and stage director in its initial seasons of the Santa Fe Opera. Author of numerous cookbooks, he was also critic of operatic recordings for "Stereo Review" and was active with the Metropolitan Opera's auditions programs. He is survived by his sister and several nieces and nephews. A memorial service for immediate family members will be held in Wilmington. For online condolences, please visit: Chandlerfuneralhome.com 1/3

BRIDWELL--Norman. Died December 12, 2014, on Marthas Vineyard at the age of 86. Norman is mourned by all of his friends at Scholastic, the global publishing, education and media company, where his beloved children's series, Clifford the Big Red Dog, has been nurtured and published for more than fifty years. Bridwell created the character of Clifford in 1963 and went on to write and illustrate more than 150 titles in the series, which now boasts 129 million books in print in 13 languages. In 2000, everyone's favorite BIG red dog made his television debut on PBS Kids and the animated series quickly became one of the network's biggest children's hits. Norman Bridwell's books about Clifford, childhood's most loveable dog, could only have been written by a gentle man with a great sense of humor. Norman personified the values that parents and educators hope to communicate to children kindness, compassion, helpfulness, gratitude through the Clifford stories which have been loved for more than fifty years. The magic of the character and stories Norman created with Clifford is that children can see themselves in this big dog who tries very hard to be good, but is somewhat clumsy and always bumping into things and making mistakes. What comforts the reader is that Clifford is always forgiven by Emily Elizabeth, who loves him unconditionally. At Scholastic, we are deeply saddened by the loss of our loyal and talented friend whose drawings and stories have inspired all of us and generations of children and their parents. We offer our condolences to Normans wife of 56 years, Norma Bridwell, their daughter Emily, their son Timothy and their three grandchildren. Richard Robinson Chairman, President, CEO, Scholastic

WEISS--Naomi (nee Chestney), 91 years old, daughter of Louis and Estelle, predeceased by beloved husband Irwin. Loving mother of Laurie Berke- Weiss (Brian Berke), Sara Weiss (Lawrence Wasser) and Barbara Finnerty (John). Proud grandmother of Rachel, Alex, Louis, Jason, Lindsay and Haley. Predeceased by sister Eileen, died peacefully December 15th surrounded by family. A wonderful wife, mother, mother-in- law, and grandmother, she took pride in her family, supported her daughters in everything except moving far away, and expected the world to recognize her grandchildren's accomplishments as she did. Curious, engaged, and always classy, Naomi cared about current events and fashion, traveled the world, worked, and took an interest everyone. She played a mean game of ping- pong, made terrific brownies, and was beloved for being both non-judgmental and opinionated. She will be missed by many. Services will be held at Sinai Chapels in Fresh Meadows, NY at 12:45pm on Sunday, December 21. 1/3

TAUBER--Arthur D. "Coach", 94, a resident of Manchester, NJ, died peacefully on Monday, December 15, 2014. He is survived by his wife of 72 years, Lenore, his children Roberta and Sidney Klotz, Fraida and Rabbi Yeruchem Cohen, Richard and Susan Tauber, and Steven Tauber, eleven grandchildren and many great-grandchildren. Prior to retirement, Mr. Tauber was the Director of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at the Manhattan Veterans Administration Hospital and a long time fencing coach and Athletic Director at Yeshiva University. He had many accomplishments during his life. His record as the only person to win NCAA medals in all three types of weapons-epee, foil and saber stands today. In 2001 he was elected to the NYU Athletics Hall of Fame. Mr. Tauber received the Bronze Star for his U.S. military service in World War II, and was appointed a "Chevalier" with the French Legion of Honor. After returning from the war, he began a successful career in physical medicine and rehabilitation with the Veterans Administration and was a member of the President's Committee for Rehabilitative Medicine for the VA hospital system. The family asks that donations in his memory be made to the charity of your choice. 1/3

She was predeceased by her beloved husband, Isaac Solomon, and parents, John and Goldie Smoller of Chelsea and Lynn, MA. She is survived by her daughter Diane Schoenthal of New York City and son Jeffrey Solomon and wife Sandra of Pittsburgh, PA, and very much loved grandchildren Allison Schoenthal, Andrew Schoenthal and Erica Loop, and great-grandchildren Cecilia and Cole Hoffman, London and Reese Schoenthal, and Ian Loop. Also survived by her brother Arnold Smoller and the late Saul Smoller. Funeral will be private and a Memorial Service will be held at a future date in Pompano Beach, FL. Services under the care of Torf Funeral Service, Chelsea, MA 617- 889-2900. 1/3
SLOATE--Martin. A loving husband, best friend; dedicated father, brother, and son who touched many lives. He will be deeply missed. Roxene 1/3

SLOATE--Martin. Beloved husband, father and brother. His kindness, consideration and generosity will always be remembered. Not only wonderful to his immediate and extended family, but also very caring of friends and neighbors. He will be much missed. SCHULWEIS--Rabbi Harold M. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Jewish Foundation for the Righteous deeply mourn the passing of its founder, Rabbi Harold M. Schulweis. Rabbi Schulweis was a visionary who saw possibilities that others did not and acted upon them. Rabbi will be missed by many; none more so than the Righteous Gentiles whose deeds during the Holocaust he championed for years. Establishing The Jewish Foundation for the Righteous brought attention to the bravery of non-Jews who risked their lives to save Jews during the Holocaust. Rabbi Schulweis was a man of faith, spirituality, compassion, principle, and action. He cared deeply about others and worked his entire life to make our world a much better place. Whether it was from the pulpit or whether it was through his writings, Rabbi Schulweis motivated others to action in an effort to repair our broken world. Rabbi's kindness, caring, and humility will be missed. His legacy will live on across time. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Malkah and the entire family. Harvey Schulweis, Chairman Roman Kent, President Stanlee J. Stahl, Executive Vice President 1/3

PARSON--Donna Fox, 73, died on December 16 of complications from heart surgery. Donna was born in 1941 in Ann Arbor, Michigan, and died in New York City. Donna was a remarkable and multifaceted woman whose life and work touched thousands of people. As a community organizer in Connecticut, she led the fight to stop Interstate 84 from slicing through wetlands and historic sites. She served as Executive Director of the Connecticut Citizen Action Group and of Northeast Action, a regional support center for organizing. Donna also directed two Congressional campaigns and numerous state legislative campaigns, and worked in the Connecticut Secretary of the State's office under Secretary of the State Miles Rapoport. Later, her activist work took her to New York and Washington, where she served in key positions at Public Campaign, Demos, and most recently Common Cause. Through all of this, Donna was a mentor and friend to hundreds of young organizers, especially women, in their careers and personal lives. Donna was also a traveler and a writer. She recently completed a novel about two sisters in Estonia, separated by war, and the lives they led, told in the letters they exchanged. The inspiration for the book was the Estonian heritage of her husband of 29 years, John Parson, who predeceased her in 1997. John and Donna shared a beautiful, extraordinary, and unshakeable bond. They loved, they traveled, they shared everything, and they raised two wonderful and accomplished daughters, Jennifer Parson of San Francisco and Joanna Parson of New York City. Donna is also survived by her siblings Gayle, Roger, and Michael Fox, all of Michigan. No funeral services are planned. A memorial service will be held at a future date. Donations in her memory can be made to the Windcall Institute, on whose board she served for seven years, at www.windcall.org, or with a check made out to Common Counsel Foundation at CCF, 405-14th Street, Suite 809, Oakland, CA 94612. 1/3

GUIHER--James M.,Jr., died on December 17 in Columbia, Maryland. Beloved husband of Elizabeth "Liddy" Hart Guiher and father of Catharine Brownfield Guiher and Deborah Guiher Chamblee. The only child of Ruth Souders and James M. Guiher, Sr., he was born in Clarksburg, WV, on February 21, 1927. He was raised in Clarksburg and graduated from Washington Irving High School in 1945. After military service as Private First Class in the army in post-WWII occupied Germany, he attended Princeton University on the GI bill, class of 1951. He attended Harvard Law School, but did not finish, opting instead to get an MFA degree from the Museum School of Fine Arts in Boston in 1954. He married Liddy in 1954 and they settled in New York City. Jim worked for Prentice-Hall publishing company, where he rose to be the sponsoring editor for art and geology books. His crowning achievement there was publishing the textbook edition of H.W. Janson's "History of Art." Later, he became editor-in-chief of the elementary and high school textbooks division. He retired from publishing in 1976 to pursue a writing career and intellectual pursuits. Valuing the wisdom of Greek pagan culture, he wrote two Greek-themed plays, "Aphrodite" and "Candoo!", which he self-published in 2010. In later life, he had become increasingly concerned about political discord and religious intolerance, both in the United States and around the world, and felt that the Greek philosophy of "everything in moderation, nothing to excess" held the key to the world's problems. Jim devoted great efforts to preserving family history and artifacts. He ensured that the avant- garde films of Liddy's uncle, Jim Davis, were housed at Anthology Film Archives, curated by Robert Haller, and that numerous family historical documents were housed at the West Virginia and Regional History Center at the University of West Virginia, curated by John Cuthbert. After living in NYC for 60 years, he moved to Maryland in October 2014 to Charlestown retirement community, where his daughter Deborah works. He was looking forward to a new chapter of his life, and to continue working on disseminating his wisdom and insights through his writings, but increasingly nagging health issues resulted in his time being cut short. His parting wish for humanity is for people around the world to follow a path of moderation rather than fanaticism. He was pre-deceased by his wife, Liddy, in 2011. He is survived by his two daughters, Catharine (Brooklyn, NY) and Deborah (Columbia, MD), his son-in-law Jeff Chamblee, and two grandchildren, Rebecca Guiher Chamblee and Benjamin Guiher Chamblee. The funeral will be held at the Davis Funeral Home in Clarksburg, WV on Saturday January 3 at 11:00am. A memorial will be held in New York City at a later date. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Anthology Film Archives, 32 Second Avenue, New York, NY 10003; or the West Virginia and Regional History Center, c/o WVU Foundation (IMO Jim Guiher FUND 2U139), PO Box 1650 -Morgantown, WV 26507-1650. 1/3

FIER--Andrew. Beloved husband for over 55 years to Phyllis. Loving father of Amy Gitlin and Lisa Caliandro. Devoted grandfather of Elkanah, Eve and Sarah. Service to be held at the funeral home he helped establish, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam, Sunday at 9:30am. 1/3

DETWILER--Richard Mott, 93, died December 17 in Rye Brook, NY. He was born in Lancaster, PA, June 2, 1921 to William Sanderson Detwiler and Gertrude Mott Detwiler. A graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and Yale University, he enlisted in the U.S. Marine Corps Reserve while an undergraduate and he served in the Pacific, landing in Nagasaki shortly after the explosion of the atomic bomb. During the Korean Conflict he served as commanding officer of the Marine Corps public information office in New York. Following a stint as a reporter and feature editor with the Rocky Mountain News, he worked in public relations at Ford, Chase National Bank, and the BBDO advertising agency in New York, where he was vice president and director of public relations when he retired. He was married to Barbara Ann Burns of New Rochelle, NY from 1951 until her death in 2011. They lived in Pelham Manor, NY where he served as a town trustee. Following his retirement, they lived in Melvin Village, NH for more than 30 years. He is survived by a daughter, Anne D. Crecraft, of Sterling, VA; sons Richard Jr., of Bronxville, NY; John B. Detwiler, of Charlotte, NC; and William S. Detwiler, of Brooklyn, NY; and eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:30am on Monday in the chapel at The Wartburg, One Wartburg Place, Mount Vernon, NY. Donations may be made to Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, NH. 1/3

BARNETT--Harold Charles, 89, of Bronxville, NY passed away on December 11th of natural causes. Mr. Barnett was born on December 30, 1924 in Yonkers, NY to Charles and Catherine Watson Barnett. He was the youngest and last to pass away of eight brothers, all of whom served simultaneously in World War II. Mr. Barnett served in the USN from 1942 to 1945, including a posting in the Aleutian Islands. He married, Rita Caruso, also a native of Yonkers on June 15, 1946 in Mt Carmel Church in Yonkers. He graduated from Pace College with a degree in Accounting and went to work for the Conover-Mast Company in Manhattan. Later he worked for the Hearst Magazines Division of Hearst Corporation for over 20 years, from which he retired in 1991. He was a long time usher at the Church of St Joseph in Bronxville, and a member of the New York Athletic Club where he was an avid swimmer. Mr. Barnett was an avid golfer and was the genealogical expert for his entire extended family. ALTER--Jerome. The New Synagogue Of Palm Beach mourns the death of Jerome Alter of blessed memory -a quintessential mensch, our dear friend and congregant. ACKART--Robert C.,age 93, of Wilmington, DE passed away in his sleep on Sunday, December 14, 2014 at the Methodist Country House. Robert was a longtime volunteer with The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, was stage manager of Central City's work premiere of Douglas Moore's "The Ballad of Bay Doe" and stage director in its initial seasons of the Santa Fe Opera. Author of numerous cookbooks, he was also critic of operatic recordings for "Stereo Review" and was active with the Metropolitan Opera's auditions programs. He is survived by his sister and several nieces and nephews. A memorial service for immediate family members will be held in Wilmington. For online condolences, please visit: Chandlerfuneralhome.com 1/3
WILLNER--Alvin. After five years you are still missed and remembered with love. Jane (Harold), Jay (Jeanne), Stella.

BRIDWELL--Norman. Died December 12, 2014, on Marthas Vineyard at the age of 86. Norman is mourned by all of his friends at Scholastic, the global publishing, education and media company, where his beloved children's series, Clifford the Big Red Dog, has been nurtured and published for more than fifty years. Bridwell created the character of Clifford in 1963 and went on to write and illustrate more than 150 titles in the series, which now boasts 129 million books in print in 13 languages. In 2000, everyone's favorite BIG red dog made his television debut on PBS Kids and the animated series quickly became one of the network's biggest children's hits. Norman Bridwell's books about Clifford, childhood's most loveable dog, could only have been written by a gentle man with a great sense of humor. Norman personified the values that parents and educators hope to communicate to children kindness, compassion, helpfulness, gratitude through the Clifford stories which have been loved for more than fifty years. The magic of the character and stories Norman created with Clifford is that children can see themselves in this big dog who tries very hard to be good, but is somewhat clumsy and always bumping into things and making mistakes. What comforts the reader is that Clifford is always forgiven by Emily Elizabeth, who loves him unconditionally. At Scholastic, we are deeply saddened by the loss of our loyal and talented friend whose drawings and stories have inspired all of us and generations of children and their parents. We offer our condolences to Normans wife of 56 years, Norma Bridwell, their daughter Emily, their son Timothy and their three grandchildren. Richard Robinson Chairman, President, CEO, Scholastic

ALTER--Jerome. December 15 2014, born February 16 1928, Brooklyn, NY. Loving husband to Chris, father of Ken, Karen (Paul), and Stuart (Beth), step-father of Edwige (John); 8 grandchildren. Founding member/President, Hillel School of Lawrence; Board of Directors, Shaare Tefilah of Far Rockaway; member, New Synagogue of Palm Beach. He will be greatly missed, but live on in our beautiful memories.

How much plaintiffs’ law firms have contributed to benefit state attorneys general.

At least nine former attorneys general, in recent years, have worked with law firms seeking to serve attorneys general on a contingency basis. Some serve as lawyers at these firms, actually litigating cases, and others are simply hired to make introductions. Either way, it can be lucrative work.

Nowhere has the battle been more intense over the last year than in Louisiana, where groups aligned with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and major pharmaceutical companies and the business community teamed up to push the State Legislature to crack down on the hiring of outside lawyers by the attorney general.

SAVIN--Robert S.,89, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, formerly of Mamaroneck, NY, passed away December 18th from Alzheimer's Disease. He was born and raised in Bridgeport, CT, was an US Army Veteran, and married in July 1951 to Barbara Low. In 1954 he joined his father-in-law Max M. Low at IPCO, a multi health care company where he eventually became its CEO. He also sat on the board of SAVIN Corporation. Bob became active in many charities, amongst them the United Hebrew Geriatric Center of New Rochelle, where he served as a past president and trustee. He and his family were donors there of the Low Savin Residence, an assisted living facility. He also worked tirelessly for the American Friends of the Hebrew University,which awarded him the coveted Scopus Award in 1983. For many years he co chaired with Howard Cosell the annual Sports Dinner held in memory of the 11 slain Israeli Olympians. In addition he was a founder of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, The Hebrew University in Jerusalem as well as the Truman Peace Institute. After leaving corporate life Bob became involved in Park City, Utah, where he bought and developed Z Place, an entertainment Center that for many years was the headquarters for the Sundance Film Festival. He was one of the first homeowners at the Stein Erikson Lodge in Deer Valley, where he spent many hours skiing, his favorite sport. In addition to his wife Barbara of 63 years, he is survived by his two loving children, Debi (Steve) Scoggan of Park City Utah, Scott of Santa Monica CA. and two adoring grandchildren Skyler and Scarlett Scoggan. Graveside Services will be held on Tuesday, December 23rd 11am, at Glenville Cemetery, 99 Memory Lane, Greenwich, CT For directions call 914- 967-4908 or WJC 914-698-2960. Donations in Bob's name may be made to United Hebrew Geriatric, 391 Pelham Road, New Rochelle, NY 10805 or a charity of your choice. 1/3

SARGOY--Ida Menter, age 103. April 6, 1911 -December 17, 2014, a loving wife to Milton, who preceded her in death, mother of Kenneth, grandmother of Chris and Allison, and mother-in-law of Joan. She lived a long, fruitful life and will be greatly missed but will live on in our memories. 1/3

MALOFF--Aaron N.,96. Retired Superintendent of Queens High Schools and former Principal of Jamaica High School and John Jay High School, passed away on December 19, 2014 in Bronx, NY surrounded by loving family. A lifelong New Yorker, he was born November 22, 1918, educated in NYC public schools and City College of New York (BA and MA). Served as an Air Force flight navigator in the Pacific during WWII. Taught English, then moved into leadership positions guiding elementary through high schools to excellence and training others to do so. Proudly developed Academic Index to measure and improve school achievement (New York Times January 17, 1984). Predeceased by parents David and Yetta, wife Muriel, brothers Nathan, Rubin and Saul. Left to cherish his memory are his children Laurie (Joel) Kramer, Ellen Case, Peter Maloff (MG Denton); grandchildren Matt Kramer (Katie Barrett), Eli Kramer (Jessica Cordova), Adam Kramer, Ben Case (Jane Morril), Danny Case (Emily Meredith), Meredith Case, Kate Maloff, Michael Maloff; great-grandchildren Caroline, Charlotte, Olivia, Talia, Ella. Also survived by loving companion Cecile Littwin. Services to honor his memory will be held on Sunday December 21, 2014, 2:00pm at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, NY. He will be laid to rest at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Donations in his memory preferred to ACLU or donor's choice. 1/3

HOWARD--Robert. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Robert Howard, our deepest sympathies on the occasion of his passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to his life. May all who loved him be comforted. Joshua M. Davidson, Senior Rabbi John H. Streicker, President 1/3

HOWARD--Robert. Historic Entrepreneur, at the age of 91 on December 19, 2014. Visionary, entrepreneur and technical innovator in various fields of corporate endeavor. His most noteworthy invention was the iconic dot matrix printer which helped pioneer the adoption of personal computing. His numerous additional inventions became the foundation for the 27 companies and the many thousands of jobs he created. He is survived by his loving wife Kit, his sister Sylvia Howard Fuhrman, devoted and loving children Ellen Howard Toon and her husband James, Richard Howard and his wife Lois, Dr. Lawrence Howard and his wife Judith, Jodi Smith Spolansky and her husband Steven and Brett Smith. His cherished grandchildren Ian Howard, Seth Howard, Kathryn Howard, Genna Howard, Ben Howard, Michael McKenna and Phillip Toon and Griffin Spolansky, Gage Spolansky, Peyton Spolansky, Lawson Spolansky and Chase Spolansky. Services Sunday, December 21 at 11:00a.m. Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, Main Sanctuary. Shiva on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Robert Howard may be made to the Robert Howard Philanthropic Fund, Greater Miami Jewish Federation, 4200 Biscayne Boulevard, Miami, FL 33137 www.jewishmiami.org. 1/3

FIER--Andy. The Board of Directors and staff of Plaza Jewish Community Chapel wish to express their heartfelt condolences to Phyllis and family on the death of Andy Fier, Executive Director Emeritus of Plaza Jewish Community Chapel. His love of family, Plaza and Judaism will be remembered for generations to come. May his memory forever be a blessing. Harold Handler, Chairman 1/3

DIESING--Richard C.,May 7, 1925 -December 16, 2014. Born in Springfield, IL, passed away peacefully from Alzheimer's at Jewish Home Lifecare, Manhattan. Educated at Concordia Lutheran High School, St. Paul, MN; Concordia Lutheran Seminary, St. Louis; University of Chicago. Predeceased by parents, Charlotte and Frederick C. Diesing, and brother Edward F. Diesing, all of St. Paul. Survived by: sister Lois R. Diesing, Arlington, MA; Terrence McCafferty, longtime friend and loyal caregiver in Richard's last years. Richard was the Director of Hudson Neighborhood Conservation Corp. He was a Social Worker at Volunteers Of America for many years. Richard was a Bach and classical music devotee and devoted his life to others. He was an active volunteer at the United Nations Association. Simple graveside services will be held at 1:30pm, Monday, December 22, at All Faiths Cemetery, at 67-29 Metropolitan Avenue, Middle Village, Queens (across from M Train Station). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Volunteers of America -Greater New York, 340 West 85th St., NY, NY 10024. "Schon Schlafen, Richard". 1/3

FIER--Andrew. Beloved husband for over 55 years to Phyllis. Loving father of Amy Gitlin and Lisa Caliandro. Devoted grandfather of Elkanah, Eve and Sarah. Service to be held at the funeral home he helped establish, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st and Amsterdam, Sunday at 9:30am. 1/3

BOXER--Jerome, 93, of Scarsdale, NY. Survived by his wife of 66 years, Evelyn; son Martin and wife Sandy; daughter Deborah; and grandchildren David, Felicia, and Michael. Decorated WWII Veteran with 33 combat missions, the Distinguished Flying Cross, Purple Heart, and Air Medal with 3 OLC. Services: Riverside Chapel, Mt. Vernon at 10am on December 21. 1/3

BLEETSTEIN--Glenna Dee, of Salt Lake City then New York, died on Sunday, December 14 at an age she preferred not to mention. Widow of Jacob Bleetstein, beloved mother of Oscar and grandmother of Henry. She loved her friends dearly and will be missed by many. Services will be held on December 23, 2014 at 11am at Frank E. Campbell in Manhattan. 1/3

BING--Cynthia Eaton. Passed away peacefully at Mt. Sinai Hospital on December 12 after a long illness. Cynthia was born on April 6, 1942 in Belfast, ME. She attended Abbott Academy (Philips Andover Academy) and Connecticut College for Women (Connecticut College). After moving to New York City, she worked for Holland America Line as head of group sales. In 1972, she married Alexander Bing III, partner at L.F. Rothschild & Co. Cynthia was a dedicated mother to three young children when she began her career as a philanthropist in fields of education and environmental protection. She served on many boards including: Phillips Academy, Connecticut College, Trevor Day School, The Parents League of New York, Prep for Prep, Early Steps, Search and Care, New York State Association of Independent Schools, New York League of Conservation Voters, and Environmental Advocates. In many cases, Cynthia served as board president or acted as a committee head. Cynthia spent her summers with her family in Montana where enjoyed the mountains and cross-country horseback riding. Cynthia's parents, Lorimer and Ruth Eaton, and one child, Abigail R. Bing predeceased her. She is survived by her husband, Alexander Bing III; brother, Eben R. Eaton; daughter, Cynthia K. Bing; son, Alexander M. Bing; step-daughter, Virginia G. Bing; granddaughter, Eloise B. Padial; and son- in-law, Michael S. Padial. A Memorial Service is to be held at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and 5th Ave., at 3pm, January 6 with reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Church of The Heavenly Rest and/or Search and Care. 1/3

WINIKOFF--Stanley. The Board of Directors and Membership of Glen Head Country Club announce with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed Member Stanley Winikoff. Our deepest sympathies are extended to the bereaved family. Jeffrey Weingarten, President
WILLNER--Alvin. After five years you are still missed and remembered with love. Jane (Harold), Jay (Jeanne), Stella.

SMITH--Harry P.,89, of Roseland, NJ, formerly of New York City, passed away on Tuesday, November 18, 2014. Served in the Navy, WWII, and worked as a textile designer for Manes & Co for over 30 years. World traveler and GMHC volunteer for over 25 years. Beloved uncle to Lillian Rockwood and great uncle to Lucas and Jessica. He valued family, his family of friends and the wonderful times they shared on Fire Island and traveling. His warmth and humor will be missed. Memorial service will be at a later date.

SLOATE--Martin (Marty), passed on December 15, 2014 in Delray Beach FL after a long illness. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife, Roberta (1990), mother of his children Pamela and Jonathan, and survived by his loving wife Roxene and his siblings Alan Sloate (Phyllis) and Laura Sloate. He was a man of great generosity, friendship and love. He now lies in painless peace. Laura Sloate

JENSEN--Camille McLean Anderson. Died on December 18 of natural causes at her residence in Darien, Connecticut. She was 95. Camille was born on December 14, 1919, in Holly Springs, Mississippi, the daughter of Percy Harmon and Camille McLean Anderson. She attended Miss Hutchison's School in Memphis and graduated from Mary Baldwin College in Staunton, Virginia, in 1941. In 1942 she was named Maid of Cotton at the Memphis Cotton Carnival by the National Cotton Council. She married Frode Jensen, a physician, in 1948 and settled in Denver, Colorado. In 1950 they moved to Riverdale, New York, where she participated in the Parent Teachers Association at the Riverdale Country School, was a founding member of the Board of the Wave Hill Association, served on the board of the Girl Scouts Association of Greater New York, was a founder of the Riverdale Presbyterian Church Nursery School, and was a member of the board of governors of the Riverdale Yacht Club. On weekends she and Frode enjoyed their country home at the Gipsy Trail Club in Carmel, New York. After her husband's death in 1973, Camille enjoyed a successful career as a realtor in Riverdale with Robert E. Hill, Inc. In 1987, she retired and moved to New Canaan, Connecticut, where she lived for 25 years. Camille was predeceased by her husband, Frode, and is survived by her three children; her son, Frode (Skip) and his wife, Kitty, of Park City, Utah, her daughter Camille, of Manhattan, and her son, Peter, of Phoenixville, Pennsylvania. She is also survived by her five grandchildren: Christian McLean, Catherine Spotswood Hall, and Henry Carter Jensen; and Matthew St. John and Alexander Jensen Douglas. Funeral arrangements are being handled by Edward Lawrence Funeral Home in Darien, CT. Funeral services will be private. Camille will be interred in the Hamilton College Cemetery. A memorial service next spring is planned in Clinton, NY. Contributions in Camille's memory can be made to the Frode and Camille Jensen Scholarship Fund at Hamilton College, 198 College Hill Road, Clinton, NY 13323.

BELLSEY--Ruthellen "Rusty" November 7, 1932 - December 17, 2014. Devoted wife to Edwin and the late Jerome Glucksman; mother to Jim, Bill, Debi and Janet, grandmother to Jay, Drew and Elizabeth; mother-in-law to Linda, Barry and Amy; beloved sister, aunt, sister-in-law and friend. Successful real estate agent in Scarsdale. Remembered for her intelligence. Forever in our hearts. Donations may be made to Westchester Reform Temple, Attn: Rabbi or Cantor Discretionary Fund.

PARSON--Donna Fox, 73, died on December 16 of complications from heart surgery. Donna was born in 1941 in Ann Arbor, Michigan, and died in New York City. Donna was a remarkable and multifaceted woman whose life and work touched thousands of people. As a community organizer in Connecticut, she led the fight to stop Interstate 84 from slicing through wetlands and historic sites. She served as Executive Director of the Connecticut Citizen Action Group and of Northeast Action, a regional support center for organizing. Donna also directed two Congressional campaigns and numerous state legislative campaigns, and worked in the Connecticut Secretary of the State's office under Secretary of the State Miles Rapoport. Later, her activist work took her to New York and Washington, where she served in key positions at Public Campaign, Demos, and most recently Common Cause. Through all of this, Donna was a mentor and friend to hundreds of young organizers, especially women, in their careers and personal lives. Donna was also a traveler and a writer. She recently completed a novel about two sisters in Estonia, separated by war, and the lives they led, told in the letters they exchanged. The inspiration for the book was the Estonian heritage of her husband of 29 years, John Parson, who predeceased her in 1997. John and Donna shared a beautiful, extraordinary, and unshakeable bond. They loved, they traveled, they shared everything, and they raised two wonderful and accomplished daughters, Jennifer Parson of San Francisco and Joanna Parson of New York City. Donna is also survived by her siblings Gayle, Roger, and Michael Fox, all of Michigan. No funeral services are planned. A memorial service will be held at a future date. Donations in her memory can be made to the Windcall Institute, on whose board she served for seven years, at www.windcall.org, or with a check made out to Common Counsel Foundation at CCF, 405-14th Street, Suite 809, Oakland, CA 94612. 1/3

NORTON--Christina Jennifer, after a courageous fight against cancer, Christina Jennifer Norton died on December 8th. Born in New York and raised in Italy, Dr. Norton earned a Doctor of Veterinary Medicine degree from Universita di Bologna. She practiced in Brooklyn Heights and Manhattan. Christina was passionate about opera, art, animals, birding and the environment. She will be missed by all who knew her for her intelligence, beauty, grace and fortitude. Contributions in her memory can be made to National Resources Defense Council or American Bird Conservancy. From her loving friends. 1/3

NORTH FABRICAND-- Heather Foreman Clark was born in Somerville, Massachusetts on January 14, 1929. She died December 15, 2014. Heather was an operating room nurse at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital in New York and a well loved school nurse at Packer Collegiate Institute in Brooklyn Heights, New York. After retiring from Packer after 12 years, she devoted much of her time to her volunteer work at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in the American wing. Heather and her beloved husband Burton Fabricand travelled the world, from the North to the South Pole and all continents and countless countries in between. Her generosity of spirit, love and money endeared her to all that met her. Her absolute and total devotion to Burton was enviable and was admired by all that knew them or saw them together. Heather North Fabricand was predeceased by her first husband, Joseph Edward North, and later by Burton Paul Fabricand. She is survived by her children Robin North James, Leslie North Wainwright, Anthony North, Thaddeus North and stepchildren Nicole Fabricand Person and Lori Fabricand Remmen and seven grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the American Wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in NYC. 1

MICHAELSON--Arline, on December 17, 2014. Loving wife of Arthur. Cherished mother of Barbara (Steven), Sally and David. Devoted aunt. Dedicated teacher for 34 years at the Great Neck Public Schools and passionate artist. Services 1pm, Sunday, December 21, 2014 at Temple Beth El of Great Neck. MALOFF--Aaron N.,96. Retired Superintendent of Queens High Schools and former Principal of Jamaica High School and John Jay High School, passed away on December 19, 2014 in Bronx, NY surrounded by loving family. A lifelong New Yorker, he was born November 22, 1918, educated in NYC public schools and City College of New York (BA and MA). Served as an Air Force flight navigator in the Pacific during WWII. Taught English, then moved into leadership positions guiding elementary through high schools to excellence and training others to do so. Proudly developed Academic Index to measure and improve school achievement (New York Times January 17, 1984). Predeceased by parents David and Yetta, wife Muriel, brothers Nathan, Rubin and Saul. Left to cherish his memory are his children Laurie (Joel) Kramer, Ellen Case, Peter Maloff (MG Denton); grandchildren Matt Kramer (Katie Barrett), Eli Kramer (Jessica Cordova), Adam Kramer, Ben Case (Jane Morril), Danny Case (Emily Meredith), Meredith Case, Kate Maloff, Michael Maloff; great-grandchildren Caroline, Charlotte, Olivia, Talia, Ella. Also survived by loving companion Cecile Littwin. Services to honor his memory will be held on Sunday December 21, 2014, 2:00pm at Sinai Chapel, 162-05 Horace Harding Expwy, Fresh Meadows, NY. He will be laid to rest at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. Donations in his memory preferred to ACLU or donor's choice. 1/3

LAMEL--Linda H. Linda H. Lamel, passed away peacefully on December 5th after a valiant, three-year struggle against thymic cancer. Raised in both Brooklyn and Queens, she became a proud Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Queens College, NYU, and Brooklyn Law School. She became a pioneer of the women's movement and a leader of the insurance industry, specializing in regulation, solvency, life and health insurance, corporate governance, compliance, claims adjudication, and executive compensation. She was New York State's first female Deputy Superintendent of Insurance and a founder of the National Organization for Women (NOW) on Long Island. As President and CEO of The College of Insurance, she helped launch the insurance industry careers of numerous proteges. She was the Campaign Manager and later Chief of Staff for Lieutenant Governor Mary Anne Krupsak. After government service, she worked in the insurance industry as a Vice President of TIAA-CREF, Executive Director of the Risk and Insurance Management Society (RIMS), CEO of Claims on Line, Inc. and as a consultant, trainer, and arbitrator. Ms. Lamel has served as a director of several insurance companies and most recently served on the board of Universal American Co. and American Progressive Insurance Co. and SCOR Reinsurance Co. Ms. Lamel held many leadership roles in industry and bar organizations, including having served as chair of the ABA Torts and Insurance Practice Section, Executive Committee of the NYSBA Insurance Section, Association of Professional Insurance Women, the Insurance and Risk Management Council of the American Management Association, chair of the Medical Malpractice Committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, Co-chair of the Insurance Law Committee of the New York County Lawyers Association, Founding Director of the American Society of Workers Comp Professionals, the Reinsurance Advisory Committee to Senator Biden of the Senate Committee on the Judiciary, and member of the Presidential Council of AIDA-US. In 1988, Ms. Lamel was selected as the Insurance Woman of the Year by the Association of Professional Insurance Women and in 2000 was selected by Crain's Business Insurance as one of the 100 Women Industry Leaders. Over the past 10 years, Ms. Lamel taught as Adjunct Professor of Insurance Law at Brooklyn Law School and as Adjunct Professor of Economics at Queens College. Ms. Lamel also served in leadership roles for many non-profit organizations, including but not limited to Phi Beta Kappa Society, the League of Women Voters, Hour Children (Astoria), Boy Scouts of Greater New York, Queens College Business Advisory Council, and President of the Alumni Association for Brooklyn Law School. Ms. Lamel enjoyed theater, travel, beaches and chocolate. She is survived by her daughter, Diana Sands, her sisters Donna Weintraub and Eileen Hill, her brother Jerry Treppel, and her mother, Sylvia Treppel, as well as friends and colleagues who will miss her bright mind and warm heart. Contributions may be made in her honor to Hour Children, Inc. A memorial celebration for Ms. Lamel will be scheduled for the spring in New York City. 1/3

KLEIN--Irwin, died peacefully on December 19th at the age of 91. After graduating Phi Beta Kappa from City College of New York, he was selected to train as a language officer at the University of Michigan. He served in both WWII and the Korean war as a Japanese interpreter and interrogator, receiving a bronze medal. After the war, he received an MBA from Harvard University. He joined Music Corporation of America and was sent to open Tokyo's first international television office. He joined ABC International and was sent to Venezuela to represent their interest in a television station; subsequently the government declared that all television stations had to be Venezuelan owned. He opted to remain with the local station for over two decades. He married his wife Maggie Webster in 1972 and ten years later, they launched Magel selling television films and merchandising rights for most of the animation companies. In 2004 he retired to Litchfield, CT and passed his retirement years surrounded by friends and family who he loved and who loved him dearly. He is survived by his nephew and grand nephews and nieces, and his beloved wife of 42 years. He was a unique character and was loved for his wonderful sense of humor and love of life. He will be missed by us all, but his sparkle will stay with all who loved him. Funeral Service will be held on Sunday December 21, 2014 at "The Riverside" Amsterdam Ave and 76th Street, NYC. 1/3

KAHN--Richard Sanders. 88, of New York City and Martinsville, NJ, died Tuesday, December 2nd, 2014 at home with his family by his side. Born in Miami, FL, Richard, an only child, moved with his parents to NYC in the 1930's; a city he adored and was proud to be a part of for the remainder of his life. Richard was very proud to have served in the United States Military, first as a Merchant Marine and then as a member of the US Army in WWII. He went on to earn his undergraduate degree from City College, a J.D. from Fordham University School of Law and an LL.M, Masters of Law, from New York University School of Law. He was especially honored to have been sworn-in to argue before the Supreme Court of the United States. For thirty years, and until his retirement, Richard worked as Lead General Counsel of International Tax for Bristol Myers Squibb Corporation. He held similar roles at several other companies prior to that; including Olin and DuPont. During his tenure, he had the pleasure of traveling to, and working with, people in countries around the globe. He cherished those experiences and the lifelong friendships that were made along the way. In addition to being an active member of the New York and Martinsville, NJ communities for close to 40 years, he was also a passionate and generous contributor to many educational institutions as well as charities devoted to animal rights -dogs in particular. Richard, Mr. Kahn, Dick, or Dr. Kahn as he was proud to be called, was devoted to his family and was an amazing husband and father. He was preceded in death by his beloved wife Maxine, after 57 wonderful years of marriage. He is survived by, and will be deeply missed by, his devoted child- ren Sandra Berinstein, Valerie Kahn, Jennifer Snyder, Dana Cooper, Daphne Schechter and Michael Kahn, as well as their spouses and his 12 adoring grandchildren, Oliver Berinstein, Benjamin and Rebecca Schmierer, Spencer, Preston and Griffin Snyder, Joshua and Samuel Cooper, Samantha and Justin Schechter and Jamie and Elise Kahn, as well as by his cherished dog, Poco. Some words from his children: "I will never forget his genius, hysterical wit and his love for his children; but mostly, his enduring love for mom." Michael; "I was always so proud to be your daughter; thanks for your brilliance, humor and compassion." Ducky; "Always have cash, drink good wine and rely on yourself. Forever in my mind and heart." Dana; "He was caring and generous, charming and witty. He made everyone laugh." Jenny; "If it doesn't breathe, it doesn't count. I know he still has my back and I his." Valerie; "We all loved you deeply. Here's looking at you, kid." Sandy. The family remembered him privately at his Martinsville home, with his final resting place Paris, France; the only place on earth he loved more than his beloved NYC. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to the Seeing Eye Dog www.seeingeye.org and Rawhide Rescue www. rawhiderescue.weebly.com 1/3

HURWITZ--Uri (Uriel), died on Saturday, December 13, 2014. Age 83. He was born in Berlin and grew up in Palestine/Israel. He leaves behind his wife of 53 years, Johanna, two children, Nomi and Benjamin (Kimberly), three grandchildren, Ethan Richardson, Juliet and Fiona Hurwitz and hundreds of friends. Retired as a lecturer of Hebrew from Queens College (CUNY), he continued as an independent scholar researching Hebrew names and history. He also was a published novelist, a linguist fluent in several languages. He always asked people where they came from so he could learn a few new words and phrases in their native tongue, He loved classical music, nature, dogs, cats and donkeys and the state of Vermont. Everyone who knew him realized he was sui generis (if they knew that phrase). In recent years he discovered the TV series Everybody Loves Raymond. What we hope he knew was that everybody loved Uri. Contributions in his memory may be sent to Hospice Care Network, 99 Sunnyside Blvd., Woodbury, NY 11797. 1/3

HOWARD--Robert. We are extremely saddened by the loss of this great man and cherished friend. We are so fortunate to have enjoyed a deep and abiding friendship with this extraordinarily warm and generous human being. Bob was a highly respected and visionary business leader, but he was also a dedicated friend and devoted family man whose unwavering loyalty and remarkable determination, as well as playful sense of humor, endeared him to all. His spirit was fierce, his love boundless and his joie de vivre unparalleled. We will miss him dearly. Melissa and Bob Mittman 1/3

HOWARD--Robert. Historic Entrepreneur, at the age of 91 on December 19, 2014. Visionary, entrepreneur and technical innovator in various fields of corporate endeavor. His most noteworthy invention was the iconic dot matrix printer which helped pioneer the adoption of personal computing. His numerous additional inventions became the foundation for the 27 companies and the many thousands of jobs he created. He is survived by his loving wife Kit, his sister Sylvia Howard Fuhrman, devoted and loving children Ellen Howard Toon and her husband James, Richard Howard and his wife Lois, Dr. Lawrence Howard and his wife Judith, Jodi Smith Spolansky and her husband Steven and Brett Smith. His cherished grandchildren Ian Howard, Seth Howard, Kathryn Howard, Genna Howard, Ben Howard, Michael McKenna and Phillip Toon and Griffin Spolansky, Gage Spolansky, Peyton Spolansky, Lawson Spolansky and Chase Spolansky. Services Sunday, December 21 at 11:00a.m. Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street, Main Sanctuary. Shiva on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday. In lieu of flowers, donations in memory of Robert Howard may be made to the Robert Howard Philanthropic Fund, Greater Miami Jewish Federation, 4200 Biscayne Boulevard, Miami, FL 33137 www.jewishmiami.org. 1/3

HOWARD--Robert. We join the family he so profoundly loved in mourning the loss of our dear Bob. In addition to being a genius engineer who helped usher in the computer age, he was a central figure in the lives of three generations of our family and in the lives of so many others. Wisdom, generosity of spirit, love of life, and playful humor marked his personality. His good works, devotion to family and friends, and inner strength inspired us all. The Coller Family 1/3

HENSCHEL--Dr. Leonard P.,85, of Kew Gardens, N.Y. passed away peacefully on December 18, 2014 after a brief illness. Dr. Henschel was born in Washington, D.C. to the late Joseph and Leah (Cooper) Henschel. He graduated from Syracuse University and obtained his MD degree at the University of New York, Upstate. He completed his residency at the University of Michigan. Dr. Henschel was a psychiatrist specializing in adolescent development and maintained a thriving practice well into his 70's. His other interests included a love of books, travel and a passionate interest in horticulture. Dr. Henschel was an active member of the Greater Orchid Society of New York. He maintained an extensive orchid collection and enjoyed giving impromptu tours of his greenhouse. Dr. Henschel is survived by his sister, Shirley Henschel, his brother Herbert Henschel (Marilyn), his nephews, Dr. Marc Henschel (Deborah), Stephen Henschel (Jocelyn) and Eric Henschel (Laurie), three great nephews, a great niece and his lifelong friend, Mario Silva. 1/3

HALMAN--Talat Sait. Talat Sait Halman, 83, Bilkent (Ankara), Turkey, and New York City, died from a heart attack at Bilkent University on December 5. Halman was born in Istanbul in 1931 in the first decade of Ataturk's Republic. He studied at the country's leading institution, the American Robert College of Istanbul. In 1952 he came to New York for graduate studies at Columbia University. A year and a half later he was hired to teach Turkish there. While a graduate student he worked as a clerk at the Record Hunter, New York's famed classical music store; a year later he became the general manager when the owner died suddenly, and he brought the company out of bankruptcy within three years. After graduate studies, Halman stayed in the United States for the next four decades and had a distinguished career at Columbia, Princeton, the University of Pennsylvania, and New York University, where he served as chairman of the Department of Near Eastern Languages and Literatures. He returned briefly to Turkey to serve as his country's first Minister of Culture (1971); in the 1980s he served as Turkey's first and only Ambassador for Cultural Affairs, stationed in New York. At this time he also served as Deputy Permanent Representative to the United Nations. Halman was appointed as a delegate to UNESCO in 1989 and later was elected to the Executive Board and served with distinction as president of its primary commission, Programme and External Relations; since 2003 he served as president of the Turkish National Committee for UNICEF. Among myriad awards, Halman received the Knight Grand Cross, G.B.E, from Queen Elizabeth during her 1971 state visit to Turkey. After 45 years in the United States, Halman joined Bilkent in 1996 as founding chairman of the university's Department of Turkish Literature and most recently had also been serving as Dean of Humanities and Letters. It was Halman's humanism and cross-cultural approach that is his most lasting legacy. In 1976 he arranged a Middle Eastern Literature symposium that took place both at the New York Public Research Library and Princeton University. It was the first such conference that included both Israeli and Arab writers. He opened the way for the teaching of Turkish literature and culture at major universities in the U.S. Before that, Middle Eastern studies departments concentrated primarily on Arab and Persian studies. Halman published nearly 3,000 articles, essays, newspaper columns, and reviews in English and in Turkish. He translated over 10,000 poems from English into Turkish and Turkish into English, and wrote over 80 books, including 11 volumes of his own poetry. He was William Faulkner's first Turkish translator. This publication of "Knight's Gambit" had a tremendous impact on the nascent short-story and novel genres in the Turkish Republic. For his work as a translator he won Columbia University's Thornton Wilder Prize. Among his books in Turkish are a massive volume of the poetry of ancient civilizations, the poetry of ancient Anatolia and the Near East, Eskimo poems, ancient Egyptian poetry, the rubais of Rumi, the quatrains of Baba Tahir Uryan, several collections of Yunus Emre poetry, two anthologies of modern American poetry, and books of selected poems of Wallace Stevens and Langston Hughes. He also translated works by Mark Twain and Eugene O'Neill. Translations of Shakespeare's "Complete Sonnets" count among his major achievements and have been published in many editions. This was the first time that the sonnets had been translated into Turkish using meter and rhyme. Earlier this year his translations of Shakespeare's long narrative poems, again into meter and rhyme, were published in Istanbul. Halman also wrote an original play about Shakespeare, his plays, and Turkish productions; the play was produced to the acclamation of Turkish theater audiences. Halman saw culture as a "unifying force; when a nation develops itself culturally, humanism begins," he always said. It is Turkey's cultural plurality, the recognition of the inherent power of the cultural synthesis that the Turkish nation has fostered over the past fifteen centuries, combined with the numerous and diverse civilizations in the area that is now Turkey, that Halman sought to encourage and promote. The world's literary and cultural stage has lost a truly unique and irreplaceable talent--poet, translator, columnist, belletrist, accomplished academic, diplomat, charismatic public speaker, social and cultural critic, writers' activist, and much more. All of these contributions plus his willingness to share his wisdom and knowledge will be remembered by the countless audiences he enlightened, the numerous students he inspired and encouraged, and future generations who will benefit from this legacy. Talat Halman is survived by his wife Seniha, daughter Defne, son Hur (from a former marriage), and grandchildren Melissa, William, and Olivia. His son Sait predeceased him in 1983. Jayne L. Warner Colleague and family friend 1/3

HALEVI--Judith Rosenblum, 70, wife of Gabriel Halevi, sister Muriel Rosenblum Fleischmann; actress, developer, activist, died December 13, 2014. Memorial site/date to be planned. Gifts/Smilow Cancer Center, Yale New Haven. 1/3

GOSNELL--Georgia P. Georgia Potter Gosnell, died on December 17th, 2014 at her home in Rochester, New York. She was eighty-four. She was predeceased by her husband, Thomas Hale Gosnell, and her son, Thomas Craig Gosnell. She is survived by Robin Gosnell Travers, Arthur Andrews Gosnell and his wife Page, Elizabeth Gosnell Miller and her husband Richard, and Silvia Gosnell, as well as eleven "wonderful" grandchildren. A graduate of Vassar College, Mrs. Gosnell lived for fifty-seven years "with Lake Ontario in front of her and the Big Woods behind her." She organized Rochester's first Earth Day, called "Now Not Tomorrow" in 1970. In 2006, she and her husband donated ninety-six wooded acres to the Trust for Public Land as a forever wild preserve. In 1978, she was named to the Board of the George Eastman House and spearheaded its restoration. The Eastman House named her Honorary Curator for her efforts. In recent years, she has generously supported the Golisano Children's Hospital at the University of Rochester Medical Center, the Al Sigl Community of Agencies and the Nantucket Historical Association. In 2014, she was named Rochester's Philanthropist of the Year. Although she spent time in Rochester, and on Nantucket and John's Island, Mrs. Gosnell loved to sail the world with her husband on their beloved ketch, Timoneer. They traveled from Labrador to Fiji to the Outer Hebrides through the Mediterranean and around Cape Horn. She belonged to many clubs, including the Genesee Valley Club, the Country Club of Rochester, the Chatterbox Club, the New York Yacht Club and the Nantucket Yacht Club. A Memorial Service will be held on Monday, December 22nd at 11:00am at Third Presbyterian Church, located at 4 Meigs Street in Rochester. In lieu of flowers, please send any contributions to the George Eastman House, 900 East Avenue, Rochester, New York 14607. To share a memory of Georgia or send a condolence to the family, visit: www.anthonychapels.com. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Harriet L.,95. Passed away December 13, 2014. Beloved wife of Milton J. Friedman, survived by her loving son, Peter. She had a life long love of music and was an excellent pianist, a patron of the Metropolitan Opera, a friend of Lincoln Center, and a fond subscriber and supporter of many Lincoln Center organizations. She was also devoted to WNET-13 for whom she served as a volunteer for three decades. 1/3

FIER--Andy.
