His love of family, Plaza and Judaism will be remembered for generations to come. May his memory forever be a blessing. Harold Handler, Chairman 1/3

ETTINGER--Margaret Dorothea Foerster, MS. October 15, 1924 -November 7, 2014. Radcliffe '45, and Bank Street '81. Born in Cambridge, MA. into a family of professors. She grew up in Princeton, where she once rollerskated into her neighbor Einstein. Lived well and died peacefully. Beloved wife of Thomas P., cherished mother of Elizabeth, Thomas E. and Mark, adored grandmother of Caroline and Kate. Early Modern dancer, Lieder singer and long term psychoanalyst, she loved nature, the arts and knowledge. We will always miss you! 1/3

ERNST--Roger. Roger Ernst, passed away in Tampa, Florida on November 17, 2014, surrounded by his children. Born in New York City to Morris L. and Margaret Ernst, Roger attended City and Country School, George School, Williams College, and the National War College. He served in the US Army, and was Assistant Director for NATO and for Planning in the Office of the Secretary of Defense. He started the Peace Corps in India, served as Deputy Director of the US Economic Assistance Mission in Taiwan and Korea, and was Director of USAID in Ethiopia and Thailand. He was a Fellow at the East-West Center in Hawaii, and taught at the University of South Florida. A lifelong summer resident of Nantucket, MA, his trademark red sail was as well-known in the harbor as his smile was on land. An exercise devotee, he ran 1000 miles a year for 25 years. He loved travelling and dancing with his wife Jean O'Mara Ernst, to whom he proposed on the day they met. He is predeceased by his wife Jean, and his sisters Constance Bessie and Joan Dauman. He is survived by daughter Debbe Nicholson, her husband Jeff and son Sam; and son David, his wife Jennifer and their children, Ben, Julia and Daniel. A memorial service will be held in Nantucket this summer. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to the Nantucket Rotary Club or the Nantucket Conservation Foundation. 1/3

EARLE--Barbara.,loving mother and wife, who devoted her life to music, gardens, poetry and numerous civic activities, died on December 10, 2014 at the Essex Meadows retirement community in Essex, CT. She was 89 years old. Barbara was the daughter of the Margaretta and Gordon Aymar. She was born in New York City and grew up in Darien, CT. She attended The Thomas School, Barnard College and Julliard School of Music. She married Harry W. Earle, of Norwalk, CT in 1944 upon his return from service in WWII. Barbara co-founded Person-to-Person, the Connecticut-based volunteer organization that helps those in need, and also served for many years as a hospice volunteer. She was an accomplished poet and, early in life, a musician who studied the harp and played professionally. At age 58, she earned her college degree, graduating summa cum laude from the University of Wisconsin/Oshkosh. Barbara is most remembered for her intense love and devotion to family and friends, and having a deep and lasting influence on the communities where she lived. Her daughters Penryhn Cook and Barbara Ballard; her sons, David, John and Gordon; as well as her sister Carol Armstrong survive her. She was the proud grandmother of eleven grandchildren and one great granddaughter. She is predeceased by her brother, Gordon Aymar, Jr. and by Harry Earle, her husband of 56 years. A memorial service will be held at The First Congregational Church of Old Lyme on January 17th at 2pm. The address is 4 Lyme Street, (Corner of Lyme Street and Ferry Road) Old Lyme, CT. A reception will follow the service. Memorial donations may be made to Middlesex Hospice & Palliative Care, located at 28 Crescent Street, Middletown, CT 06457 or Person-to Person, located at 1864 Post Road, Darien, CT 06820. To share a memory of Barbara or send a condolence to her family please visit www.rwwfh.com. 1/3

DIAMOND--Beverly, on December 15, 2014. Devoted daughter of the late Carl and Eva Diamond. Beloved wife of Michael Dreizen. Contributions in her memory made to City of Hope would be appreciated. 1/3

DETWILER--Richard Mott, 93, died December 17 in Rye Brook, NY. He was born in Lancaster, PA, June 2, 1921 to William Sanderson Detwiler and Gertrude Mott Detwiler. A graduate of Phillips Exeter Academy and Yale University, he enlisted in the U.S. Marine Corps Reserve while an undergraduate and he served in the Pacific, landing in Nagasaki shortly after the explosion of the atomic bomb. During the Korean Conflict he served as commanding officer of the Marine Corps public information office in New York. Following a stint as a reporter and feature editor with the Rocky Mountain News, he worked in public relations at Ford, Chase National Bank, and the BBDO advertising agency in New York, where he was vice president and director of public relations when he retired. He was married to Barbara Ann Burns of New Rochelle, NY from 1951 until her death in 2011. They lived in Pelham Manor, NY where he served as a town trustee. Following his retirement, they lived in Melvin Village, NH for more than 30 years. He is survived by a daughter, Anne D. Crecraft, of Sterling, VA; sons Richard Jr., of Bronxville, NY; John B. Detwiler, of Charlotte, NC; and William S. Detwiler, of Brooklyn, NY; and eight grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:30am on Monday in the chapel at The Wartburg, One Wartburg Place, Mount Vernon, NY. Donations may be made to Phillips Exeter Academy, Exeter, NH. 1/3

BLEETSTEIN--Glenna Dee, of Salt Lake City then New York, died on Sunday, December 14 at an age she preferred not to mention. BING--Cynthia Eaton. Passed away peacefully at Mt. Sinai Hospital on December 12 after a long illness. Cynthia was born on April 6, 1942 in Belfast, ME. She attended Abbott Academy (Philips Andover Academy) and Connecticut College for Women (Connecticut College). After moving to New York City, she worked for Holland America Line as head of group sales. In 1972, she married Alexander Bing III, partner at L.F. Rothschild & Co. Cynthia was a dedicated mother to three young children when she began her career as a philanthropist in fields of education and environmental protection. She served on many boards including: Phillips Academy, Connecticut College, Trevor Day School, The Parents League of New York, Prep for Prep, Early Steps, Search and Care, New York State Association of Independent Schools, New York League of Conservation Voters, and Environmental Advocates. In many cases, Cynthia served as board president or acted as a committee head. Cynthia spent her summers with her family in Montana where enjoyed the mountains and cross-country horseback riding. Cynthia's parents, Lorimer and Ruth Eaton, and one child, Abigail R. Bing predeceased her. She is survived by her husband, Alexander Bing III; brother, Eben R. Eaton; daughter, Cynthia K. Bing; son, Alexander M. Bing; step-daughter, Virginia G. Bing; granddaughter, Eloise B. Padial; and son- in-law, Michael S. Padial. A Memorial Service is to be held at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and 5th Ave., at 3pm, January 6 with reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Church of The Heavenly Rest and/or Search and Care. 1/3

He is also survived by his nieces, Faith and Mechele, Faith's daughters and Mechele's husband Sander. OPPENHEIM--Eva Miodownik. Passed on December 19. Most beloved wife of Alan, mother of Adrienne and Stephanie, grandmother of Idan and sister of John. She was a gifted poet whose words will live on through her poetry. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Scleroderma Foundation. NEWMAN--Joel. On December 17, 2014 Joel Newman, Ph.D. died in his home in Provincetown, Massachusetts. Born in Brooklyn, NY in 1918, he was 96. Dr. Newman played an important role in the early music revival in New York City. His 1962 doctoral thesis on the early Italian composer, Salamone Rossi, remains the definitive work on him. In the 1950's, Dr Newman became the musicologist for the New York Pro Musica and joined the music department at Columbia University. He taught at Columbia for more than 30 years and after retirement continued teaching as Professor Emeritus. Newman studied recorder with Bernard Krainis and played in the first American Recorder Society ensemble under Erich Katz. He was proficient on early instruments, piano, organ and harpsichord. He received the Distinguished Achievement Award from the American Record Society in 2007 for his work as a musicologist, music editor and musician. After retirement, Joel Newman settled in Provincetown, Massachusetts, ran his own sheet music business and was co- owner of the Provincetown Bookshop. He is predeceased by Elloyd Hanson, his husband and partner of 46 years, and by his brother, Morris Newman. Joel is survived by his twin sisters, Phoebe Sheres and Dorothy Swayze, and a host of fond nieces, nephews and great nieces and nephews. Joel will be greatly missed and remembered for his pithy sense of humor, his erudition and his charm.

JENSEN--Camille McLean Anderson. Died on December 18 of natural causes at her residence in Darien, Connecticut. She was 95. Camille was born on December 14, 1919, in Holly Springs, Mississippi, the daughter of Percy Harmon and Camille McLean Anderson. She attended Miss Hutchison's School in Memphis and graduated from Mary Baldwin College in Staunton, Virginia, in 1941. In 1942 she was named Maid of Cotton at the Memphis Cotton Carnival by the National Cotton Council. She married Frode Jensen, a physician, in 1948 and settled in Denver, Colorado. In 1950 they moved to Riverdale, New York, where she participated in the Parent Teachers Association at the Riverdale Country School, was a founding member of the Board of the Wave Hill Association, served on the board of the Girl Scouts Association of Greater New York, was a founder of the Riverdale Presbyterian Church Nursery School, and was a member of the board of governors of the Riverdale Yacht Club. On weekends she and Frode enjoyed their country home at the Gipsy Trail Club in Carmel, New York. After her husband's death in 1973, Camille enjoyed a successful career as a realtor in Riverdale with Robert E. Hill, Inc. In 1987, she retired and moved to New Canaan, Connecticut, where she lived for 25 years. Camille was predeceased by her husband, Frode, and is survived by her three children; her son, Frode (Skip) and his wife, Kitty, of Park City, Utah, her daughter Camille, of Manhattan, and her son, Peter, of Phoenixville, Pennsylvania. She is also survived by her five grandchildren: Christian McLean, Catherine Spotswood Hall, and Henry Carter Jensen; and Matthew St. John and Alexander Jensen Douglas. Funeral arrangements are being handled by Edward Lawrence Funeral Home in Darien, CT. Funeral services will be private. Camille will be interred in the Hamilton College Cemetery. A memorial service next spring is planned in Clinton, NY. Contributions in Camille's memory can be made to the Frode and Camille Jensen Scholarship Fund at Hamilton College, 198 College Hill Road, Clinton, NY 13323.
HENDRIX--Holland Lee, Age 66. Died suddenly of lung cancer in Albuquerque, NM on November 26.

FUSCO--Honorable Louis Jr.,peacefully passed away on December 19th 2014 in his home at the age of 95. He graduated from St. Johns University School of Law in 1947. Thereafter he became an Assistant United States Attorney and was first elected to the bench in the State of New York in 1975 and rose to the level of Administrative Judge of the Supreme Court in Bronx County. During his tenure as administrative judge he pioneered the concept of a dual track system and a telephone alert system for witnesses, jurors and lawyers. All of these programs dramatically reduced the backlog of civil cases in Bronx County from five years to eight weeks. He was the founder and president of the Tri-State Italian-American Congress which gave out almost seven million dollars in scholarships to students of Italian-American heritage in need. He is survived by his nieces and nephews Delores (Harriet) Filardi, Geraldine Barradas, Ernest (Fran) Fusco, Con Filardi, Michael (Michele) Borrelli and Alberto (William) Reynolds. He is also survived by many loving great nieces and nephews. Visitation will be held in Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home located at 1076 Madison Avenue New York, NY 10028 on Monday December 22, 2014 from 5-9pm. A Mass of Christian burial will take place in St. Igatius Loyola Church located at 980 Park Avenue New York, NY 10028 on Tuesday December 23, 2014 at 10am. Entombment to follow in Gate of Heaven Cemetery Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in Louis's honor to the Tri-State Italian-American Congress 36 Farview Terrace Paramus, New Jersey 07652 www.trisiac.org

"i carry your heart with me (i carry it in my heart) i am never without it (anywhere i go you go, my dear; and whatever is done by only me is your doing, my darling) i fear no fate (for you are my fate, my sweet) i want no world (for beautiful you are my world, my true) and it's you are whatever a moon has always meant i carry your heart (i carry it in my heart)" "i carry your heart" by e e Cummings IKE 1/3

WIT--Harold Maurice 86, Died December 14, 2014. Born September 6, 1928, Newton, Massachusetts to Martha Basist Wit (deceased) and Maurice Wit (deceased), older brother Phillip Wit (deceased). The boys were known as "Big Moose" and "Little Moose." Harold attended Buckingham Browne & Nichols, Harvard University (Phi Beta Kappa), and Yale Law School (Yale Law Review). Harold's marriages: Louise Untermeyer Frankel, Joan Rosenthal Sovern (deceased), Judith Ginsberg Wit, and Susan King Wit. He had two children with Joan Rosenthal Sovern: David Wit and Hannah Wit (deceased). He worked as an attorney at Cravath, Swaine & Moore LLP; was Managing Director of Allen & Company; and was on the Board of Directors at Toys "R" Us, Inc. and MCI. He established the lecture series, "Living a Spiritual Life in a Secular World" at Harvard Divinity School. Harold was a Navy Captain in the Korean War (Battleship USS Iowa). He was a member of Pathworks: A Spiritual Center for Growth and Learning. Harold wrote poetry and authored the book A Shovel is to Dig With. He lived in New York City, East Hampton, and Santa Fe New Mexico. Harold built the well-known tower on his property at 17 Cross Highway in East Hampton. He headed Watchdogs of the North Fork to stop commercial development in East Hampton. Over his 40 years in East Hampton Harold planted specimen trees, acres of wild flowers, and vegetables. He farmed honey bees and harvested their honey. He loved riding his red tractor. He drafted and sent to the Supreme Court a bill to allow residents of second homes the right to vote in cities where they owned second homes. He was an avid reader--reading a book a day and several books at one time. Harold was an ardent Republican, a loyal American, and a true patriot who deeply loved his country. Harold was an eccentric dresser who didn't care what others thought. He was an outstanding cook and baker whose "Holiday Booze Cake" will long be remembered. Harold will always be known for his acerbic wit, sense of fairness, brilliant mind, outspoken opinions, sensitivity, and generous kindness to others. He will be loved and missed by those he leaves behind: David, Kathleen, Natasha, and Dylan Wit; Simon, Clare, Simone, and Clark Ginsberg; Greg, Enna, and Noah Roggin; Kevin, Jennifer, Jake, and Ryan Roggin; Kurt and Jimmy Serrano; Jesse and Keri Ryback; Luke, Ciara, Aibhlin, Rowan, and Nora Ryback; Petie Wit (his loving and faithful companion who sat on his lap until the very end) and Sue/his "Mighty Mouse", wife of seventeen years, who will carry his heart in her heart forever. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Santa Fe Animal Shelter & Humane Society (sfhumanesociety.org and 505-983-4309) would be greatly appreciated. 1/3

WINIKOFF--Stanley, 98 years. We are saddened by the passing of our loving father. He was the beloved and devoted husband to the late Marcia for 68 years and proud grandfather of Eli and Samantha. Dedicated to the game of golf and a mentor to many in the box business, Stanley was a passionate aficionado of bialy's. Our parents shared a wonderful life together and we were lucky to have them for as long as we did. Amy, Linda and Ken. Graveside Services, Old Montefiore Cemetery, December 22, 10am. 1/3

STONE--Emerson Law. The CBS News executive who produced the only live call-in show with a sitting United States President has died. A lover of nature, language, music, and family, he died Monday after a fall. He lived in Greenwich, CT, with his wife Louisa H. Stone. From 1952 to 1987, Emerson rose from the CBS mailroom to the Vice Presidency, first for network radio and later for radio and television news practices. During the call-in for "Ask President Carter," he handled the kill switch, in case of offensive calls. He made CBS the first network to broadcast 24-hour news and supervised radio coverage of the Vietnam War, the Robert Kennedy and Martin Luther King, Jr., assassinations, all Apollo moon landings, Watergate, and political conventions. Winner of two Peabody Awards, he worked with such greats as Edward R. Murrow and Walter Cronkite and brought Charles Os- good to the network. He was the network's first ombudsman. Born February 15, 1928 in New Haven to Emerson L. Stone and Grace K. Stone, he graduated from Yale University, class of 1948, and later won the university's highest honor, the Yale Medal. His brother Jon, head writer and director of "Sesame Street," died in 1997. Their sister Diana chairs the Dwight Englewood School language department. Emerson leaves his wife of 59 years; three daughters, Lise, Mei, and Kris, a son-in-law Stephen B. Heintz; and six grandchildren. The family will celebrate his life on January 17, 2015 at the Round Hill Community Church. Memorial donations are suggested to Doctors Without Borders or Yale University. 1/3

SILAS--C. J. "Pete." The Board of Governors, Trustees, staff and members of Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA) wish to express their profound sorrow over the passing of our dear friend and colleague Pete Silas. Pete's legacy with the Clubs goes back to his boyhood in Miami, FL, where he was an active member of the Boys' Club. He never stopped giving back throughout this life, supporting education through the Phillips 66 scholarship program for Club members, and serving 30 years on the BGCA Board of Governors, including two as chairman. He became a Life Member in 2000. Pete was awarded BGCA's highest honor, the Herbert Hoover Humanitarian Award, and was one of the first inductees into BGCA's National Alumni Hall of Fame. He played a vital role in helping BGCA relocate its national headquarters to Atlanta in 1994. Pete's passion for helping kids and his generous spirit will always be remembered by all who had the privilege to know him. Our heartfelt condolences and prayers go out to his wife Theo and their children and family. Boys & Girls Clubs of America Ron Gidwitz, Chairman James Clark, President 1

SNYDER--Robert (Bob) T.,passed away in his sleep on December 10th in his Sag Harbor home after returning from a rehearsal with the Sag Harbor Community Band for their annual Holiday concert. He lived in New York City and spent Januaries in Sanibel, Florida. Born in the Bronx on April 7, 1930, Bob grew up on Long Beach on Long Island where as a teenager, he worked as a life guard. A Columbia College and Columbia Law School graduate, Bob continued his support of Columbia as president of his Columbia College alumni class. Bob worked as a labor lawyer and served 19 years as a Judge with the National Labor Relations Board. In recent years he worked as an Arbitrator. An avid sportsman, starting with his award as Best All Round Athlete in summer camp, Bob continued to play tennis throughout his life and avidly followed the Columbia football, basketball, and baseball teams. Beginning with playing jazz as a teenager and then at Columbia College as manager of the Marching Band, Bob turned to classical music as an adult and participated in chamber music groups in Sag Harbor, Manhattan, and Sanibel, Florida. He also played clarinet for many years in the Sag Harbor Community Band. Bob loved Sag Harbor, and it has been his second home since 1970. He was a contributor to the book Voices of Sag Harbor, a collection of oral histories about the village. Bob was passionate about his music, and passionate about the law, fairly considered and executed, as an essential component of our democracy. Bob is survived by his wife Elaine Congress, son Adam Snyder, daughter-in-law Cece Cutler, grandson Jack Snyder, cousin Joan Snyder, and Adam's mother Patricia Stegman. A service was held on Sunday, December 14 at Yardley and Pino Funeral Home in Sag Harbor and a Memorial Service is planned for Saturday, March 28th 2:00pm at the Princeton/Columbia Club, 15 West 43rd Street in New York City. For more details, email: congress@fordham.edu. Contributions in memory can be made to one of Bob's favorite charities, including Amnesty International, Doctors without Borders, Channel 13 (PBS), and American Friends Service Committee. 1/3

NAPTIME Written and illustrated by Iris de Moüy. Translated by Shelley Tanaka. 24 pp. Groundwood/House of Anansi. $16.95. (Picture book; ages 2 to 5) 
 
It’s bad enough for tiny humans. For the proud young animals of the savanna, the concept of nap time is downright insulting. “Naps are for little babies,” according to a strapping crocodile; the giraffe declares herself “too tall,” the monkey “too busy.” De Moüy, who fills her bold, black-outlined gouache illustrations with great character, cleverly turns the tables on her readers, introducing a little girl — a former reluctant napper herself? — who outwits the beasts with the old “just close one eye” trick.

SIEGMAN--Felix, MD. The leadership and Board of Trustees of Maimonides Medical Center mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend. SICKINGER--Timothy John, the son of Kenneth and Virginia Sickinger, died December 9 in Redding, Connecticut. His wife of 55 years, Susanna Gay Gibson Sickinger, the daughter of Frank and Mildred Gibson, died two days earlier. Tim's 34-year advertising career included 20 years at Ogilvy & Mather in Chicago, New York and London, managing accounts such as American Express, Sears, Mattel, Marriott and TWA. He left Ogilvy as a senior vice president, and spent the next decade as a founding partner, general manager and executive vice president at Bozell Worldwide in Omaha. SHARP--Penelope Chester, of Northford, CT and Fishers Island, NY died peacefully at home on December 14 at age 76. Born and raised in Greenwich, CT, Penni graduated from Miss Porter's School, Sarah Lawrence College and earned a Master of Forest Science degree from the Yale School of Forestry. An accomplished botanist and wetland biologist, she worked as a consultant for municipal and private clients and held leadership positions in numerous environmental organizations in Connecticut. On Fishers Island she served as president of the Henry L. Ferguson Museum and its Land Trust from 2003 until her death and shared her considerable knowledge of the natural world with all who knew her. Fond of music, she also sang with Cappella Cantorum. A devoted mother and grandmother, she loved being with her son and daughter and her four beloved grandchildren. She is survived by her husband, Gregory A. Sharp, her son, Stephen M. McPherson, Jr., her daughter, Eugenie McPherson Trevor, her grandchildren, Ashlyn and Alexa McPherson, and John B. Trevor V and Eliza T. Trevor, her sister Clare Stone, her brothers Colby M. Chester, IV and Geoffrey Chester, five nieces, a nephew and her Labrador. A celebration of Penni's life will be held at a later date. Donations, in lieu of flowers, may be made to Cappella Cantorum or the Henry L. Ferguson Museum. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Deborah Klein. December 11, 1930 -December 12, 2014. Deborah Klein Schwartz, beloved mother and grandmother, passed away on December 12, 2014, one day after her 84th birthday. Deborah is survived by her two children: daughter, Andrea Schwartz Nagler, and son, Peter Schwartz. A Memorial Service will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Rd, Scarsdale, NY, on December 29th at 11:30am, followed by a graveside service at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery at 1:30pm. SCHULWEIS--Rabbi Harold M. The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family and the Jewish people in mourning the loss of Rabbi Harold M. Schulweis, one of the most influential leaders of synagogue life in Judaism's Conservative Movement. Rabbi Schulweis was ordained at JTS, where he studied under Mordecai Kaplan, and went on to introduce synagogue- based havurot and innovate Jewish thought, women's and LGBTQ participation, and interreligious dialog. He was a progressive man of moral courage; an activist who lived and modeled the values of Judaism and Torah. The path he walked so nobly is one we all are pledged to continue. May his wife Malkah, his children Seth Schulweis, Ethan (Cindy) Schulweis, and Alisa (Peter) Reich, and eleven grandchildren be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold M. Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair 1/3

SAVIN--Robert. The Board of Directors and Administration of United Hebrew of New Rochelle mourn the passing of Mr. Robert Savin, esteemed member of our Board of Directors, and long- time supporter of United Hebrew. SAVIN--Robert S.,89, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL, formerly of Mamaroneck, NY, passed away December 18th from Alzheimer's Disease. He was born and raised in Bridgeport, CT, was an US Army Veteran, and married in July 1951 to Barbara Low. In 1954 he joined his father-in-law Max M. Low at IPCO, a multi health care company where he eventually became its CEO. He also sat on the board of SAVIN Corporation. Bob became active in many charities, amongst them the United Hebrew Geriatric Center of New Rochelle, where he served as a past president and trustee. He and his family were donors there of the Low Savin Residence, an assisted living facility. He also worked tirelessly for the American Friends of the Hebrew University,which awarded him the coveted Scopus Award in 1983. For many years he co chaired with Howard Cosell the annual Sports Dinner held in memory of the 11 slain Israeli Olympians. In addition he was a founder of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, The Hebrew University in Jerusalem as well as the Truman Peace Institute. After leaving corporate life Bob became involved in Park City, Utah, where he bought and developed Z Place, an entertainment Center that for many years was the headquarters for the Sundance Film Festival. He was one of the first homeowners at the Stein Erikson Lodge in Deer Valley, where he spent many hours skiing, his favorite sport. In addition to his wife Barbara of 63 years, he is survived by his two loving children, Debi (Steve) Scoggan of Park City Utah, Scott of Santa Monica CA. and two adoring grandchildren Skyler and Scarlett Scoggan. Graveside Services will be held on Tuesday, December 23rd 11am, at Glenville Cemetery, 99 Memory Lane, Greenwich, CT For directions call 914- 967-4908 or WJC 914-698-2960. Donations in Bob's name may be made to United Hebrew Geriatric, 391 Pelham Road, New Rochelle, NY 10805 or a charity of your choice. 1/3

WRESCHNER RUSTOW-- Margrit, PhD. 14 May 1925 -19 December 2014. A great and rare woman who triumphed over the Nazis, survived three concentration camps and devoted her life to tell her story and heal survivors. Daughter to Leo and Friederike (Klaber) Wreschner, sister to Renee Herman and Lotte Salzberger, and widow of Dankwart Rustow. Born in Frankfurt am Main, fled to Amsterdam, survived Westerbork, Ravensbrueck and Theresienstadt. Graduated from Columbia University, worked for many years as a psychoanalyst, researched and lectured on the psychological experiences and healing of holocaust survivors. Told her story to young persons on three continents. Lovingly remembered by her nieces and nephews: Gaby Salzberger and Eli, Fania (Oz), Dean and Nadav Salzberger. Memorial Monday at 11:30am at The Riverside, 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. Burial Tuesday at Center Cemetery, New Milford, CT. 1/3

WAX--Sarah. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member, Sarah Wax, who together with her late husband, Robert, were benefactors of the Synagogue and Day School. Sincere condolences to her children, Steven (Pia) Wax, Terri (Michael) Pomeranc, Robin (Larry) Lazar, Melanie Srour, grandchildren, sister Lee and brother Lou. May the family find comfort among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Herman Hochberg, President 1/3

SARGOY--Ida Menter, age 103. April 6, 1911 -December 17, 2014, a loving wife to Milton, who preceded her in death, mother of Kenneth, grandmother of Chris and Allison, and mother-in-law of Joan. She lived a long, fruitful life and will be greatly missed but will live on in our memories. 1/3

NORTON--Christina Jennifer, after a courageous fight against cancer, Christina Jennifer Norton died on December 8th. Born in New York and raised in Italy, Dr. Norton earned a Doctor of Veterinary Medicine degree from Universita di Bologna. She practiced in Brooklyn Heights and Manhattan. Christina was passionate about opera, art, animals, birding and the environment. She will be missed by all who knew her for her intelligence, beauty, grace and fortitude. Contributions in her memory can be made to National Resources Defense Council or American Bird Conservancy. From her loving friends. 1/3

LaGRUA--John Alfred, Jr. John Alfred LaGrua, Jr.,of New York City, died October 4 after a long illness. His death saddened friends and relatives, leaving the community depleted by the loss of a strong and sensitive individual. The cause of his death was heart failure, according to members of his family. The son of John A. LaGrua, Sr. and Mary Arbuthnot LaGrua, John was born in 1930 and grew up in Queens and Manhattan, attending for one year Columbia College before transferring to Princeton, where he joined Tiger Inn and graduated with the Class of 1952. A long career in Wall Street banking followed, eventually leading to his service as president and CEO of several international banks. He led a joint venture of Deutsch Bank and the Union Bank of Switzerland, which later became a part of UBS, the largest bank in Europe. He also served as president and CEO of Scandinavian Securities Corp, an investment bank responsible for the Wallenberg Interests in Sweden. John lived for a number of years in San Francisco and Chicago and travelled extensively in the latter phases of his career, acquiring broad cultural experiences and many friends abroad. He worked for several years for the United States Agency for International Development (USAID) and was especially proud of his work teaching the United States banking system in St. Petersburg, Russia. John was a member of the Links Club and the River Club in Manhattan and the Meadow Club of Southampton, L.I. Since retirement, John was especially drawn to Central Park where he made many friends while walking his dog each day. He contributed regularly to the upkeep and improvement of the Park and also authored an article about the Park for a local publication. John is survived by a sister, Gloria Dugan, of Naples, FL, a niece, Barbara Beuerlein, of Huntington, NY, a niece, Pamela Dugan, of Naples, FL, and a grand-nephew, William Beuerlein, of Huntington. He will be missed by them and his many friends. A Memorial Mass for John will be held at the Lady Chapel, Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Ave, New York, on Tuesday, December 23 at 1:30pm, Father George Witt presiding. 1/3

HOWARD--Robert. We are extremely saddened by the loss of this great man and cherished friend. We are so fortunate to have enjoyed a deep and abiding friendship with this extraordinarily warm and generous human being. Bob was a highly respected and visionary business leader, but he was also a dedicated friend and devoted family man whose unwavering loyalty and remarkable determination, as well as playful sense of humor, endeared him to all. His spirit was fierce, his love boundless and his joie de vivre unparalleled. We will miss him dearly. Melissa and Bob Mittman 1/3

GLATZER--Jewel. At the age of 96 on December 21, 2014 in Aventura, Florida. Jewel was born and raised in the Bronx, New York and resided in Manhattan, New York for more than forty years prior to moving to Aventura in 2010. Jewel began her career as a clothing model in New York's garment center where she met her husband of sixty one years, Mark, who predeceased her in 2001. Jewel worked until she was 80 years old, spending the last 20 years of her career as a senior researcher for an executive recruiter, Webb, Johnson Associates, Inc. Jewel is survived by her sons, Jeffrey (Marti Reich) and Hal (Valerie Jonas and Valerie's daughter, Hannah Armstrong), granddaughters Samantha Glatzer (Brian Loges) and Jessica Glatzer Murphy (Matthew Murphy), step-grandchildren, Rabbi Jonathan Freirich (Ginny Reel) and Liz Freirich (Saul Kaiserman), great- grandchildren, Hannah, Sarah and Abigail Loges, Lucas and Julia Murphy, step-great grandchildren, Jude and Sadie Freirich and Jory and Zeva Kaiserman. Jewel is also survived by her former daughter-in-law, Liz Glatzer, Jewel's sister, Maxine Kaufman and niece Iris Kaufman. There will be a private memorial service. Contributions in Jewel's memory can be made to Dorot, 171 West 85th Street, New York, NY 10024, www.dorotusa.org. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Adele. "Ah, but a man's reach should exceed his grasp, Or what's a heaven for?" (R. Browning, "Andrea Del Sarto"). Now you can run and throw the frisbee with "the girls". Love, S, S, I and L 1/3

DIESING--Richard C.,May 7, 1925 -December 16, 2014. Born in Springfield, IL, passed away peacefully from Alzheimer's at Jewish Home Lifecare, Manhattan. Educated at Concordia Lutheran High School, St. Paul, MN; Concordia Lutheran Seminary, St. Louis; University of Chicago. Predeceased by parents, Charlotte and Frederick C. Diesing, and brother Edward F. Diesing, all of St. Paul. Survived by: sister Lois R. Diesing, Arlington, MA; Terrence McCafferty, longtime friend and loyal caregiver in Richard's last years. Richard was the Director of Hudson Neighborhood Conservation Corp. He was a Social Worker at Volunteers Of America for many years. Richard was a Bach and classical music devotee and devoted his life to others. He was an active volunteer at the United Nations Association. Simple graveside services will be held at 1:30pm, Monday, December 22, at All Faiths Cemetery, at 67-29 Metropolitan Avenue, Middle Village, Queens (across from M Train Station). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Volunteers of America -Greater New York, 340 West 85th St., NY, NY 10024. "Schon Schlafen, Richard". 1/3

BROCKMAN--Alan, 83, on December 20, 2014, after a brief illness. Alan was an attorney at Tenzer Greenblatt Fallon & Kaplan and Blank Rome LLP for nearly 60 years, having joined Tenzer Greenblatt in 1957 and having been elected as partner in 1968 and ultimately serving as Senior Counsel. Alan was a graduate of Amherst College and Columbia Law School. He served in the armed forces upon his graduation from law school, prior to commencing the practice of law. Alan was the long-time President of the Fire Island Pines Property Owners' Association. Although primarily a corporate and a real estate attorney, Alan's practice encompassed many areas of law. Alan was a meticulous lawyer and a wonderful friend. He will be sorely missed. Contributions in his memory may be made to the FIPPOA Charitable Foundation, Inc., P.O. Box 5305, Fire Island Pines, NY 11782. There will be no funeral service. A celebration of his life will be held at Whyte Hall in Fire Island Pines on Saturday, May 9, 2015. 1/3

BING--Cynthia. Trevor Day School shares heartfelt condolences with Sandy, Cynthia, Alexander, Virginia, and the entire Bing family. Cynthia was a devoted Trustee and Board President who led selflessly and with great acumen and humor. She was a generous and compassionate friend to many and she will be profoundly missed. Sally Rocker,Board President Scott Reisinger, Head of School 1/3
KATZ--Michael. 12/20/2002. Beloved husband of Margaret, Adored father of Joshua and Jonathan, dear father-in- law of Rachel, grandfather of Sacha, Michael and Marisol Jade Katz.
GARITY--Natalie Lyons. 12/22/89. Remembered with love by your family. We miss you Mom.

SERPHOS--Susan. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Susan Serphos, and extend sincere condolences to her family. James Dreyfus, President

SERPHOS--Susan Eising. Passed away peacefully on December 20 at the age of 73. Susan was the devoted mother of Michael J. Serphos (Abbe) of Manhattan and Mary L. Serphos of Marin, California, loving sister to Richard A. Eising, Jr. (Diane) of Rye and proud grandmother of Brayden and Kate. Susan's deeply caring, kind and gentle nature will be profoundly missed by all who knew and loved her.

SAVIN--Robert. You and Barbara, Fred and I have been friends for over 50 years. So many wonderful times shared. Skiing, traveling, watching our children grow up. Thanks for the memories. Rest in peace, dear friend. Phyllis Pressman

LESHOWITZ-FALLIK--Ruth, age 99, of Deerfield Beach passed away on December 18. Loving mother of Mel (Ellen), Barry (Phyllis), and Gloria (Stanley); devoted to eight grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Actively involved in Brooklyn, as PTA president and as a leader of her Congregation; in Florida, as a leader of Na'Amat, B'nai Brith and Brandeis.

LANDSBERGER--Kurt, 94, of Verona, NJ and Delray beach, FL, passed away December 19th. Graveside services will be held Monday, December 22nd at 1:30 at King Solomon Cemetery, 550 Dwasline Rd. in Clifton. The evening of Monday the 22nd, at 7:30pm, there will be a memorial service held at Congregation Beth Ahm, located at 56 Grove Avenue in Verona. A successful businessman, he founded Bel Art Products of Pequanock NJ in 1946 and Maddak, Inc in 1979. A newspaper columnist, he regularly contributed to the Verona Cedar Grove Times with a weekly column. As an environmental and human rights activist, he and his late wife Anny were the founders of the Hilltop Preservation in Verona and founded the Kurt and Anny Landsberger Scholarship for Environmental Studies at Ramapo College, Rowan University and Seton Hall University. Their foundation also funded the Essex County Environmental Center in Roseland. He funded the Landsberger Holocaust Collections at the Verona and Pequanock Libraries. Mr. Landsberger was born in Prague in 1920 and immigrated to the United States in 1939. He served in the Army, during WW II as a translator. He was a published author of seven books. Married to the late Anny for 64 years, he leaves his second wife Rita Figarsky Feigenbaum of Albany, NY and Delray Beach, FL, as well as sons David (Lue) and Allen (Dianna) and grandchildren Joshua, Seth, Hannah, Nicholas and Alexa. Also surviving are four great-great-grandchildren. Services are by J. L. Apter Memorial Chapels of Cedar Grove.

HILPERT--Pamela Lynn, M.D.,Ph.D., a prominent Los Angeles radiologist, died on December 4, 2014 at her home in Pacific Palisades, CA after a courageous battle with cancer. Dr. Hilpert was born August 16, 1955 in Ossining, NY. After graduating from Mount Holyoke College, she received a Ph.D. in developmental neurophysiology from the University of Rochester and an M.D. from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. As a clinical faculty member at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital, Pennsylvania Hospital, and the University of Pennsylvania, she worked in ultrasound, CT, MRI, fetal echocardiography, and interventional radiology. She authored research papers and book chapters, co-authored the book Clinical Pelvic Imaging, and lectured internationally. Throughout Dr. Hilpert's career she was a committed advocate for women's health, developing the women's imaging program at Little Company of Mary Hospital in Torrance, CA and designing and managing the Women's Wellness Center at the Beach Cities Health District Campus. She was a founding member of Pacific Advanced Radiology Medical Group and a radiologist for RadNet, Inc. She is survived by Philip Kellman, her husband of 26 years, and three children Julia Ann, Laura Nicole, and Kimberly Fern Kellman. Contributions to the Cancer Support Community: cancersupportcommunity.org.

DREYFUSS--Arnold, 86, passed away on December 18, 2014 in Lantana, FL. Survived by his wife of 66 years Lenore (nee Schulman) and children Moshe and Lynn, five grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. He loved life, his family, was a great athlete and friend. His smile and humor will be sorely missed.
